class="ArticleHeader__hed___GPB7e">A Chef’s Mini-Empire in the Evelyn Hotel</h1><h2 class="ArticleHeader__dek___2rbDs">The less ambitious the food, the better it tends to be at Jonathan Benno’s trio of restaurants, which together provide a look into the mind of the chef.</h2><div class="ArticleHeader__metaInfo___1aBON"><div class="ArticleContributors__byline___3-luq"><div role="button" tabindex="0"><figure class="Figure__figure___U_9Te Figure__fullHeight___3uICS ArticleLedeImage__lede___1rVAF "><div class="placeholder"><div class="placeholder-buttress"></div><div class="placeholder-content"><div class="Image__image___1PhYl Figure__image___1hDvt ArticleLedeImage__image___17_0r" role="button" tabindex="0"><picture class="component-responsive-image"><source media="(min-width: 1280px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1176229ec14d553b1ae7c0/master/w_649,c_limit/181224_r33456.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1176229ec14d553b1ae7c0/master/w_1298,c_limit/181224_r33456.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 1024px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1176229ec14d553b1ae7c0/master/w_813,c_limit/181224_r33456.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1176229ec14d553b1ae7c0/master/w_1626,c_limit/181224_r33456.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1176229ec14d553b1ae7c0/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33456.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1176229ec14d553b1ae7c0/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33456.jpg 2x"/><source srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1176229ec14d553b1ae7c0/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33456.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1176229ec14d553b1ae7c0/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33456.jpg 2x"/><img alt="" src="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1176229ec14d553b1ae7c0/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33456.jpg" title=""/></picture><button class="Button__button___2vDCa Button__seeMore___czyKz ArticleLedeImage__button___3yTRZ"><div class="Button__content___d_gRZ"><i class="Button__icon___x9PXG Button__left___27AnT "><svg width="18" height="18" viewBox="0 0 18 18" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M2 14.6l5-5 1.5 1.3-5 5H7v2H0v-7h2v3.6zM16 3.4l-5 5-1.5-1.3 5-5H11V0h7v7h-2V3.4z" fill="#A2A2A2" fill-rule="evenodd" /></svg></i></div></button></div></div></div><figcaption class="ImageCaption__captionWrapper___2h5XI ImageCaption__default___3TPB5"><span class="ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO"><div><p>At Benno, the most formal of three new places to eat in the Evelyn Hotel, all under the purview of the chef Jonathan Benno, the best things on the prix-fixe menu are the least fussy, including the pastry chef Lindsey Bittner’s miniature chocolate babka, served with a quenelle of coffee-cardamom gelato.</p></div></span><small class="ImageCaption__credit___rg3mC ">Photograph by Eric Helgas for The New Yorker</small></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div id="articleBody" data-template="two-column" class="ArticleBody__articleBody___1GSGP"><div><div><div class="SectionBreak SectionBreak__sectionBreak___1ppA7"></div><div class="SectionBreak SectionBreak__sectionBreak___1ppA7"><p>The <span data-page="page_1"></span>other night at Benno, a new restaurant in the Evelyn Hotel, I had to wonder if a pair of couples sitting at the bar were plants: they were dressed, like guests at a Jay Gatsby soirée, in full nineteen-twenties attire, the women in sequinned flapper gowns, feathered headpieces, and boas, the men in crisp tuxedos. Their presence put a fine point on the fact that the Evelyn is an immaculately preserved Beaux Arts-era building and that Benno, situated in what used to be the ladies’ lounge, is a restaurant for capital-“F” Fine Dining.</p><div class="Callout__feature-small___1KziP" data-type="callout" data-callout="feature-small"><div class="ImageEmbed__container___1S6AV "><div class="Lightbox__lightbox___2lLZl Lightbox__white___jj_9p " role="button" tabindex="0"><figure class="Figure__figure___U_9Te Figure__fullHeight___3uICS "><div class="placeholder"><div class="placeholder-buttress"></div><div class="placeholder-content"><div class="Image__image___1PhYl Figure__image___1hDvt ImageEmbed__image___VwXNk" role="button" tabindex="0"><picture class="component-responsive-image"><source media="(min-width: 1280px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373/master/w_774,c_limit/181224_r33487.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373/master/w_1548,c_limit/181224_r33487.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 1024px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373/master/w_813,c_limit/181224_r33487.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373/master/w_1626,c_limit/181224_r33487.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33487.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33487.jpg 2x"/><source srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33487.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33487.jpg 2x"/><img alt="" src="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33487.jpg" title=""/></picture><button class="Button__button___2vDCa Button__seeMore___czyKz ImageEmbed__button___1EF1B"><div class="Button__content___d_gRZ"><i class="Button__icon___x9PXG Button__left___27AnT "><svg width="18" height="18" viewBox="0 0 18 18" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M2 14.6l5-5 1.5 1.3-5 5H7v2H0v-7h2v3.6zM16 3.4l-5 5-1.5-1.3 5-5H11V0h7v7h-2V3.4z" fill="#A2A2A2" fill-rule="evenodd" /></svg></i></div></button></div></div></div><figcaption class="ImageCaption__captionWrapper___2h5XI ImageCaption__default___3TPB5"><span class="ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO"><div><p>The brodetto, or seafood stew, for two comprises carefully cooked clams, mussels, squid, lobster, shrimp, scallops, and monkfish, in a rich, salty broth, studded with an orzo-like Sardinian pasta known as fregola.</p></div></span><small class="ImageCaption__credit___rg3mC ">Photograph by Eric Helgas for The New Yorker</small></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><p>It’s one of three places to eat in the Evelyn, a mini-empire under the rule of Jonathan Benno, whom you might call a chef’s chef—far from a household name but deeply respected in the restaurant industry, thanks to his tenure at the French Laundry, Gramercy Tavern, Craft, Per Se, and Lincoln Ristorante. Benno the restaurant, where the menu is prix fixe, joins the much more casual Leonelli Taberna, which serves Italian comfort food, and Leonelli Focacceria e Pasticceria, a counter offering focaccia, topped and sliced like pizza, plus pastries, sandwiches, and salads.</p><div class="Callout__feature-small___1KziP" data-type="callout" data-callout="feature-small"><div class="ImageEmbed__container___1S6AV "><div class="Lightbox__lightbox___2lLZl Lightbox__white___jj_9p " role="button" tabindex="0"><figure class="Figure__figure___U_9Te Figure__fullHeight___3uICS "><div class="placeholder"><div class="placeholder-buttress"></div><div class="placeholder-content"><div class="Image__image___1PhYl Figure__image___1hDvt ImageEmbed__image___VwXNk" role="button" tabindex="0"><picture class="component-responsive-image"><source media="(min-width: 1280px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e/master/w_774,c_limit/181224_r33488.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e/master/w_1548,c_limit/181224_r33488.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 1024px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e/master/w_813,c_limit/181224_r33488.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e/master/w_1626,c_limit/181224_r33488.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33488.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33488.jpg 2x"/><source srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33488.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33488.jpg 2x"/><img alt="" src="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33488.jpg" title=""/></picture><button class="Button__button___2vDCa Button__seeMore___czyKz ImageEmbed__button___1EF1B"><div class="Button__content___d_gRZ"><i class="Button__icon___x9PXG Button__left___27AnT "><svg width="18" height="18" viewBox="0 0 18 18" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M2 14.6l5-5 1.5 1.3-5 5H7v2H0v-7h2v3.6zM16 3.4l-5 5-1.5-1.3 5-5H11V0h7v7h-2V3.4z" fill="#A2A2A2" fill-rule="evenodd" /></svg></i></div></button></div></div></div><figcaption class="ImageCaption__captionWrapper___2h5XI ImageCaption__default___3TPB5"><span class="ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO"><div><p>Steelhead trout is poached in olive oil and served on a bed of Moroccan olives, pine nuts, and Cara Cara orange.</p></div></span><small class="ImageCaption__credit___rg3mC ">Photograph by Eric Helgas for The New Yorker</small></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><p>Together, they provide an interesting look into the mind of the chef. Leonelli Taberna, Benno has said, is meant to evoke his childhood memories “of sitting around the table with my family and eating my grandma’s eggplant parmesan.” Leonelli Focacceria feels like an homage to the cafés of Rome. And Benno is, presumably, his crown jewel, the culmination of a long and prestigious career in a distinctive echelon of restaurants.</p><div class="Callout__feature-small___1KziP" data-type="callout" data-callout="feature-small"><div class="ImageEmbed__container___1S6AV "><div class="Lightbox__lightbox___2lLZl Lightbox__white___jj_9p " role="button" tabindex="0"><figure class="Figure__figure___U_9Te Figure__fullHeight___3uICS "><div class="placeholder"><div class="placeholder-buttress"></div><div class="placeholder-content"><div class="Image__image___1PhYl Figure__image___1hDvt ImageEmbed__image___VwXNk" role="button" tabindex="0"><picture class="component-responsive-image"><source media="(min-width: 1280px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121/master/w_774,c_limit/181224_r33491.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121/master/w_1548,c_limit/181224_r33491.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 1024px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121/master/w_813,c_limit/181224_r33491.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121/master/w_1626,c_limit/181224_r33491.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33491.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33491.jpg 2x"/><source srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33491.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33491.jpg 2x"/><img alt="" src="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33491.jpg" title=""/></picture><button class="Button__button___2vDCa Button__seeMore___czyKz ImageEmbed__button___1EF1B"><div class="Button__content___d_gRZ"><i class="Button__icon___x9PXG Button__left___27AnT "><svg width="18" height="18" viewBox="0 0 18 18" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M2 14.6l5-5 1.5 1.3-5 5H7v2H0v-7h2v3.6zM16 3.4l-5 5-1.5-1.3 5-5H11V0h7v7h-2V3.4z" fill="#A2A2A2" fill-rule="evenodd" /></svg></i></div></button></div></div></div><figcaption class="ImageCaption__captionWrapper___2h5XI ImageCaption__default___3TPB5"><span class="ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO"><div><p>The dining room, which has the unmistakable air of capital-“F” Fine Dining, is situated in what used to be the Beaux Arts-era hotel’s glamorous ladies’ lounge.</p></div></span><small class="ImageCaption__credit___rg3mC ">Photograph by Eric Helgas for The New Yorker</small></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><p>But has the era for such restaurants passed? After two meals at Benno, I felt exhausted by the pomp and circumstance. One night, I mistook the contents of a vase on my table for reed-shaped fragrance diffusers; they turned out to be spindly breadsticks, or “housemade grissini,” seasoned with Calabrian chili and herbes de Provence. A canapé of duck liver and smoked-eel terrine atop black-olive purée—sprinkled with caramelized cocoa nibs and served with a shooter of lukewarm butternut-squash consommé, as sweet as an Italian-soda syrup—came off like a “Top Chef” challenge gone wrong. Even pastas, including a lovely green garganelli in a veal-and-porcini ragù, were fussy, served in plates shaped like U.F.O.s, with nowhere to rest your silverware should you want to pause for a sip of a fantastically fruity Nebbiolo.</p><div class="Callout__feature-small___1KziP" data-type="callout" data-callout="feature-small"><div class="ImageEmbed__container___1S6AV "><div class="Lightbox__lightbox___2lLZl Lightbox__white___jj_9p " role="button" tabindex="0"><figure class="Figure__figure___U_9Te Figure__fullHeight___3uICS "><div class="placeholder"><div class="placeholder-buttress"></div><div class="placeholder-content"><div class="Image__image___1PhYl Figure__image___1hDvt ImageEmbed__image___VwXNk" role="button" tabindex="0"><picture class="component-responsive-image"><source media="(min-width: 1280px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681/master/w_774,c_limit/181224_r33489.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681/master/w_1548,c_limit/181224_r33489.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 1024px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681/master/w_813,c_limit/181224_r33489.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681/master/w_1626,c_limit/181224_r33489.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33489.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33489.jpg 2x"/><source srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33489.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33489.jpg 2x"/><img alt="" src="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33489.jpg" title=""/></picture><button class="Button__button___2vDCa Button__seeMore___czyKz ImageEmbed__button___1EF1B"><div class="Button__content___d_gRZ"><i class="Button__icon___x9PXG Button__left___27AnT "><svg width="18" height="18" viewBox="0 0 18 18" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M2 14.6l5-5 1.5 1.3-5 5H7v2H0v-7h2v3.6zM16 3.4l-5 5-1.5-1.3 5-5H11V0h7v7h-2V3.4z" fill="#A2A2A2" fill-rule="evenodd" /></svg></i></div></button></div></div></div><figcaption class="ImageCaption__captionWrapper___2h5XI ImageCaption__default___3TPB5"><span class="ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO"><div><p>The menu at the more casual Leonelli Taberna, meanwhile, is meant to evoke the family meals of Benno’s childhood. Tigelle, a variety of flatbread from Modena, in northern Italy, is served with a choice of dips, including a thrillingly spicy one made with charred eggplant.</p></div></span><small class="ImageCaption__credit___rg3mC ">Photograph by Eric Helgas for The New Yorker</small></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><p>The less ambitious the food, the better it tended to be. I would almost go back just for the simple coddled egg, cooled with a dollop of black-truffle mousseline and garnished with tiny fingerling potatoes, pioppini mushrooms, and leeks. Each mussel, clam, and beautiful rhombus of squid in the brodetto, or seafood stew, for two was perfectly cooked. Dessert was a high point: a flaky miniature babka, with coffee-cardamom gelato; an al-dente baked apple, with granola and tart-apple sorbet. But who wouldn’t roll their eyes at the coffee service, which involves a waiter standing tableside as he weighs grounds on a scale, explains the temperature of the water, and expounds on the mechanics of a pour-over?</p><div class="Callout__feature-small___1KziP" data-type="callout" data-callout="feature-small"><div class="ImageEmbed__container___1S6AV "><div class="Lightbox__lightbox___2lLZl Lightbox__white___jj_9p " role="button" tabindex="0"><figure class="Figure__figure___U_9Te Figure__fullHeight___3uICS "><div class="placeholder"><div class="placeholder-buttress"></div><div class="placeholder-content"><div class="Image__image___1PhYl Figure__image___1hDvt ImageEmbed__image___VwXNk" role="button" tabindex="0"><picture class="component-responsive-image"><source media="(min-width: 1280px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2/master/w_774,c_limit/181224_r33490.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2/master/w_1548,c_limit/181224_r33490.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 1024px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2/master/w_813,c_limit/181224_r33490.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2/master/w_1626,c_limit/181224_r33490.jpg 2x"/><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33490.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33490.jpg 2x"/><source srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33490.jpg, https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2/master/w_1454,c_limit/181224_r33490.jpg 2x"/><img alt="" src="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2/master/w_727,c_limit/181224_r33490.jpg" title=""/></picture><button class="Button__button___2vDCa Button__seeMore___czyKz ImageEmbed__button___1EF1B"><div class="Button__content___d_gRZ"><i class="Button__icon___x9PXG Button__left___27AnT "><svg width="18" height="18" viewBox="0 0 18 18" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M2 14.6l5-5 1.5 1.3-5 5H7v2H0v-7h2v3.6zM16 3.4l-5 5-1.5-1.3 5-5H11V0h7v7h-2V3.4z" fill="#A2A2A2" fill-rule="evenodd" /></svg></i></div></button></div></div></div><figcaption class="ImageCaption__captionWrapper___2h5XI ImageCaption__default___3TPB5"><span class="ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO ImageCaption__caption___1EOQO"><div><p>Lindsey Bittner’s desserts for Leonelli Taberna are just as good as those at Benno. Ricotta-based cannoli gelato is flecked with chocolate chunks and candied orange and garnished with a piece of fried pastry shell.</p></div></span><small class="ImageCaption__credit___rg3mC ">Photograph by Eric Helgas for The New Yorker</small></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><p>Benno shares a pastry chef, the talented Lindsey Bittner, with Leonelli Taberna, and it’s hard to come up with a reason not to eat there instead. It’s a warm, lively extension of the hotel’s beautiful lobby. Pasta—including a wonderful spinach-noodle-and-bolognese lasagna—is served in the usual tableware. Though the menu can be uneven—the burger with hot peppers and provolone was a bit dry one night, and beware the cacio-e-pepe ravioli, which sounds too good to be true for a reason—it’s generally imbued with a sense of curiosity and excitement about unpretentious Italian cooking. An impressive array of housemade salumi and regional specialties like tigelle, a kind of embossed flatbread from Modena, for slathering with thrillingly spicy charred-eggplant dip, are worth a visit. It’s the sort of food you can imagine Jonathan Benno preparing at the end of a long night, kicking off his shoes and relaxing at home. <em class="">(Benno tasting menu $95-$145. Leonelli Taberna dishes $9-$26.)</em> ♦</p></div></div></div></div><footer class="ArticleFooter__footer___3-wlJ"><span class="ArticleDisclaimer__articleDisclaimer___2kCNX">This article appears in the print edition of the December 24 & 31, 2018, issue, with the headline “Benno / Leonelli Taberna.”</span><div class="ArticleContributors__bio___3XQjk"><div class="ArticleContributors__contributorWrapper___1CrIJ"><div class="Avatar__avatar___1_uRc ArticleContributors__bioAvatar___11Nu0"><a class="Link__link___3dWao " https://media.newyorker.com/photos/59097b77019dfc3494ea36d9/1:1/w_260,c_limit/goldfield-hannah.png 2x"/><img alt="" src="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/59097b77019dfc3494ea36d9/1:1/w_130,c_limit/goldfield-hannah.png" title=""/></picture></div></a></div><ul class="ArticleContributors__contributorBios___3_jrJ false"><li><p class="ArticleContributors__contributorBioText___3m1QB">Hannah Goldfield is the food critic for The New Yorker.</p><a class="Link__link___3dWao a Deal That Democrats Are Sure to Reject</h2></a><h2 class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__dek___1rygJ">The most revealing aspect of Saturday’s proposal is its bland predictability.</h2><p class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__byline___eynVy">By <a class="Link__link___3dWao " href="/contributors/jonathan-blitzer" title="Jonathan Blitzer" rel="author">Jonathan Blitzer</a></p><span Found Us? An Interview with the Harvard Astronomer Avi Loeb About the Mysterious Interstellar Object ‘Oumuamua</h2></a><h2 class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__dek___1rygJ">Avi Loeb discusses why we need to consider the possibility that the object was sent by aliens, the dangers of unscientific speculation, and what belief in an advanced extraterrestrial civilization has in common with faith in God.</h2><p class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__byline___eynVy">By <a class="Link__link___3dWao " href="/contributors/isaac-chotiner" title="Isaac Chotiner" rel="author">Isaac Chotiner</a></p><span class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__timestamp___1YE3P">Jan. 16, 2019</span></div></div><div class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__row___1MVU6"><div class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__story___1S5ZJ" data-track-type="recircItem" data-track-location="mod-related" data-service="tbd" data-source="parsely" data-track-position="0"><a class="Link__link___3dWao RecirculationRecommendedStories__image___3M88v " href="/news/the-new-yorker-interview/how-journalism-survives-an-interview-with-jill-abramson"><div class="Image__image___1PhYl" role="button" tabindex="0"><picture class="component-responsive-image"><source media="(min-width: 1024px)" href="/news/the-new-yorker-interview/how-journalism-survives-an-interview-with-jill-abramson"><h2 class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__hed___3cnVL">How Journalism Survives: An Interview with Jill Abramson</h2></a><h2 class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__dek___1rygJ">In her new book, the former executive editor of the New York <em>Times</em> says that she was “determined to capture this moment of wrenching transition” in journalism.</h2><p class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__byline___eynVy">By <a class="Link__link___3dWao " href="/contributors/isaac-chotiner" title="Isaac Chotiner" rel="author">Isaac Chotiner</a></p><span class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__timestamp___1YE3P">Jan. 20, 2019</span></div><div class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__story___1S5ZJ" data-track-type="recircItem" data-track-location="mod-related" data-service="tbd" data-source="parsely" data-track-position="1"><a class="Link__link___3dWao RecirculationRecommendedStories__image___3M88v " href="/culture/culture-desk/what-hamilton-in-san-juan-means-to-puerto-rico"><div class="Image__image___1PhYl" role="button" tabindex="0"><picture class="component-responsive-image"><source media="(min-width: 1024px)" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c3e2a6a9d69a04dde6b1493/4:3/w_474,c_limit/Schulman-Hamilton-Puerto-Rico.jpg, src="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5c3e2a6a9d69a04dde6b1493/4:3/w_620,c_limit/Schulman-Hamilton-Puerto-Rico.jpg" title=""/></picture></div></a><span class="Rubric__rubric___3hrQE RecirculationRecommendedStories__rubric___2phUL">Culture Desk</span><a class="Link__link___3dWao " href="/culture/culture-desk/what-hamilton-in-san-juan-means-to-puerto-rico"><h2 class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__hed___3cnVL">What “Hamilton” in San Juan Means to Puerto Rico</h2></a><h2 class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__dek___1rygJ">In bringing “Hamilton” to Puerto Rico, Lin-Manuel Miranda called international attention to the island’s progress and also to its daunting obstacles.</h2><p class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__byline___eynVy">By <a class="Link__link___3dWao " href="/contributors/michael-schulman" title="Michael Schulman" rel="author">Michael Schulman</a></p><span class="RecirculationRecommendedStories__timestamp___1YE3P">Jan. 17, 2019</span></div></div></div></section></article><div data-cm-unit="show-failsafe"><div data-cns="cns-slot-global-footer" class=""></div></div></section><footer data-track-type="nav" D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20less%20ambitious%20the%20food%2C%20the%20better%20it%20tended%20to%20be.%20I%20would%20almost%20go%20back%20just%20for%20the%20simple%20coddled%20egg%2C%20cooled%20with%20a%20dollop%20of%20black-truffle%20mousseline%20and%20garnished%20with%20tiny%20fingerling%20potatoes%2C%20pioppini%20mushrooms%2C%20and%20leeks.%20Each%20mussel%2C%20clam%2C%20and%20beautiful%20rhombus%20of%20squid%20in%20the%20brodetto%2C%20or%20seafood%20stew%2C%20for%20two%20was%20perfectly%20cooked.%20Dessert%20was%20a%20high%20point%3A%20a%20flaky%20miniature%20babka%2C%20with%20coffee-cardamom%20gelato%3B%20an%20al-dente%20baked%20apple%2C%20with%20granola%20and%20tart-apple%20sorbet.%20But%20who%20wouldn%E2%80%99t%20roll%20their%20eyes%20at%20the%20coffee%20service%2C%20which%20involves%20a%20waiter%20standing%20tableside%20as%20he%20weighs%20grounds%20on%20a%20scale%2C%20explains%20the%20temperature%20of%20the%20water%2C%20and%20expounds%20on%20the%20mechanics%20of%20a%20pour-over%3F%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522feature-small%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EBenno%20shares%20a%20pastry%20chef%2C%20the%20talented%20Lindsey%20Bittner%2C%20with%20Leonelli%20Taberna%2C%20and%20it%E2%80%99s%20hard%20to%20come%20up%20with%20a%20reason%20not%20to%20eat%20there%20instead.%20It%E2%80%99s%20a%20warm%2C%20lively%20extension%20of%20the%20hotel%E2%80%99s%20beautiful%20lobby.%20Pasta%E2%80%94including%20a%20wonderful%20spinach-noodle-and-bolognese%20lasagna%E2%80%94is%20served%20in%20the%20usual%20tableware.%20Though%20the%20menu%20can%20be%20uneven%E2%80%94the%20burger%20with%20hot%20peppers%20and%20provolone%20was%20a%20bit%20dry%20one%20night%2C%20and%20beware%20the%20cacio-e-pepe%20ravioli%2C%20which%20sounds%20too%20good%20to%20be%20true%20for%20a%20reason%E2%80%94it%E2%80%99s%20generally%20imbued%20with%20a%20sense%20of%20curiosity%20and%20excitement%20about%20unpretentious%20Italian%20cooking.%20An%20impressive%20array%20of%20housemade%20salumi%20and%20regional%20specialties%20like%20tigelle%2C%20a%20kind%20of%20embossed%20flatbread%20from%20Modena%2C%20for%20slathering%20with%20thrillingly%20spicy%20charred-eggplant%20dip%2C%20are%20worth%20a%20visit.%20It%E2%80%99s%20the%20sort%20of%20food%20you%20can%20imagine%20Jonathan%20Benno%20preparing%20at%20the%20end%20of%20a%20long%20night%2C%20kicking%20off%20his%20shoes%20and%20relaxing%20at%20home.%20%3Cem%3E(Benno%20tasting%20menu%20%2495-%24145.%20Leonelli%20Taberna%20dishes%20%249-%2426.)%3C%2Fem%3E%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The ",["inline-embed",{"type":"analytics","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22analytics%22%2C%22url%22%3A%221%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}],"other night at Benno, a new restaurant in the Evelyn Hotel, I had to wonder if a pair of couples sitting at the bar were plants: they were dressed, like guests at a Jay Gatsby soirée, in full nineteen-twenties attire, the women in sequinned flapper gowns, feathered headpieces, and boas, the men in crisp tuxedos. Their presence put a fine point on the fact that the Evelyn is an immaculately preserved Beaux Arts-era building and that Benno, situated in what used to be the ladies’ lounge, is a restaurant for capital-“F” Fine Dining."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1175bf3fdb463f29450373%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1175bf3fdb463f29450373"}]],["p","It’s one of three places to eat in the Evelyn, a mini-empire under the rule of Jonathan Benno, whom you might call a chef’s chef—far from a household name but deeply respected in the restaurant industry, thanks to his tenure at the French Laundry, Gramercy Tavern, Craft, Per Se, and Lincoln Ristorante. Benno the restaurant, where the menu is prix fixe, joins the much more casual Leonelli Taberna, which serves Italian comfort food, and Leonelli Focacceria e Pasticceria, a counter offering focaccia, topped and sliced like pizza, plus pastries, sandwiches, and salads."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1175bf50c60350034bc49e%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1175bf50c60350034bc49e"}]],["p","Together, they provide an interesting look into the mind of the chef. Leonelli Taberna, Benno has said, is meant to evoke his childhood memories “of sitting around the table with my family and eating my grandma’s eggplant parmesan.” Leonelli Focacceria feels like an homage to the cafés of Rome. And Benno is, presumably, his crown jewel, the culmination of a long and prestigious career in a distinctive echelon of restaurants."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1175bf9adb1e541adb8121"}]],["p","But has the era for such restaurants passed? After two meals at Benno, I felt exhausted by the pomp and circumstance. One night, I mistook the contents of a vase on my table for reed-shaped fragrance diffusers; they turned out to be spindly breadsticks, or “housemade grissini,” seasoned with Calabrian chili and herbes de Provence. A canapé of duck liver and smoked-eel terrine atop black-olive purée—sprinkled with caramelized cocoa nibs and served with a shooter of lukewarm butternut-squash consommé, as sweet as an Italian-soda syrup—came off like a “Top Chef” challenge gone wrong. Even pastas, including a lovely green garganelli in a veal-and-porcini ragù, were fussy, served in plates shaped like U.F.O.s, with nowhere to rest your silverware should you want to pause for a sip of a fantastically fruity Nebbiolo."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1175bf2eb5b760bfa5e681"}]],["p","The less ambitious the food, the better it tended to be. I would almost go back just for the simple coddled egg, cooled with a dollop of black-truffle mousseline and garnished with tiny fingerling potatoes, pioppini mushrooms, and leeks. Each mussel, clam, and beautiful rhombus of squid in the brodetto, or seafood stew, for two was perfectly cooked. Dessert was a high point: a flaky miniature babka, with coffee-cardamom gelato; an al-dente baked apple, with granola and tart-apple sorbet. But who wouldn’t roll their eyes at the coffee service, which involves a waiter standing tableside as he weighs grounds on a scale, explains the temperature of the water, and expounds on the mechanics of a pour-over?"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2"}]],["p","Benno shares a pastry chef, the talented Lindsey Bittner, with Leonelli Taberna, and it’s hard to come up with a reason not to eat there instead. It’s a warm, lively extension of the hotel’s beautiful lobby. Pasta—including a wonderful spinach-noodle-and-bolognese lasagna—is served in the usual tableware. Though the menu can be uneven—the burger with hot peppers and provolone was a bit dry one night, and beware the cacio-e-pepe ravioli, which sounds too good to be true for a reason—it’s generally imbued with a sense of curiosity and excitement about unpretentious Italian cooking. An impressive array of housemade salumi and regional specialties like tigelle, a kind of embossed flatbread from Modena, for slathering with thrillingly spicy charred-eggplant dip, are worth a visit. It’s the sort of food you can imagine Jonathan Benno preparing at the end of a long night, kicking off his shoes and relaxing at home. ",["em","(Benno tasting menu $95-$145. Leonelli Taberna dishes $9-$26.)"]," ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/12/24/a-chefs-mini-empire-in-the-evelyn-hotel","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c79ee7fe02cbd163329","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5c2e1c79ee7fe02cbd163329","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Food","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"food"},{"id":"5afc81b4577f6a3b0500895c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Tags","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"tags"}],"name":"Food","parent":[{"id":"5afc81b4577f6a3b0500895c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5afc81b4577f6a3b0500895c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Tags","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"tags"}],"name":"Tags","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81b4577f6a3b0500895c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Tags","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"tags"},"slug":"tags"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81b4577f6a3b0500895c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Tags","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"tags"},"slug":"food"},{"id":"5c2e1c7c397f5b30646d05f2","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5c2e1c7c397f5b30646d05f2","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Restaurants","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"restaurants"},{"id":"5afc81b4577f6a3b0500895c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Tags","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"tags"}],"name":"Restaurants","parent":[{"id":"5afc81b4577f6a3b0500895c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hie Tigelle, a variety of flatbread from Modena, in northern Italy, is served with a choice of dips, including a thrillingly spicy one made with charred eggplant."]],"altText":"A variety of flatbread from Modena, in northern Italy, is served with a choice of dips, including a thrillingly spicy one made with charred eggplant.","credit":"Photograph by Eric Helgas for The New Yorker","filename":"181224_r33489.jpg","revision":4,"tags":[],"title":"181224_r33489","notes":"_wordpress_id:3766392","variants":{}},"5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2":{"id":"5c1175c0a520f549a03f03c2","modelName":"photo","collection":"photos","aspectRatios":{"master":{"width":2560,"height":1829,"format":"JPEG","duration":null,"url":"https://cn-copilot-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/tny-services/production/2018/12/12/5c1175bfa520f549a03f03c1_181224_r33490.jpg"},"2:2":{"override":false,"height":1829,"width":1829,"modifications":{"crop":{"height":1829,"width":1829,"x":365.5,"y":0}},"duration":null},"16:9":{"override":false,"height":1440,"width":2560,"modifications":{"crop":{"height":1440,"width":2560,"x":0,"y":0}},"duration":null},"4:3":{"override":false,"height":1827,"width":2436,"modifications":{"crop":{"height":1827,"width":2436,"x":62,"y":0}},"duration":null},"3:4":{"override":false,"height":1828,"width":1371,"modifications":{"crop":{"height":1828,"width":1371,"x":594.5,"y":0}},"duration":null},"2:3":{"override":false,"height":1827,"width":1218,"modifications":{"crop":{"height":1827,"width":1218,"x":671,"y":0}},"duration":null},"3:2":{"override":false,"height":1706,"width":2559,"modifications":{"crop":{"height":1706,"width":2559,"x":0.5,"y":0}},"duration":null},"1:1":{"override":false,"height":1829,"width":1829,"modifications":{"crop":{"height":1829,"width":1829,"x":365.5,"y":0}},"duration":null}},"caption":["div",["p","Lindsey Bittner’s desserts for Leonelli Taberna are just as good as those at Benno. D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"iframe","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22iframe%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22http%3A%2F%2Faudm.herokuapp.com%2Fplayer-embed%3Fpub%3Dnewyorker%26articleID%3D5c11417e50c60350034bc462%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22100%25%22%2C%22height%22%3A%2290%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}]]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThis%20past%20July%2C%20on%20the%20final%20day%20of%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E%20summit%20in%20Brussels%2C%20Angela%20Merkel%2C%20the%20German%20Chancellor%2C%20proposed%20a%20closed-door%20emergency%20meeting.%20The%20emergency%20was%20Donald%20Trump.%20Minutes%20earlier%2C%20the%20President%20had%20arrived%20late%20to%20a%20session%20where%20the%20Presidents%20of%20Ukraine%20and%20Georgia%20were%20making%20their%20case%20to%20join%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E.%20Trump%20interrupted%20their%20presentation%20and%20unleashed%20a%20verbal%20assault%20on%20the%20members%20of%20the%20alliance%2C%20calling%20them%20deadbeats%20and%20free%20riders%20on%20American%20power.%20Trump%20threatened%20to%20go%20his%20%E2%80%9Cown%20way%E2%80%9D%20if%20they%20didn%E2%80%99t%20immediately%20pay%20more%20for%20their%20own%20defense.%20His%20barrage%20centered%20on%20Merkel%2C%20Europe%E2%80%99s%20longest-serving%20democratic%20leader.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CYou%2C%20Angela%2C%E2%80%9D%20Trump%20chided%20Merkel.%20Most%20of%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E%E2%80%99s%20members%20had%20failed%20to%20fulfill%20the%20goal%20of%20spending%20two%20per%20cent%20of%20G.D.P.%20for%20defense%2C%20but%20Trump%20focussed%20on%20Germany%E2%80%99s%20military%20spending%20of%20just%20over%20one%20per%20cent%20of%20G.D.P.%20In%20front%20of%20television%20cameras%20the%20previous%20day%2C%20he%20had%20accused%20Germany%20of%20being%20%E2%80%9Ctotally%20controlled%20by%20Russia%2C%E2%80%9D%20because%20of%20a%20proposed%20new%20gas%20pipeline.%20His%20tweets%20that%20day%20sounded%20like%20blackmail.%20%E2%80%9CWhat%20good%20is%20NATO%20if%20Germany%20is%20paying%20Russia%20billions%20of%20dollars%20for%20gas%20and%20energy%3F%20The%20U.S.%20is%20paying%20for%20Europe%E2%80%99s%20protection%2C%20then%20loses%20billions%20on%20Trade.%20Must%20pay%202%25%20of%20GDP%20IMMEDIATELY%2C%20not%20by%202025.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ENow%2C%20with%20the%20room%20cleared%20of%20staff%2C%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E%20leaders%20sat%20stunned%20by%20what%20one%20called%20the%20%E2%80%9Cbizarre%20spectacle%E2%80%9D%20of%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20harangue.%20It%20fell%20to%20another%20woman%2C%20Dalia%20Grybauskait%C4%97%2C%20the%20President%20of%20Lithuania%2C%20to%20defend%20Merkel.%20Germany%20had%20sent%20troops%20to%20protect%20Lithuania%20from%20Russia%2C%20Grybauskait%C4%97%20pointed%20out%2C%20and%20Merkel%20was%20committed%20to%20spending%20more%20on%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E%E2%80%99s%20common%20defense.%20The%20Danish%20and%20the%20Norwegian%20Prime%20Ministers%20also%20pushed%20back.%20In%20the%20corner%20of%20the%20room%2C%20Merkel%20strategized%20with%20other%20Europeans%20about%20how%20to%20stop%20Trump.%20Eventually%2C%20Mark%20Rutte%2C%20the%20Prime%20Minister%20of%20the%20Netherlands%2C%20offered%20the%20President%20what%20he%20appeared%20to%20want%20most%3A%20a%20way%20to%20claim%20victory.%20Rutte%20noted%20that%2C%20since%20Trump%20took%20office%2C%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E%20allies%20had%20collectively%20raised%20their%20defense%20budgets%20by%20some%20seventy%20billion%20dollars.%20Take%20the%20win%2C%20he%20urged%20the%20President.%20Trump%20did%20just%20that.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnd%20yet%2C%20when%20he%20emerged%20from%20the%20meeting%20and%20spoke%20with%20reporters%2C%20Trump%20lied%2C%20claiming%20not%20only%20that%20his%20allies%20had%20capitulated%20to%20him%20but%20also%20that%20they%20would%20consider%20his%20demand%20to%20raise%20their%20annual%20military%20spending%20to%20four%20per%20cent%20of%20G.D.P.%2C%20an%20assertion%20so%20politically%20impossible%20that%20Emmanuel%20Macron%2C%20the%20President%20of%20France%2C%20immediately%20issued%20a%20public%20rebuttal.%20Trump%2C%20of%20course%2C%20went%20on%20behaving%20in%20his%20erratic%2C%20inexplicable%20manner.%20As%20he%20left%20the%20summit%2C%20he%20interrupted%20the%20Chancellor%20while%20she%20was%20addressing%20her%20fellow%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E%20leaders%2C%20and%20kissed%20her.%20%E2%80%9CI%20love%20this%20woman%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CIsn%E2%80%99t%20she%20great%3F%E2%80%9D%20A%20senior%20German%20official%20who%20told%20me%20about%20that%20particular%20Trumpian%20flourish%20resisted%20any%20attempt%20at%20full%20understanding.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20up%20to%20psychologists%20and%20historians%20what%20to%20make%20of%20that%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20Four%20days%20later%2C%20Trump%20ended%20his%20European%20tour%20in%20Helsinki.%20There%2C%20standing%20next%20to%20Vladimir%20Putin%2C%20he%20spoke%20with%20bewildering%20sympathy%20for%20Russian%20foreign%20policy%2C%20ill-concealed%20contempt%20for%20his%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E%20partners%2C%20and%20implausible%20skepticism%20about%20his%20own%20intelligence%20services.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20astonishing%20week%20in%20Europe%20was%20the%20culmination%20of%20a%20four-month%20period%20in%20which%20the%20President%20imposed%20tariffs%20on%20allies%20by%20calling%20them%20%E2%80%9Cnational%20security%E2%80%9D%20threats%2C%20pulled%20out%20of%20the%20Iran%20nuclear%20deal%2C%20which%20they%20had%20jointly%20negotiated%20with%20the%20United%20States%2C%20and%20held%20affectionate%20summits%20with%20two%20of%20the%20world%E2%80%99s%20most%20powerful%20autocrats%2C%20Putin%20and%20Kim%20Jong%20Un%2C%20while%20casting%20aspersions%20on%20America%E2%80%99s%20most%20constant%20allies.%20No%20one%20was%20more%20of%20a%20constant%20target%20than%20Angela%20Merkel.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EEuropean%20leaders%20now%20worry%20that%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20illiberal%20aims%20go%20well%20beyond%20his%20insistent%20demands%20on%20Merkel%20to%20pay%20more%20for%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E%20and%20stop%20shipping%20so%20many%20cars%20to%20the%20U.S.%20%E2%80%9CMany%20European%20leaders%20have%20told%20me%20that%20they%20are%20convinced%20that%20President%20Trump%20is%20determined%20to%20destroy%20the%20E.U.%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20former%20senior%20U.S.%20official%20told%20me.%20Trump%20has%20begun%20publicly%20calling%20the%20E.U.%20a%20%E2%80%9Cfoe%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20promoting%20the%20resurgence%20of%20nationalism%2C%20which%20Macron%20and%20Merkel%20see%20as%20a%20direct%20threat.%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20Secretary%20of%20State%2C%20Mike%20Pompeo%2C%20in%20a%20recent%20speech%20at%20the%20German%20Marshall%20Fund%20in%20Brussels%2C%20attacked%20the%20United%20Nations%2C%20the%20E.U.%2C%20the%20World%20Bank%2C%20and%20the%20International%20Monetary%20Fund%2C%20and%20derided%20what%20he%20called%20Europe%E2%80%99s%20flawed%20vision%20of%20multilateralism%20as%20%E2%80%9Can%20end%20to%20itself.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EEurope%20has%20had%20many%20fights%20with%20American%20Presidents%20over%20the%20years%2C%20but%20never%20in%20the%20seven%20decades%20since%20the%20end%20of%20the%20Second%20World%20War%20has%20it%20confronted%20one%20so%20openly%20hostile%20to%20its%20core%20institutions.%20Since%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20election%2C%20Europe%E2%80%99s%20leaders%20have%20feared%20that%20it%20would%20come%20to%20this%2C%20but%20they%20have%20disagreed%20about%20how%20to%20respond%20to%20him.%20Many%20hoped%20to%20wait%20Trump%20out.%20A%20few%20urged%20confrontation.%20Others%2C%20especially%20in%20nations%20more%20vulnerable%20to%20Russia%2C%20urged%20accommodation.%20(Poland%20offered%20to%20name%20a%20new%20military%20base%20Fort%20Trump.)%20Macron%20tried%20flattery%2C%20and%20then%2C%20when%20that%20failed%2C%20he%20reverted%20to%20public%20criticism%20of%20Trump-style%20nationalism.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20challenge%20from%20Trump%20has%20been%20especially%20personal%20for%20Germans%2C%20whose%20close%20relationship%20with%20the%20United%20States%20has%20defined%20their%20nation%E2%80%99s%20postwar%20renaissance.%20Merkel%20grew%20up%20in%20Communist%20East%20Germany%20and%20credits%20the%20United%20States%20as%20essential%20to%20the%20liberation%20of%20the%20East%20and%20to%20German%20reunification.%20As%20the%20head%20of%20Europe%E2%80%99s%20largest%20and%20wealthiest%20nation%2C%20she%20has%20sought%20to%20guide%20the%20Continent%20through%20the%20standoff%20with%20Trump%2C%20but%20has%20struggled%2C%20because%20the%20President%E2%80%99s%20harsh%20words%20reflect%20a%20painful%20truth%3A%20Europeans%20are%20dependent%20on%20the%20United%20States%20for%20their%20security%20and%20increasingly%20divided%20as%20Putin%E2%80%99s%20Russia%20threatens%20the%20nations%20in%20the%20east.%20%E2%80%9CNot%20all%20of%20what%20he%20says%20is%20wrong%2C%E2%80%9D%20said%20the%20senior%20German%20official%2C%20one%20of%20ten%20who%20spoke%20with%20me.%20%E2%80%9CEurope%20has%20been%20free-riding%20for%20some%20time.%E2%80%9D%20Asked%20for%20comment%20about%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20criticism%20of%20Merkel%2C%20a%20White%20House%20spokesperson%20told%20me%2C%20%E2%80%9CHe%20is%20often%20toughest%20on%20his%20friends%2C%20and%20he%20considers%20her%20one.%20He%20views%20Germany%20as%20a%20powerful%2C%20prosperous%20country%20that%20should%20be%20doing%20more%20on%20defense%20spending.%E2%80%9D%20But%20the%20risks%20for%20Trump%20are%20also%20considerable%3A%20call%20your%20friends%20enemies%20long%20enough%2C%20and%20eventually%20they%20may%20start%20to%20believe%20you.%20Is%20this%2C%20then%2C%20finally%2C%20the%20end%20of%20Pax%20Americana%3F%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","This past July, on the final day of the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"NATO"]," summit in Brussels, Angela Merkel, the German Chancellor, proposed a closed-door emergency meeting. The emergency was Donald Trump. Minutes earlier, the President had arrived late to a session where the Presidents of Ukraine and Georgia were making their case to join ",["em",{"class":"small"},"NATO"],". Trump interrupted their presentation and unleashed a verbal assault on the members of the alliance, calling them deadbeats and free riders on American power. Trump threatened to go his “own way” if they didn’t immediately pay more for their own defense. His barrage centered on Merkel, Europe’s longest-serving democratic leader."],["p","“You, Angela,” Trump chided Merkel. Most of ",["em",{"class":"small"},"NATO"],"’s members had failed to fulfill the goal of spending two per cent of G.D.P. for defense, but Trump focussed on Germany’s military spending of just over one per cent of G.D.P. In front of television cameras the previous day, he had accused Germany of being “totally controlled by Russia,” because of a proposed new gas pipeline. His tweets that day sounded like blackmail. “What good is NATO if Germany is paying Russia billions of dollars for gas and energy? The U.S. is paying for Europe’s protection, then loses billions on Trade. Must pay 2% of GDP IMMEDIATELY, not by 2025.”"],["p","Now, with the room cleared of staff, the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"NATO"]," leaders sat stunned by what one called the “bizarre spectacle” of Trump’s harangue. It fell to another woman, Dalia Grybauskaitė, the President of Lithuania, to defend Merkel. Germany had sent troops to protect Lithuania from Russia, Grybauskaitė pointed out, and Merkel was committed to spending more on ",["em",{"class":"small"},"NATO"],"’s common defense. The Danish and the Norwegian Prime Ministers also pushed back. In the corner of the room, Merkel strategized with other Europeans about how to stop Trump. Eventually, Mark Rutte, the Prime Minister of the Netherlands, offered the President what he appeared to want most: a way to claim victory. Rutte noted that, since Trump took office, the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"NATO"]," allies had collectively raised their defense budgets by some seventy billion dollars. Take the win, he urged the President. Trump did just that."],["p","And yet, when he emerged from the meeting and spoke with reporters, Trump lied, claiming not only that his allies had capitulated to him but also that they would consider his demand to raise their annual military spending to four per cent of G.D.P., an assertion so politically impossible that Emmanuel Macron, the President of France, immediately issued a public rebuttal. Trump, of course, went on behaving in his erratic, inexplicable manner. As he left the summit, he interrupted the Chancellor while she was addressing her fellow ",["em",{"class":"small"},"NATO"]," leaders, and kissed her. “I love this woman,” he said. “Isn’t she great?” A senior German official who told me about that particular Trumpian flourish resisted any attempt at full understanding. “It’s up to psychologists and historians what to make of that,” he said. Four days later, Trump ended his European tour in Helsinki. There, standing next to Vladimir Putin, he spoke with bewildering sympathy for Russian foreign policy, ill-concealed contempt for his ",["em",{"class":"small"},"NATO"]," partners, and implausible skepticism about his own intelligence services."],["p","The astonishing week in Europe was the culmination of a four-month period in which the President imposed tariffs on allies by calling them “national security” threats, pulled out of the Iran nuclear deal, which they had jointly negotiated with the United States, and held affectionate summits with two of the world’s most powerful autocrats, Putin and Kim Jong Un, while casting aspersions on America’s most constant allies. No one was more of a constant target than Angela Merkel."],["p","European leaders now worry that Trump’s illiberal aims go well beyond his insistent demands on Merkel to pay more for ",["em",{"class":"small"},"NATO"]," and stop shipping so many cars to the U.S. “Many European leaders have told me that they are convinced that President Trump is determined to destroy the E.U.,” a former senior U.S. official told me. Trump has begun publicly calling the E.U. a “foe,” and promoting the resurgence of nationalism, which Macron and Merkel see as a direct threat. Trump’s Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, in a recent speech at the German Marshall Fund in Brussels, attacked the United Nations, the E.U., the World Bank, and the International Monetary Fund, and derided what he called Europe’s flawed vision of multilateralism as “an end to itself.”"],["p","Europe has had many fights with American Presidents over the years, but never in the seven decades since the end of the Second World War has it confronted one so openly hostile to its core institutions. Since Trump’s election, Europe’s leaders have feared that it would come to this, but they have disagreed about how to respond to him. Many hoped to wait Trump out. A few urged confrontation. Others, especially in nations more vulnerable to Russia, urged accommodation. (Poland offered to name a new military base Fort Trump.) Macron tried flattery, and then, when that failed, he reverted to public criticism of Trump-style nationalism."],["p","The challenge from Trump has been especially personal for Germans, whose close relationship with the United States has defined their nation’s postwar renaissance. Merkel grew up in Communist East Germany and credits the United States as essential to the liberation of the East and to German reunification. As the head of Europe’s largest and wealthiest nation, she has sought to guide the Continent through the standoff with Trump, but has struggled, because the President’s harsh words reflect a painful truth: Europeans are dependent on the United States for their security and increasingly divided as Putin’s Russia threatens the nations in the east. “Not all of what he says is wrong,” said the senior German official, one of ten who spoke with me. “Europe has been free-riding for some time.” Asked for comment about Trump’s criticism of Merkel, a White House spokesperson told me, “He is often toughest on his friends, and he considers her one. He views Germany as a powerful, prosperous country that should be doing more on defense spending.” But the risks for Trump are also considerable: call your friends enemies long enough, and eventually they may start to believe you. Is this, then, finally, the end of Pax Americana?"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EOn%20November%2016%2C%202016%2C%20eight%20days%20after%20Trump%20was%20elected%2C%20Barack%20Obama%20flew%20to%20Berlin%20to%20meet%20with%20Merkel%3B%20it%20was%20the%20last%20foreign%20trip%20of%20his%20Presidency.%20Obama%20and%20Merkel%20had%20not%20started%20out%20as%20good%20friends%2C%20but%20they%20had%20become%20as%20close%20as%20two%20public%20figures%20could%20be.%20Over%20dinner%20in%20the%20Adlon%20Hotel%2C%20they%20discussed%20the%20shocking%20events%20of%20the%20previous%20few%20months%2C%20particularly%20Great%20Britain%E2%80%99s%20referendum%20to%20leave%20the%20European%20Union%20and%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20victory%20running%20on%20the%20slogan%20%E2%80%9CAmerica%20First.%E2%80%9D%20Through%20the%20windows%20of%20their%20private%20dining%20room%2C%20Merkel%20and%20Obama%20could%20see%20the%20floodlit%20Brandenburg%20Gate%2C%20the%20symbol%20of%20a%20reunified%20Berlin.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EMerkel%2C%20who%20was%20nearing%20the%20end%20of%20her%20third%20term%2C%20confided%20that%20she%20reluctantly%20felt%20that%20she%20had%20to%20run%20again%2C%20in%20order%20to%20be%20a%20buffer%20against%20Trump%2C%20Brexit%2C%20and%20the%20surge%20of%20right-wing%20populism%20throughout%20Europe.%20Obama%20urged%20her%20to%20do%20so.%20%E2%80%9CObama%20was%20obsessed%20with%20the%20fate%20of%20Europe%20during%20his%20last%20year%20in%20office%2C%E2%80%9D%20Charles%20Kupchan%2C%20who%20served%20as%20Obama%E2%80%99s%20top%20National%20Security%20Council%20adviser%20on%20European%20affairs%20and%20accompanied%20him%20on%20the%20trip%2C%20told%20me.%20After%20the%20election%2C%20the%20situation%20seemed%20even%20more%20urgent.%20%E2%80%9CHis%20view%20was%20that%20Merkel%20was%20needed%20to%20keep%20Europe%20together%2C%E2%80%9D%20Kupchan%20said.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20was%20afraid%20that%2C%20without%20Merkel%2C%20Humpty%20Dumpty%20was%20going%20to%20fall%20off%20the%20wall.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20dinner%20was%20emotional.%20Obama%20later%20told%20Benjamin%20Rhodes%2C%20his%20deputy%20national-security%20adviser%2C%20that%20he%20had%20said%20to%20Merkel%20that%20the%20Trump%20Presidency%20would%20be%20like%20a%20storm.%20Obama%20told%20her%20to%20just%20%E2%80%9Ctry%20to%20find%20some%20high%20ground%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20hold%20on%20to%20it%2C%20Rhodes%20recalled%20to%20me.%20By%20the%20time%20they%20said%20good%20night%2C%20three%20hours%20later%2C%20it%20was%20the%20longest%20that%20Obama%20had%20been%20alone%20with%20another%20world%20leader%20in%20his%20eight%20years%20in%20office.%20In%20an%20adjoining%20room%2C%20advisers%20to%20Merkel%20and%20Obama%20were%20concluding%20their%20own%20dinner.%20Rhodes%20offered%20a%20rueful%20toast%3A%20To%20Angela%20Merkel%2C%20he%20said%2C%20now%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20leader%20of%20the%20free%20world.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ERhodes%20was%20not%20the%20first%20to%20bestow%20this%20title%20on%20Merkel.%20When%20%3Cem%3ETime%3C%2Fem%3E%20named%20her%20its%20Person%20of%20the%20Year%2C%20in%202015%2C%20it%20called%20her%20%E2%80%9CChancellor%20of%20the%20Free%20World%2C%E2%80%9D%20citing%20her%20decision%20to%20take%20in%20more%20than%20a%20million%20refugees.%20Merkel%E2%80%99s%20immigration%20policy%20infuriated%20Trump%2C%20and%20he%20seized%20on%20it%20to%20help%20define%20his%20candidacy%20for%20the%20White%20House.%20%E2%80%9CI%20told%20you%20%40TIME%20Magazine%20would%20never%20pick%20me%20as%20person%20of%20the%20year%2C%E2%80%9D%20Trump%20tweeted.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20picked%20person%20who%20is%20ruining%20Germany.%E2%80%9D%20He%20often%20brought%20the%20Chancellor%20up%20on%20the%20campaign%20trail%20in%202016%2C%20saying%20at%20a%20rally%20in%20March%2C%20%E2%80%9CWhat%20Merkel%20did%20to%20Germany%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20a%20sad%2C%20sad%20shame.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBefore%20the%20election%2C%20Henry%20Kissinger%20had%20visited%20Berlin%2C%20and%20he%20advised%20German%20officials%20to%20arrange%20a%20meeting%20with%20Jared%20Kushner%2C%20which%20they%20did%2C%20although%20the%20German%20policy%20%C3%A9lite%2C%20like%20the%20rest%20of%20the%20world%2C%20didn%E2%80%99t%20think%20Trump%20would%20win.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20were%20extremely%20poorly%20prepared%20for%20this%2C%E2%80%9D%20Wolfgang%20Ischinger%2C%20the%20former%20German%20Ambassador%20to%20the%20United%20States%2C%20who%20now%20heads%20the%20Munich%20Security%20Conference%2C%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CI%20think%20everybody%20has%20been%20in%20quite%20a%20state%20of%20shock.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAfter%20Trump%20was%20elected%2C%20other%20world%20leaders%20schemed%20to%20play%20golf%20with%20Trump%20or%20schmooze%20him%20at%20Trump%20Tower.%20Merkel%2C%20for%20her%20part%2C%20released%20a%20statement%2C%20at%20once%20congratulating%20the%20President-elect%20and%20subtly%20announcing%20their%20differences.%20It%20spoke%20of%20%E2%80%9Ccommon%20values%2C%E2%80%9D%20including%20%E2%80%9Cdemocracy%2C%20liberty%2C%20respect%20of%20the%20law%20and%20of%20human%20dignity.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522cartoon%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522cartoon%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fcartoon%25252F5c12cee8ef12204ae0c0605f%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c12cee8ef12204ae0c0605f%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c12cee8ef12204ae0c0605f%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cee8ef12204ae0c0605f%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20foreign-policy%20establishment%2C%20in%20both%20Washington%20and%20Berlin%2C%20told%20Merkel%20and%20her%20advisers%20that%20Trump%20was%20sometimes%20unpredictable%20and%20volatile%2C%20but%20not%20an%20existential%20threat.%20He%20was%20ignorant%2C%20but%20would%20be%20constrained%20by%20his%20staff.%20He%20didn%E2%80%99t%20really%20mean%20what%20he%20said.%20One%20veteran%20of%20Republican%20Administrations%20recommended%20%E2%80%9Cstrategic%20patience%2C%E2%80%9D%20telling%20a%20senior%20German%20diplomat%20to%20ignore%20the%20tweets%20and%20focus%20on%20policy.%20Other%20Europeans%20received%20similar%20advice%20and%20came%20to%20similar%20conclusions.%20Rob%20Malley%2C%20a%20senior%20Obama%20adviser%20on%20Europe%2C%20who%20now%20heads%20the%20International%20Crisis%20Group%2C%20said%2C%20of%20the%20French%2C%20%E2%80%9CTheir%20view%20was%20that%20you%20shouldn%E2%80%99t%20take%20irreversible%20steps%20as%20the%20result%20of%20a%20reversible%20Presidency.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EFrom%20the%20start%2C%20Merkel%20entertained%20no%20illusions%20that%20Trump%20could%20be%20easily%20managed.%20Still%2C%20she%20had%20surmounted%20serious%20differences%20with%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20two%20predecessors%2C%20George%C2%A0W.%20Bush%20and%20Obama%2C%20and%20became%20close%20partners%20with%20both.%20When%20Merkel%20took%20office%2C%20in%20late%202005%2C%20Germany%20had%20not%20moved%20past%20its%20antipathy%20for%20Bush%2C%20whose%20invasion%20of%20Iraq%20had%20opened%20a%20rift%20with%20her%20predecessor%2C%20Gerhard%20Schr%C3%B6der.%20But%20Merkel%20and%20Bush%20got%20along%2C%20and%20their%20unlikely%20friendship%20was%20captured%20for%20the%20cameras%20when%20Bush%20gave%20her%20a%20back%20rub%20at%20a%20G-8%20summit.%20With%20Obama%2C%20a%20decisive%20moment%20came%20in%202014%2C%20when%20Russia%20illegally%20annexed%20the%20Ukrainian%20territory%20of%20Crimea.%20Obama%20and%20Merkel%20worked%20together%20to%20form%20a%20coherent%20response%20to%20Putin%E2%80%99s%20aggression%2C%20imposing%20sanctions%20and%20demanding%20peace%20talks.%20By%202016%2C%20they%20spoke%20as%20often%20as%20once%20a%20week%20and%20had%20what%20advisers%20for%20both%20leaders%20told%20me%20was%20a%20genuine%20personal%20and%20intellectual%20connection.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ERussia%20figured%20heavily%20in%20the%20dinner%20conversation%20at%20the%20Adlon%3A%20Trump%20was%20threatening%20to%20abandon%20the%20Ukraine%20policy%20and%20embrace%20Putin.%20Obama%E2%80%99s%20lobbying%20that%20night%20to%20get%20Merkel%20to%20run%20for%20a%20fourth%20term%20was%2C%20I%E2%80%99ve%20been%20told%20by%20German%20sources%2C%20critical%20in%20her%20considerations.%20%E2%80%9CI%20think%20the%20Chancellor%20listened%20very%20carefully%20to%20what%20%5BObama%5D%20said%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20senior%20German%20official%20told%20me.%20As%20Rhodes%20recounts%20in%20his%20memoir%2C%20%E2%80%9CThe%20World%20as%20It%20Is%2C%E2%80%9D%20when%20Obama%20left%20the%20country%2C%20on%20November%2018th%2C%20he%20thought%20he%20saw%20a%20tear%20rolling%20down%20Merkel%E2%80%99s%20face%20as%20she%20said%20goodbye.%20Obama%20turned%20to%20Rhodes%20and%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CAngela%2C%20she%E2%80%99s%20all%20alone.%E2%80%9D%20Two%20days%20later%2C%20Merkel%20announced%20that%2C%20because%20of%20%E2%80%9Cinsecure%20times%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20was%20running%20again.%20However%2C%20she%20cautioned%20those%20who%20hoped%20that%20she%20would%20be%20a%20foil%20for%20Trump%20and%20the%20Trump-friendly%20forces%20throughout%20Europe%3A%20%E2%80%9CNo%20person%20alone%2C%20not%20even%20the%20most%20experienced%2C%20can%20turn%20things%20to%20good%20in%20Germany%2C%20Europe%2C%20and%20the%20world%2C%20especially%20not%20a%20Chancellor%20of%20the%20Federal%20Republic%20of%20Germany.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","On November 16, 2016, eight days after Trump was elected, Barack Obama flew to Berlin to meet with Merkel; it was the last foreign trip of his Presidency. Obama and Merkel had not started out as good friends, but they had become as close as two public figures could be. Over dinner in the Adlon Hotel, they discussed the shocking events of the previous few months, particularly Great Britain’s referendum to leave the European Union and Trump’s victory running on the slogan “America First.” Through the windows of their private dining room, Merkel and Obama could see the floodlit Brandenburg Gate, the symbol of a reunified Berlin."],["p","Merkel, who was nearing the end of her third term, confided that she reluctantly felt that she had to run again, in order to be a buffer against Trump, Brexit, and the surge of right-wing populism throughout Europe. Obama urged her to do so. “Obama was obsessed with the fate of Europe during his last year in office,” Charles Kupchan, who served as Obama’s top National Security Council adviser on European affairs and accompanied him on the trip, told me. After the election, the situation seemed even more urgent. “His view was that Merkel was needed to keep Europe together,” Kupchan said. “He was afraid that, without Merkel, Humpty Dumpty was going to fall off the wall.”"],["p","The dinner was emotional. Obama later told Benjamin Rhodes, his deputy national-security adviser, that he had said to Merkel that the Trump Presidency would be like a storm. Obama told her to just “try to find some high ground,” and hold on to it, Rhodes recalled to me. By the time they said good night, three hours later, it was the longest that Obama had been alone with another world leader in his eight years in office. In an adjoining room, advisers to Merkel and Obama were concluding their own dinner. Rhodes offered a rueful toast: To Angela Merkel, he said, now “the leader of the free world.”"],["p","Rhodes was not the first to bestow this title on Merkel. When ",["em","Time"]," named her its Person of the Year, in 2015, it called her “Chancellor of the Free World,” citing her decision to take in more than a million refugees. Merkel’s immigration policy infuriated Trump, and he seized on it to help define his candidacy for the White House. “I told you @TIME Magazine would never pick me as person of the year,” Trump tweeted. “They picked person who is ruining Germany.” He often brought the Chancellor up on the campaign trail in 2016, saying at a rally in March, “What Merkel did to Germany, it’s a sad, sad shame.”"],["p","Before the election, Henry Kissinger had visited Berlin, and he advised German officials to arrange a meeting with Jared Kushner, which they did, although the German policy élite, like the rest of the world, didn’t think Trump would win. “We were extremely poorly prepared for this,” Wolfgang Ischinger, the former German Ambassador to the United States, who now heads the Munich Security Conference, told me. “I think everybody has been in quite a state of shock.”"],["p","After Trump was elected, other world leaders schemed to play golf with Trump or schmooze him at Trump Tower. Merkel, for her part, released a statement, at once congratulating the President-elect and subtly announcing their differences. It spoke of “common values,” including “democracy, liberty, respect of the law and of human dignity.”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c12cee8ef12204ae0c0605f%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cee8ef12204ae0c0605f%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c12cee8ef12204ae0c0605f%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c12cee8ef12204ae0c0605f"}]],["p","The foreign-policy establishment, in both Washington and Berlin, told Merkel and her advisers that Trump was sometimes unpredictable and volatile, but not an existential threat. He was ignorant, but would be constrained by his staff. He didn’t really mean what he said. One veteran of Republican Administrations recommended “strategic patience,” telling a senior German diplomat to ignore the tweets and focus on policy. Other Europeans received similar advice and came to similar conclusions. Rob Malley, a senior Obama adviser on Europe, who now heads the International Crisis Group, said, of the French, “Their view was that you shouldn’t take irreversible steps as the result of a reversible Presidency.”"],["p","From the start, Merkel entertained no illusions that Trump could be easily managed. Still, she had surmounted serious differences with Trump’s two predecessors, George W. Bush and Obama, and became close partners with both. When Merkel took office, in late 2005, Germany had not moved past its antipathy for Bush, whose invasion of Iraq had opened a rift with her predecessor, Gerhard Schröder. But Merkel and Bush got along, and their unlikely friendship was captured for the cameras when Bush gave her a back rub at a G-8 summit. With Obama, a decisive moment came in 2014, when Russia illegally annexed the Ukrainian territory of Crimea. Obama and Merkel worked together to form a coherent response to Putin’s aggression, imposing sanctions and demanding peace talks. By 2016, they spoke as often as once a week and had what advisers for both leaders told me was a genuine personal and intellectual connection."],["p","Russia figured heavily in the dinner conversation at the Adlon: Trump was threatening to abandon the Ukraine policy and embrace Putin. Obama’s lobbying that night to get Merkel to run for a fourth term was, I’ve been told by German sources, critical in her considerations. “I think the Chancellor listened very carefully to what [Obama] said,” a senior German official told me. As Rhodes recounts in his memoir, “The World as It Is,” when Obama left the country, on November 18th, he thought he saw a tear rolling down Merkel’s face as she said goodbye. Obama turned to Rhodes and said, “Angela, she’s all alone.” Two days later, Merkel announced that, because of “insecure times,” she was running again. However, she cautioned those who hoped that she would be a foil for Trump and the Trump-friendly forces throughout Europe: “No person alone, not even the most experienced, can turn things to good in Germany, Europe, and the world, especially not a Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EA%20few%20days%20before%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20Inauguration%2C%20John%C2%A0B.%20Emerson%2C%20Obama%E2%80%99s%20Ambassador%20to%20Germany%2C%20met%20for%20the%20last%20time%20with%20Merkel%20in%20her%20glass-walled%20office%20on%20the%20seventh%20floor%20of%20the%20Chancellery%2C%20in%20Berlin.%20%E2%80%9CMy%20advice%20was%3A%20get%20to%20Washington%20as%20fast%20as%20possible%20and%20build%20a%20personal%20relationship%20with%20him%2C%20because%20that%E2%80%99s%20how%20Trump%20operates%2C%E2%80%9D%20Emerson%20recalled.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20March%2C%20Merkel%20flew%20to%20Washington%20for%20her%20first%20meeting%20with%20Trump.%20She%20%E2%80%9Chad%20never%20prepared%20longer%20or%20harder%20for%20an%20initial%20meeting%20with%20a%20head%20of%20government%20than%20for%20her%20first%20meeting%20with%20President%20Trump%2C%E2%80%9D%20one%20of%20her%20top%20national-security%20aides%20told%20a%20fellow-diplomat.%20Merkel%20studied%20a%201990%20%3Cem%3EPlayboy%3C%2Fem%3E%20interview%20with%20the%20future%20President%2C%20which%20has%20become%20something%20of%20a%20runic%20text%20for%20Trumpologists%20on%20both%20sides%20of%20the%20Atlantic.%20She%20also%20watched%20episodes%20of%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20NBC%20reality%20show%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Apprentice%2C%E2%80%9D%20read%20his%201987%20book%2C%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Art%20of%20the%20Deal%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20spoke%20with%20Canada%E2%80%99s%20Prime%20Minister%2C%20Justin%20Trudeau%2C%20who%20had%20recently%20met%20one-on-one%20with%20Trump.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20first%20Trump-Merkel%20encounter%20in%20the%20Oval%20Office%20began%20with%20almost%20comically%20awful%20optics%3A%20Merkel%20offered%20a%20ceremonial%20handshake%20for%20the%20cameras%2C%20which%20Trump%20seemed%20to%20rebuff.%20After%20the%20photographers%20left%20the%20room%2C%20Trump%20reportedly%20announced%2C%20%E2%80%9CAngela%2C%20you%20owe%20me%20one%20trillion%20dollars.%E2%80%9D%20(A%20White%20House%20spokesperson%20denied%20that%20Trump%20used%20that%20language%2C%20but%20acknowledged%20that%20he%20shared%20the%20sentiment%20with%20the%20Chancellor.)%20Steve%20Bannon%2C%20the%20hard-line%20nationalist%20who%20was%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20chief%20strategist%20at%20the%20time%2C%20had%20asked%20the%20National%20Security%20Council%20to%20come%20up%20with%20a%20number%20to%20dramatize%20how%20much%20more%20money%20would%20have%20gone%20to%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E%20since%202006%20if%20the%20allies%20had%20been%20spending%20two%20per%20cent%20of%20their%20G.D.P.%20on%20defense%2C%20according%20to%20Ivo%20Daalder%20and%20James%C2%A0M.%20Lindsay%E2%80%99s%20book%2C%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Empty%20Throne.%E2%80%9D%20This%20calculation%20ignored%20the%20fact%20that%20the%20two-per-cent%20goal%20isn%E2%80%99t%20supposed%20to%20take%20effect%20until%202024%2C%20never%20mind%20that%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ENATO%3C%2Fem%3E%20allies%20don%E2%80%99t%20%E2%80%9Cowe%E2%80%9D%20Trump%20anything.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EMerkel%20intended%20to%20talk%20about%20Putin%20and%20the%20threat%20posed%20by%20his%20dream%20of%20Russia%E2%80%99s%20retaking%20former%20Soviet%20territory.%20She%20brought%20with%20her%20a%20handout%20prepared%20for%20Trump%2C%20who%20she%20knew%20disdained%20lengthy%20briefing%20papers.%20It%20included%20a%20map%20that%20showed%20the%20borders%20of%20the%20Soviet%20bloc%20in%201982%2C%20overlaid%20with%20Putin%E2%80%99s%20current%20territorial%20ambitions.%20Trump%20was%20unmoved.%20Merkel%20later%20told%20others%20that%20he%20had%20interrupted%20her%20efforts%20to%20discuss%20Russia%20in%20order%20to%20boast%20about%20his%20poll%20ratings%20among%20Republican%20voters.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20President%20and%20the%20Chancellor%20are%20almost%20epically%20mismatched.%20Merkel%20is%20a%20trained%20scientist%2C%20who%20declined%20a%20teaching%20position%20because%20she%20refused%
