\u003c/g>\u003c/svg>"}}},{"body":["div",["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c104be4459b5106f3fced42%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c104be4459b5106f3fced42%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104be4459b5106f3fced42%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104be4459b5106f3fced42%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104be4459b5106f3fced42%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104be4459b5106f3fced42%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c104be4459b5106f3fced42%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c104be4459b5106f3fced42"}]]],["p",["strong",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Mind-Unraveled-Memoir-Kurt-Eichenwald/dp/0399593624"},"A Mind Unraveled"]],["em",", by Kurt Eichenwald (Ballantine)"],". This account of the author’s struggle with epileptic seizures as a young man merges elements of medical drama, anti-discrimination fable, and coming-of-age memoir. Eichenwald, an investigative journalist, uses official records, letters, diaries, and interviews with friends and family to reconstruct events beginning forty years ago. The result is both poignant and infuriating: a cavalcade of desperate loved ones, inept doctors, and college administrators who try to kick him out because of his seizures. Most vivid are the descriptions of near-fatal injuries and emotional ravages he sustained. Of awakening from a seizure, Eichenwald writes, “It was as if I had fallen from the sky, with no memory of where I had been or how I had returned.”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c104bf3c6b2757bf40d129d%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c104bf3c6b2757bf40d129d%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104bf3c6b2757bf40d129d%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104bf3c6b2757bf40d129d%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104bf3c6b2757bf40d129d%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104bf3c6b2757bf40d129d%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c104bf3c6b2757bf40d129d%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c104bf3c6b2757bf40d129d"}]]],["p",["strong",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Writer-Our-Time-Life-Berger/dp/1786637421"},"A Writer of Our Time"]],["em",", by Joshua Sperling (Verso)"],". The British writer and art critic John Berger, who died in 2017, is the subject of this dense but engaging intellectual biography. Tracing Berger’s creative evolution, the book analyzes highlights from his vast output—the influential 1972 BBC series “Ways of Seeing,” which he never considered a major work; the Booker Prize-winning novel “G.” (and his denunciation of the prize); stories inspired by the French peasants among whom he lived for decades—and situates them within his empathetic Marxism. And though, for Berger, “the defeat of political ideals was a kind of personal genesis,” Sperling notes, “he certainly never let go of his politics, which remained, until his death, a powerful source of self-belief.”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c104c04c5aa777fdb411e63%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c104c04c5aa777fdb411e63%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104c04c5aa777fdb411e63%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104c04c5aa777fdb411e63%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104c04c5aa777fdb411e63%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104c04c5aa777fdb411e63%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c104c04c5aa777fdb411e63%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c104c04c5aa777fdb411e63"}]]],["p",["strong",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Split-Tooth-Tanya-Tagaq/dp/0670070092"},"Split Tooth"]],["em",", by Tanya Tagaq (Viking)"],". This mystical novel draws on the author’s life to tell the story of a young girl growing up in Nunavut in the nineteen-seventies, in an Inuit community that has experienced “government relocation, the shift into capitalism, and the moulting of the Shaman Skin.” Her days are spent in fear—hiding from gatherings that turn drunken and violent, warding off bullies, suffering sexual abuse, and finding dangerous or mind-altering ways to distract herself from it all. In a magic-realist turn, she is raped one night by the northern lights and gives birth to twins—one benevolent, one malign. Tagaq’s surreal meld of poetry and prose transmutes the Arctic’s boundless beauty, intensity, and desolation into a wrenching contemporary mythology."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c104c136b4194149d9af9ca%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c104c136b4194149d9af9ca%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104c136b4194149d9af9ca%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104c136b4194149d9af9ca%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104c136b4194149d9af9ca%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104c136b4194149d9af9ca%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c104c136b4194149d9af9ca%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c104c136b4194149d9af9ca"}]]],["p",["strong",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Seventeen-Novel-Hideo-Yokoyama/dp/0374261245"},"Seventeen"]],["em",", by Hideo Yokoyama, translated from the Japanese by Louise Heal Kawai (MCD)"],". To honor a friend’s last wish, the protagonist of this novel, a veteran journalist named Yuuki, sets out to scale a formidable rock face in Gunma Prefecture, Japan, where, seventeen years earlier, a plane crash killed more than five hundred people. In Yuuki’s newsroom, the disaster sets a sense of mission and ambitions for a career-making scoop in conflict with old grudges and departmental feuds. Yokoyama moves his vivid characters through an adrenaline-filled, if somewhat male-dominated, narrative, offset by Yuuki’s more meditative reëxamination of his life, as he ruminates on public tragedy and private pain, haunted by the words of his friend: “I climb up to step down.”"]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59babd482af19b1403458545","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"59babd482af19b1403458545","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Books","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"books"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"Books","parent":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"books"},{"id":"5907ef77019dfc3494e9c911","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Books","parent":[],"photos":{},"slug":"books-tag"}]},"channel":"","contentSource":"magazine","contentTags":[],"contentType":"article","contributors":[],"dek":"","formatting":{},"hed":"Briefly \u003c/g>\u003c/svg>"}}},{"body":["div",["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EOn%20a%20recent%20morning%2C%20Elizabeth%20Chan%2C%20America%E2%80%99s%20most%20successful%2C%20and%20perhaps%20only%2C%20full-time%20Christmas-song%20singer-slash-composer%2C%20was%20waiting%20in%20a%20dingy%20back%20corridor%20of%20Macy%E2%80%99s%20to%20meet%20Santa.%20Ahead%20of%20her%20in%20line%2C%20children%20whined%20and%20shopping%20bags%20rustled.%20A%20tinny%20karaoke%20version%20of%20%E2%80%9CDeck%20the%20Halls%E2%80%9D%20piped%20through%20the%20department-store%20speakers.%20Chan%20groaned.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20really%20generic%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said%2C%20of%20the%20song.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBut%20Santa%20was%20Santa%2C%20and%20Chan%20thought%20it%20would%20be%20nice%20for%20her%20eighteen-month-old-daughter%2C%20Noelle%2C%20to%20meet%20him.%20%E2%80%9CEverybody%20has%20the%20luxury%20of%20dealing%20with%20Santa%20for%20only%20a%20month%2C%E2%80%9D%20Chan%20said.%20She%20wore%20a%20black%20knit%20cap%20and%20a%20burgundy%20coat%2C%20and%20pushed%20Noelle%20in%20a%20stroller.%20But%2C%20she%20said%2C%20in%20her%20household%20it%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9Ca%20year-round%20issue.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%202012%2C%20Chan%20quit%20her%20job%20as%20an%20executive%20at%20Cond%C3%A9%20Nast%20to%20pursue%20her%20dream%20of%20creating%20%E2%80%9Ca%20great%20Christmas%20standard%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94a%20song%20like%20%E2%80%9CWhite%20Christmas%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94that%20would%20be%20sung%20year%20after%20year%20for%20generations.%20There%20were%20obstacles%3A%20though%20Chan%20had%20a%20good%20voice%2C%20she%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20a%20professional%20songwriter.%20She%20and%20her%20husband%2C%20a%20designer%2C%20would%20have%20to%20go%20into%20their%20savings.%20But%20she%20was%20determined.%20%E2%80%9CChristmas%20music%20has%20a%20magical%20ability%20to%20transport%20you%20to%20your%20childhood%20or%20happier%20times%2C%E2%80%9D%20Chan%20said.%20%E2%80%9CAt%20least%2C%20for%20me%20it%20does.%E2%80%9D%20Growing%20up%20in%20Battery%20Park%20City%2C%20in%20a%20family%20of%20Chinese%20and%20Filipino%20immigrants%2C%20she%20loved%20the%20traditions%3A%20%E2%80%9CWriting%20a%20letter%20to%20Santa%2C%20being%20good.%E2%80%9D%20Each%20year%20on%20Christmas%20Eve%2C%20the%20family%20would%20gather%20at%20her%20uncle%E2%80%99s%20house%2C%20in%20New%20Jersey.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EFor%20nearly%20two%20years%2C%20Chan%20wrote%20a%20Christmas%20song%20a%20day.%20She%20recorded%20fifty%2C%20paying%20for%20studio%20time%20and%20musicians.%20She%20sent%20demos%20to%20music%20producers%20and%20to%20Kelly%20Clarkson%E2%80%99s%20then%20record%20label.%20No%20dice.%20Her%20savings%20dwindled%2C%20along%20with%20her%20family%E2%80%99s%20patience.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20were%2C%20like%2C%20%E2%80%98What%20are%20you%20doing%3F%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20Chan%20recalled.%20%E2%80%9C%C2%A0%E2%80%98Go%20get%20a%20real%20job.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EWhen%20Chan%20was%20on%20the%20verge%20of%20giving%20up%2C%20a%20colleague%20suggested%20that%20she%20put%20out%20the%20songs%20herself.%20A%20ten-thousand-dollar%20Kickstarter%20campaign%20later%2C%20she%20released%20an%20album%20called%20%E2%80%9CEveryday%20Holidays.%E2%80%9D%20The%20single%20%E2%80%9CFa%20La%20La%E2%80%9D%20landed%20on%20the%202013%20%3Cem%3EBillboard%3C%2Fem%3E%20chart%2C%20right%20between%20two%20songs%20by%20Clarkson.%20Chan%20has%20now%20released%20seven%20albums%20and%20had%20four%20%3Cem%3EBillboard%3C%2Fem%3E%20hits%2C%20including%20this%20year%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FBest-Gift-Ever-Elizabeth-Chan%2Fdp%2FB07HFKDCNM%5C%22%3EBest%20Gift%20Ever%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20song%20she%20wrote%20for%20her%20husband%20which%20reached%20the%20Top%20Ten%20earlier%20this%20month.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBrian%20Demay%2C%20the%20corporate%20program%20director%20for%20Cumulus%20Media%2C%20said%20that%20Chan%20is%20the%20only%20full-time%20Christmas%20singer-songwriter%20he%20knows%20of%2C%20and%20that%20he%20plays%20her%20music%20regularly%20on%20WRRM%2C%20in%20Cincinnati.%20%E2%80%9CMy%20parents%20raised%20me%20on%20Nat%20King%20Cole%2C%20Bing%20Crosby%2C%20Dean%20Martin%2C%20Tony%20Bennett%2C%20and%20the%20Harry%20Simeone%20Chorale%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CI%20would%20count%20Elizabeth%20among%20those.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAt%20Macy%E2%80%99s%2C%20the%20line%20shuffled%20past%20some%20abandoned%20shelving%20units.%20Noelle%20fidgeted.%20%E2%80%9CThis%20is%20the%20least%20Christmassy%20thing%20I%E2%80%99ve%20done%20this%20year%2C%E2%80%9D%20Chan%20said%2C%20peering%20behind%20a%20door%20to%20a%20staff%20locker%20room.%20%E2%80%9CDon%E2%80%99t%20open%20it%E2%80%94you%E2%80%99ll%20find%20a%20couple%20of%20unhappy%20elves%20on%20their%20smoke%20break.%E2%80%9D%20She%20talked%20about%20her%20songwriting%20process.%20Every%20year%2C%20from%20January%20to%20August%2C%20she%20churns%20out%20between%20fifty%20and%20a%20hundred%20Christmas%20songs%2C%20recording%20only%20the%20ones%20whose%20melodies%20she%20can%20still%20remember%20months%20later.%20They%20span%20multiple%20genres%2C%20from%20%E2%80%9CChristmas%20in%20the%20City%2C%E2%80%9D%20an%20earnest%20ballad%2C%20to%20%E2%80%9CVixen%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20naughty-girl%20pop%20number%20inspired%20by%20the%20reindeer%20name.%20(Sample%20lyric%3A%20%E2%80%9CDon%E2%80%99t%20get%20mad%20%E2%80%99cause%20you%20can%E2%80%99t%20play%20these%20reindeer%20games.%E2%80%9D)%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20totally%20eclectic%2C%20and%20that%E2%80%99s%20what%20makes%20it%20fun%20for%20me%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EMariah%20Carey%E2%80%99s%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FMerry-Christmas-Mariah-Carey%2Fdp%2FB000002A46%2Fref%3Dpd_lpo_sbs_15_img_0%3F_encoding%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bpsc%3D1%26amp%3BrefRID%3DYDSB5WH9NKQH5KN95721%5C%22%3E1994%20hit%3C%2Fa%3E%20%E2%80%9CAll%20I%20Want%20for%20Christmas%20Is%20You%E2%80%9D%20played%20in%20Macy%E2%80%99s.%20Chan%20is%20ambivalent%20about%20the%20song%2C%20which%20Carey%20crafted%20%E2%80%9Cto%20sound%20like%20it%20was%20from%2C%20like%2C%20the%20nineteen-fifties%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CA%20lot%20of%20artists%20try%20to%20replicate%20what%20they%20think%20Christmas%20%3Cem%3Eshould%3C%2Fem%3E%20sound%20like.%E2%80%9D%20Chan%20prefers%20to%20focus%20on%20her%20own%20life.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Ghost%20of%20Christmas%20Past%E2%80%9D%20is%20about%20missing%20her%20grandmother.%20(%E2%80%9CThe%20years%20go%20by%20so%20fast%C2%A0%2F%C2%A0I%20thought%20that%20it%20would%20last.%E2%80%9D)%20Recently%2C%20she%E2%80%99s%20been%20rediscovering%20the%20holiday%20through%20her%20daughter%E2%80%99s%20eyes.%20%E2%80%9CShe%E2%80%99s%20my%20enzyme%2C%E2%80%9D%20Chan%20said%2C%20and%20asked%20Noelle%2C%20%E2%80%9CCan%20you%20say%20%E2%80%98enzyme%E2%80%99%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20line%20moved%20again.%20%E2%80%9CRudolph%20the%20Red-Nosed%20Reindeer%E2%80%9D%3A%20Yay%20or%20nay%3F%20%E2%80%9CYay%2C%E2%80%9D%20Chan%20said.%20%E2%80%9CBut%20I%20know%20it%E2%80%99s%20very%20controversial%20now.%20People%20are%20saying%20that%20it%E2%80%99s%20a%20song%20about%20bullying.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAfter%20an%20hour%2C%20Chan%20and%20Noelle%20entered%20Santaland%20at%20last.%20An%20elf%20waved%20from%20a%20candy-cane%20visitor%E2%80%99s%20kiosk.%20Toy%20bears%20and%20ducks%20frolicked%20in%20winter%20scenes.%20A%20train%20display%20whirred%20below%20a%20twinkling%20night%20sky.%20Noelle%20beamed.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ETchaikovsky%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9CDance%20of%20the%20Sugar%20Plum%20Fairy%E2%80%9D%20was%20playing.%20Chan%20approved.%20She%20hires%20violinists%20and%20cellists%20for%20many%20of%20her%20songs.%20%E2%80%9CThere%E2%80%99s%20something%20about%20orchestral%20music%20that%20just%20evokes%20emotion%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20elves%20whisked%20Noelle%20and%20Chan%20into%20Santa%E2%80%99s%20room%2C%20where%20he%20gamely%20tried%20to%20engage%20the%20now%20stone-faced%20toddler%20as%20an%20elf%20snapped%20photos.%20Then%20it%20was%20over.%20Mother%20and%20daughter%20were%20ushered%20into%20another%20line%20to%20purchase%20the%20pictures.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EExiting%2C%20Chan%20reflected%20on%20the%20experience%2C%20which%20she%20described%20as%20%E2%80%9Cweird%E2%80%9D%20and%20%E2%80%9Ccounter%20to%20my%20philosophy%20on%20Christmas.%E2%80%9D%20She%20was%20already%20working%20on%20a%20new%20song%3A%20%E2%80%9CIn%20my%20mind%2C%20the%20verse%20is%2C%20you%20know%2C%20%E2%80%98Christmas%20is%20not%20in%20the%20store.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","On a recent morning, Elizabeth Chan, America’s most successful, and perhaps only, full-time Christmas-song singer-slash-composer, was waiting in a dingy back corridor of Macy’s to meet Santa. Ahead of her in line, children whined and shopping bags rustled. A tinny karaoke version of “Deck the Halls” piped through the department-store speakers. Chan groaned. “It’s really generic,” she said, of the song."],["p","But Santa was Santa, and Chan thought it would be nice for her eighteen-month-old-daughter, Noelle, to meet him. “Everybody has the luxury of dealing with Santa for only a month,” Chan said. She wore a black knit cap and a burgundy coat, and pushed Noelle in a stroller. But, she said, in her household it’s “a year-round issue.”"],["p","In 2012, Chan quit her job as an executive at Condé Nast to pursue her dream of creating “a great Christmas standard”—a song like “White Christmas”—that would be sung year after year for generations. There were obstacles: though Chan had a good voice, she wasn’t a professional songwriter. She and her husband, a designer, would have to go into their savings. But she was determined. “Christmas music has a magical ability to transport you to your childhood or happier times,” Chan said. “At least, for me it does.” Growing up in Battery Park City, in a family of Chinese and Filipino immigrants, she loved the traditions: “Writing a letter to Santa, being good.” Each year on Christmas Eve, the family would gather at her uncle’s house, in New Jersey."],["p","For nearly two years, Chan wrote a Christmas song a day. She recorded fifty, paying for studio time and musicians. She sent demos to music producers and to Kelly Clarkson’s then record label. No dice. Her savings dwindled, along with her family’s patience. “They were, like, ‘What are you doing?’ ” Chan recalled. “ ‘Go get a real job.’ ”"],["p","When Chan was on the verge of giving up, a colleague suggested that she put out the songs herself. A ten-thousand-dollar Kickstarter campaign later, she released an album called “Everyday Holidays.” The single “Fa La La” landed on the 2013 ",["em","Billboard"]," chart, right between two songs by Clarkson. Chan has now released seven albums and had four ",["em","Billboard"]," hits, including this year’s “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Best-Gift-Ever-Elizabeth-Chan/dp/B07HFKDCNM"},"Best Gift Ever"],",” a song she wrote for her husband which reached the Top Ten earlier this month."],["p","Brian Demay, the corporate program director for Cumulus Media, said that Chan is the only full-time Christmas singer-songwriter he knows of, and that he plays her music regularly on WRRM, in Cincinnati. “My parents raised me on Nat King Cole, Bing Crosby, Dean Martin, Tony Bennett, and the Harry Simeone Chorale,” he said. “I would count Elizabeth among those.”"],["p","At Macy’s, the line shuffled past some abandoned shelving units. Noelle fidgeted. “This is the least Christmassy thing I’ve done this year,” Chan said, peering behind a door to a staff locker room. “Don’t open it—you’ll find a couple of unhappy elves on their smoke break.” She talked about her songwriting process. Every year, from January to August, she churns out between fifty and a hundred Christmas songs, recording only the ones whose melodies she can still remember months later. They span multiple genres, from “Christmas in the City,” an earnest ballad, to “Vixen,” a naughty-girl pop number inspired by the reindeer name. (Sample lyric: “Don’t get mad ’cause you can’t play these reindeer games.”) “It’s totally eclectic, and that’s what makes it fun for me,” she said."],["p","Mariah Carey’s ",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Merry-Christmas-Mariah-Carey/dp/B000002A46/ref=pd_lpo_sbs_15_img_0?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=YDSB5WH9NKQH5KN95721"},"1994 hit"]," “All I Want for Christmas Is You” played in Macy’s. Chan is ambivalent about the song, which Carey crafted “to sound like it was from, like, the nineteen-fifties,” she said. “A lot of artists try to replicate what they think Christmas ",["em","should"]," sound like.” Chan prefers to focus on her own life. “The Ghost of Christmas Past” is about missing her grandmother. (“The years go by so fast / I thought that it would last.”) Recently, she’s been rediscovering the holiday through her daughter’s eyes. “She’s my enzyme,” Chan said, and asked Noelle, “Can you say ‘enzyme’?”"],["p","The line moved again. “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer”: Yay or nay? “Yay,” Chan said. “But I know it’s very controversial now. People are saying that it’s a song about bullying.”"],["p","After an hour, Chan and Noelle entered Santaland at last. An elf waved from a candy-cane visitor’s kiosk. Toy bears and ducks frolicked in winter scenes. A train display whirred below a twinkling night sky. Noelle beamed."],["p","Tchaikovsky’s “Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy” was playing. Chan approved. She hires violinists and cellists for many of her songs. “There’s something about orchestral music that just evokes emotion,” she said."],["p","The elves whisked Noelle and Chan into Santa’s room, where he gamely tried to engage the now stone-faced toddler as an elf snapped photos. Then it was over. Mother and daughter were ushered into another line to purchase the pictures."],["p","Exiting, Chan reflected on the experience, which she described as “weird” and “counter to my philosophy on Christmas.” She was already working on a new song: “In my mind, the verse is, you know, ‘Christmas is not in the store.’ ” ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c862bfcc72cd92d053f","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Elizabeth \u003c/g>\u003c/svg>"}}},{"body":["div",["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22iframe%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522iframe%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522https%253A%252F%252Fwww.wnyc.org%252Fwidgets%252Fondemand_player%252Fthenewyorker%252F%2523file%253Dhttps%253A%252F%252Fdownloads.newyorker.com%252Fmp3%252F181224_gaitskill_audio.mp3%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522100%2525%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%252260%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253E%253Cem%253E%253Cstrong%253EAudio%253A%253C%252Fstrong%253E%253C%252Fem%253E%2520Mary%2520Gaitskill%2520reads.%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"iframe","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22iframe%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wnyc.org%2Fwidgets%2Fondemand_player%2Fthenewyorker%2F%23file%3Dhttps%3A%2F%2Fdownloads.newyorker.com%2Fmp3%2F181224_gaitskill_audio.mp3%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22100%25%22%2C%22height%22%3A%2260%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%3Cp%3E%3Cem%3E%3Cstrong%3EAudio%3A%3C%2Fstrong%3E%3C%2Fem%3E%20Mary%20Gaitskill%20reads.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""}]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3ECarol%20had%20just%20come%20to%20her%20new%20sort-of%20home%20in%20a%20town%20called%20Rhinehorn.%20She%20had%20driven%20five%20hours%20from%20her%20former%20home%20in%20Duchess%20County%20and%20arrived%20with%20stunned%2C%20hunted%20relief.%20She%20had%20come%20to%20Rhinehorn%20for%20a%20six-month%20job%20as%20an%20admin%20assistant%20in%20the%20dean%20of%20students%E2%80%99%20office%20at%20a%20private%20college.%20The%20job%20had%20come%20through%20a%20Facebook%20friend%2C%20an%20acquaintance%20from%20high%20school%2C%20who%20was%20also%20friends%20with%20the%20admin%20assistant%20for%20whom%20Carol%20was%20standing%20in%3B%20thanks%20to%20their%20vague%20connection%2C% ight%2C%20the%20red%20flowers%2C%20the%20decorative%20stone%20animals%2C%20and%20the%20twirling%20little%20ornament%20in%20the%20shape%20of%20a%20star%20looked%20eerie%20and%20foreign%20in%20the%20dawn%20light.%20She%20had%20not%20seen%20the%20robed%20woman%20before%20or%20the%20dog%2C%20which%20ran%20at%20her%2C%20barking%2C%20when%20she%20started%20the%20car.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EShe%20got%20breakfast%20by%20herself%20at%20a%20diner%2C%20and%20thought%20about%20going%20by%20the%20motel%20to%20say%20goodbye%20to%20the%20%E2%80%9Cboyfriend.%E2%80%9D%20Instead%2C%20she%20picked%20up%20her%20cat%20at%20the%20vet%20(she%20had%20boarded%20the%20animal%20overnight)%20and%20drove%20to%20her%20new%20home%3A%20a%20sunny%20two-room%20annex%20attached%20to%20a%20red%20Dutch%20Colonial%20on%20a%20residential%20street%20without%20a%20sidewalk.%20The%20furniture%20(saggy%20couch%2C%20weird%20end%20tables%2C%20mismatched%20dining%20set)%20looked%20as%20though%20it%20had%20come%20from%20a%20Salvation%20Army%20showroom%20display%2C%20and%2C%20as%20she%20learned%20later%2C%20it%20had.%20Her%20bedroom%20looked%20out%20on%20a%20lot%20overgrown%20with%20wildflowers%3B%20her%20sitting%20room%20faced%20the%20neighbors%E2%80%99%20yard%2C%20which%20had%20strong%2C%20confident%20grass%20and%20a%20hammock%20full%20of%20children%E2%80%99s%20toys.%20Carol%E2%80%99s%20yard%20was%20mostly%20weeds%2C%20but%20there%20was%20on%20its%20periphery%20a%20beautiful%20tree%20with%20spreading%2C%20somehow%20joyous%20branches%3B%20she%20looked%20out%20on%20it%20and%20felt%20dim%2C%20seeping%20gratitude%20for%20its%20beauty.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ECarol%20was%20fifty-seven%20but%20she%20did%20not%20feel%20that%20old.%20She%20did%20not%20feel%20any%20age.%20She%20might%20have%20liked%20that%20ambiguity.%20But%20instead%20it%20was%20frightening%2C%20as%20if%20she%20had%20found%20herself%20on%20the%20wrong%20side%20of%20what%20had%20suddenly%20been%20revealed%20as%20the%20iron%20law%20of%20the%20world.%20This%20feeling%20was%20made%20worse%20by%20the%20realization%20that%20no%20one%20occupied%20the%20Dutch%20Colonial%20she%20was%20annexed%20to%3B%20being%20attached%20to%20an%20empty%20house%20felt%20like%20being%20attached%20to%20the%20ghost%20of%20her%20marriage%2C%20unable%20to%20live%20in%20it%20or%20to%20get%20away%20from%20it.%20On%20her%20third%20night%20in%20Rhinehorn%2C%20she%20went%20out%20at%20dusk%20and%2C%20not%20even%20caring%20if%20anyone%20saw%20her%2C%20pressed%20her%20face%20against%20the%20windows%20of%20the%20empty%20house%20and%20peered%20in.%20The%20place%20was%20not%20only%20much%20bigger%20than%20hers%2C%20the%20furniture%20in%20it%20was%20nicer%20than%20what%20she%20had.%20It%20was%20generic%20and%20bland%2C%20but%20at%20least%20it%20all%20matched%20and%20the%20couch%20probably%20didn%E2%80%99t%20sag%20when%20sat%20on.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EShe%20looked%20on%20the%20bright%20side.%20Her%20rent%20was%20next%20to%20nothing%2C%20which%20meant%20that%20she%20could%20pay%20down%20the%20ruinous%20debt%20she%20had%20accrued%20by%20trying%20to%20support%20Lloyd%E2%80%99s%20life-coach%20business%20as%20it%20had%20gone%20bust.%20The%20bed%20was%20comfortable%2C%20the%20TV%20was%20huge%2C%20the%20cat%20loved%20the%20yard%2C%20and%20Carol%20enjoyed%20watching%20the%20little%20creature%20timidly%20patrol%20its%20border.%20The%20job%20was%20O.K.%20(routing%20students%20through%20the%20correct%20channels%2C%20making%20keys%2C%20paperwork%2C%20constant%20screen%20time)%3B%20it%20was%20essentially%20work%20that%20she%20could%20forget%20as%20soon%20as%20she%20returned%20to%20her%20temporary%20home%20in%20the%20evening.%20Although%20Carol%20had%20a%20master%E2%80%99s%20degree%20in%20English%20and%20had%20once%20wanted%20to%20teach%2C%20she%20had%20long%20ago%20accepted%20this%20kind%20of%20work%20and%20was%20good%20at%20it.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThere%20was%20peace%20in%20this%3A%20she%20watched%20the%20news%20while%20exercising%20with%20a%20hula%20hoop%20for%20twenty%20minutes%2C%20ate%2C%20played%20with%20the%20cat%2C%20then%20walked%20around%20the%20neighborhood%20feeling%20her%20body%20shifting%20tectonically%20under%20her%20brain.%20Despite%20her%20age%2C%20she%20was%20still%20bleeding%20almost%20monthly%2C%20and%20this%20anomaly%20was%20a%20strain%20on%20the%20organization%20of%20her%20self.%20The%20sky%20of%20her%20psyche%20had%20gone%20Technicolor%20with%20hormonal%20discharge%3B%20it%20was%20full%20of%20huge%2C%20luridly%20burning%20stars.%20The%20most%20pacific%20grasses%20and%20meadows%20of%20her%20inner%20being%20were%20subject%20to%20sudden%20sinkholes%20full%20of%20bone%20and%20bilious%20tissue%2C%20spilling%20over%20with%20the%20multifarious%20faces%2C%20the%20intimate%20crimes%20and%20errors%20of%20her%20life%2C%20all%20pulling%20her%20in%20the%20opposite%20direction%20as%20she%20walked%20forward%2C%20saying%20hi%20to%20people%20and%20their%20dogs%2C%20mostly%20middle-aged%20except%20for%20one%20bent%20but%20fast-moving%20old%20lady%20with%20an%20alert%20husky.%20She%20passed%20yards%20where%20children%20played%20while%20adults%20dug%20around%20in%20border%20gardens%20or%20sat%20on%20porches%20exuding%20hard-won%20security.%20She%20never%20spoke%20to%20them%20and%20they%20did%20not%20speak%20to%20her%E2%80%94until%20the%20smiling%20husband%20across%20the%20street%20from%20her%20paused%20while%20weeding%20his%20powerful%20grass%2C%20rose%20out%20of%20his%20squat%2C%20and%20invited%20her%20to%20come%20for%20dinner%20sometime.%20She%20glanced%20at%20the%20house%3B%20it%20was%20white%20with%20red%20shutters%20and%20there%20was%20a%20clay%20relief%20of%20a%20flying%20bird%20hung%20next%20to%20the%20door.%20She%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CThat%20would%20be%20nice.%E2%80%9D%20Her%20neighbor%20introduced%20himself%20as%20Duane%3B%20he%20said%20that%20his%20wife%2C%20Dana%2C%20was%20in%20H.R.%20and%20was%20friends%20with%20the%20woman%20Carol%20had%20replaced.%20%E2%80%9CShe%E2%80%99s%20on%20maternity%20leave%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20needlessly%20explained.%20%E2%80%9CShe%E2%80%99s%20with%20her%20husband%2C%20who%E2%80%99s%20sixty%20miles%20away.%20They%20work%20in%20separate%20towns%20most%20of%20the%20time.%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9COh%2C%E2%80%9D%20Carol%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThat%20sounds%20tough.%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9CIt%20is%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CI%20think%20somebody%E2%80%99s%20going%20to%20have%20to%20change%20jobs.%E2%80%9D%20His%20two%20little%20girls%20swung%20crazily%20in%20the%20hammock%2C%20kicking%20at%20each%20other%20and%20crying%2C%20%E2%80%9CWho%20%3Cem%3Ewho!%3C%2Fem%3E%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20Or%20something%20like%20it.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EShe%20went%20back%20home%2C%20drank%20wine%20from%20a%20juice%20glass%2C%20looked%20at%20TV%2C%20answered%20e-mails%2C%20watched%20animal%20videos%20and%20horrible%20accident%2Fcrime%20videos%2C%20some%20porn.%20Strictly%20speaking%2C%20she%20didn%E2%80%99t%20watch%20porn%2C%20but%20she%20had%20got%20interested%20in%20a%20magazine%20think%20piece%20about%20torture%20porn.%20The%20cover%20image%20was%20striking%20and%20even%20artistic%2C%20and%20the%20article%20described%20a%20particular%20film%20that%20had%20been%20made%20by%20a%20former%20prostitute%20about%20her%20experience%20of%20being%20tortured%20by%20a%20psychotic%20john%3B%20she%20said%20that%20making%20the%20film%20and%20performing%20in%20it%20had%20been%20a%20healing%20experience.%20Carol%20could%20not%20resist%3A%20she%20looked%20up%20the%20trailer%20for%20the%20film%20online%20and%20saw%20that%2C%20yes%2C%20it%20was%20about%20torture.%20The%20woman%20was%20shaved%2C%20beaten%2C%20starved%2C%20made%20to%20wear%20a%20leather%20mask%2C%20and%20then%20taken%20to%20the%20desert%2C%20where%20she%20was%20forced%20to%20run%20until%20she%20collapsed.%20Carol%20described%20it%20to%20her%20younger%20friend%20Meg%20on%20the%20phone.%20%E2%80%9CDo%20you%20believe%20that%3F%E2%80%9D%20Meg%20said.%20%E2%80%9CDo%20you%20believe%20she%20really%20made%20the%20movie%20because%20it%20would%20be%20%3Cem%3Ehealing%3C%2Fem%3E%3F%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9CNo%2C%E2%80%9D%20Carol%20said.%20%E2%80%9CWell%2C%20I%20don%E2%80%99t%20know.%20Maybe.%20Maybe%20it%20was%20healing%20for%20her.%E2%80%9D%20They%20talked%20about%20Meg%E2%80%99s%20fianc%C3%A9%20for%20a%20while%2C%20then%20Carol%20got%20ready%20for%20bed%2C%20loved%20up%20the%20cat%2C%20and%20had%20low-key%20sex%20thoughts%20about%20the%20guy%20she%E2%80%99d%20run%20away%20from%20the%20night%20before%20coming%20to%20Rhinehorn.%20Her%20mind%20eased%20into%20sleep%2C%20calmly%20sorting%20images%20of%20what%20she%E2%80%99d%20done%20that%20day%E2%80%94then%20woke%20with%20a%20jerk%2C%20as%20though%20she%E2%80%99d%20hit%20the%20brake%20on%20a%20car%20driving%20in%20deep%20mud%2C%20wildly%20swerving.%20She%20concentrated%20on%20the%20cat%E2%80%99s%20little%20body%20next%20to%20her%20and%20thought%2C%20%3Cem%3ESteady%3C%2Fem%3E.%20Then%20she%20was%20in%20the%20jaws%20of%20a%20shark%2C%20screaming%20and%20fighting%20as%20it%20yanked%20her%20back%20and%20forth%2C%20down%20into%20churning%20water.%20%3Cem%3EHold%20steady%3C%2Fem%3E.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Carol had just come to her new sort-of home in a town called Rhinehorn. She had driven five hours from her former home in Duchess County and arrived with stunned, hunted relief. She had come to Rhinehorn for a six-month job as an admin assistant in the dean of students’ office at a private college. The job had come through a Facebook friend, an acquaintance from high school, who was also friends with the admin assistant for whom Carol was standing in; thanks to their vague connection, this total stranger had wrangled furnished accommodations for Carol on the ground that she was recently divorced and “struggling.” Technically, Carol was not divorced, but, yes, she was struggling, and so, except for what she could fit in her car, she had put all her stuff (the stuff from the house she’d shared with her husband, Lloyd) in a cheap storage unit on a concrete lot. She had broken up with Lloyd six months before accepting the job in Rhinehorn. The night before driving to Rhinehorn, she’d also broken up with a “boyfriend” she’d been seeing; more exactly, she’d run out of their motel room after he’d become enraged at her for singing “Ain’t Talkin’ ’Bout Love” in the shower and accused her of wanting to sodomize him."],["p","Because a popular and picaresque county fair was in progress, all the hotels were booked and she’d had to sleep in her car, which she could at least park on a quiet street. She was woken at dawn by a high, excited voice calling, “Come on! Come on, you little weirdo!” The voice was ecstatic with love, and Carol sat up heart first; a lady in a pink bathrobe on the front steps of her porch beckoned to a young dog that was wagging its tail at the edge of the woman’s yard. It was a neighborhood where Carol and her husband used to take walks, and, though she knew this yard by sight, the red flowers, the decorative stone animals, and the twirling little ornament in the shape of a star looked eerie and foreign in the dawn light. She had not seen the robed woman before or the dog, which ran at her, barking, when she started the car."],["p","She got breakfast by herself at a diner, and thought about going by the motel to say goodbye to the “boyfriend.” Instead, she picked up her cat at the vet (she had boarded the animal overnight) and drove to her new home: a sunny two-room annex attached to a red Dutch Colonial on a residential street without a sidewalk. The furniture (saggy couch, weird end tables, mismatched dining set) looked as though it had come from a Salvation Army showroom display, and, as she learned later, it had. Her bedroom looked out on a lot overgrown with wildflowers; her sitting room faced the neighbors’ yard, which had strong, confident grass and a hammock full of children’s toys. Carol’s yard was mostly weeds, but there was on its periphery a beautiful tree with spreading, somehow joyous branches; she looked out on it and felt dim, seeping gratitude for its beauty."],["p","Carol was fifty-seven but she did not feel that old. She did not feel any age. She might have liked that ambiguity. But instead it was frightening, as if she had found herself on the wrong side of what had suddenly been revealed as the iron law of the world. This feeling was made worse by the realization that no one occupied the Dutch Colonial she was annexed to; being attached to an empty house felt like being attached to the ghost of her marriage, unable to live in it or to get away from it. On her third night in Rhinehorn, she went out at dusk and, not even caring if anyone saw her, pressed her face against the windows of the empty house and peered in. The place was not only much bigger than hers, the furniture in it was nicer than what she had. It was generic and bland, but at least it all matched and the couch probably didn’t sag when sat on."],["p","She looked on the bright side. Her rent was next to nothing, which meant that she could pay down the ruinous debt she had accrued by trying to support Lloyd’s life-coach business as it had gone bust. The bed was comfortable, the TV was huge, the cat loved the yard, and Carol enjoyed watching the little creature timidly patrol its border. The job was O.K. (routing students through the correct channels, making keys, paperwork, constant screen time); it was essentially work that she could forget as soon as she returned to her temporary home in the evening. Although Carol had a master’s degree in English and had once wanted to teach, she had long ago accepted this kind of work and was good at it."],["p","There was peace in this: she watched the news while exercising with a hula hoop for twenty minutes, ate, played with the cat, then walked around the neighborhood feeling her body shifting tectonically under her brain. Despite her age, she was still bleeding almost monthly, and this anomaly was a strain on the organization of her self. The sky of her psyche had gone Technicolor with hormonal discharge; it was full of huge, luridly burning stars. The most pacific grasses and meadows of her inner being were subject to sudden sinkholes full of bone and bilious tissue, spilling over with the multifarious faces, the intimate crimes and errors of her life, all pulling her in the opposite direction as she walked forward, saying hi to people and their dogs, mostly middle-aged except for one bent but fast-moving old lady with an alert husky. She passed yards where children played while adults dug around in border gardens or sat on porches exuding hard-won security. She never spoke to them and they did not speak to her—until the smiling husband across the street from her paused while weeding his powerful grass, rose out of his squat, and invited her to come for dinner sometime. She glanced at the house; it was white with red shutters and there was a clay relief of a flying bird hung next to the door. She said, “That would be nice.” Her neighbor introduced himself as Duane; he said that his wife, Dana, was in H.R. and was friends with the woman Carol had replaced. “She’s on maternity leave,” he needlessly explained. “She’s with her husband, who’s sixty miles away. They work in separate towns most of the time.” “Oh,” Carol said. “That sounds tough.” “It is,” he said. “I think somebody’s going to have to change jobs.” His two little girls swung crazily in the hammock, kicking at each other and crying, “Who ",["em","who!"]," ” Or something like it."],["p","She went back home, drank wine from a juice glass, looked at TV, answered e-mails, watched animal videos and horrible accident/crime videos, some porn. Strictly speaking, she didn’t watch porn, but she had got interested in a magazine think piece about torture porn. The cover image was striking and even artistic, and the article described a particular film that had been made by a former prostitute about her experience of being tortured by a psychotic john; she said that making the film and performing in it had been a healing experience. Carol could not resist: she looked up the trailer for the film online and saw that, yes, it was about torture. The woman was shaved, beaten, starved, made to wear a leather mask, and then taken to the desert, where she was forced to run until she collapsed. Carol described it to her younger friend Meg on the phone. “Do you believe that?” Meg said. “Do you believe she really made the movie because it would be ",["em","healing"],"?” “No,” Carol said. “Well, I don’t know. Maybe. Maybe it was healing for her.” They talked about Meg’s fiancé for a while, then Carol got ready for bed, loved up the cat, and had low-key sex thoughts about the guy she’d run away from the night before coming to Rhinehorn. Her mind eased into sleep, calmly sorting images of what she’d done that day—then woke with a jerk, as though she’d hit the brake on a car driving in deep mud, wildly swerving. She concentrated on the cat’s little body next to her and thought, ",["em","Steady"],". Then she was in the jaws of a shark, screaming and fighting as it yanked her back and forth, down into churning water. ",["em","Hold steady"],"."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20people%20at%20the%20dean%E2%80%99s%20office%20were%20extremely%20thoughtful%20and%20(because%20they%20assumed%20her%20husband%20had%20ditched%20her%3F)%20almost%20too%20nice.%20One%20of%20them%20was%20at%20least%20able%20to%20tell%20her%20something%20about%20the%20Dutch%20Colonial%3A%20it%20was%20normally%20used%20for%20a%20visiting-professor%20position%20but%20this%20year%20the%20invited%20visitor%20had%20cancelled%20at%20the%20last%20minute%20and%20the%20backup%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20come%20until%20January.%20%E2%80%9CI%20didn%E2%80%99t%20even%20know%20there%20was%20an%20outbuilding%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20woman%20said.%20%E2%80%9CI%20mean%20an%20annex.%20I%20wonder%20what%20they%20put%20that%20on%20for%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EEventually%2C%20Carol%20had%20dinner%20with%20Dana%20and%20Duane%2C%20the%20people%20across%20the%20street.%20Their%20home%20was%20well%20kept%20but%20bloomed%20in%20the%20corners%20with%20complex%20personal%20detritus%2C%20kindhearted%20art%20and%20a%20raucous%20heap%20of%20toys%20extruding%20stuffed-animal%20legs%20and%20the%20heads%20of%20dolls%20with%20food-coloring%20hair.%20Music%20played%20from%20a%20laptop%E2%80%94a%20soft%20and%20shining%20voice%20sang%20%E2%80%9CSomeone%20to%20Watch%20Over%20Me.%E2%80%9D%20The%20younger%20girl%2C%20Ada%2C%20waltzed%20to%20the%20sound%20of%20it%20while%20the%20older%20one%2C%20Estella%2C%20sighed%20with%20impatience%20at%20its%20silky%20slowness.%20Carol%20handed%20Dana%20the%20caponata%20dish%20she%E2%80%99d%20brought%2C%20an%20eggplant%20salad%20with%20four%20tablespoons%20of%20brown%20sugar%20even%20though%20the%20recipe%20called%20for%20two%E2%80%94because%20who%20could%20expect%20kids%20to%20eat%20eggplant%20otherwise%3F%20%E2%80%9COh%2C%20it%20looks%20great%2C%E2%80%9D%20Dana%20said%20and%20put%20it%20on%20the%20table%20along%20with%20the%20beef-rib%20dinner%20she%E2%80%99d%2 e%20went%20grave%20at%20the%20insult%20and%20she%20lowered%20her%20eyes.%20She%20seemed%20the%20happier%20of%20the%20girls%2C%20shiny-eyed%2C%20vibrant%2C%20and%20sun-brown%2C%20with%20deeply%20colored%20lips.%20Estella%20was%20paler%20and%20more%20recessive%2C%20already%20critical%20and%20disappointed.%20But%20she%20was%20a%20nice%20kid.%20She%20didn%E2%80%99t%20want%20to%20eat%20the%20caponata%2C%20but%20when%20she%20tasted%20how%20sweet%20it%20was%20she%20gave%20Carol%20a%20look%20of%20pleasure%20that%20landed%20very%20gently.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIt%20was%20a%20nice%20evening%20that%20somehow%20had%20the%20effect%20of%20making%20Carol%20feel%20shy%20about%20seeing%20her%20neighbors%20again.%20Instead%20of%20walking%20in%20the%20evenings%2C%20she%20began%20to%20drive%20around%20the%20country%20surrounding%20Rhinehorn.%20This%20place%20was%20mysterious%20to%20her%3B%20there%20was%20a%20character%20to%20it%20that%20felt%20just%20outside%20her%20range%20of%20experience.%20The%20road%20into%20the%20farmland%20was%20a%20county%20road%2C%20sparsely%20lined%20with%20economically%20mismatched%20houses%E2%80%94beat-up%20boxes%20with%20meagre%20strips%20of%20yard%20were%20situated%20next%20to%20charming%20farmhouses%20set%20back%20amid%20leafy%20trees.%20Carol%20was%20mesmerized%20by%20the%20mixture%20of%20colors%20and%20textures%20flashing%20past%3A%20grasses%2C%20stone%20fences%2C%20an%20old%20wooden%20house%20stripped%20of%20paint%2C%20a%20bush%20unselfishly%20extending%20its%20bright-pink%20flowers%20against%20the%20wall%20of%20a%20dull-green%20house%2C%20making%20the%20drab%20color%20into%20a%20gorgeous%20celadon.%20There%20was%20a%20family%20she%20saw%20often%20outside%20a%20dirty-looking%20white%20house%2C%20hanging%20laundry%2C%20lounging%20on%20a%20torn%2C%20filthy%20couch%2C%20and%2C%20once%2C%20cooking%20on%20a%20tiny%20grill%20on%20their%20patch%20of%20lawn%2C%20standing%20and%20eating%20off%20paper%20plates%2C%20no%20table%2C%20just%20a%20Styrofoam%20cooler%20of%20canned%20drinks.%20She%20glimpsed%20a%20plump%20girl%20in%20shorts%2C%20fiercely%20chewing%2C%20and%20a%20shirtless%20man%20with%20a%20fat%20back%2C%20crouched%20at%20the%20grill%2C%20his%20body%20radiant%20with%20generosity%20as%20he%20handed%20somebody%20a%20plate%20of%20meat.%20Carol%20passed%20them%20going%20fifty-five%20but%20still%20they%20affected%20her%2C%20like%20some%20submerged%20memory%2C%20a%20torn%20photo%20of%20a%20forgotten%20family%20stuck%20randomly%20in%20an%20old%20album.%20Then%20came%20billboards%20offering%20debt%20resolution%2C%20gym%20memberships%2C%20and%20help%20for%20feminine%20incontinence%2C%20and%20one%20for%20something%20called%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Acceptance%20Journey%E2%80%9D%20that%20depicted%20large%2C%20benign-looking%20people%20of%20color%20hugging%20one%20another.%20She%20thought%2C%20It%20must%20be%20something%20to%20do%20with%20church%2C%20that%20last%20one.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBack%20in%20the%20annex%20she%20would%20turn%20on%20the%20TV%20and%20drink%20while%20watching%20non-stop%20news%20rehashing%20situations%20she%20had%20already%20heard%20about.%20She%20changed%20the%20channel%20at%20ten-minute%20commercial%20intervals%20to%20watch%20shows%20about%20terrible%20crimes.%20It%20was%20a%20mashup%20of%20mayhem%2C%20real%20and%20imagined%3A%20old%20people%20buried%20alive%20by%20their%20friends%E2%80%99%20kids%20who%20had%20cleaned%20out%20their%20bank%20accounts%3B%20a%20woman%20held%20captive%20and%20raped%20in%20a%20storage%20locker%20for%20months%3B%20a%20bullied%20office%20worker%20avenging%20himself%20violently%3B%20a%20scrawny%20teen-ager%20trying%20to%20defend%20Islam%20by%20blowing%20up%20a%20school.%20Sometimes%20Carol%20watched%2C%20drank%2C%20and%20cried%3B%20sometimes%20she%20texted%20somebody%20from%20her%20old%20life%20and%20described%20how%20boring%20it%20was%20in%20Rhinehorn.%20Once%2C%20she%20passed%20out%20crying%20and%20woke%20at%20two%20in%20the%20morning%20with%20her%20face%20numb%20against%20the%20disgusting%20carpet%2C%20her%20phone%20clutched%20in%20one%20hand%20and%20the%20worried%20cat%20pawing%20her%20ear.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EWhere%20would%20she%20go%20after%20this%3F%20How%20could%20she%20live%3F%20How%20were%20any%20of%20them%20going%20to%20live%3F%20Her%20poor%20husband%20or%20even%20her%20crazy%20%E2%80%9Cboyfriend%2C%E2%80%9D%20whose%20wife%20had%20left%20him%20with%20no%20warning%2C%20taking%20the%20pots%20and%20pans%20with%20her.%20No%20wonder%20he%20was%20on%20the%20lookout%20re%3A%20sodomy.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The people at the dean’s office were extremely thoughtful and (because they assumed her husband had ditched her?) almost too nice. One of them was at least able to tell her something about the Dutch Colonial: it was normally used for a visiting-professor position but this year the invited visitor had cancelled at the last minute and the backup couldn’t come until January. “I didn’t even know there was an outbuilding,” the woman said. “I mean an annex. I wonder what they put that on for?”"],["p","Eventually, Carol had dinner with Dana and Duane, the people across the street. Their home was well kept but bloomed in the corners with complex personal detritus, kindhearted art and a raucous heap of toys extruding stuffed-animal legs and the heads of dolls with food-coloring hair. Music played from a laptop—a soft and shining voice sang “Someone to Watch Over Me.” The younger girl, Ada, waltzed to the sound of it while the older one, Estella, sighed with impatience at its silky slowness. Carol handed Dana the caponata dish she’d brought, an eggplant salad with four tablespoons of brown sugar even though the recipe called for two—because who could expect kids to eat eggplant otherwise? “Oh, it looks great,” Dana said and put it on the table along with the beef-rib dinner she’d made after, probably, a full day of H.R. Duane, who taught junior high, beamed and bantered with the children about their projects until Estella snapped, “Oh, Dad, stop pretending that everything about us is so great,” embarrassing him into silence."],["p","They prayed before eating, asking God to remind them to always help those who had less than they. Carol wondered for an affronted moment if maybe they meant her. Then she thought, Well, it’s O.K., I do have less than them, and tucked in. Dana was a great cook and an unusual conversationalist, though afterward Carol could not remember anything they had talked about, except (dimly) the reasons that fracking was not entirely a bad idea and the mysterious existence of certain early mammals, the funny shapes of which Ada’s first-grade class had made into cookies. Instead, she remembered the warm feeling of life in the house, the layers of it. She remembered Dana’s white, loose-fitting face with its frame of nondescript brown hair indicating the plain female of the species: no vanity, nothing meant to allure. Practical intelligence, nimble strength, and deep animal will were her traits. Duane, in comparison, seemed human and heady but pliant, wanting to please and be pleased; he had been visibly hurt when his eight-year-old daughter had snapped at him, and it had not occurred to him to snap back. Dana had not seemed to notice, but Ada had; her face went grave at the insult and she lowered her eyes. She seemed the happier of the girls, shiny-eyed, vibrant, and sun-brown, with deeply colored lips. Estella was paler and more recessive, already critical and disappointed. But she was a nice kid. She didn’t want to eat the caponata, but when she tasted how sweet it was she gave Carol a look of pleasure that landed very gently."],["p","It was a nice evening that somehow had the effect of making Carol feel shy about seeing her neighbors again. Instead of walking in the evenings, she began to drive around the country surrounding Rhinehorn. This place was mysterious to her; there was a character to it that felt just outside her range of experience. The road into the farmland was a county road, sparsely lined with economically mismatched houses—beat-up boxes with meagre strips of yard were situated next to charming farmhouses set back amid leafy trees. Carol was mesmerized by the mixture of colors and textures flashing past: grasses, stone fences, an old wooden house stripped of paint, a bush unselfishly extending its bright-pink flowers against the wall of a dull-green house, making the drab color into a gorgeous celadon. There was a family she saw often outside a dirty-looking white house, hanging laundry, lounging on a torn, filthy couch, and, once, cooking on a tiny grill on their patch of lawn, standing and eating off paper plates, no table, just a Styrofoam cooler of canned drinks. She glimpsed a plump girl in shorts, fiercely chewing, and a shirtless man with a fat back, crouched at the grill, his body radiant with generosity as he handed somebody a plate of meat. Carol passed them going fifty-five but still they affected her, like some submerged memory, a torn photo of a forgotten family stuck randomly in an old album. Then came billboards offering debt resolution, gym memberships, and help for feminine incontinence, and one for something called “The Acceptance Journey” that depicted large, benign-looking people of color hugging one another. She thought, It must be something to do with church, that last one."],["p","Back in the annex she would turn on the TV and drink while watching non-stop news rehashing situations she had already heard about. She changed the channel at ten-minute commercial intervals to watch shows about terrible crimes. It was a mashup of mayhem, real and imagined: old people buried alive by their friends’ kids who had cleaned out their bank accounts; a woman held captive and raped in a storage locker for months; a bullied office worker avenging himself violently; a scrawny teen-ager trying to defend Islam by blowing up a school. Sometimes Carol watched, drank, and cried; sometimes she texted somebody from her old life and described how boring it was in Rhinehorn. Once, she passed out crying and woke at two in the morning with her face numb against the disgusting carpet, her phone clutched in one hand and the worried cat pawing her ear."],["p","Where would she go after this? How could she live? How were any of them going to live? Her poor husband or even her crazy “boyfriend,” whose wife had left him with no warning, taking the pots and pans with her. No wonder he was on the lookout re: sodomy."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EIt%20was%20late%20November%20when%20she%20came%20home%20and%20saw%20an%20envelope%20sitting%20in%20the%20crotch%20of%20the%20tree%20in%20her%20yard.%20She%20thought%2C%20Someone%20has%20written%20to%20me!%20She%20reached%20for%20it%20eagerly%20and%20turned%20it%20over%20to%20read%20the%20address.%20It%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CTo%20the%20Grinch.%E2%80%9D%20She%20opened%20the%20envelope%20and%20read%2C%20%E2%80%9CDear%20Grinch%3A%20How%20are%20you%3F%20We%20are%20good.%20Are%20you%20getting%20ready%20for%20Christmas%3F%20Are%20you%20at%20the%20Whos%E2%80%99%20already%3F%20Here%20is%20what%20I%20would%20like%3A%20silk%20slippers%20from%20Target%20(pink%20and%20silver)%2C%20a%20ceramic%20cat%20and%20kittens%2C%20a%20beauty%20kit%20in%20a%20vinyl%20case%2C%20it%20could%20be%20leopard%20or%20zebra%20if%20they%20have%20it.%20I%20know%20it%E2%80%99s%20early%2C%20but%20I%20want%20to%20give%20you%20plenty%20of%20time!%20Love%2C%20Estella.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EShe%20e-mailed%20Dana%20and%20discovered%20that%2C%20according%20to%20family%20lore%2C%20the%20Grinch%20used%20the%20tree%20in%20Carol%E2%80%99s%20yard%20as%20a%20mail-delivery%20system%3B%20Dana%20had%20meant%20to%20get%20the%20letter%20in%20the%20morning%20but%20had%20been%20late%20for%20work.%20Carol%20said%20she%20would%20bring%20the%20letter%20to%20Dana%20the%20next%20day%2C%20then%20surfed%20some%20animal%20videos.%20But%20she%20was%20thinking%20of%20the%20heap%20of%20toys%20across%20the%20street%2C%20the%20winking%20corners%2C%20the%20music%3B%20the%20family%20seemed%20to%20her%20like%20pink%20flowers%20against%20a%20dull%20background.%20She%20e-mailed%20Dana%20again%20and%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CWould%20it%20be%20O.K.%20if%20I%20wrote%20back%20to%20Estella%3F%20As%20the%20Grinch%3F%20It%20could%20be%20fun!%E2%80%9D%20And%20almost%20right%20away%20Dana%20answered%20yes.%20Excited%2C%20Carol%20got%20a%20note %20more%20subtle%20damage%20could%20be%20inflicted%20by%20incautious%20words%2C%20hurtful%20facial%20expressions%2C%20an%20insensitive%20lack%20of%20attention%20at%20the%20wrong%20moment.%20Grace%E2%80%99s%20husband%20owned%20a%20coffee%20company%20that%20had%20made%20him%20rich%2C%20so%20leaving%20her%20job%20might%20have%20been%20a%20reasonable%20choice%E2%80%94except%20that%20then%20the%20marriage%20had%20broken%20up%20and%20Grace%20had%20found%20herself%20a%20single%20mother%20with%20next%20to%20no%20job%20skills%2C%20at%20the%20age%20of%20fifty-three.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CYou%20don%E2%80%99t%20know%20what%E2%80%99s%20happening%20in%20the%20little%20girl%E2%80%99s%20life%2C%E2%80%9D%20Grace%20said.%20%E2%80%9CShe%20could%20be%20especially%20sensitive%20to%20any%20kind%20of%20rupture.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%20don%E2%80%99t%20know%20why.%20Her%20parents%20are%20the%20most%20stable%20people%20in%20the%20world.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CHow%20well%20do%20you%20know%20them%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIt%20was%20Grace%20who%20had%20ended%20the%20marriage.%20Her%20husband%20had%20never%20got%20over%20his%20disappointment%20at%20having%20an%20autistic%20son%2C%20however%20high-functioning%2C%20and%20his%20unkindness%20to%20the%20boy%20had%20caused%20such%20a%20rift%20that%20for%20the%20past%20five%20years%20the%20couple%20had%20slept%20on%20different%20floors%20of%20their%20house.%20Grace%E2%80%99s%20therapist%20had%20urged%20her%20to%20separate%20for%20the%20sake%20of%20her%20son%20and%20for%20her%20own%20self-esteem.%20Grace%E2%80%99s%20hairdresser%20had%20urged%20her%20to%20wait%20it%20out%3A%20%E2%80%9CI%20believe%20there%E2%80%99s%20still%20love%20there%2C%20but%20even%20if%20there%20isn%E2%80%99t%20you%20have%20to%20take%20the%20long%20view%E2%80%94eventually%20he%E2%80%99ll%20die%20and%20you%20and%20Jonny%20will%20have%20that%20big%20house.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ECarol%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20sure%20who%20was%20right%2C%20the%20therapist%20or%20the%20hairdresser%2C%20and%20lately%20neither%20was%20Grace.%20But%2C%20listening%20to%20Grace%20describe%20her%20online-dating%20experiences%2C%20Carol%20was%20thinking%20hairdresser.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","It was late November when she came home and saw an envelope sitting in the crotch of the tree in her yard. She thought, Someone has written to me! She reached for it eagerly and turned it over to read the address. It said, “To the Grinch.” She opened the envelope and read, “Dear Grinch: How are you? We are good. Are you getting ready for Christmas? Are you at the Whos’ already? Here is what I would like: silk slippers from Target (pink and silver), a ceramic cat and kittens, a beauty kit in a vinyl case, it could be leopard or zebra if they have it. I know it’s early, but I want to give you plenty of time! Love, Estella.”"],["p","She e-mailed Dana and discovered that, according to family lore, the Grinch used the tree in Carol’s yard as a mail-delivery system; Dana had meant to get the letter in the morning but had been late for work. Carol said she would bring the letter to Dana the next day, then surfed some animal videos. But she was thinking of the heap of toys across the street, the winking corners, the music; the family seemed to her like pink flowers against a dull background. She e-mailed Dana again and said, “Would it be O.K. if I wrote back to Estella? As the Grinch? It could be fun!” And almost right away Dana answered yes. Excited, Carol got a notebook of lined paper and wrote her message in a crude, Grinchy hand: “Hey Estella, this is the Grinch. I was staying with the Whos but we had a big fight so I left. I’m back to hating Christmas again, and I’m spending it in the cave with my Winged Servants. But even though I hate Christmas I still like you, and I’ll see about that list! Your friend, the Grinch.” She tore it roughly from the binder—she thought this was what a Grinch would do—and put it in a plain envelope addressed to Estella, which she then placed in the tree."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c115dff17c5b74ef07ee7f5%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c115dff17c5b74ef07ee7f5%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c115dff17c5b74ef07ee7f5%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c115dff17c5b74ef07ee7f5"}]],["p","The next day, she took a different turn off the county road and found herself in a less populated place. This road was mostly pastures and fields of crops, tucked in and fallow for the winter. The few houses were set back so far off the road that she almost didn’t see them. The sun had just gone down, and white light glowed between the darkening sky and the dormant fields, the crouching, saturnine orchards. Hers was the only car on the road then and she was surprised to see, on such an untravelled byway, another billboard advertising “The Acceptance Journey.” It, too, depicted pairs of large, benign people of color, men and women looking joyfully at her with their arms around each other. Carol felt a rush of emotion, the strong desire to go wherever these people were, to accept and to be accepted. She wondered if a white person would be allowed in; not long ago, a white man had gone to a black church claiming that he wanted to pray and had murdered people instead. But was the billboard advertising a church?"],["p","When she got home, Carol surreptitiously checked the tree and was sorry to find no envelope. The next day, there was no envelope, or the day after that. Carol quit driving and began walking again, hoping to run into her neighbors. She did see them; they smiled and waved. Ten days passed and still there was no envelope. Finally, Carol approached Dana from the street and asked if Estella had got the letter. “I read it over her shoulder,” Dana said. “She didn’t say anything, but she got very stony. Then she went upstairs. Duane asked her about it at dinner, but she said that it was personal and she didn’t want to talk about it.”"],["p","Carol began apologizing, but Dana said, “Don’t worry about it—she might still write back to you. I’m curious what she’ll say.”"],["p","Carol went back to the annex, poured some wine, and called her sister Grace, in New Jersey. She told her the story and concluded, “What kind of snowflake is this kid? It’s a Grinch, what does she expect?” She meant to be funny, but her sister didn’t laugh. She went on, “I mean, you gotta let a Grinch be a Grinch!” Her sister said, “I’m surprised the girl’s mother would let you write to her like that. I mean, she doesn’t know you; you could’ve said anything.”"],["p","“I guess she thinks I’m a nice person,” Carol said."],["p","“Oh, I’m sure she does. I mean, you are a nice person! But still. If it were me—”"],["p","Carol gritted her teeth. Her sister had stopped working because her son had Asperger’s and she didn’t trust anyone to babysit him; it wasn’t just that anyone could be a molester—although anyone could, even girls could—it was that more subtle damage could be inflicted by incautious words, hurtful facial expressions, an insensitive lack of attention at the wrong moment. Grace’s husband owned a coffee company that had made him rich, so leaving her job might have been a reasonable choice—except that then the marriage had broken up and Grace had found herself a single mother with next to no job skills, at the age of fifty-three."],["p","“You don’t know what’s happening in the little girl’s life,” Grace said. “She could be especially sensitive to any kind of rupture.”"],["p","“I don’t know why. Her parents are the most stable people in the world.”"],["p","“How well do you know them?”"],["p","It was Grace who had ended the marriage. Her husband had never got over his disappointment at having an autistic son, however high-functioning, and his unkindness to the boy had caused such a rift that for the past five years the couple had slept on different floors of their house. Grace’s therapist had urged her to separate for the sake of her son and for her own self-esteem. Grace’s hairdresser had urged her to wait it out: “I believe there’s still love there, but even if there isn’t you have to take the long view—eventually he’ll die and you and Jonny will have that big house.”"],["p","Carol wasn’t sure who was right, the therapist or the hairdresser, and lately neither was Grace. But, listening to Grace describe her online-dating experiences, Carol was thinking hairdresser."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EAfter%20she%20hung%20up%2C%20she%20decided%20to%20write%20another%20letter.%20This%20time%20she%20chose%20to%20write%20on%20unlined%20printer%20paper%2C%20which%20seemed%20a%20little%20nicer.%20She%20wrote%2C%20%E2%80%9CDear%20Estella%3A%20I%20am%20one%20of%20the%20Grinch%E2%80%99s%20Winged%20Assistants%20and%20I%20am%20writing%20to%20you%20because%20the%20Grinch%20is%20too%20embarrassed%20to%20write%20himself.%20He%20is%20very%20upset%20because%20you%20didn%E2%80%99t%20answer%20his%20letter%20and%20he%20thinks%20you%20are%20angry%20at%20him%20about%20the%20Whos.%20Just%20between%20you%20and%20me%2C%20Estella%2C%20he%E2%80%99s%20angry%20at%20himself.%20He%20knows%20the%20fight%20with%20the%20Whos%20was%20his%20fault%20but%20he%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20know%20how%20to%20apologize.%20I%20know%20he%20cares%20a%20great%20deal%20about%20what%20you%20think%2C%20and%20I%E2%80%99m%20wondering%20if%20maybe%20you%20could%20write%20to%20him%20and%20give%20him%20some%20advice.%20I%20think%20it%20would%20make%20a%20big%20difference!%20But%20please%20don%E2%80%99t%20mention%20that%20I%20asked%20you!%20Secretly%20Yours%2C%20Winged%20Assistant%20002.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBecause%20it%20had%20been%20two%20weeks%20since%20the%20last%20letter%2C%20Carol%20decided%20to%20distress%20this%20one%20so%20that%20Estella%20would%20think%20the%20Winged%20Assistant%20had%20written%20sooner.%20She%20sprinkled%20it%20lightly%20with%20water%2C%20then%20took%20it%20out%20to%20the%20yard%2C%20where%20she%20rubbed%20it%20with%20dirt%2C%20walked%20on%20it%2C%20then%20buried%20it%20under%20a%20pile%20of%20leaves%20with%20a%20rock%20on%20top.%20She%20let%20it%20sit%20there%20for%20a%20day%2C%20then%20took%20it%20back%20into%20the%20house%20and%20let%20it%20dry%20on%20the%20heater%3B%20in%20the%20interim%2C%20she%20e-mailed%20Dana%20and%2C%20when%20she%20got%20the%20O.K.%2C%20she%20went%20a
