lied.%20%E2%80%9CWhat%20you%20want%20is%20to%20destroy%20yourself.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CEvery%20woman%20I%E2%80%99ve%20ever%20been%20with%20said%20she%20loved%20me%2C%E2%80%9D%20her%20boyfriend%20had%20said.%20%E2%80%9CI%20don%E2%80%99t%20even%20want%20to%20hear%20it.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CHow%20about%20if%20I%20say%20it%20and%20you%20verbally%20abuse%20me%3F%E2%80%9D%20she%E2%80%99d%20suggested.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHe%E2%80%99d%20considered%20this%20for%20a%20moment.%20Then%20he%E2%80%99d%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CYou%E2%80%99re%20desperate%20for%20something.%20I%20don%E2%80%99t%20really%20know%20what%20it%20is%20but%20that%E2%80%99s%20O.K.%20I%20like%20desperate%20people.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CThe%20Grinch%20was%20so%20embarrassed%20that%20he%20went%20into%20his%20room%20and%20didn%E2%80%99t%20even%20come%20out%20for%20dinner.%20But%20when%20a%20kind%20Who%20mother%E2%80%94she%20saw%20what%20had%20happened%E2%80%94brought%20him%20some%20food%2C%20he%20realized%20he%20had%20to%20come%20back%20out.%20When%20he%20came%20out%20and%20saw%20the%20little%20girl%20he%E2%80%99d%20scared%2C%20he%20tried%20to%20smile%20at%20her.%20But%2C%20because%20he%20was%20ashamed%20and%20didn%E2%80%99t%20feel%20like%20smiling%2C%20it%20came%20out%20like%20a%20terrible%20Grinch-face%20and%20she%20just%20ran%20away%20again.%20Which%20was%20too%20much%20for%20the%20Grinch.%20He%20went%20to%20his%20room%2C%20opened%20the%20window%2C%20summoned%20his%20Winged%20Assistants%2C%20and%20fled%20back%20to%20his%20cave.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20murderer%2C%20the%20serial%20killer%2C%20had%20been%20cornered%20as%20he%20loomed%20above%20his%20terrified%20victim.%20%E2%80%9CDrop%20the%20gun!%E2%80%9D%20an%20agent%20cried.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20know%20what%20you%E2%80%99re%20going%20through!%E2%80%9D%20But%20the%20murderer%20was%20too%20desperate%20to%20surrender%3B%20he%20tried%20to%20shoot%20the%20agents%20and%20went%20down%20in%20a%20hail%20of%20bullets.%20Carol%20turned%20off%20the%20TV.%20Somehow%2C%20somewhere%20inside%20her%2C%20love%20and%20torture%20had%20got%20squished%20together.%20And%20it%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20just%20in%20her.%20As%20the%20idiot%20box%20dutifully%20confirmed%2C%20it%20was%20always%20happening%2C%20of%20course%20it%20was%20happening%3A%20torture%20disguised%20as%20love%20and%20healing%2C%20and%20sometimes%20the%20other%20way%20around.%20Love%20would%20always%20try%20to%20love%2C%20and%20torture%20could%20only%20torture.%20People%20try%20to%20make%20the%20two%20things%20be%20friends%E2%80%94%3Cem%3Ewe%20know%20what%20you%E2%80%99re%20going%20through!%3C%2Fem%3E%E2%80%94and%20sometimes%20it%20even%20seemed%20as%20though%20they%20could%20be%3B%20they%20were%2C%20after%20all%2C%20often%20attracted%20to%20each%20other.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EShe%20could%20not%20think%20of%20what%20else%20the%20Winged%20Assistant%20could%20say%20about%20the%20Grinch%2C%20so%20she%20just%20went%20to%20bed.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","After she hung up, she decided to write another letter. This time she chose to write on unlined printer paper, which seemed a little nicer. She wrote, “Dear Estella: I am one of the Grinch’s Winged Assistants and I am writing to you because the Grinch is too embarrassed to write himself. He is very upset because you didn’t answer his letter and he thinks you are angry at him about the Whos. Just between you and me, Estella, he’s angry at himself. He knows the fight with the Whos was his fault but he doesn’t know how to apologize. I know he cares a great deal about what you think, and I’m wondering if maybe you could write to him and give him some advice. I think it would make a big difference! But please don’t mention that I asked you! Secretly Yours, Winged Assistant 002.”"],["p","Because it had been two weeks since the last letter, Carol decided to distress this one so that Estella would think the Winged Assistant had written sooner. She sprinkled it lightly with water, then took it out to the yard, where she rubbed it with dirt, walked on it, then buried it under a pile of leaves with a rock on top. She let it sit there for a day, then took it back into the house and let it dry on the heater; in the interim, she e-mailed Dana and, when she got the O.K., she went across the street and knocked on the door. Dana let her in with a subtle dramatic flair; Carol spoke in a tone of bewilderment tinged with wonder. “Estella,” she said. “I found a letter in my yard that seems to be for you. It’s from someone calling himself a Winged Assistant.”"],["p","“I know who that is!” the child said, jumping up from the sofa."],["p","The next evening, there was a letter lying in the lap of the tree."],["p","“Dear Winged Assistant: I’m sure that if the Grinch apologized the Whos would accept right away, they are so nice! But I can write to the Grinch. If you tell me what the fight was about, it would help me give advice. Love, Estella.”"],["p","Carol drank, watched TV, and thought about what to write back. For some reason, she thought of the couples counsellor she and her husband had seen, a woman named Mitzi, with long, powerful arms and a glass eye. Mitzi had seen each of them alone first, and then the two of them together. When Carol came by herself, Mitzi had asked her why she wanted to break up with her husband. Carol had said, “I don’t. I just want to have sex with other people.” Mitzi had a chest of toys in her office and she’d asked Carol to choose a toy that best represented the part of her that wanted so badly to have sex with other people that she was willing to jeopardize her marriage. Carol chose a troll doll with pink hair and a rhinestone navel. “So,” Mitzi had said to the doll. “Who are you?” Carol had felt a perverse, exultant glow sneak over her face. She’d smiled and said, “My name is Legion.”"],["p","On her favorite show, the F.B.I. was closing in on a serial killer who disembowelled women and made them scrub their own guts off the floor until they died. As always, the heroes had figured out who the killer was through computer-based psychological analysis. They had scientifically deduced that his mother had been a maid who had dropped dead while working for a sadistic rich woman. This show nearly always ended with F.B.I. agents bursting in on the villain in the midst of his last crime and shouting, “Drop the gun! We know what you’re going through!” Which seemed a tall order in this case."],["p","She wrote, “Dear Estella: Thank you for writing back. What happened is this. The Grinch was at the Whos’ and he was helping them get ready for Christmas early, like usual. He was wrapping the presents and . . .”"],["p","“How do you see the next five years of your life?” Mitzi had asked. “What would you like those five years to be like?” Lloyd had answered, “I want us to own a house with a guest room and two bathrooms. I want dogs and maybe a horse. I want us to live securely with our animals.” Plainly moved, Mitzi had turned to Carol. “And what would you like for the next five years?” Instead of speaking, Carol had jumped up and started dancing. She’d danced around the office, gyrating her hips, singing a wordless song, her hands out as if she were holding onto somebody’s thrusting hips. Mitzi had stared in horror. Her husband had laughed, as if it actually made him happy to see her dance, and maybe it did. They used to dance in the living room like that, wildly and comically."],["p","“. . . right when he was wrapping his present for his favorite little Who girl, she ran up and said, ‘Is that for me? Can I see it?’ She got so close that she saw the present and the surprise was ruined. And the Grinch snapped at her and made such a terrible face that she cried and ran away.”"],["p","Lloyd had laughed in the therapist’s office but he cried in his sleep and tried to punch her in the face. The next day at breakfast he said, “You’ve dishonored me.” She pounded the table and cried out, “I’ve ",["em","dishonored"]," you? What is this, the Army? If it is, I’ve been the good soldier. I’ve paid for everything! And I don’t care about honor anymore. I want to live! I want love! I want love!”"],["p","“You have love,” he replied. “What you want is to destroy yourself.”"],["p","“Every woman I’ve ever been with said she loved me,” her boyfriend had said. “I don’t even want to hear it.”"],["p","“How about if I say it and you verbally abuse me?” she’d suggested."],["p","He’d considered this for a moment. Then he’d said, “You’re desperate for something. I don’t really know what it is but that’s O.K. I like desperate people.”"],["p","“The Grinch was so embarrassed that he went into his room and didn’t even come out for dinner. But when a kind Who mother—she saw what had happened—brought him some food, he realized he had to come back out. When he came out and saw the little girl he’d scared, he tried to smile at her. But, because he was ashamed and didn’t feel like smiling, it came out like a terrible Grinch-face and she just ran away again. Which was too much for the Grinch. He went to his room, opened the window, summoned his Winged Assistants, and fled back to his cave.”"],["p","The murderer, the serial killer, had been cornered as he loomed above his terrified victim. “Drop the gun!” an agent cried. “We know what you’re going through!” But the murderer was too desperate to surrender; he tried to shoot the agents and went down in a hail of bullets. Carol turned off the TV. Somehow, somewhere inside her, love and torture had got squished together. And it wasn’t just in her. As the idiot box dutifully confirmed, it was always happening, of course it was happening: torture disguised as love and healing, and sometimes the other way around. Love would always try to love, and torture could only torture. People try to make the two things be friends—",["em","we know what you’re going through!"],"—and sometimes it even seemed as though they could be; they were, after all, often attracted to each other."],["p","She could not think of what else the Winged Assistant could say about the Grinch, so she just went to bed."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EShe%20woke%20early%20the%20next%20morning%20and%20decided%20to%20go%20for%20a%20walk.%20It%20was%20clear%20and%20cold%20when%20she%20started%20out%2C%20but%20clouds%20rolled%20in%20suddenly%20and%20it%20started%20to%20snow.%20The%20snow%20made%20the%20town%20quiet%3B%20it%20seemed%20as%20if%20the%20only%20people%20on%20the%20street%20were%20old%20men%20walking%20heavily%2C%20as%20though%20they%20were%20coming%20to%20the%20end%20of%20a%20long%20journey.%20The%20sudden%20snowfall%20had%20a%20bleak%20magic%20that%20touched%20a%20simple%20place%20in%20her%3A%20the%20need%20for%20and%20love%20of%20home.%20The%20old%20gas%20station%20with%20its%20flying%20horse%2C%20the%20hardware%20store%20called%20Crest%2C%20the%20gift%20store%20with%20its%20assortment%20of%20novelty%20belt%20buckles%2C%20coasters%2C%20artificial%20flowers%2C%20and%20hand-knit%20purses%2C%20the%20liquor%20store%20that%20gave%20you%20discount%20points%2C%20the%20small%2C%20elegant%20oblong%20of%20an%20apartment%20building%20with%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Saratogan%E2%80%9D%20spelled%20across%20its%20stucco%20front%20in%20stylish%20metallic%20script%E2%80%94what%20kind%20of%20person%20would%20put%20that%20building%20here%2C%20and%20what%20would%20it%20be%20like%20to%20live%20under%20the%20fading%20spell%20of%20its%20signage%3F%20She%20heard%20church%20music%2C%20so%20faint%20on%20the%20wind%20that%20it%20was%20like%20something%20at%20the%20very%20bottom%20of%20a%20half-remembered%20dream%3A%20not%20beautiful%20but%20mysterious%2C%20a%20toiling%20incantation%2C%20with%20voices%20surging%20under%20it%20and%20a%20lone%20voice%20shouting%20over%20it%2C%20vibrating%20between%20supplication%20and%20command.%20Baptist%2C%20she%20thought%2C%20and%20turned%20intuitively%20down%20a%20side%20street%20toward%20the%20sound.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522cartoon%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522cartoon%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fcartoon%25252F5c115dffef12204ae0c05e19%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c115dffef12204ae0c05e19%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c115dffef12204ae0c05e19%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c115dffef12204ae0c05e19%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EIt%20was%20a%20street%20of%20houses%20that%20looked%20put%20together%20as%20if%20they%20were%20toys%2C%20fast%20and%20with%20secret%2C%20cockeyed%20affection.%20One%20of%20them%2C%20originally%20white%2C%20had%20been%20roughly%20painted%20with%20giant%20superheroes%20speeding%20in%20fight%20mode%20across%20its%20walls%2C%20their%20faces%20blurred%20and%20their%20shapes%20too%20botched%20to%20be%20recognizable%20except%E2%80%94great%20red%20Christ!%E2%80%94there%20was%20Spider-Man%2C%20his%20arms%20spread%20triumphantly%20between%20two%20upper-story%20windows%2C%20scarlet%20toes%20grazing%20the%20frame%20of%20the%20front%20door%2C%20friends%20and%20enemies%20ranged%20about%20him%20like%20angels%2C%20menacing%20and%20celebrating.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20house%20was%20mischievous%20and%20pagan%2C%20but%20still%20it%20seemed%20in%20league%20with%20the%20church%20just%20a%20few%20doors%20down.%20The%20church%20was%20a%20triangular%20building%20with%20a%20modest% 20A%20smiling%2C%20middle-aged%20couple%20walked%20past%2C%20woolly%20in%20their%20coats.%20Politely%2C%20Pastor%20Robertson%20turned%20back%20to%20Carol.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20accept%20everybody%20in%20Jesus.%20Is%20it%20something%20particular%20you%20are%20needing%20today%2C%20Karen%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CSomething%20called%20an%20Acceptance%20Journey%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CYou%20mean%20a%20faith%20journey%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CNo%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20Acceptance%20Journey.%20I%20saw%20it%20advertised%20on%20a%20billboard%20on%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20on%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%E2%80%9D%20She%20realized%20her%20mistake%20but%20did%20not%20know%20how%20to%20get%20out%20of%20it.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20a%20picture%20of%20people%20hugging%20each%20other%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CLike%20some%20kind%20of%20special%20group%20where%20people%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EA%20look%20of%20understanding%20came%20to%20the%20man%2C%20followed%20by%20an%20adamant%20adjustment%20of%20his%20expression.%20%E2%80%9CI%20know%20the%20billboard%20you%20are%20referring%20to%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said%20a%20little%20curtly.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20don%E2%80%99t%20do%20that%20here%E2%80%94Hey!%20I%20saw%20your%20boy%20out%20on%20the%20field%20the%20other%20day%2C%20he%20looked%20great!%E2%80%9D%20A%20bouquet%20of%20smiles%20and%20friendly%20sounds%20went%20past%20in%20the%20quietly%20thickening%20snow.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CYou%20can%20come%20in%20and%20pray%20with%20us%20if%20you%20want%20to%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20pastor%20said%2C%20coming%20back%20to%20Carol.%20%E2%80%9CBut%20we%20don%E2%80%99t%20offer%20what%20you%20are%20looking%20for.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ECarol%20blushed%3B%20she%20opened%20her%20mouth%20and%20tried%20to%20speak.%20But%20the%20pastor%20turned%20away%20to%20greet%20a%20very%20old%20white%20woman%20hobbling%20on%20a%20walker%2C%20assisted%20by%20a%20young%20light-skinned%20black%20woman%20with%20a%20kind%20and%20intrepid%20face.%20The%20old%20woman%20looked%20down%20with%20pulled-in%20lips%2C%20concentrating%20all%20her%20effort%20on%20moving%20forward%2C%20but%20the%20young%20woman%20faced%20Pastor%20Robertson%20with%20confident%20expectation%2C%20which%20he%20answered%20without%20missing%20a%20beat.%20%E2%80%9CRoberta!%20So%20glad%20to%20see%20you%2C%20my%20dear!%20Eunice%2C%20God%20bless%20you%E2%80%94%E2%80%9D%20and%20Carol%20walked%20away.%20She%20didn%E2%80%99t%20even%20feel%20that%20she%20was%20being%20rude%2C%20or%2C%20more%20precisely%2C%20she%20didn%E2%80%99t%20care.%20She%20felt%20rebuffed%20and%20bewildered.%20%3Cem%3EWe%20don%E2%80%99t%20do%20that%20here%3C%2Fem%3E%E2%80%94don%E2%80%99t%20do%20what%3F%20She%20walked%20down%20the%20block%2C%20fumbled%20in%20her%20purse%20for%20her%20phone%2C%20and%20tried%20to%20Google%20%E2%80%9CAcceptance%20Journey.%E2%80%9D%20But%20she%20had%20no%20service.%20She%20walked%20all%20the%20way%20around%20the%20block%2C%20Googling%20vainly%20and%20repeatedly%3B%20when%20she%20arrived%20back%20at%20the%20church%2C%20the%20door%20was%20closed.%20She%20stood%20before%20it%2C%20listening%20to%20muffled%20music%20and%20voices%20crying%20%E2%80%9CJesus!%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%3Cem%3EMy%20name%20is%20Legion%3C%2Fem%3E%E2%80%94well%2C%20no%20wonder%20she%E2%80%99d%20said%20it.%20There%20was%20a%20legion%20of%20voices%20and%20faces%20in%20her%20and%20around%20her%2C%20cruel%20and%20ruthless%20and%20loud%2C%20talking%20gigantically%20and%20dancing%20lewdly%20while%20between%20their%20prancing%20legs%20a%20blind%20little%20creature%20stumbled%2C%20squeaking%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20want%20love%2C%20I%20want%20love!%E2%80%9D%20Carol%20was%20touched%20by%20the%20image%20of%20the%20old%20woman%20with%20her%20walker%2C%20working%20so%20hard%20to%20move%20forward.%20She%20wished%20she%20could%20go%20into%20the%20church%20and%20pray%2C%20but%20she%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20imagine%20herself%20there%2C%20among%20good%20people%20so%20profoundly%20linked.%20Instead%20she%20closed%20her%20eyes%20and%20listened%20to%20the%20music%20and%20prayed.%20She%20saw%20the%20naked%20prostitute%20running%20in%20the%20desert%3B%20the%20woman%20was%20playing%20a%20part%20she%E2%80%99d%20chosen%2C%20at%20least%20in%20the%20movie%2C%20but%20still%20Carol%20prayed%20for%20her%2C%20for%20people%20to%20find%20her%20and%20give%20her%20water%2C%20wrap%20her%20in%20cool%20sheets%2C%20take%20her%20to%20where%20she%20could%20be%20nourished%20and%20get%20well.%20She%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20imagine%20people%20helping%20the%20man%20who%20had%20tortured%20her%2C%20so%20instead%20she%20prayed%20for%20angels%E2%80%94masculine%20angels%20with%20wings%20like%20those%20of%20powerful%20birds%20or%20bats%2C%20strong%20and%20leathery%2C%20the%20tendons%20and%20bones%20visible%E2%80%94who%20would%20wrap%20him%20in%20those%20wings%20and%20the%20wings%20would%20speak%20to%20him%20and%20hold%20him.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20music%20stopped.%20She%20opened%20her%20eyes.%20She%20heard%20the%20pastor%20speaking%20but%20could%20not%20make%20out%20his%20words.%20The%20snow%20was%20sticking%3B%20the%20wind%20had%20come%20up.%20She%20decided%20to%20get%20something%20warming%20in%20her%20for%20the%20walk%20home.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","She woke early the next morning and decided to go for a walk. It was clear and cold when she started out, but clouds rolled in suddenly and it started to snow. The snow made the town quiet; it seemed as if the only people on the street were old men walking heavily, as though they were coming to the end of a long journey. The sudden snowfall had a bleak magic that touched a simple place in her: the need for and love of home. The old gas station with its flying horse, the hardware store called Crest, the gift store with its assortment of novelty belt buckles, coasters, artificial flowers, and hand-knit purses, the liquor store that gave you discount points, the small, elegant oblong of an apartment building with “The Saratogan” spelled across its stucco front in stylish metallic script—what kind of person would put that building here, and what would it be like to live under the fading spell of its signage? She heard church music, so faint on the wind that it was like something at the very bottom of a half-remembered dream: not beautiful but mysterious, a toiling incantation, with voices surging under it and a lone voice shouting over it, vibrating between supplication and command. Baptist, she thought, and turned intuitively down a side street toward the sound."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c115dffef12204ae0c05e19%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c115dffef12204ae0c05e19%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c115dffef12204ae0c05e19%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c115dffef12204ae0c05e19"}]],["p","It was a street of houses that looked put together as if they were toys, fast and with secret, cockeyed affection. One of them, originally white, had been roughly painted with giant superheroes speeding in fight mode across its walls, their faces blurred and their shapes too botched to be recognizable except—great red Christ!—there was Spider-Man, his arms spread triumphantly between two upper-story windows, scarlet toes grazing the frame of the front door, friends and enemies ranged about him like angels, menacing and celebrating."],["p","The house was mischievous and pagan, but still it seemed in league with the church just a few doors down. The church was a triangular building with a modest personality, despite the pink-and-green neon sign announcing “Springfield Baptist Church,” which protruded from its side like a thought balloon. Its main door was open and thronged with people, and the organ music poured out, toiling and mysterious no more, rising with ease and cheer. A black man in a dark suit with a woollen scarf around his neck stood at the center of the congregation as people came to him singly and in groups, black people brightly dressed in their good coats and winter boots, smiling adults and children bursting with energy, one boy breaking away to make a snowball that he hastily dropped at his mother’s command. Carol stopped in her tracks. ",["em","The Acceptance Journey!"]," Her heart beat with amazement and she impulsively crossed the street, hesitated, then got in line behind a cluster of middle-aged women, who were being greeted fulsomely by the gentleman at the door. “What you doin’ out here in this weather, pastor?” a frosted-haired lady asked in a joyful and submissive voice. “Where’s Jerome?” “Jerome is not feeling well today, Miss Janice, and, besides, I want to welcome back sister Eunice, first time back since she broke her hip!” The women praised God with words and powerful “um-hmm”s. Then one of them noticed Carol with a quick up-and-down."],["p","Carol was suddenly timid. The man did not look at all like a pastor to her. He was slender, straight-backed, and youthful in appearance, martially impervious to the cold, with a strict manner that was accentuated by his suit. Carol now felt confusion on top of timidity, and she must have communicated it because he appraised her sideways before she even got to him, and when he met her eyes it was with the look of someone assessing a possible problem. But, even with those eyes, he took her hand and spoke with sharp, shapely kindness. “Welcome, sister. You’re visiting our fellowship today?”"],["p","“I don’t know,” Carol said, aware of the women regarding her with erect alertness. “I wanted to ask . . .” She trailed off. The women were all wearing skirts and high-heeled boots. She was wearing black jeans and a gray parka."],["p","“You are welcome to pray with us,” he said, softening his eyes, even squeezing her hand, realizing, it seemed, that he was merely looking at a confused and timid woman. “I’m Pastor Robertson, and you are?”"],["p","“Carol,” she said and hesitated. “Um, I was wondering, do you do Acceptance Journeys here?”"],["p","“We accept everybody,” the pastor replied. “More important, Jesus accepts everybody. We accept—” He looked past her with a burst of feeling. “Hello, Strongs! Glad to finally see ",["em","you"],", sir!” A smiling, middle-aged couple walked past, woolly in their coats. Politely, Pastor Robertson turned back to Carol. “We accept everybody in Jesus. Is it something particular you are needing today, Karen?”"],["p","“Something called an Acceptance Journey?”"],["p","“You mean a faith journey?”"],["p","“No, it’s Acceptance Journey. I saw it advertised on a billboard on . . . on . . .” She realized her mistake but did not know how to get out of it. “It’s a picture of people hugging each other,” she said. “Like some kind of special group where people . . .”"],["p","A look of understanding came to the man, followed by an adamant adjustment of his expression. “I know the billboard you are referring to,” he said a little curtly. “We don’t do that here—Hey! I saw your boy out on the field the other day, he looked great!” A bouquet of smiles and friendly sounds went past in the quietly thickening snow."],["p","“You can come in and pray with us if you want to,” the pastor said, coming back to Carol. “But we don’t offer what you are looking for.”"],["p","Carol blushed; she opened her mouth and tried to speak. But the pastor turned away to greet a very old white woman hobbling on a walker, assisted by a young light-skinned black woman with a kind and intrepid face. The old woman looked down with pulled-in lips, concentrating all her effort on moving forward, but the young woman faced Pastor Robertson with confident expectation, which he answered without missing a beat. “Roberta! So glad to see you, my dear! Eunice, God bless you—” and Carol walked away. She didn’t even feel that she was being rude, or, more precisely, she didn’t care. She felt rebuffed and bewildered. ",["em","We don’t do that here"],"—don’t do what? She walked down the block, fumbled in her purse for her phone, and tried to Google “Acceptance Journey.” But she had no service. She walked all the way around the block, Googling vainly and repeatedly; when she arrived back at the church, the door was closed. She stood before it, listening to muffled music and voices crying “Jesus!”"],["p",["em","My name is Legion"],"—well, no wonder she’d said it. There was a legion of voices and faces in her and around her, cruel and ruthless and loud, talking gigantically and dancing lewdly while between their prancing legs a blind little creature stumbled, squeaking, “I want love, I want love!” Carol was touched by the image of the old woman with her walker, working so hard to move forward. She wished she could go into the church and pray, but she couldn’t imagine herself there, among good people so profoundly linked. Instead she closed her eyes and listened to the music and prayed. She saw the naked prostitute running in the desert; the woman was playing a part she’d chosen, at least in the movie, but still Carol prayed for her, for people to find her and give her water, wrap her in cool sheets, take her to where she could be nourished and get well. She couldn’t imagine people helping the man who had tortured her, so instead she prayed for angels—masculine angels with wings like those of powerful birds or bats, strong and leathery, the tendons and bones visible—who would wrap him in those wings and the wings would speak to him and hold him."],["p","The music stopped. She opened her eyes. She heard the pastor speaking but could not make out his words. The snow was sticking; the wind had come up. She decided to get something warming in her for the walk home."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EShe%20chose%20a%20place%20she%E2%80%99d%20never%20been%20before%2C%20a%20place%20at%20which%20she%20did%20not%20expect%20to%20find%20anyone%20she%20knew.%20It%20was%20cheap%20and%20colorless%2C%20except%20for%20orange-and-white-checked%20tablecloths%2C%20but%20cakes%20were%20displayed%2C%20and%20pies%20with%20red%20filling%3B%20the%20overhead%20heater%20roared.%20An%20elderly%20waitress%20who%20was%20cleaning%20the%20floor%20with%20a%20dry%20mop%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CSeat%20yourself%2C%20I%E2%80%99ll%20be%20right%20with%20you%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20Carol%20found%20a%20table.%20In%20the%20seconds%20it%20took%20to%20walk%20to%20an%20open%20table%2C%20her%20glasses%20fogged%2C%20and%20she%20took%20them%20off%20before%20removing%20her%20coat.%20She%20was%20cleaning%20them%20with%20a%20napkin%20when%20Dana%20spoke%20to%20her%20from%20the%20next%20table%2C%20a%20welcoming%20greeting%20completely%20contradicted%20by%20her%20expression%2C%20which%20was%20that%20of%20someone%20trapped.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9COh!%E2%80%9D%20Carol%20said.%20%E2%80%9CHow%20are%20you%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CWell%2C%20I%E2%80%99m%20here%2C%E2%80%9D%20Dana%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CYeah%2C%20me%2C%20too.%E2%80%9D%20%3Cem%3EDon%E2%80%99t%20worry%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20she%20transmitted%2C%20%3Cem%3EI%20don%E2%80%99t%20want%20to%20talk%2C%20either%3C%2Fem%3E.%20She%20looked%20at%20the%20laminated%20menu%20already%20on%20the%20table%3B%20eggs%2C%20pancakes%2C%20fruit%20salad%2C%20cottage%20cheese%2C%20bagels.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CWhat%20brings%20you%20out%20in%20this%20weather%3F%E2%80%9D%20Dana%20asked.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%20went%20for%20a%20walk.%E2%80%9D%20Sandwiches%2C%20sausages%2C%20spaghetti%2C%20onion%20soup.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CWow.%20You%20have%20healthy%20habits.%20I%20cut%20church%20and%20drove%20here.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIt% he%20Grinch%20answering%20her%20letters%3F%E2%80%9D%20Carol%20asked.%20%E2%80%9CI%20think%20she%20knows%20and%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20know%20at%20the%20same%20time%2C%E2%80%9D%20Dana%20said.%20%E2%80%9CShe%E2%80%99s%20at%20an%20age%20where%20she%20can%20believe%20in%20things%20that%20she%20knows%20aren%E2%80%99t%20real.%E2%80%9D%20She%20paused.%20%E2%80%9CWhat%20kind%20of%20business%20was%20your%20husband%20trying%20to%20run%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CWell%2C%20acting%20was%20his%20first%20love%2C%20but%20he%20was%20a%20social%20worker.%20He%20developed%20a%20special%20relationship%20with%20a%20client%20who%20would%20actually%20pay%20him%20to%20go%20on%20business%20trips%20with%20him%2C%20basically%20to%20keep%20him%20off%20drugs.%20So%20he%20decided%20to%20quit%20his%20job%20at%20the%20clinic%20and%20become%20a%20life%20coach.%20Which%20might%E2%80%99ve%20worked%20out%20if%20the%20one%20client%20hadn%E2%80%99t%20overdosed.%20But%20he%20decided%20life%20coaching%20was%20where%20it%20was%20at.%20He%20thought%20he%20could%20get%20back%20into%20acting%20while%20being%20a%20life%20coach.%20He%20thought%20anything%20could%20happen.%20And%20so%20did%20I.%20In%20a%20different%20way.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CAnything%20%3Cem%3Ecan%3C%2Fem%3E%20happen%2C%E2%80%9D%20Dana%20said%20cheerfully.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CYes%2C%E2%80%9D%20Carol%2C%20said.%20%E2%80%9CUnfortunately.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","She chose a place she’d never been before, a place at which she did not expect to find anyone she knew. It was cheap and colorless, except for orange-and-white-checked tablecloths, but cakes were displayed, and pies with red filling; the overhead heater roared. An elderly waitress who was cleaning the floor with a dry mop said, “Seat yourself, I’ll be right with you,” and Carol found a table. In the seconds it took to walk to an open table, her glasses fogged, and she took them off before removing her coat. She was cleaning them with a napkin when Dana spoke to her from the next table, a welcoming greeting completely contradicted by her expression, which was that of someone trapped."],["p","“Oh!” Carol said. “How are you?”"],["p","“Well, I’m here,” Dana said."],["p","“Yeah, me, too.” ",["em","Don’t worry"],", she transmitted, ",["em","I don’t want to talk, either"],". She looked at the laminated menu already on the table; eggs, pancakes, fruit salad, cottage cheese, bagels."],["p","“What brings you out in this weather?” Dana asked."],["p","“I went for a walk.” Sandwiches, sausages, spaghetti, onion soup."],["p","“Wow. You have healthy habits. I cut church and drove here.”"],["p","It was unmistakable; she did want to talk. Her face said, “Oh, no, not you,” but her posture was uncertain, and in her voice Carol could feel the pressure of need. Sure enough, she said, “I needed a break. Some time alone.” She glanced at Carol, then faced her. “My mother died last summer.”"],["p","Carol said she was sorry. The waitress brought coffee. The death was expected but terrible and had sent Dana’s unstable only sister into a mad pinwheel of illness and addiction that Dana feared would end in homelessness. “The safety net is being punched full of holes,” she said. “I’m afraid her disability will be taken away. I wish she could just come and stay with us for a little while, but Duane didn’t even want her to come for Christmas—at least I prevailed on that.”"],["p","Dana’s rice pudding came. Carol ordered a vegetable omelette with fries. Dana apologized for oversharing; she asked what Carol was doing for Christmas. Carol revealed that she was spending it with ",["em","her"]," sister, who thought that she, Carol, was crazy."],["p","“You?” Dana said. “You don’t seem crazy. You seem independent and tough.” She jerked her chin up, as if giving her props."],["p","“Well, first I spent a lot of money on my husband’s kooky business, then I left him. She left her husband, too. But he was an asshole. To their child. In my marriage, I was the asshole.”"],["p","Dana looked at Carol directly, eyes creepy with supposition. But she said, “You don’t seem like an asshole, either.”"],["p","“I didn’t feel like one,” she said slowly. “But I think hardly anybody does.”"],["p","“No asshole would answer a letter in a tree from a kid.”"],["p",["em","Oh, actually, one might"],". “Speaking of that, how’s Estella?”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c115dff50c60350034bc468%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c115dff50c60350034bc468%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c115dff50c60350034bc468%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c115dff50c60350034bc468"}]],["p","Dana shrugged and began to meticulously pick the raisins out of her rice pudding. “She thinks a lot. She feels a lot. She’s sad about her grandmother. She’s picked up on what’s gone on between me and Duane. About my sister. Honestly, I think that’s why she took your Grinch letter so hard.”"],["p","“I’m writing another one,” Carol said. “It’ll be better.”"],["p","“I hope you realize you don’t have to,” Dana said earnestly. “Only if it’s fun for you. It should be fun.”"],["p","They sat silently for a long moment, Carol picking at her fries, Dana finishing her coffee. The café was clearing out; the waitress gathered loads of dishes in both arms, gallantly blowing a stray strand of hair from her face as she walked. Carol wanted to tell Dana just how not like an asshole she’d felt. How her body had suddenly surged with a strength and confidence she’d never had before; she didn’t really know when it had happened, but the volume had been all at once turned up very high inside her, and men were able to hear it, sometimes even young men: she’d walked into a bar near Penn Station one afternoon and a young man had said, “Excuse me, but you have such a beautiful face, you are glowing!” He’d offered to buy her a drink and she’d said no, but she hadn’t taken her eyes off the young man until he left the bar and, oh, she wished he hadn’t. If it wasn’t that night, it was a night soon after that that she’d dreamed of a lion leaping to embrace her with its huge paws, showing her its teeth and claws but not hurting her, instead holding her with love in its powerful body. Very soon after that a friend had sent her a video set to a bombastic love song, about a lion who’d been rescued as a cub, ecstatically embracing his rescuer and rubbing against him like a cat. She hated the bombastic song, but, still, after the dream the video had seemed to her like a sign, a sign that plainly said, ",["em","If Lloyd can just quit his job and do what he wants, then I should do what I want, too"],"."],["p","But she didn’t tell Dana any of this. Instead she asked her, “Have you ever heard of something called an Acceptance Journey? I’ve seen billboards up and I can’t tell what they’re for.”"],["p","“Oh, yeah,” Dana said. “It’s some kind of outreach to gay and transgender people; some of the professors are involved in it. Why?”"],["p","“Just wondered.”"],["p","They got their checks; Dana offered her a ride home and she accepted. It was a struggle getting out of the parking lot, and the streets were slick. At the intersections, heavy old traffic signals swayed on their wires."],["p","“Do you think Estella knows it’s not really the Grinch answering her letters?” Carol asked. “I think she knows and doesn’t know at the same time,” Dana said. “She’s at an age where she can believe in things that she knows aren’t real.” She paused. “What kind of business was your husband trying to run?”"],["p","“Well, acting was his first love, but he was a social worker. He developed a special relationship with a client who would actually pay him to go on business trips with him, basically to keep him off drugs. So he decided to quit his job at the clinic and become a life coach. Which might’ve worked out if the one client hadn’t overdosed. But he decided life coaching was where it was at. He thought he could get back into acting while being a life coach. He thought anything could happen. And so did I. In a different way.”"],["p","“Anything ",["em","can"]," happen,” Dana said cheerfully."],["p","“Yes,” Carol, said. “Unfortunately.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThey%20pulled%20up%20to%20Carol%E2%80%99s%20house%3B%20Estella%20and%20Ada%20were%20in%20the%20front%20yard%2C%20at%20the%20foot%20of%20the%20tree.%20Carol%20got%20out%20and%20they%20ran%20to%20the%20car%2C%20Estella%20shouting%2C%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Winged%20Assistant%20came!%20But%20he%20didn%E2%80%99t%20leave%20anything!%E2%80%9D%20The%20girls%20went%20back%20across%20the%20street%20to%20regale%20their%20mother%20as%20she%20got%20out%20of%20the%20car.%20Carol%20went%20to%20the%20tree%20and%20saw%20what%20they%20were%20talking%20about%3A%20the%20puzzling%20tracks%20of%20what%20was%20perhaps%20a%20very%20large%20bird.%20And%20at%20the%20edge%20of%20her%20vision%20she%20could%20see%2C%20or%20half%20see%2C%20a%20Winged%20Assistant%2C%20stork-legged%2C%20swift%2C%20and%20subtle%2C%20coming%20to%20check%20the%20tree.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ECarol%20went%20into%20the%20house%2C%20back%20to%20the%20letter%20she%E2%80%99d%20started.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CYou%20may%20be%20wondering%20why%20the%20Grinch%20was%20so%20embarrassed.%20The%20thing%20is%2C%20Estella%2C%20when%20somebody%E2%80%99s%20heart%20grows%20very%20big%20very%20fast%2C%20as%20happened%20to%20the%20Grinch%20so%20many%20years%20ago%2C%20sometimes%20it%20can%20be%20too%20sensitive%20and%20get%20confused.%20Because%20it%E2%80%99s%20suddenly%20bigger%2C%20it%20feels%20things%20bigger.%20That%E2%80%99s%20what%20happened%20to%20the%20Grinch.%20He%20got%20confused%20by%20his%20feelings%20and%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20know%20how%20to%20get%20back%20on%20the%20right%20track.%20He%E2%80%99s%20basically%20not%20sure%20he%20can%20still%20be%20good.%20It%20would%20help%20to%20know%20that%20you%20believe%20he%20can!%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ECarol%20put%20the%20letter%20in%20an%20envelope%20and%20went%20out%20in%20the%20car%20to%20look%20for%20a%20long%20pair%20of%20barbecue%20tongs.%20The%20snow%20had%20begun%20to%20come%20down%20again%2C%20in%20gigantic%20flakes%2C%20soft%2C%20slow%20blobs%20that%20reminded%20her%20of%20Oobleck.%20Without%20knowing%20why%2C%20she%20thought%20of%20the%20time%2C%20toward%20the%20end%20of%20their%20marriage%2C%20when%20Lloyd%20had%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CWhy%20did%20you%20have%20to%20talk%20about%20it%3F%20Why%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20we%20just%20lie%20and%20cheat%20like%20everybody%20else%3F%E2%80%9D%20She%20smiled.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EShe%20found%20some%20excellent%20tongs%20in%20the%20housewares%20section%20of%20the%20humbly%20striving%20Tops.%20While%20she%20waited%20in%20the%20checkout%20line%2C%20she%20pulled%20up%20Lloyd%E2%80%99s%20number%20and%20thought%20about%20texting%20him.%20As%20she%20was%20doing%20that%2C%20Dana%20texted%20her%20and%20asked%20if%20she%20would%20like%20to%20come%20to%20dinner.%20She%20said%20yes%2C%20and%20picked%20up%20a%20bottle%20of%20wine%20at%20the%20liquor%20store%20that%20gave%20a%20discount%20for%20shopping%20at%20Tops.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIt%20was%20a%20low-key%20dinner%20of%20lasagna%2C%20salad%2C%20and%20garlic%20bread%3B%20they%20held%20hands%20and%20prayed%20before%20they%20ate.%20Carol%20looked%20for%20tension%20between%20Dana%20and%20Duane%20but%20didn%E2%80%99t%20find%20it.%20She%20remembered%20how%2C%20when%20she%20had%20felt%20the%20most%20desperate%20about%20her%20marriage%2C%20people%20would%20tell%20her%2C%20%E2%80%9CYou%20look%20so%20happy.%E2%80%9D%20They%20had%20silly%20conversations%2C%20about%20a%20book%20they%20had%20all%20read%20in%20high%20school%2C%20about%20whether%20fracking%20really%20would%20come%20to%20Rhinehorn%2C%20about%20how%20just%20five%20years%20ago%20you%20could%20not%20have%20imagined%20a%20President%20whose%20third%20wife%20had%20posed%20naked%3B%20they%20discussed%20whether%20this%20was%20a%20good%20or%20a%20bad%20thing.%20Carol%20glanced%20at%20the%20girls%3B%20Estella%20was%20looking%20supercilious%2C%20Ada%20was%20eating%20her%20bread%20with%20greasy%2C%20dream-faced%20absorption.%20Dana%20said%20that%20there%20was%20a%20possibility%20that%20the%20woman%20Carol%20was%20replacing%20might%20not%20come%20back%2C%20which%20would%20mean%20that%20Carol%20might%20be%20able%20to%20stay%20on%2C%20if%20she%20wanted.%20Carol%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9COh%2C%20really!%20Nobody%20told%20me%20that!%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EShe%20came%20home%20around%20nine%2C%20had%20a%20juice%20jar%20of%20wine%2C%20watched%20a%20movie%20about%20a%20heroic%20horse%20that%20had%20fought%20for%20the%20Allies%20in%20the%20First%20World%20War%2C%20and%20typed%20a%20text%20message%20she%20didn%E2%80%99t%20send.%20It%20was%20just%20past%20midnight%20when%20she%20put%20on%20her%20coat%2C%20put%20the%20Winged%20Assistant%E2%80%99s%20letter%20in%20her%20pocket%2C%20and%20got%20the%20tongs.%20The%20plows%20had%20come%20and%20banked%20the%20snow%2C%20which%20was%20now%20falling%20lightly%20or%20perhaps%20just%20drifting.%20She%20went%20to%20the%20wooded%20edge%20of%20the%20empty%20lot%20beside%20her%20place%20and%20found%20a%20light%20bough%20that%20had%20come%20off%20a%20small%20pine%20tree.%20She%20walked%20back%20into%20the%20street%2C%20sweeping%20her%20tracks%20with%20the%20bough.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20night%20was%20clear%2C%20and%20she%20could%20see%20stars.%20Snow%20rested%20thickly%20on%20each%20tree%20branch.%20She%20thought%20of%20the%20music%20she%E2%80%99d%20heard%20outside%20the%20church.%20She%20thought%20of%20her%20prayers.%20She%20felt%20wonder%20and%20pain.%20But%20she%20didn%E2%80%99t%20concentrate%20on%20either.%20She%20concentrated%20on%20sweeping%20away%20her%20tracks%20and%20then%20on%20gripping%20the%20letter%20firmly%20in%20the%20tongs.%20She%20stretched%20her%20body%20over%20the%20piece%20of%20yard%20between%20the%20street%20and%20the%20tree%20and%20placed%20the%20letter.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","They pulled up to Carol’s house; Estella and Ada were in the front yard, at the foot of the tree. Carol got out and they ran to the car, Estella shouting, “The Winged Assistant came! But he didn’t leave anything!” The girls went back across the street to regale their mother as she got out of the car. Carol went to the tree and saw what they were talking about: the puzzling tracks of what was perhaps a very large bird. And at the edge of her vision she could see, or half see, a Winged Assistant, stork-legged, swift, and subtle, coming to check the tree."],["p","Carol went into the house, back to the letter she’d started."],["p","“You may be wondering why the Grinch was so embarrassed. The thing is, Estella, when somebody’s heart grows very big very fast, as happened to the Grinch so many years ago, sometimes it can be too sensitive and get confused. Because it’s suddenly bigger, it feels things bigger. That’s what happened to the Grinch. He got confused by his feelings and doesn’t know how to get back on the right track. He’s basically not sure he can still be good. It would help to know that you believe he can!”"],["p","Carol put the letter in an envelope and went out in the car to look for a long pair of barbecue tongs. The snow had begun to come down again, in gigantic flakes, soft, slow blobs that reminded her of Oobleck. Without knowing why, she thought of the time, toward the end of their marriage, when Lloyd had said, “Why did you have to talk about it? Why couldn’t we just lie and cheat like everybody else?” She smiled."],["p","She found some excellent tongs in the housewares section of the humbly striving Tops. While she waited in the checkout line, she pulled up Lloyd’s number and thought about texting him. As she was doing that, Dana texted her and asked if she would like to come to dinner. She said yes, and picked up a bottle of wine at the liquor store that gave a discount for shopping at Tops."],["p","It was a low-key dinner of lasagna, salad, and garlic bread; they held hands and prayed before they ate. Carol looked for tension between Dana and Duane but didn’t find it. She remembered how, when she had felt the most desperate about her marriage, people would tell her, “You look so happy.” They had silly conversations, about a book they had all read in high school, about whether fracking really would come to Rhinehorn, about how just five years ago you could not have imagined a President whose third wife had posed naked; they discussed whether this was a good or a bad thing. Carol glanced at the girls; Estella was looking supercilious, Ada was eating her bread with greasy, dream-faced absorption. Dana said that there was a possibility that the woman Carol was replacing might not come back, which would mean that Carol might be able to stay on, if she wanted. Carol said, “Oh, really! Nobody told me that!”"],["p","She came home around nine, had a juice jar of wine, watched a movie about a heroic horse that had fought for the Allies in the First World War, and typed a text message she didn’t send. It was just past midnight when she put on her coat, put the Winged Assistant’s letter in her pocket, and got the tongs. The plows had come and banked the snow, which was now falling lightly or perhaps just drifting. She went to the wooded edge of the empty lot beside her place and found a light bough that had come off a small pine tree. She walked back into the street, sweeping her tracks with the bough."],["p","The night was clear, and she could see stars. Snow rested thickly on each tree branch. She thought of the music she’d heard outside the church. She thought of her prayers. She felt wonder and pain. But she didn’t concentrate on either. She concentrated on sweeping away her tracks and then on gripping the letter firmly in the tongs. She stretched her body over the piece of yard between the street and the tree and placed the letter. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"5907efd0019dfc3494e9c92f","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5907efd0019dfc3494e9c92f","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Fiction","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"fiction"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"Fiction","parent":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"fiction"}]}]},"channel":"","contentSource":"magazine","contentTags":[{"name":";","url":"/tag/"}],"contentType":"article","contributors":[{"name":"Mary 580%259D%253A%253C%252Fstrong%253E%255CnBen%2520Taub%2520on%2520the%2520future%2520of%2520Iraq%252C%2520following%2520the%2520Islamic%2520State%25E2%2580%2599s%2520defeat%2520in%2520Mosul.%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EAhmed%20had%20no%20lawyer%2C%20and%20so%20Sahar%20called%20upon%20an%20elderly%20state%20attorney%20named%20Hussein%2C%20who%20was%20seated%20in%20the%20gallery%2C%20to%20spontaneously%20craft%20a%20defense.%20Hussein%20walked%20over%20to%20a%20lectern%2C%20repeated%20from%20memory%20what%20Ahmed%20had%20said%2C%20and%2C%20without%20requesting%20his%20release%2C%20concluded%20with%20a%20plea%20for%20%E2%80%9Cmercy%20in%20his%20sentencing.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAhmed%20wept%20as%20he%20was%20led%20out%20of%20the%20room.%20His%20trial%20had%20lasted%20four%20and%20a%20half%20minutes.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20next%20suspect%20insisted%20that%20he%20had%20been%20arrested%20by%20mistake%E2%80%94that%20his%20name%20was%20similar%20to%20that%20of%20someone%20in%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E.%20A%20private%20defense%20lawyer%20explained%20that%20his%20client%20had%20confessed%20to%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20affiliation%20under%20torture%E2%80%94he%20had%20a%20medical%20examination%20to%20prove%20it%E2%80%94but%20none%20of%20the%20judges%20appeared%20to%20be%20listening.%20As%20the%20lawyer%20spoke%2C%20they%20cracked%20jokes%2C%20signed%20documents%2C%20and%20beckoned%20their%20assistants%20to%20collect%20folders%20from%20the%20bench.%20Sahar%20yawned.%20The%20trial%20lasted%20eight%20minutes.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20third%20suspect%20was%20a%20twenty-three-year-old%20from%20a%20village%20near%20Mosul%2C%20charged%20with%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20affiliation%20and%20arrested%20while%20in%20a%20displaced-persons%20camp.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522cartoon%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522cartoon%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fcartoon%25252F5c12cc9b2eb5b760bfa5e878%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c12cc9b2eb5b760bfa5e878%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c12cc9b2eb5b760bfa5e878%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cc9b2eb5b760bfa5e878%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CWhen%20did%20you%20join%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%3F%E2%80%9D%20Sahar%20asked.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%20didn%E2%80%99t%20join%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20suspect%20replied.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CThen%20why%20did%20you%20thumbprint%20this%20confession%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CThey%20blindfolded%20me%20and%20made%20me%20do%20it.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CEnough%20evidence%E2%80%94I%20ask%20for%20a%20guilty%20verdict%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20prosecutor%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20suspect%E2%80%99s%20defense%20lawyer%20carefully%20explained%20that%20regional%20intelligence%20reports%20showed%20that%20the%20suspect%20had%20been%20mistaken%20for%20someone%20with%20a%20similar%20name.%20In%20terrorism%20trials%2C%20the%20mere%20presence%20of%20a%20private%20defense%20lawyer%20can%20signal%20the%20suspect%E2%80%99s%20likely%20innocence%3B%20most%20lawyers%20refuse%20to%20take%20on%20ambiguous%20cases%2C%20out%20of%20fear%20that%20the%20security%20services%20will%20harass%20them%20for%20perceived%20links%20to%20the%20Islamic%20State.%20(Last%20year%2C%20Iraqi%20courts%20issued%20arrest%20warrants%20for%20at%20least%20fifteen%20defense%20lawyers%20and%20charged%20them%20with%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20affiliation.)%20But%2C%20as%20the%20lawyer%20spoke%2C%20the%20judges%20tended%20to%20administrative%20tasks.%20The%20trial%20was%20over%20in%20nine%20minutes.%20%E2%80%9CI%20hate%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%E2%80%94they%20blew%20up%20my%20house!%E2%80%9D%20the%20suspect%20shouted%2C%20in%20tears%2C%20as%20he%20was%20led%20out%20of%20court.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inline-ad%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253Eadvertisement%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EBy%20noon%2C%20Sahar%20had%20presided%20over%20ten%20trials%2C%20involving%20twenty%20suspects.%20The%20courtroom%20lost%20power%20twice%2C%20but%20Sahar%20kept%20going%20in%20the%20dark%2C%20skimming%20documents%20by%20the%20light%20of%20his%20cell%20phone.%20The%20final%20case%20before%20lunch%20involved%20three%20defendants%2C%20all%20badly%20injured.%20As%20they%20limped%20into%20the%20courtroom%2C%20a%20security%20officer%20put%20three%20plastic%20chairs%20in%20the%20cage.%20The%20last%20suspect%20to%20appear%20was%20a%20bald%2C%20bespectacled%20man%20in%20his%20mid-thirties%2C%20named%20Louai%3B%20he%20was%20hunched%20over%20a%20pair%20of%20short%20wooden%20crutches%2C%20and%20moved%20as%20if%20one%20of%20his%20legs%20were%20paralyzed%20and%20his%20vertebrae%20were%20no%20longer%20aligned.%20Courtroom%202%20was%20silent%2C%20except%20for%20the%20sounds%20of%20him%20struggling%20toward%20the%20cage.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522feature-medium%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c104b521b07900f29567d0a%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c104b521b07900f29567d0a%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104b521b07900f29567d0a%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104b521b07900f29567d0a%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3ESahar%20questioned%20the%20other%20suspects%20first.%20One%2C%20named%20Haidar%2C%20who%20wore%20a%20back%20brace%2C%20said%20that%20he%20had%20been%20mistakenly%20arrested%20for%20a%20car-bomb%20attack%2C%20in%202014%2C%20and%20that%20in%20the%20course%20of%20an%20interrogation%2C%20to%20make%20the%20torture%20stop%2C%20he%20had%20started%20naming%20random%20people%2C%20including%20Louai.%20Judge%20Sahar%20then%20called%20upon%20Louai%2C%20who%20rose%20from%20his%20chair%20and%20gripped%20the%20cage%20to%20support%20himself.%20%E2%80%9CI%20went%20to%20sell%20my%20car%20in%20the%20market%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThen%20Haidar%20called%20me%2C%20and%20I%20was%20ambushed%2C%20arrested.%E2%80%9D%20He%20spoke%20in%20an%20urgent%2C%20high-pitched%20tone%2C%20but%20he%20stuttered%20and%20slurred%20his%20words%3B%20during%20interrogations%2C%20he%20said%2C%20officers%20had%20beaten%20him%20so%20badly%20that%20he%20suffered%20a%20blood%20clot%20in%20his%20brain.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20also%20broke%20my%20back!%E2%80%9D%20he%20shouted.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20broke%20my%20feet%20and%20hands!%20I%20can%20barely%20walk!%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CEnough%20evidence%E2%80%94I%20ask%20for%20a%20guilty%20verdict%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20prosecutor%20said.%20It%20was%20the%20only%20phrase%20she%20uttered%20in%20court%20that%20morning.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHaidar%E2%80%99s%20lawyer%20noted%20that%20there%20was%20no%20witness%20and%20no%20material%20evidence%2C%20and%20that%20his%20request%20for%20a%20medical%20examination%2C%20to%20prove%20that%20Haidar%20had%20been%20tortured%2C%20had%20been%20rejected.%20Louai%E2%80%99s%20lawyer%20explained%20that%20Louai%E2%80%99s%20confession%20had%20been%20coerced%20and%20made%20no%20sense%3A%20he%20had%20said%20that%20he%20remotely%20detonated%20the%20car%20bomb%2C%20when%2C%20in%20fact%2C%20the%20police%20had%20concluded%20that%20it%20was%20a%20suicide%20attack.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ELouai%20had%20spent%20four%20years%20in%20pretrial%20detention%2C%20and%2C%20during%20the%20two%20or%20three%20minutes%20allotted%20to%20his%20defense%2C%20the%20judges%20had%20been%20talking%20among%20themselves.%20%E2%80%9CI%20haven%E2%80%99t%20seen%20a%20judge%20until%20now!%E2%80%9D%20he%20shouted.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CTake%20them%20out%2C%E2%80%9D%20Sahar%20said.%20A%20security%20officer%20opened%20the%20cage.%20It%20took%20Louai%20nearly%20two%20minutes%20to%20limp%20to%20the%20door.%20Sahar%20took%20a%20lunch%20break%2C%20then%20ordered%20his%20execution.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","A September morning in Baghdad. Traffic halted at checkpoints and roadblocks as bureaucrats filed behind blast walls and the temperature climbed to a hundred and fifteen degrees. At the Central Criminal Court, a guard ran his baton along the bars of a small cell holding dozens of terrorism suspects awaiting trial. They were crammed on a wooden bench and on the floor, a sweaty tangle of limbs and dejected expressions. Many were sick or injured—covered in scabies, their joints twisted and their bones cracked. Iraqi prisons have a uniform code—different colors for pretrial suspects, convicts, and those on death row—but several who had not yet seen a judge or a lawyer were already dressed as if they had been sentenced to death."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-right%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Chr%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%3Cem%3EThis%20piece%20was%20supported%20by%20the%20Pulitzer%20Center.%3C%2Fem%3E%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Chr%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["hr"],["p",["em","This piece was supported by the Pulitzer Center."]],["hr"]],["p","Down the hall, the aroma of Nescafé and cigarettes filled a windowless room, where defense lawyers sat on couches, balancing stacks of paper on their laps. Most were staring at their phones; others sat in silence, arms crossed, eyes closed. In terrorism cases, lawyers are usually denied access to their clients until the hearing begins."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inline-ad%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["p","advertisement"]],["p","Shortly after ten o’clock, three judges in long black robes shuffled into Courtroom 2 and sat at the bench. Suhail Abdullah Sahar, a bald, middle-aged man with a thin, jowly face, sat in the center. There were twenty-one cases on his docket that day, sixteen related to terrorism. He quietly read out a name; a security officer shouted it down the hall to one of his colleagues, who shouted it to the guard, who shouted it into the cell. Out came a young man named Ahmed. A security officer led him to a wooden cage in the middle of the courtroom. Judge Sahar accused him of having joined ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," in Qayyarah, a small town south of Mosul."],["p","“Sir, I swear, I have never been to Qayyarah,” Ahmed said."],["p","Sahar was skeptical. “I have a written confession here, with your thumbprint on it,” he said."],["p","“Sir, I swear, I gave my thumbprint on a blank paper,” Ahmed replied. “And I was tortured by the security services.” Sahar listed Ahmed’s supposed jihadi associates; Ahmed denied knowing any of them."],["p","“Enough evidence,” the prosecutor said. “I ask for a guilty verdict.”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cneembed%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cneembed%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522script%252Fvideo%252F5c1149cc8c1abc0c48000006.js%253Fautoplay%253D0%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253E%253Cstrong%253EWatch%2520%25E2%2580%259CThe%2520Backstory%25E2%2580%259D%253A%253C%252Fstrong%253E%255CnBen%2520Taub%2520on%2520the%2520future%2520of%2520Iraq%252C%2520following%2520the%2520Islamic%2520State%25E2%2580%2599s%2520defeat%2520in%2520Mosul.%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cneembed","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cneembed%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22script%2Fvideo%2F5c1149cc8c1abc0c48000006.js%3Fautoplay%3D0%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%3Cp%3E%3Cstrong%3EWatch%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Backstory%E2%80%9D%3A%3C%2Fstrong%3E%5CnBen%20Taub%20on%20the%20future%20of%20Iraq%2C%20following%20the%20Islamic%20State%E2%80%99s%20defeat%20in%20Mosul.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""}]],["p","Ahmed had no lawyer, and so Sahar called upon an elderly state attorney named Hussein, who was seated in the gallery, to spontaneously craft a defense. Hussein walked over to a lectern, repeated from memory what Ahmed had said, and, without requesting his release, concluded with a plea for “mercy in his sentencing.”"],["p","Ahmed wept as he was led out of the room. His trial had lasted four and a half minutes."],["p","The next suspect insisted that he had been arrested by mistake—that his name was similar to that of someone in ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],". A private defense lawyer explained that his client had confessed to ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," affiliation under torture—he had a medical examination to prove it—but none of the judges appeared to be listening. As the lawyer spoke, they cracked jokes, signed documents, and beckoned their assistants to collect folders from the bench. Sahar yawned. The trial lasted eight minutes."],["p","The third suspect was a twenty-three-year-old from a village near Mosul, charged with ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," affiliation and arrested while in a displaced-persons camp."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c12cc9b2eb5b760bfa5e878%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cc9b2eb5b760bfa5e878%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c12cc9b2eb5b760bfa5e878%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c12cc9b2eb5b760bfa5e878"}]],["p","“When did you join ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],"?” Sahar asked."],["p","“I didn’t join,” the suspect replied."],["p","“Then why did you thumbprint this confession?”"],["p","“They blindfolded me and made me do it.”"],["p","“Enough evidence—I ask for a guilty verdict,” the prosecutor said."],["p","The suspect’s defense lawyer carefully explained that regional intelligence reports showed that the suspect had been mistaken for someone with a similar name. In terrorism trials, the mere presence of a private defense lawyer can signal the suspect’s likely innocence; most lawyers refuse to take on ambiguous cases, out of fear that the security services will harass them for perceived links to the Islamic State. (Last year, Iraqi courts issued arrest warrants for at least fifteen defense lawyers and charged them with ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," affiliation.) But, as the lawyer spoke, the judges tended to administrative tasks. The trial was over in nine minutes. “I hate ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],"—they blew up my house!” the suspect shouted, in tears, as he was led out of court."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inline-ad%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["p","advertisement"]],["p","By noon, Sahar had presided over ten trials, involving twenty suspects. The courtroom lost power twice, but Sahar kept going in the dark, skimming documents by the light of his cell phone. The final case before lunch involved three defendants, all badly injured. As they limped into the courtroom, a security officer put three plastic chairs in the cage. The last suspect to appear was a bald, bespectacled man in his mid-thirties, named Louai; he was hunched over a pair of short wooden crutches, and moved as if one of his legs were paralyzed and his vertebrae were no longer aligned. Courtroom 2 was silent, except for the sounds of him struggling toward the cage."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-medium%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104b521b07900f29567d0a%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104b521b07900f29567d0a%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c104b521b07900f29567d0a%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c104b521b07900f29567d0a"}]],["p","Sahar questioned the other suspects first. One, named Haidar, who wore a back brace, said that he had been mistakenly arrested for a car-bomb attack, in 2014, and that in the course of an interrogation, to make the torture stop, he had started naming random people, including Louai. Judge Sahar then called upon Louai, who rose from his chair and gripped the cage to support himself. “I went to sell my car in the market,” he said. “Then Haidar called me, and I was ambushed, arrested.” He spoke in an urgent, high-pitched tone, but he stuttered and slurred his words; during interrogations, he said, officers had beaten him so badly that he suffered a blood clot in his brain. “They also broke my back!” he shouted. “They broke my feet and hands! I can barely walk!”"],["p","“Enough evidence—I ask for a guilty verdict,” the prosecutor said. It was the only phrase she uttered in court that morning."],["p","Haidar’s lawyer noted that there was no witness and no material evidence, and that his request for a medical examination, to prove that Haidar had been tortured, had been rejected. Louai’s lawyer explained that Louai’s confession had been coerced and made no sense: he had said that he remotely detonated the car bomb, when, in fact, the police had concluded that it was a suicide attack."],["p","Louai had spent four years in pretrial detention, and, during the two or three minutes allotted to his defense, the judges had been talking among themselves. “I haven’t seen a judge until now!” he shouted."],["p","“Take them out,” Sahar said. A security officer opened the cage. It took Louai nearly two minutes to limp to the door. Sahar took a lunch break, then ordered his execution."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20Islamic%20State%20has%20been%20mostly%20destroyed%20on%20the%20battlefield%2C%20but%20the%20war%20is%20far%20from%20over.%20Air%20strikes%20cannot%20kill%20an%20idea%2C%20and%20so%20it%20has%20fallen%20to%20Iraq%E2%80%99s%20fractured%20security%2C%20intelligence%2C%20and%20justice%20systems%20to%20try%20to%20finish%20the%20task.%20But%2C%20insofar%20as%20there%20is%20a%20strategy%2C%20it%20seems%20almost%20perfectly%20crafted%20to%20bring%20about%20the%20opposite%20of%20its%20intent.%20American%20and%20Iraqi%20military%20officials%20spent%20years%20planning%20the%20campaign%20to%20rid%20Iraq%20of%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20as%20if%20the%20absence%20of%20the%20jihadis%20would%20automatically%20lead%20Iraq%20toward%20the%20bright%20democratic%20future%20that%20George%C2%A0W.%20Bush%E2%80%99s%20Administration%20had%20envisaged%20when%20U.S.%20forces%20invaded%20the%20country%2C%20in%202003.%20But%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20has%20always%20derived%20much%20of%20its%20dangerous%20appeal%20from%20the%20corruption%20and%20cruelty%20of%20the%20Iraqi%20state.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inline-ad%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253Eadvertisement%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EFor%20three%20years%2C%20the%20Islamic%20State%20controlled%20half%20of%20Syria%20and%20a%20third%20of%20Iraq%2C%20a%20swath%20of%20territory%20approximately%20the%20size%20of%20Great%20Britain%2C%20which%20included%20millions%20of%20people.%20Several%20members%20of%20its%20senior%20leadership%20had%20been%20high-level%20military%20and%20intelligence%20officers%20in%20Saddam%20Hussein%E2%80%99s%20Baathist%20regime%3B%20they%20combined%20the%20structural%20prowess%20of%20a%20police%20state%20with%20the%20cosmic%20certainty%20of%20radical%20jihadism.%20The%20group%20blew%20up%20mosques%20and%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fnews%2Fdaily-comment%2Fisis-and-the-destruction-of-history%5C%22%3Eancient%20archeological%20sites%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20and%20pursued%20a%20campaign%20of%20ethnic%20cleansing%20through%20mass%20murder%20and%20sexual%20slavery.%20It%20conscripted%20local%20bureaucrats%2C%20doctors%2C%20and%20teachers%2C%20often%20on%20pain%20of%20death%2C%20and%20devoted%20enormous%20effort%20to%20radicalizing%20a%20generation%20of%20children%20and%20inuring%20them%20to%20violence%2C%20suffering%2C%20and%20loss.%20At%20the%20height%20of%20its%20success%2C%20in%202014%2C%20there%20was%20a%20real%20possibility%20that%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20would%20capture%20Baghdad%2C%20and%20the%20Iraqi%20state%20would%20collapse.%20Now%2C%20more%20than%20a%20year%20after%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2017%2F02%2F06%2Fthe-desperate-battle-to-destroy-isis%5C%22%3E%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20lost%20Mosul%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%94its%20largest%20source%20of%20legitimacy%2C%20wealth%2C%20and%20power%E2%80%94hundreds%20of%20thousands%20of%20civilians%20are%20suffering%20at%20the%20hands%20of%20their%20liberators.%20Anyone%20with%20a%20perceived%20connection%20to%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20however%20tenuous%20or%20unclear%2C%20is%20being%20killed%20or%20cast%20out%20of%20society.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522feature-medium%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c104b61c5aa777fdb411e61%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c104b61c5aa777fdb411e61%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104b61c5aa777fdb411e61%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104b61c5aa777fdb411e61%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3ENot%20long%20ago%2C%20I%20met%20with%20a%20senior%20Iraqi%20intelligence%20official%20who%20is%20deeply%20involved%20in%20counterterrorism%20operations.%20For%20three%20hours%2C%20over%20tea%20and%20cigarettes%2C%20he%20described%20systematic%20criminality%20within%20the%20security%20forces%2C%20detailing%20patterns%20of%20battlefield%20executions%2C%20murders%20in%20detention%20centers%2C%20and%20coverups%20organized%20by%20the%20state.%20He%20spoke%20as%20a%20witness%2C%20but%20also%20as%20a%20participant%3B%20although%20he%20is%20in%20a%20position%20to%20have%20stopped%20certain%20abuses%2C%20by%20intervening%20he%20would%20have%20risked%20incurring%20accusations%20that%20he%20is%20sympathetic%20to%20the%20group%20he%20has%20sought%20to%20destroy.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHe%20believes%20that%20the%20Iraqi%20government%E2%80%99s%20response%20is%20as%20much%20a%20tactical%20blunder%20as%20it%20is%20a%20moral%20one%3B%20it%20plays%20directly%20into%20the%20jihadis%E2%80%99%20narrative%E2%80%94that%20Sunnis%2C%20who%20make%20up%20a%20minority%20of%20the%20Iraqi%20population%2C%20cannot%20live%20safely%20under%20a%20government%20dominated%20by%20Shiites.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20reaction%20is%20one%20of%20vengeance%E2%80%94it%20is%20not%20well%20thought%20out%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20rarely%20abide%20by%20the%20law.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThousands%20of%20men%20and%20boys%20have%20been%20convicted%20of%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20affiliation%2C%20and%20hundreds%20have%20been%20hanged.%20But%2C%20according%20to%20the%20senior%20intelligence%20official%2C%20these%20cases%20represent%20only%20a%20small%20fraction%20of%20the%20total%20number%20of%20detainees.%20%E2%80%9CA%20few%20of%20the%20suspects%20are%20sent%20to%20court%2C%20but%20only%20to%20maintain%20the%20illusion%20that%20we%20have%20a%20justice%20system%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESuspects%20are%20tried%20under%20a%20law%20that%20makes%20no%20distinction%20between%20a%20person%20who%20%E2%80%9Cassists%20terrorists%E2%80%9D%20and%20one%20who%20commits%20violent%20crimes%20on%20behalf%20of%20an%20extremist%20group.%20The%20conviction%20rate%20is%20around%20ninety-eight%20per%20cent.%20Family%20members%20of%20the%20accused%20rarely%20show%20up%20to%20watch%20the%20hearings%2C%20out%20of%20fear%20that%20they%20will%20be%20detained%2C%20too.%20It%E2%80%99s%20not%20uncommon%20for%20relatives%20to%20be%20rounded%20up%20by%20the%20security%20forces%20and%20sent%20to%20remote%20desert%20camps%2C%20where%20they%20are%20denied%20food%2C%20medical%20services%2C%20and%20access%20to%20documents.%20%E2%80%9CWe%E2%80%99re%20deleting%20thousands%20of%20families%20from%20Iraqi%20society%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20official%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CThis%20is%20not%20just%20revenge%20on%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E.%20This%20is%20revenge%20on%20Sunnis.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inline-ad%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253Eadvertisement%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cp%3E
