sins%20had%20been%20recruited%2C%20but%20no%20one%20in%20his%20immediate%20family%20had%20joined.%20Nevertheless%2C%20when%20Kurdish%20forces%20liberated%20his%20town%2C%20intelligence%20officers%20detained%20Ahmad%20and%20tortured%20him%20until%20he%20made%20a%20false%20confession.%20He%20lifted%20his%20shirt%20to%20reveal%20faint%20lines%20all%20over%20his%20back%2C%20from%20whipping%20and%20beating%2C%20and%20a%20twisted%20knot%20of%20a%20scar%20on%20his%20upper%20arm.%20At%20this%20point%2C%20Kurdish%20prison%20workers%20said%20that%20the%20interview%20was%20over.%20%E2%80%9CI%20showed%20the%20judge%20that%20I%20had%20been%20tortured%2C%E2%80%9D%20Ahmad%20continued.%20But%20the%20judge%20told%20him%20that%20an%20unnamed%20witness%20had%20claimed%20he%20had%20carried%20a%20gun%2C%20and%20sentenced%20him%20to%20five%20years.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Suspects who survived their capture were taken to detention facilities in and around Mosul. Iraqi law stipulates that suspects must be brought before an investigative judge within twenty-four hours of arrest, but many people languished in custody for months. Although there were only around eight thousand ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," fighters living in Mosul, and far fewer in the surrounding villages, the lists of wanted people grew to some hundred thousand names. Dank, windowless cells held a hundred or more detainees each. Some facilities had no budget for food. Injuries that had been incurred on the battlefield, or during interrogation sessions, grew infected and gangrenous. Amputations were common, and detainees routinely died of suffocation or disease."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-xsmall%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c12cc9a2eb5b760bfa5e876%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cc9a2eb5b760bfa5e876%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c12cc9a2eb5b760bfa5e876%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c12cc9a2eb5b760bfa5e876"}]],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inline-ad%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["p","advertisement"]],["p","“Hundreds of innocent people have been detained because their names are similar to those of wanted people, and the state is doing nothing to solve this,” the senior Iraqi intelligence official told me. (Mohammad is thought to be the most common name in the world.) Others are held on the basis of uncontrollable facts of identity: the suspect was a Sunni male of fighting age, from a village where the jihadis enjoyed widespread toleration or support; the suspect was the wife, father, brother, or cousin of a fighter; the suspect was a member of a rural tribe whose leader had pledged fealty to Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. If someone is found innocent and released, no letter is sent to the entire security establishment to clear his name. “He might be arrested again, and this time not get released,” the official said."],["p","In late August, I met a seventeen-year-old ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," fighter inside a facility in Iraqi Kurdistan that is holding dozens of minors who have been convicted of ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],"-related crimes. His name was Noor, and, along with another teen-ager, named Ahmad, he volunteered for an interview. In April, 2016, when Noor was fourteen, one of his friends recruited him to attend an ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," training camp. He wouldn’t specify what attracted him to the Islamic State, saying only, “If there was something I didn’t like about the group, I would not have joined.” That October, he was captured by Kurdish forces near the town of Bashiqa, dressed like a member of ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],", with long sleeves and pants stopping above the ankles, and carrying a Kalashnikov. Noor was the only jihadi in his family—he told me that he had joined ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," without his parents’ knowledge or permission—but, last year, members of a Hashd group arrested his relatives, expropriated their home and property, and sent them to detention camps."],["p","As Noor spoke, Ahmad looked uncomfortable. He said that he wanted to talk, but not with Noor in the room. A prison worker escorted Noor back to his cell."],["p","“I’ve been here for two years and eight months, trapped with all these jihadi kids!” Ahmad said in a rush. “But I’m not ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],"! They picked me up by mistake!” One of his cousins had been recruited, but no one in his immediate family had joined. Nevertheless, when Kurdish forces liberated his town, intelligence officers detained Ahmad and tortured him until he made a false confession. He lifted his shirt to reveal faint lines all over his back, from whipping and beating, and a twisted knot of a scar on his upper arm. At this point, Kurdish prison workers said that the interview was over. “I showed the judge that I had been tortured,” Ahmad continued. But the judge told him that an unnamed witness had claimed he had carried a gun, and sentenced him to five years."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20pace%20of%20arrests%20has%20recently%20slowed.%20In%20Mosul%2C%20there%20are%20now%20only%20two%20or%20three%20raids%20per%20week.%20Most%20of%20them%20are%20carried%20out%20by%20an%20Iraqi%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ESWAT%3C%2Fem%3E%20team%2C%20with%20assistance%20from%20the%20United%20States%20military%2C%20which%20provides%20intelligence%E2%80%94names%2C%20addresses%2C%20sometimes%20a%20photograph%E2%80%94as%20well%20as%20vehicles%2C%20arms%2C%20and%20air%20support.%20In%20return%2C%20American%20soldiers%20are%20given%20access%20to%20detention%20facilities%2C%20to%20collect%20the%20fingerprints%20and%20eye%20scans%20of%20high-value%20targets.%20Sometimes%20they%20take%20suspects%20away%2C%20returning%20them%20days%20or%20weeks%20later%2C%20when%20they%E2%80%99ve%20finished%20their%20own%20interrogations.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20most%20powerful%20Shiite%20paramilitary%20units%20have%20a%20similar%20relationship%20with%20the%20Iranian%20Revolutionary%20Guard.%20Security%20and%20intelligence%20officers%20from%20the%20Hashd%20still%20patrol%20the%20ruins%20of%20the%20Old%20City%2C%20occasionally%20making%20arrests.%20On%20August%2030th%2C%20a%20group%20of%20them%2C%20dressed%20in%20plain%20clothes%2C%20detained%20me%20in%20front%20of%20the%20ruins%20of%20Thenoon%20Younnes%20Abdullah%E2%80%99s%20home%2C%20and%20questioned%20me%20for%20three%20hours.%20They%20photographed%20my%20face%2C%20passport%2C%20and%20Iraqi%20visa%2C%20and%20the%20commander%2C%20a%20wide-faced%20man%20who%20goes%20by%20Abu%20Ali%2C%20warned%20that%20I%20would%20be%20arrested%20if%20I%20returned%20to%20the%20Old%20City.%20Then%20two%20Hashd%20intelligence%20officers%20grabbed%20their%20Kalashnikovs%2C%20got%20into%20my%20car%2C%20and%2C%20with%20a%20follow%20vehicle%2C%20escorted%20me%20across%20the%20bridge%20to%20East%20Mosul.%20During%20the%20drive%2C%20the%20two%20men%20showed%20me%20cell-phone%20photos%20and%20videos%20of%20supposed%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20fighters%20they%20had%20killed%20all%20over%20Iraq.%20I%20asked%20whether%20their%20unit%20shares%20intelligence%20with%2C%20or%20receives%20it%20from%2C%20any%20foreign%20governments.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20refuse%20to%20talk%20about%20this%2C%E2%80%9D%20one%20of%20them%2C%20who%20was%20wearing%20bluejeans%20and%20a%20Gucci%20baseball%20cap%2C%20said.%20%E2%80%9CBecause%20America%20is%20not%20friendly%20with%20Iran.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inline-ad%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253Eadvertisement%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EPretrial%20detention%20can%20last%20years%2C%20and%20even%20if%20detainees%20don%E2%80%99t%20die%20from%20the%20conditions%20they%20may%20still%20never%20see%20the%20inside%20of%20a%20courtroom.%20Thousands%20of%20files%20have%20been%20misplaced%20within%20the%20bureaucracy%2C%20as%20detainees%20have%20been%20transferred%20among%20sites%20run%20by%20overlapping%20security%20agencies%E2%80%94meaning%20that%2C%20on%20paper%2C%20the%20suspects%20are%20missing.%20%E2%80%9CHundreds%20more%20have%20been%20killed%20during%20interrogations%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20senior%20Iraqi%20intelligence%20official%20told%20me.%20Ministry%20of%20Health%20officials%2C%20he%20said%2C%20usually%20classify%20the%20cause%20of%20death%20as%20%E2%80%9Cunknown%E2%80%9D%20or%20%E2%80%9Cheart%20attack%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20then%20dispose%20of%20the%20corpse.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20process%20is%20so%20corrupt%20that%2C%20according%20to%20the%20official%2C%20%E2%80%9Conly%20the%20poor%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20members%20go%20to%20court.%20The%20wealthy%20ones%20can%20buy%20their%20way%20out%20of%20the%20system.%E2%80%9D%20Unable%20to%20trust%20their%20colleagues%20in%20other%20departments%20not%20to%20release%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20members%2C%20some%20intelligence%20officers%20have%20resorted%20to%20murdering%20high-value%20detainees.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522cartoon%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522cartoon%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fcartoon%25252F5c12cc9aede0f93942f07859%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c12cc9aede0f93942f07859%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c12cc9aede0f93942f07859%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cc9aede0f93942f07859%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3ENot%20long%20ago%2C%20the%20senior%20intelligence%20official%20looked%20on%20as%20a%20group%20of%20his%20subordinates%20beat%20a%20Saudi%20fighter%20with%20iron%20bars%2C%20inside%20an%20ad-hoc%20detention%20center%20near%20Mosul.%20The%20fighter%20taunted%20his%20interrogators%2C%20saying%20that%20if%20he%20recovered%20he%20would%20return%20to%20the%20battlefield%20and%20fight%20them%20again.%20They%20broke%20his%20arms%20and%20legs%2C%20and%20threw%20cinder%20blocks%20onto%20his%20back.%20%E2%80%9CWho%20knows%2C%20exactly%2C%20when%20he%20died%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20official%20said.%20%E2%80%9CBut%20he%20wanted%20to%20become%20a%20martyr%2C%20and%20so%20the%20interrogators%20obliged.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EI%20asked%20him%20whether%20the%20Iraqi%20government%20notifies%20foreign%20embassies%20when%20its%20intelligence%20officers%20kill%20their%20citizens.%20He%20said%20that%20most%20European%20fighters%20are%20referred%20to%20the%20judiciary%20unscathed%2C%20because%20their%20identities%20are%20widely%20known%2C%20and%20their%20fates%20are%20scrutinized%20by%20the%20international%20press.%20%E2%80%9CBut%20most%20of%20the%20Arab%20foreign%20fighters%20do%20not%20make%20it%20to%20court%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20do%20not%20tell%20their%20governments%20what%20happens%20to%20them%2C%20and%20their%20governments%20do%20not%20ask.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The pace of arrests has recently slowed. In Mosul, there are now only two or three raids per week. Most of them are carried out by an Iraqi ",["em",{"class":"small"},"SWAT"]," team, with assistance from the United States military, which provides intelligence—names, addresses, sometimes a photograph—as well as vehicles, arms, and air support. In return, American soldiers are given access to detention facilities, to collect the fingerprints and eye scans of high-value targets. Sometimes they take suspects away, returning them days or weeks later, when they’ve finished their own interrogations."],["p","The most powerful Shiite paramilitary units have a similar relationship with the Iranian Revolutionary Guard. Security and intelligence officers from the Hashd still patrol the ruins of the Old City, occasionally making arrests. On August 30th, a group of them, dressed in plain clothes, detained me in front of the ruins of Thenoon Younnes Abdullah’s home, and questioned me for three hours. They photographed my face, passport, and Iraqi visa, and the commander, a wide-faced man who goes by Abu Ali, warned that I would be arrested if I returned to the Old City. Then two Hashd intelligence officers grabbed their Kalashnikovs, got into my car, and, with a follow vehicle, escorted me across the bridge to East Mosul. During the drive, the two men showed me cell-phone photos and videos of supposed ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," fighters they had killed all over Iraq. I asked whether their unit shares intelligence with, or receives it from, any foreign governments. “We refuse to talk about this,” one of them, who was wearing bluejeans and a Gucci baseball cap, said. “Because America is not friendly with Iran.”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inline-ad%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["p","advertisement"]],["p","Pretrial detention can last years, and even if detainees don’t die from the conditions they may still never see the inside of a courtroom. Thousands of files have been misplaced within the bureaucracy, as detainees have been transferred among sites run by overlapping security agencies—meaning that, on paper, the suspects are missing. “Hundreds more have been killed during interrogations,” the senior Iraqi intelligence official told me. Ministry of Health officials, he said, usually classify the cause of death as “unknown” or “heart attack,” and then dispose of the corpse."],["p","The process is so corrupt that, according to the official, “only the poor ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," members go to court. The wealthy ones can buy their way out of the system.” Unable to trust their colleagues in other departments not to release ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," members, some intelligence officers have resorted to murdering high-value detainees."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c12cc9aede0f93942f07859%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cc9aede0f93942f07859%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c12cc9aede0f93942f07859%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c12cc9aede0f93942f07859"}]],["p","Not long ago, the senior intelligence official looked on as a group of his subordinates beat a Saudi fighter with iron bars, inside an ad-hoc detention center near Mosul. The fighter taunted his interrogators, saying that if he recovered he would return to the battlefield and fight them again. They broke his arms and legs, and threw cinder blocks onto his back. “Who knows, exactly, when he died,” the official said. “But he wanted to become a martyr, and so the interrogators obliged.”"],["p","I asked him whether the Iraqi government notifies foreign embassies when its intelligence officers kill their citizens. He said that most European fighters are referred to the judiciary unscathed, because their identities are widely known, and their fates are scrutinized by the international press. “But most of the Arab foreign fighters do not make it to court,” he said. “We do not tell their governments what happens to them, and their governments do not ask.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EIn%20Baghdad%2C%20the%20relentless%20pace%20of%20trials%20struck%20me%20as%20so%20incongruous%20with%20the%20lack%20of%20evidence%2C%20the%20certainty%20of%20convictions%2C%20and%20the%20severity%20of%20sentences%20that%20I%20began%20to%20wonder%20whether%20judges%20had%20access%20to%20secret%20intelligence%20reports%20that%20they%20weren%E2%80%99t%20sharing%20in%20court.%20One%20evening%2C%20I%20visited%20the%20office%20of%20Munir%20Haddad%2C%20a%20magistrate%20who%20presided%20over%20the%20trial%20of%20Saddam%20Hussein.%20It%20was%20a%20troubled%20proceeding%E2%80%94defense%20lawyers%20were%20assassinated%2C%20and%20the%20Prime%20Minister%20pressured%20judges%20into%20issuing%20a%20death%20sentence%E2%80%94but%2C%20compared%20with%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20trials%2C%20Haddad%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20believe%20the%20process%20was%20reasonably%20transparent.%20Saddam%20had%20lawyers.%20Only%20six%20or%20seven%20people%20were%20executed.%20These%20days%2C%20in%20terrorism%20courts%2C%20at%20least%20twenty-five%20people%20are%20sentenced%20to%20death%20every%20single%20day.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHaddad%20lit%20a%20cigarette%20and%20threw%20his%20legs%20over%20an%20elegant%20wooden%20chair.%20Ali%20Shimari%2C%20a%20handsome%20young%20lawyer%2C%20sat%20next%20to%20him.%20Haddad%20left%20the%20bench%20years%20ago%3B%20he%20and%20Shimari%20now%20work%20as%20a%20team%2C%20defending%20terrorism%20suspects%20whom%20they%20believe%20to%20be%20innocent.%20That%20morning%2C%20Shimari%20had%20sat%20through%20the%20same%20hearings%20that%20I%20had.%20%E2%80%9CEverything%20that%20the%20judge%20saw%2C%20the%20lawyers%20saw%2C%20too%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThere%E2%80%99s%20usually%20no%20evidence%2C%20just%20the%20confession.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EI%20asked%20Shimari%20if%20the%20arbitrary%20nature%20of%20the%20trials%20frustrated%20him.%20%E2%80%9CWhat%20can%20I%20do%3F%E2%80%9D%20he%20replied%2C%20shrugging.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20a%20defense%20lawyer.%20I%20can%E2%80%99t%20tell%20the%20judge%20to%20pay%20attention.%20You%20can%20try%20once%20or%20twice%2C%20but%20it%20has%20no%20effect.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHaddad%20laughed.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20are%20not%20in%20America%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20not%20possible%20to%20argue%20with%20the%20judge%2C%20because%20if%20you%20do%20he%E2%80%99ll%20just%20take%20it%20out%20on%20your%20client.%20As%20a%20lawyer%2C%20you%20just%20have%20to%20accept%20the%20humiliation.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inline-ad%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253Eadvertisement%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EI%20asked%20Haddad%20whether%2C%20as%20a%20former%20judge%20in%20Iraq%E2%80%99s%20highest-profile%20tribunal%2C%20he%20believed%20that%20judges%20see%20their%20role%20as%20meting%20out%20a%20kind%20of%20cosmic%20justice%2C%20even%20if%20the%20truth%20lies%20beyond%20the%20kinds%20of%20evidence%20that%20can%20plausibly%20be%20collected.%20%E2%80%9C%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20has%20so%20many%20victims%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThere%20have%20to%20be%20convictions.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522feature-medium%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c104b8b34e30108b56d7e6f%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c104b8b34e30108b56d7e6f%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104b8b34e30108b56d7e6f%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104b8b34e30108b56d7e6f%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EThaer%20Abd%20Ali%20al-Juboori%2C%20the%20spokesman%20for%20the%20Ministry%20of%20Justice%2C%20told%20me%20much%20the%20same%20thing.%20%E2%80%9CHuman-rights%20groups%20focus%20on%20the%20rights%20of%20suspects%2C%20but%20what%20about%20the%20rights%20of%20the%20victims%20and%20their%20families%3F%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20have%20undergone%20thousands%20of%20terrorist%20attacks.%20There%20is%20immense%20public%20pressure%20on%20the%20judicial%20authorities.%E2%80%9D%20He%20continued%2C%20%E2%80%9C9%2F11%20left%20three%20thousand%20people%20dead.%20The%20whole%20world%20obsessed%20over%20this%20attack.%20We%20cried%20for%20your%20innocent%20deaths.%20But%2C%20here%20in%20Iraq%2C%20we%20have%20had%20a%20terrorist%20death%20toll%20that%20has%20exceeded%20that%20by%20a%20factor%20of%20a%20hundred.%20Where%20is%20the%20sympathy%20that%20we%20have%20shown%20to%20the%20victims%20of%209%2F11%3F%20This%20is%20what%20Iraqis%20are%20upset%20about.%20We%20fight%20terrorists%20every%20day%2C%20on%20behalf%20of%20the%20rest%20of%20the%20world.%20And%20no%20one%20cares%20about%20our%20suffering.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20amount%20of%20time%20that%20convicts%20spend%20on%20the%20waiting%20list%20to%20be%20hanged%20fluctuates%20between%20months%20and%20years%2C%20because%20each%20execution%20order%20requires%20a%20signature%20from%20the%20President%20of%20Iraq.%20Barham%20Salih%2C%20a%20progressive%20Kurd%2C%20who%20was%20imprisoned%20and%20tortured%20by%20Saddam%20Hussein%E2%80%99s%20regime%2C%20assumed%20the%20Presidency%20in%20October.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20the%20past%2C%20Salih%20has%20distinguished%20himself%20through%20his%20opposition%20to%20capital%20punishment.%20In%202002%2C%20when%20he%20was%20Prime%20Minister%20of%20the%20eastern%20part%20of%20Kurdistan%2C%20he%20refused%20to%20sign%20the%20death%20warrant%20for%20an%20unrepentant%20Al%20Qaeda%20sympathizer%20who%20had%20attempted%20to%20kill%20him.%20%E2%80%9CI%20think%20this%20is%20a%20fundamental%20question%20of%20what%20type%20of%20society%20we%20want%2C%E2%80%9D%20Salih%20said%20at%20the%20time.%20%E2%80%9CI%20don%E2%80%99t%20believe%20that%20anyone%2C%20or%20the%20state%2C%20should%20take%20people%E2%80%99s%20lives.%E2%80%9D%20Sixteen%20years%20later%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20not%20clear%20that%20any%20Iraqi%20Presidency%20could%20survive%20such%20a%20stance.%20Throughout%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20period%2C%20in%20the%20aftermath%20of%20terrorist%20attacks%2C%20the%20Iraqi%20government%20has%20carried%20out%20mass%20executions%20in%20order%20to%20mollify%20an%20outraged%20public.%20I%20wrote%20to%20Salih%E2%80%99s%20press%20secretary%2C%20Lukman%20Faily%2C%20several%20times%2C%20to%20ask%20whether%20Salih%20is%20signing%20execution%20orders%2C%20but%20did%20not%20hear%20back.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EExecution%20orders%20are%20carried%20out%20by%20the%20Ministry%20of%20Justice.%20In%202009%2C%20Al%20Qaeda%20operatives%20detonated%20a%20car%20bomb%20outside%20the%20ministry%E2%80%99s%20headquarters%2C%20killing%20thirty-five%20employees.%20Four%20years%20later%2C%20terrorists%20attacked%20the%20replacement%20headquarters.%20%E2%80%9CEvery%20time%20we%20publicized%20an%20execution%2C%20we%20would%20get%20attacked%2C%E2%80%9D%20Juboori%20recalled.%20Afterward%2C%20staffers%20demanded%20to%20be%20moved%20to%20the%20Green%20Zone%20or%20to%20have%20the%20task%20of%20executing%20convicts%20referred%20to%20a%20different%20department.%20But%20after%20a%20few%20days%20they%20gave%20up%20and%20went%20back%20to%20work.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20have%20to%20earn%20a%20living%2C%E2%80%9D%20Juboori%20said.%20Today%2C%20the%20ministry%20occasionally%20publishes%20the%20numbers%20of%20people%20executed%2C%20but%20leaves%20out%20the%20names%3B%20by%20obscuring%20the%20identities%2C%20Juboori%20said%2C%20the%20ministry%20can%20accede%20to%20the%20public%E2%80%99s%20demand%20for%20results%20while%20minimizing%20the%20likelihood%20of%20retaliatory%20attacks.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ETo%20human-rights%20groups%20and%20foreign%20officials%2C%20the%20Ministry%20of%20Justice%E2%80%99s%20opacity%20is%20a%20source%20of%20frustration.%20%E2%80%9COften%20we%20would%20find%20out%20about%20mass%20executions%20by%20reading%20about%20them%20on%20the%20justice%20minister%E2%80%99s%20Facebook%20page%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20European%20diplomat%2C%20who%20spent%20much%20of%20the%20past%20three%20years%20in%20Baghdad%2C%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CThere%20will%20be%20some%20notification%20saying%20that%20they%E2%80%99ve%20killed%20forty-two%20terrorists.%20O.K.%2C%20but%20who%3F%20Of%20which%20nationalities%3F%E2%80%9D%20Juboori%20denied%20that%20this%20was%20the%20case%3B%20after%20a%20foreign%20fighter%20is%20executed%2C%20he%20said%2C%20his%20colleagues%20put%20the%20body%20in%20a%20refrigerated%20chamber%2C%20and%20inform%20the%20relevant%20embassy.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inline-ad%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253Eadvertisement%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20Iraqi%20judiciary%20has%20also%20exposed%20the%20willingness%20of%20Western%20liberal%20democracies%20to%20quietly%20regard%20due%20process%20as%20a%20strategic%20disadvantage.%20During%20the%20battle%20for%20Mosul%2C%20France%20deployed%20%C3%A9lite%20soldiers%20to%20track%20and%20kill%20its%20own%20citizens.%20Some%20five%20thousand%20Europeans%20joined%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20and%2C%20of%20the%20thousand%20or%20more%20who%20have%20returned%20to%20their%20home%20countries%2C%20very%20few%20have%20been%20charged%20with%20crimes%2C%20owing%20to%20the%20near-impossibility%20of%20collecting%20court-level%20evidence%20in%20a%20foreign%20war%20zone.%20European%20intelligence%20agencies%20are%20overwhelmed%3B%20to%20carry%20out%20comprehensive%20surveillance%20on%20a%20single%20target%20requires%20a%20team%20of%20around%20thirty%20people.%20And%20so%20countries%20that%20have%20outlawed%20capital%20punishment%20are%20tacitly%20encouraging%20Iraq%20to%20eliminate%20their%20jihadi%20citizens.%20%E2%80%9CIf%20the%20Iraqi%20government%20were%20just%20rounding%20up%20and%20killing%20Iraqis%20in%20this%20way%2C%20we%20could%20be%20more%20vocal%E2%80%9D%20in%20criticizing%20it%2C%20the%20European%20diplomat%20said.%20%E2%80%9CBut%20we%20don%E2%80%99t%20have%20any%20idea%20what%20to%20do%20about%20our%20own%20citizens.%20There%20is%20no%20policy.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","In Baghdad, the relentless pace of trials struck me as so incongruous with the lack of evidence, the certainty of convictions, and the severity of sentences that I began to wonder whether judges had access to secret intelligence reports that they weren’t sharing in court. One evening, I visited the office of Munir Haddad, a magistrate who presided over the trial of Saddam Hussein. It was a troubled proceeding—defense lawyers were assassinated, and the Prime Minister pressured judges into issuing a death sentence—but, compared with the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," trials, Haddad said, “I believe the process was reasonably transparent. Saddam had lawyers. Only six or seven people were executed. These days, in terrorism courts, at least twenty-five people are sentenced to death every single day.”"],["p","Haddad lit a cigarette and threw his legs over an elegant wooden chair. Ali Shimari, a handsome young lawyer, sat next to him. Haddad left the bench years ago; he and Shimari now work as a team, defending terrorism suspects whom they believe to be innocent. That morning, Shimari had sat through the same hearings that I had. “Everything that the judge saw, the lawyers saw, too,” he said. “There’s usually no evidence, just the confession.”"],["p","I asked Shimari if the arbitrary nature of the trials frustrated him. “What can I do?” he replied, shrugging. “I’m a defense lawyer. I can’t tell the judge to pay attention. You can try once or twice, but it has no effect.”"],["p","Haddad laughed. “We are not in America,” he said. “It’s not possible to argue with the judge, because if you do he’ll just take it out on your client. As a lawyer, you just have to accept the humiliation.”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inline-ad%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["p","advertisement"]],["p","I asked Haddad whether, as a former judge in Iraq’s highest-profile tribunal, he believed that judges see their role as meting out a kind of cosmic justice, even if the truth lies beyond the kinds of evidence that can plausibly be collected. “",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," has so many victims,” he said. “There have to be convictions.”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-medium%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c104b8b34e30108b56d7e6f%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c104b8b34e30108b56d7e6f%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c104b8b34e30108b56d7e6f%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c104b8b34e30108b56d7e6f"}]],["p","Thaer Abd Ali al-Juboori, the spokesman for the Ministry of Justice, told me much the same thing. “Human-rights groups focus on the rights of suspects, but what about the rights of the victims and their families?” he said. “We have undergone thousands of terrorist attacks. There is immense public pressure on the judicial authorities.” He continued, “9/11 left three thousand people dead. The whole world obsessed over this attack. We cried for your innocent deaths. But, here in Iraq, we have had a terrorist death toll that has exceeded that by a factor of a hundred. Where is the sympathy that we have shown to the victims of 9/11? This is what Iraqis are upset about. We fight terrorists every day, on behalf of the rest of the world. And no one cares about our suffering.”"],["p","The amount of time that convicts spend on the waiting list to be hanged fluctuates between months and years, because each execution order requires a signature from the President of Iraq. Barham Salih, a progressive Kurd, who was imprisoned and tortured by Saddam Hussein’s regime, assumed the Presidency in October."],["p","In the past, Salih has distinguished himself through his opposition to capital punishment. In 2002, when he was Prime Minister of the eastern part of Kurdistan, he refused to sign the death warrant for an unrepentant Al Qaeda sympathizer who had attempted to kill him. “I think this is a fundamental question of what type of society we want,” Salih said at the time. “I don’t believe that anyone, or the state, should take people’s lives.” Sixteen years later, it’s not clear that any Iraqi Presidency could survive such a stance. Throughout the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," period, in the aftermath of terrorist attacks, the Iraqi government has carried out mass executions in order to mollify an outraged public. I wrote to Salih’s press secretary, Lukman Faily, several times, to ask whether Salih is signing execution orders, but did not hear back."],["p","Execution orders are carried out by the Ministry of Justice. In 2009, Al Qaeda operatives detonated a car bomb outside the ministry’s headquarters, killing thirty-five employees. Four years later, terrorists attacked the replacement headquarters. “Every time we publicized an execution, we would get attacked,” Juboori recalled. Afterward, staffers demanded to be moved to the Green Zone or to have the task of executing convicts referred to a different department. But after a few days they gave up and went back to work. “We have to earn a living,” Juboori said. Today, the ministry occasionally publishes the numbers of people executed, but leaves out the names; by obscuring the identities, Juboori said, the ministry can accede to the public’s demand for results while minimizing the likelihood of retaliatory attacks."],["p","To human-rights groups and foreign officials, the Ministry of Justice’s opacity is a source of frustration. “Often we would find out about mass executions by reading about them on the justice minister’s Facebook page,” a European diplomat, who spent much of the past three years in Baghdad, told me. “There will be some notification saying that they’ve killed forty-two terrorists. O.K., but who? Of which nationalities?” Juboori denied that this was the case; after a foreign fighter is executed, he said, his colleagues put the body in a refrigerated chamber, and inform the relevant embassy."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inline-ad%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["p","advertisement"]],["p","The Iraqi judiciary has also exposed the willingness of Western liberal democracies to quietly regard due process as a strategic disadvantage. During the battle for Mosul, France deployed élite soldiers to track and kill its own citizens. Some five thousand Europeans joined ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],", and, of the thousand or more who have returned to their home countries, very few have been charged with crimes, owing to the near-impossibility of collecting court-level evidence in a foreign war zone. European intelligence agencies are overwhelmed; to carry out comprehensive surveillance on a single target requires a team of around thirty people. And so countries that have outlawed capital punishment are tacitly encouraging Iraq to eliminate their jihadi citizens. “If the Iraqi government were just rounding up and killing Iraqis in this way, we could be more vocal” in criticizing it, the European diplomat said. “But we don’t have any idea what to do about our own citizens. There is no policy.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EFor%20many%20terrorism%20convicts%2C%20a%20stop%20before%20the%20gallows%20is%20a%20spot%20on%20Iraqi%20state%20television%2C%20as%20participants%20in%20a%20reality%20show%20called%20%E2%80%9CIn%20the%20Grip%20of%20the%20Law.%E2%80%9D%20Prisoners%20explain%20on%20camera%20how%20they%20supposedly%20plotted%20and%20committed%20heinous%20acts%2C%20sometimes%20visiting%20the%20scenes%20of%20their%20crimes.%20They%20also%20renounce%20terrorism%2C%20and%20agree%20that%20they%20deserve%20to%20die.%20One%20afternoon%20in%20September%2C%20the%20host%2C%20Ahmad%20Hassan%2C%20welcomed%20me%20to%20the%20studios%20of%20Al%20Iraqiya%2C%20shook%20my%20hand%2C%20and%20threatened%20to%20sue%20me%20if%20I%20misquoted%20him.%20He%20recalled%20an%20incident%20in%20which%20a%20foreign%20journalist%20had%20quoted%20him%20as%20saying%20%E2%80%9Cjihadis%E2%80%9D%20when%20he%20had%20actually%20said%20%E2%80%9C%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20terrorist%20gangs%E2%80%9D%3B%20in%20the%20days%20after%20publication%2C%20Iraqi%20politicians%20and%20security%20officials%20asked%20him%20why%20he%E2%80%99d%20used%20a%20word%20that%20could%20be%20perceived%20in%20a%20neutral%20light.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522feature-large%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c12cc9aef12204ae0c06031%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c12cc9aef12204ae0c06031%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c12cc9aef12204ae0c06031%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cc9aef12204ae0c06031%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EJust%20off%20the%20set%2C%20a%20director%20was%20working%20on%20an%20upcoming%20episode.%20A%20man%20in%20an%20orange%20jumpsuit%20was%20sobbing%20onscreen.%20The%20director%20spliced%20in%20footage%20from%20an%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20video%2C%20featuring%20a%20mass%20execution.%20%E2%80%9CThis%20is%20Mowafaq%20Ahmad%20Shihab%E2%80%94he%E2%80%99s%20from%20a%20first-class%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20family%2C%E2%80%9D%20Hassan%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CMost%20of%20his%20sons%20worked%20for%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20terrorist%20gangs.%E2%80%9D%20In%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20footage%2C%20a%20masked%20man%20lifted%20a%20pistol%20to%20the%20head%20of%20a%20kneeling%20hostage.%20%E2%80%9CHis%20son%20will%20now%20carry%20out%20an%20execution%20of%20some%20prisoners%2C%E2%80%9D%20Hassan%20said%2C%20as%20the%20footage%20rolled%20on.%20%E2%80%9CAnd%20what%20Mowafaq%20confessed%20in%20the%20investigation%20is%20that%20he%20was%20helping%20his%20son%20execute%20innocent%20citizens.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inline-ad%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253Eadvertisement%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EHe%20pointed%20to%20a%20figure%20in%20the%20crowd.%20%E2%80%9CMowafaq%20is%20in%20the%20background%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20To%20my%20eye%2C%20there%20was%20practically%20no%20resemblance%3A%20the%20man%20in%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20video%20had%20a%20full%20head%20of%20white%20hair%2C%20whereas%20Mowafaq%20was%20mostly%20bald%2C%20and%20what%20hair%20he%20had%20was%20black%2C%20except%20for%20a%20bit%20of%20gray%20in%20his%20beard.%20When%20the%20show%20aired%2C%20two%20weeks%20later%2C%20the%20clip%20was%20blurred%20to%20obscure%20the%20differences.%20But%20there%20was%20still%20an%20inconsistency%20between%20the%20episode%20and%20its%20trailer%3A%20the%20arrows%20for%20Mowafaq%20pointed%20to%20two%20different%20men.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAccording%20to%20Hassan%2C%20the%20show%2C%20which%20airs%20on%20Friday%20evenings%2C%20has%20millions%20of%20viewers.%20%E2%80%9CIn%20the%20Grip%20of%20the%20Law%E2%80%9D%20is%20dependent%20on%20the%20involvement%20of%20the%20legal%20and%20security-intelligence%20establishments%2C%20and%20glorifies%20their%20work.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20the%20only%20program%20in%20this%20country%20that%20increases%20public%20trust%20and%20confidence%20in%20the%20security%20forces%20and%20judicial%20offices%2C%E2%80%9D%20Mujahid%20Aboalhail%2C%20the%20head%20of%20Al%20Iraqiya%2C%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CIt%20passes%20the%20message%20to%20the%20whole%20world%20that%20the%20fate%20of%20these%20terrorists%20is%20in%20the%20grip%20of%20the%20law!%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHassan%20walked%20over%20to%20the%20set%20where%20he%20films%20his%20opening%20statements.%20He%20took%20off%20his%20jacket%20and%20sat%20behind%20a%20large%20wooden%20desk%E2%80%94clear%2C%20except%20for%20a%20single%20lamp.%20Behind%20him%20was%20a%20map%20of%20Baghdad%2C%20decorated%20with%20images%20of%20police%20reports%20and%20mug%20shots%20of%20various%20suspects.%20He%20wore%20a%20white%20shirt%20with%20light-blue%20pinstripes%2C%20a%20deep-red%20tie%2C%20and%20an%20oversized%20watch%3B%20his%20black%20hair%20was%20slicked%20back%2C%20shining%20under%20the%20stage%20lights.%20Hassan%20put%20his%20elbows%20on%20the%20table%20and%20scowled%E2%80%94the%20caricature%20of%20a%20TV%20detective.%20There%20was%20a%20bookshelf%20filled%20with%20evidence%20binders%2C%20but%20they%20were%20empty.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CAsk%20me%20what%20you%20would%20like%20to%20know%2C%E2%80%9D%20Hassan%20said.%20I%20led%20off%20with%20a%20biographical%20question.%20He%20ignored%20it%2C%20unlocked%20his%20phone%2C%20and%20started%20reading%20aloud%20a%20prepared%20statement%2C%20occasionally%20stopping%20in%20the%20middle%20of%20a%20phrase%20in%20order%20to%20catch%20his%20breath.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20idea%20for%20this%20program%20came%20to%20me%20because%20Iraq%20suffered%20many%20terrorist%20attacks%2C%20lots%20of%20vicious%20acts%20of%20bloodshed%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20read.%20%E2%80%9CThis%20program%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20just%20do%20interviews.%20It%20also%20shows%20CCTV%2C%20weapons%2C%20car%20bombs%2C%20explosives%E2%80%94actual%20evidence.%20This%20has%20helped%20maintain%20pressure%20against%20terror%20groups.%20It%20also%20helps%20spread%20awareness%20to%20security%20forces%20about%20how%20terrorist%20groups%20operate.%20It%20also%20gives%20awareness%20to%20the%20citizens%20to%20beware%20terrorist%20tactics%2C%20and%20helps%20citizens%20gain%20confidence%20in%20the%20security-intelligence%20establishment.%E2%80%9D%20He%20paused.%20%E2%80%9CDo%20you%20want%20me%20to%20talk%20about%20how%20I%20pick%20the%20prisoners%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CIs%20that%20in%20the%20statement%3F%E2%80%9D%20I%20asked.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%20have%20written%20a%20set%20of%20responses%20to%20questions%20I%20expect%20you%20to%20ask.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHassan%20insisted%20that%20he%20merely%20offers%20prisoners%20%E2%80%9Ca%20chance%20to%20repent%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20that%20they%20take%20him%20up%20on%20it%20because%20they%20%E2%80%9Cfeel%20regret.%E2%80%9D%20But%20the%20substance%20and%20tone%20of%20their%20confessions%20raise%20questions.%20In%20Mowafaq%E2%80%99s%20episode%2C%20he%20is%20marched%20down%20a%20sealed-off%20street%20in%20Mosul%2C%20handcuffed%20and%20blindfolded%2C%20and%20forced%20to%20kneel%20in%20front%20of%20a%20line%20of%20masked%20members%20of%20the%20security%20forces.%20His%20blindfold%20is%20removed%3B%20they%E2%80%99re%20holding%20automatic%20weapons.%20It%20looks%20like%20the%20lead-up%20to%20a%20street%20execution%E2%80%94the%20director%20used%20a%20split%20screen%20to%20mirror%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20tape%E2%80%94and%2C%20as%20Hassan%20questions%20him%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20not%20at%20all%20clear%20that%20Mowafaq%2C%20who%20has%20already%20been%20sentenced%20to%20death%2C%20knows%20otherwise.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","For many terrorism convicts, a stop before the gallows is a spot on Iraqi state television, as participants in a reality show called “In the Grip of the Law.” Prisoners explain on camera how they supposedly plotted and committed heinous acts, sometimes visiting the scenes of their crimes. They also renounce terrorism, and agree that they deserve to die. One afternoon in September, the host, Ahmad Hassan, welcomed me to the studios of Al Iraqiya, shook my hand, and threatened to sue me if I misquoted him. He recalled an incident in which a foreign journalist had quoted him as saying “jihadis” when he had actually said “",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," terrorist gangs”; in the days after publication, Iraqi politicians and security officials asked him why he’d used a word that could be perceived in a neutral light."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-large%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c12cc9aef12204ae0c06031%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cc9aef12204ae0c06031%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c12cc9aef12204ae0c06031%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c12cc9aef12204ae0c06031"}]],["p","Just off the set, a director was working on an upcoming episode. A man in an orange jumpsuit was sobbing onscreen. The director spliced in footage from an ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," video, featuring a mass execution. “This is Mowafaq Ahmad Shihab—he’s from a first-class ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," family,” Hassan told me. “Most of his sons worked for the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," terrorist gangs.” In the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," footage, a masked man lifted a pistol to the head of a kneeling hostage. “His son will now carry out an execution of some prisoners,” Hassan said, as the footage rolled on. “And what Mowafaq confessed in the investigation is that he was helping his son execute innocent citizens.”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inline-ad%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["p","advertisement"]],["p","He pointed to a figure in the crowd. “Mowafaq is in the background,” he said. To my eye, there was practically no resemblance: the man in the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," video had a full head of white hair, whereas Mowafaq was mostly bald, and what hair he had was black, except for a bit of gray in his beard. When the show aired, two weeks later, the clip was blurred to obscure the differences. But there was still an inconsistency between the episode and its trailer: the arrows for Mowafaq pointed to two different men."],["p","According to Hassan, the show, which airs on Friday evenings, has millions of viewers. “In the Grip of the Law” is dependent on the involvement of the legal and security-intelligence establishments, and glorifies their work. “It’s the only program in this country that increases public trust and confidence in the security forces and judicial offices,” Mujahid Aboalhail, the head of Al Iraqiya, told me. “It passes the message to the whole world that the fate of these terrorists is in the grip of the law!”"],["p","Hassan walked over to the set where he films his opening statements. He took off his jacket and sat behind a large wooden desk—clear, except for a single lamp. Behind him was a map of Baghdad, decorated with images of police reports and mug shots of various suspects. He wore a white shirt with light-blue pinstripes, a deep-red tie, and an oversized watch; his black hair was slicked back, shining under the stage lights. Hassan put his elbows on the table and scowled—the caricature of a TV detective. There was a bookshelf filled with evidence binders, but they were empty."],["p","“Ask me what you would like to know,” Hassan said. I led off with a biographical question. He ignored it, unlocked his phone, and started reading aloud a prepared statement, occasionally stopping in the middle of a phrase in order to catch his breath. “The idea for this program came to me because Iraq suffered many terrorist attacks, lots of vicious acts of bloodshed,” he read. “This program doesn’t just do interviews. It also shows CCTV, weapons, car bombs, explosives—actual evidence. This has helped maintain pressure against terror groups. It also helps spread awareness to security forces about how terrorist groups operate. It also gives awareness to the citizens to beware terrorist tactics, and helps citizens gain confidence in the security-intelligence establishment.” He paused. “Do you want me to talk about how I pick the prisoners?”"],["p","“Is that in the statement?” I asked."],["p","“I have written a set of responses to questions I expect you to ask.”"],["p","Hassan insisted that he merely offers prisoners “a chance to repent,” and that they take him up on it because they “feel regret.” But the substance and tone of their confessions raise questions. In Mowafaq’s episode, he is marched down a sealed-off street in Mosul, handcuffed and blindfolded, and forced to kneel in front of a line of masked members of the security forces. His blindfold is removed; they’re holding automatic weapons. It looks like the lead-up to a street execution—the director used a split screen to mirror the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," tape—and, as Hassan questions him, it’s not at all clear that Mowafaq, who has already been sentenced to death, knows otherwise."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EOn%20July%2010%2C%202017%2C%20a%20twenty-five-year-old%20woman%20from%20Shirqat%2C%20who%20goes%20by%20Umm%20Saleh%2C%20arrived%20at%20a%20camp%20for%20the%20internally%20displaced%2C%20just%20outside%20Qayyarah.%20She%20had%20spent%20the%20previous%20week%20running%20between%20buildings%20in%20Mosul%E2%80%99s%20Old%20City%2C%20where%20an%20air%20strike%20on%20a%20school%20had%20killed%20her%20father%2C%20her%20brothers%2C%20and%20one%20of%20her%20sisters.%20Umm%20Saleh%E2%80%99s%20husband%20survived%20the%20explosion%2C%20but%20amid%20the%20chaos%20the%20couple%20lost%20track%20of%20each%20other%2C%20and%20so%20she%20left%20Mosul%20with%20their%20three%20children%2C%20carrying%20the%20youngest%20in%20her%20arms.%20Members%20of%20the%20Iraqi%20security%20forces%20robbed%20and%20harassed%20Umm%20Saleh%20at%20every%20checkpoint.%20Many%20of%20them%20obscured%20their%20faces%20with%20balaclavas%20and%20masks%2C%20and%20had%20patches%20on%20their%20uniforms%20of%20the%20skull%20worn%20by%20the%20Punisher%2C%20a%20Marvel%20Comics%20antihero%20who%20kidnaps%2C%20extorts%2C%20and%20murders%20people%20in%20the%20pursuit%20of%20his%20own%20conception%20of%20justice%3B%20the%20skull%20is%20the%20last%20thing%20that%20his%20victims%20see%20before%20they%20die.%20%E2%80%9CIf%20the%20Americans%20weren%E2%80%99t%20behind%20us%2C%20we%20would%20burn%20you%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20soldier%20told%20Umm%20Saleh.%20She%20had%20left%20Mosul%20with%20some%20cash%20and%20gold%20but%20arrived%20in%20Qayyarah%20penniless.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EUmm%20Saleh%20expected%20to%20reunite%20there%20with%20her%20husband.%20He%20hadn%E2%80%99t%20joined%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20but%20his%20brothers%20had%20been%20conscripted%20as%20fighters.%20Because%20he%20hadn%E2%80%99t%20denounced%20them%20or%20severed%20ties%2C%20on%20the%20way%20to%20the%20displaced-persons%20camp%20he%20was%20picked%20out%20of%20line%20during%20a%20security%20screening%2C%20and%20taken%20away.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inline-ad%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253Eadvertisement%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EOne%20day%2C%20a%20member%20of%20the%20Iraqi%20security%20forces%20visited%20the%20camp%2C%20promising%20to%20look%20into%20the%20cases%20of%20detainees%2C%20for%20a%20fee%20of%20a%20thousand%20dollars.%20Umm%20Saleh%E2%80%99s%20mother%20and%20sister%20sold%20all%20their%20gold%20to%20pay%20the%20bribe%2C%20and%20Umm%20Saleh%20gave%20him%20her%20husband%E2%80%99s%20name.%20The%20soldier%20took%20the%20money%20and%20never%20came%20back.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAt%20the%20camp%2C%20Umm%20Saleh%20was%20placed%20in%20a%20sector%20populated%20by%20widows%20of%20the%20Islamic%20State%20who%20had%20also%20grown%20up%20in%20Shirqat.%20Because%20Umm%20Saleh%E2%80%99s%20husband%20was%20mistaken%20for%20an%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20fighter%2C%20she%20is%20now%20perceived%20by%20camp%20administrators%20and%20guards%20as%20the%20female%20head%20of%20an%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20family.%20Her%20children%20are%20growing%20up%20fatherless%20and%20isolated%20from%20the%20rest%20of%20society%2C%20unable%20to%20attend%20Iraqi%20schools.%20%E2%80%9CPeople%20look%20at%20us%20differently%2C%E2%80%9D%20another%20woman%20in%20the%20sector%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CEven%20small%20children%20in%20the%20camp%20point%20at%20my%20children%20and%20say%2C%20%E2%80%98%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E!%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E!%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20The%20government%20refuses%20to%20recognize%20or%20replace%20Umm%20Saleh%E2%80%99s%20infant%20son%E2%80%99s%20birth%20certificate%2C%20because%20it%20was%20issued%20by%20the%20Islamic%20State%3B%20as%20with%20tens%20of%20thousands%20of%20other%20Iraqi%20children%2C%20his%20own%20country%20has%20rendered%20him%20effectively%20stateless.%20The%20camp%20is%20now%20Umm%20Saleh%E2%80%99s%20de-facto%20prison%3B%20Iraqi%20security%20forces%20stole%20her%20identity%20card%20at%20a%20checkpoint%2C%20and%20without%20it%20she%20cannot%20leave.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522feature-medium%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c12cc9aef12204ae0c06030%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c12cc9aef12204ae0c06030%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c12cc9aef12204ae0c06030%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cc9aef12204ae0c06030%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EAt%20night%2C%20Umm%20Saleh%20and%20the%20other%20women%20in%20her%20sector%20try%20to%20avoid%20the%20camp%20toilets%2C%20which%20are%20unlit%2C%20to%20minimize%20the%20chances%20of%20being%20raped%20by%20guards.%20Members%20of%20armed%20groups%20routinely%20enter%20the%20camp%20to%20harass%20them%2C%20rob%20them%2C%20assault%20them%2C%20or%20burn%20down%20their%20tents.%20One%20night%2C%20three%20Hashd%20fighters%20raped%20a%20young%20woman%20named%20Amani%20while%20she%20was%20washing%20inside%20her%20tent.%20%E2%80%9COne%20of%20them%20had%20a%20shop%20that%20I%20used%20to%20visit%20in%20Shirqat%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CAnother%20was%20my%20neighbor.%E2%80%9D%20During%20the%20attack%2C%20they%20berated%20her%20for%20her%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20affiliation.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAmani%20was%20abandoned%20at%20birth%2C%20grew%20up%20in%20an%20orphanage%2C%20and%20married%20when%20she%20was%20around%20fourteen.%20Two%20years%20later%2C%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20came%20to%20Shirqat.%20Her%20husband%20joined%2C%20and%20forced%20Amani%20to%20move%20with%20him%20to%20Mosul.%20She%20was%20miserable%3B%20she%20hated%20having%20to%20cover%20her%20face%20in%20public.%20She%20became%20pregnant%2C%20and%20soon%20afterward%20her%20husband%20went%20to%20fight%20in%20the%20Makhoul%20Mountains%2C%20where%20he%20met%20and%20married%20another%20woman.%20A%20few%20months%20later%2C%20he%20fled%20with%20his%20new%20bride%20to%20Syria%2C%20and%20divorced%20Amani%20by%20phone.%20She%20deleted%20his%20number%20and%20escaped%20from%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20territory.%20When%20she%20reached%20Qayyarah%2C%20she%20tried%20to%20legally%20divorce%20her%20husband%2C%20but%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20able%20to%2C%20because%20her%20I.D.%20had%20expired%20and%20her%20husband%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20present.%20The%20Iraqi%20government%20refuses%20to%20issue%20her%20a%20new%20I.D.%2C%20because%20it%20considers%20her%20an%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20wife.%20Without%20documentation%2C%20she%20has%20no%20freedom%20of%20movement%2C%20and%20is%20deprived%20of%20access%20to%20Iraqi%20civil%20services.%20She%20wants%20to%20return%20to%20Shirqat%2C%20but%20fears%20that%2C%20even%20if%20she%20made%20it%20out%20of%20the%20camp%2C%20she%20would%20be%20detained%20or%20killed%20by%20Hashd%20fighters%20or%20by%20her%20former%20neighbors.%20%E2%80%9CI%20have%20not%20seen%20happiness%20at%20any%20moment%20in%20my%20life%2C%E2%80%9D%20Amani%20said%2C%20tears%20streaming%20down%20her%20cheeks.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20another%20sector%2C%20a%20frail%2C%20eighty-two-year-old%20man%20named%20Hellou%20Hamad%2C%20who%20was%20also%20from%20Shirqat%2C%20was%20lying%20on%20a%20filthy%20mattress%2C%20unable%20to%20get%20up.%20He%20had%20been%20sent%20to%20the%20camp%20more%20than%20a%20year%20ago%2C%20because%20three%20of%20his%20sons%20had%20joined%20the%20Islamic%20State.%20%E2%80%9CI%20tried%20to%20stop%20them%2C%20but%20they%20were%20bored%20and%20single%20and%20jobless%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20told%20me.%20The%20surrounding%20tents%20were%20populated%20by%20his%20female%20relatives%20and%20their%20children.%20Many%20kids%20in%20the%20camp%20urinate%20uncontrollably%20in%20the%20night%2C%20as%20a%20result%20of%20the%20trauma%20induced%20by%20the%20war%3B%20among%20the%20women%2C%20there%20are%20high%20rates%20of%20suicide.%20%E2%80%9COur%20houses%20were%20burned%E2%80%94we%20are%20rejected%20by%20our%20community%2C%E2%80%9D%20Hamad%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CI%20am%20the%20only%20man%20in%20this%20block.%20All%20the%20others%20are%20in%20prison%20or%20dead.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","On July 10, 2017, a twenty-five-year-old woman from Shirqat, who goes by Umm Saleh, arrived at a camp for the internally displaced, just outside Qayyarah. She had spent the previous week running between buildings in Mosul’s Old City, where an air strike on a school had killed her father, her brothers, and one of her sisters. Umm Saleh’s husband survived the explosion, but amid the chaos the couple lost track of each other, and so she left Mosul with their three children, carrying the youngest in her arms. Members of the Iraqi security forces robbed and harassed Umm Saleh at every checkpoint. Many of them obscured their faces with balaclavas and masks, and had patches on their uniforms of the skull worn by the Punisher, a Marvel Comics antihero who kidnaps, extorts, and murders people in the pursuit of his own conception of justice; the skull is the last thing that his victims see before they die. “If the Americans weren’t behind us, we would burn you,” a soldier told Umm Saleh. She had left Mosul with some cash and gold but arrived in Qayyarah penniless."],["p","Umm Saleh expected to reunite there with her husband. He hadn’t joined ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],", but his brothers had been conscripted as fighters. Because he hadn’t denounced them or severed ties, on the way to the displaced-persons camp he was picked out of line during a security screening, and taken away."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inline-ad%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["p","advertisement"]],["p","One day, a member of the Iraqi security forces visited the camp, promising to look into the cases of detainees, for a fee of a thousand dollars. Umm Saleh’s mother and sister sold all their gold to pay the bribe, and Umm Saleh gave him her husband’s name. The soldier took the money and never came back."],["p","At the camp, Umm Saleh was placed in a sector populated by widows of the Islamic State who had also grown up in Shirqat. Because Umm Saleh’s husband was mistaken for an ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," fighter, she is now perceived by camp administrators and guards as the female head of an ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," family. Her children are growing up fatherless and isolated from the rest of society, unable to attend Iraqi schools. “People look at us differently,” another woman in the sector told me. “Even small children in the camp point at my children and say, ‘",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],"! ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],"!’ ” The government refuses to recognize or replace Umm Saleh’s infant son’s birth certificate, because it was issued by the Islamic State; as with tens of thousands of other Iraqi children, his own country has rendered him effectively stateless. The camp is now Umm Saleh’s de-facto prison; Iraqi security forces stole her identity card at a checkpoint, and without it she cannot leave."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-medium%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c12cc9aef12204ae0c06030%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12cc9aef12204ae0c06030%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c12cc9aef12204ae0c06030%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c12cc9aef12204ae0c06030"}]],["p","At night, Umm Saleh and the other women in her sector try to avoid the camp toilets, which are unlit, to minimize the chances of being raped by guards. Members of armed groups routinely enter the camp to harass them, rob them, assault them, or burn down their tents. One night, three Hashd fighters raped a young woman named Amani while she was washing inside her tent. “One of them had a shop that I used to visit in Shirqat,” she told me. “Another was my neighbor.” During the attack, they berated her for her ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," affiliation."],["p","Amani was abandoned at birth, grew up in an orphanage, and married when she was around fourteen. Two years later, ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," came to Shirqat. Her husband joined, and forced Amani to move with him to Mosul. She was miserable; she hated having to cover her face in public. She became pregnant, and soon afterward her husband went to fight in the Makhoul Mountains, where he met and married another woman. A few months later, he fled with his new bride to Syria, and divorced Amani by phone. She deleted his number and escaped from ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," territory. When she reached Qayyarah, she tried to legally divorce her husband, but wasn’t able to, because her I.D. had expired and her husband wasn’t present. The Iraqi government refuses to issue her a new I.D., because it considers her an ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," wife. Without documentation, she has no freedom of movement, and is deprived of access to Iraqi civil services. She wants to return to Shirqat, but fears that, even if she made it out of the camp, she would be detained or killed by Hashd fighters or by her former neighbors. “I have not seen happiness at any moment in my life,” Amani said, tears streaming down her cheeks."],["p","In another sector, a frail, eighty-two-year-old man named Hellou Hamad, who was also from Shirqat, was lying on a filthy mattress, unable to get up. He had been sent to the camp more than a year ago, because three of his sons had joined the Islamic State. “I tried to stop them, but they were bored and single and jobless,” he told me. The surrounding tents were populated by his female relatives and their children. Many kids in the camp urinate uncontrollably in the night, as a result of the trauma induced by the war; among the women, there are high rates of suicide. “Our houses were burned—we are rejected by our community,” Hamad told me. “I am the only man in this block. All the others are in prison or dead.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThere%20are%20eight%20camps%20in%20the%20desert%20near%20Qayyarah%2C%20housing%20roughly%20a%20hundred%20and%20fifty%20thousand%20people.%20During%20the%20war%2C%20most%20residents%20were%20people%20who%20had%20been%20displaced%20by%20the%20Islamic%20State.%20But%20now%20the%20proportion%20of%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E-linked%20families%20is%20growing%2C%20as%20those%20who%20are%20unaffiliated%20return%20to%20their%20villages.%20The%20largest%20of%20the%20facilities%20is%20Airstrip%20Camp%2C%20which%20I%20visited%20twice%20in%20late%20August%3B%20between%20my%20visits%2C%20more%20than%20eleven%20hundred%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E-linked%20Iraqi%20men%2C%20women%2C%20and%20children%20arrived%20in%20Qayyarah%20from%20a%20camp%20in%20eastern%20Syria.%20The%20journey%20had%20taken%20two%20days%2C%20and%20the%20Iraqi%20government%20had%20transported%20them%20from%20the%20border%20in%20open%20trucks%2C%20in%20hundred-and-fifteen-degree%20weather%2C%20without%20providing%20food%20or%20water.%20At%20least%20one%20person%20died.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAt%20the%20entrance%20to%20Airstrip%20Camp%2C%20down%20a%20long%2C%20unpaved%20road%2C%20men%20holding%20machine%20guns%20stood%20in%20the%20shade%20of%20a%20cinder-block%20hut%2C%20near%20a%20tattered%20Iraqi%20flag.%20Inside%20were%20tents%20covered%20in%20dust%E2%80%94blue%20canvas%20turned%20a%20deep%20brown%2C%20held%20to%20the%20ground%20with%20rope%20and%20sandbags%20caked%20in%20mud.%20Clotheslines%20and%20gullies%20of%20green%20sewage%20separated%20the%20tents%2C%20and%20the%20camp%E2%80%99s%20razor-wire%20fence%20had%20caught%20thousands%20of%20plastic%20bags%2C%20which%20thrashed%20noisily%20in%20the%20breeze.%20Children%20hauled%20wheelbarrows%20and%20carts%20filled%20with%20water%20jugs%20and%20sacks%20of%20grain.%20On%20the%20horizon%2C%20a%20surveillance%20balloon%20floated%20above%20Qayyarah%E2%80%99s%20air%20base%2C%20from%20which%20the%20U.S.%20military%20had%20staged%20much%20of%20the%20Mosul%20campaign.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inline-ad%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253Eadvertisement%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EOne%20of%20my%20visits%20coincided%20with%20that%20of%20the%20country%20head%20of%20a%20major%20international%20N.G.O.%20%E2%80%9CThis%20is%20set%20up%20like%20a%20concentration%20camp%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said%2C%20gesturing%20at%20the%20fence.%20%E2%80%9CAll%20the%20barbed%20wire%2C%20the%20division%20of%20sectors.%20There%20are%20no%20social%20spaces.%20There%20are%20no%20spaces%20for%20the%20children%20to%20play.%20There%20are%20no%20places%20for%20people%20to%20gather.%20There%E2%80%99s%20one%20entrance%20in%20and%20out.%20And%20have%20you%20seen%20the%20guys%20at%20the%20entrance%3F%20Most%20of%20them%20are%20from%20militias.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThroughout%20Nineveh%20Province%2C%20camp%20administrators%20and%20workers%20routinely%20deprive%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E-linked%20families%20of%20food%2C%20clean%20water%2C%20and%20medical%20services.%20The%20N.G.O.%20country%20director%20told%20me%20that%20he%20had%20travelled%20more%20than%20two%20hundred%20miles%20from%20Baghdad%2C%20%E2%80%9Cto%20make%20sure%20that%20our%20Iraqi%20staff%20are%20not%20falling%20into%20these%20types%20of%20revenge%20attitudes.%E2%80%9D%20He%20added%2C%20%E2%80%9CThey%20say%2C%20%E2%80%98These%20people%20killed%20my%20family%2C%20and%20now%20I%20have%20to%20help%20them%3F%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20In%20some%20camps%2C%20humanitarian%20workers%20offer%20aid%20in%20exchange%20for%20sex.%20Many%20women%20are%20pregnant%20from%20having%20been%20raped%20by%20the%20security%20forces%20or%20from%20having%20sex%20to%20feed%20themselves%20and%20their%20children.%20Although%20the%20fighting%20has%20ended%2C%20%E2%80%9Cthese%20camps%20are%20meant%20to%20stay%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20N.G.O.%20director%20said.%20%E2%80%9CIf%20you%20are%20ten%20years%20old%20now%2C%20and%20you%20have%20no%20food%2C%20no%20assistance%2C%20and%20your%20mother%20has%20to%20prostitute%20herself%20to%20survive%2C%20and%20the%20whole%20of%20Iraqi%20society%20blames%20you%20because%20you%20were%20close%20to%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%E2%80%94in%20two%2C%20three%2C%20four%20years%2C%20what%20are%20you%20going%20to%20do%3F%20It%E2%80%99s%20clear.%20The%20seeds%20for%20the%20next%20conflict%20are%20all%20here.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAt%20a%20police%20compound%20in%20West%20Mosul%2C%20I%20asked%20a%20colonel%20named%20Mezhar%20Sedoon%20whether%20he%20thought%20that%20the%20camps%20are%20creating%20more%20security%20problems%20than%20they%20are%20solving.%20%E2%80%9CSome%20of%20the%20mothers%20in%20the%20camp%20are%20raising%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20children%2C%20but%20others%20have%20become%20prostitutes%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20He%20laughed.%20%E2%80%9CMoney-money%2C%20fucky-fucky!%E2%80%9D%20he%20said%20in%20English.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99d%20rather%20they%20become%20whores%20than%20raise%20terrorists!%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESome%20women%20try%20to%20carry%20out%20abortions%20inside%20their%20tents.%20Others%20give%20birth%2C%20and%20discard%20the%20babies%20in%20unpopulated%20parts%20of%20the%20camp.%20Those%20who%20are%20found%20alive%20often%20end%20up%20in%20the%20care%20of%20Sukaina%20Mohammad%20Ali%20Younnis%2C%20an%20Iraqi%20government%20official%20who%20is%20in%20charge%20of%20women%E2%80%99s%20and%20children%E2%80%99s%20issues%20in%20Mosul.%20Over%20tea%20in%20Erbil%2C%20the%20capital%20of%20Iraqi%20Kurdistan%2C%20she%20showed%20me%20hundreds%20of%20photographs%20of%20children%20she%20has%20found%20in%20camps%2C%20on%20the%20streets%2C%20and%20dead%20in%20trash%20cans.%20Earlier%20this%20year%2C%20she%20saw%20someone%20throw%20a%20bundle%20out%20of%20a%20car%2C%20and%20found%20that%20it%20was%20a%20baby%20boy.%20She%20showed%20me%20a%20video%20of%20herself%20cradling%20him%20in%20the%20back%20of%20an%20ambulance%2C%20as%20blood%20bubbled%20out%20of%20his%20nostrils.%20He%20died%20on%20the%20way%20to%20the%20hospital.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EOutside%20the%20camps%2C%20thousands%20of%20other%20children%20have%20been%20abandoned%20or%20orphaned%20by%20the%20war.%20Many%20of%20them%20were%20born%20to%20Yazidi%20women%20who%20had%20been%20kidnapped%20by%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20and%20forced%20into%20sexual%20slavery.%20%E2%80%9CAfter%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20the%20Yazidis%20accepted%20the%20women%20back%20into%20the%20community%2C%20but%20not%20their%20half-%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20babies%2C%E2%80%9D%20Younnis%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20force%20the%20women%20to%20turn%20over%20their%20children%20to%20the%20orphanage.%20Every%20day%2C%20these%20women%20call%20me%2C%20wanting%20to%20know%20how%20their%20children%20are%20doing.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHundreds%20of%20small%20children%20are%20living%20in%20Iraqi%20prisons.%20Those%20whose%20parents%20were%20foreign%20fighters%20are%20often%20present%20in%20the%20courtroom%20when%20their%20mothers%20are%20sentenced%20to%20death.%20Iraqi%20children%20whom%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20trained%20to%20become%20fighters%20and%20potential%20suicide%20bombers%20are%20imprisoned%2C%20as%20if%20their%20lives%20were%20irredeemable.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20are%20useless%20in%20interrogations%E2%80%94they%20just%20cry%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20senior%20Iraqi%20intelligence%20official%20said.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20are%20holding%20children%20as%20young%20as%20twelve%20in%20cells%20with%20hard-core%20jihadi%20fighters.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThousands%20of%20children%20in%20Mosul%20live%20on%20the%20street%2C%20searching%20through%20the%20trash%20for%20scrap%20to%20sell.%20%E2%80%9CAfter%20their%20parents%20were%20killed%20or%20imprisoned%2C%20their%20relatives%20refused%20to%20take%20them%20in%2C%E2%80%9D%20Younnis%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20are%20seen%20as%20tainted%2C%20even%20if%20they%20were%20too%20young%20to%20absorb%20the%20ideology.%E2%80%9D%20Many%20of%20them%20hang%20out%20in%20traffic%20and%20at%20checkpoints%2C%20choking%20on%20dust%20and%20diesel%2C%20trying%20to%20wipe%20down%20windshields%20or%20sell%20water%20and%20tissues%20to%20passing%20motorists.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20will%20do%20anything%20for%20fifty%20dollars%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CI%20go%20to%20many%20government%20officials%2C%20asking%20to%20find%20ways%20to%20help%20these%20kids%2C%20but%20they%20all%20say%2C%20%E2%80%98It%E2%80%99s%20not%20my%20area%20of%20responsibility.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inline-ad%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cp%253Eadvertisement%253C%252Fp%253E%255Cn%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CThe%20camps%20are%20a%20time%20bomb%2C%E2%80%9D%20Younnis%20continued.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20fathers%20are%20in%20prison%20or%20dead.%20The%20mothers%20are%20being%20raped.%20They%20will%20raise%20the%20kids%20accordingly%2C%20and%20their%20sons%20will%20seek%20revenge.%20This%20won%E2%80%99t%20just%20affect%20Mosul%2C%20or%20Nineveh%2C%20or%20Iraq.%20This%20will%20affect%20the%20whole%20world.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","There are eight camps in the desert near Qayyarah, housing roughly a hundred and fifty thousand people. During the war, most residents were people who had been displaced by the Islamic State. But now the proportion of ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],"-linked families is growing, as those who are unaffiliated return to their villages. The largest of the facilities is Airstrip Camp, which I visited twice in late August; between my visits, more than eleven hundred ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],"-linked Iraqi men, women, and children arrived in Qayyarah from a camp in eastern Syria. The journey had taken two days, and the Iraqi government had transported them from the border in open trucks, in hundred-and-fifteen-degree weather, without providing food or water. At least one person died."],["p","At the entrance to Airstrip Camp, down a long, unpaved road, men holding machine guns stood in the shade of a cinder-block hut, near a tattered Iraqi flag. Inside were tents covered in dust—blue canvas turned a deep brown, held to the ground with rope and sandbags caked in mud. Clotheslines and gullies of green sewage separated the tents, and the camp’s razor-wire fence had caught thousands of plastic bags, which thrashed noisily in the breeze. Children hauled wheelbarrows and carts filled with water jugs and sacks of grain. On the horizon, a surveillance balloon floated above Qayyarah’s air base, from which the U.S. military had staged much of the Mosul campaign."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inline-ad%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["p","advertisement"]],["p","One of my visits coincided with that of the country head of a major international N.G.O. “This is set up like a concentration camp,” he said, gesturing at the fence. “All the barbed wire, the division of sectors. There are no social spaces. There are no spaces for the children to play. There are no places for people to gather. There’s one entrance in and out. And have you seen the guys at the entrance? Most of them are from militias.”"],["p","Throughout Nineveh Province, camp administrators and workers routinely deprive ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],"-linked families of food, clean water, and medical services. The N.G.O. country director told me that he had travelled more than two hundred miles from Baghdad, “to make sure that our Iraqi staff are not falling into these types of revenge attitudes.” He added, “They say, ‘These people killed my family, and now I have to help them?’ ” In some camps, humanitarian workers offer aid in exchange for sex. Many women are pregnant from having been raped by the security forces or from having sex to feed themselves and their children. Although the fighting has ended, “these camps are meant to stay,” the N.G.O. director said. “If you are ten years old now, and you have no food, no assistance, and your mother has to prostitute herself to survive, and the whole of Iraqi society blames you because you were close to ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],"—in two, three, four years, what are you going to do? It’s clear. The seeds for the next conflict are all here.”"],["p","At a police compound in West Mosul, I asked a colonel named Mezhar Sedoon whether he thought that the camps are creating more security problems than they are solving. “Some of the mothers in the camp are raising ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," children, but others have become prostitutes,” he said. He laughed. “Money-money, fucky-fucky!” he said in English. “I’d rather they become whores than raise terrorists!”"],["p","Some women try to carry out abortions inside their tents. Others give birth, and discard the babies in unpopulated parts of the camp.
