Those who are found alive often end up in the care of Sukaina Mohammad Ali Younnis, an Iraqi government official who is in charge of women’s and children’s issues in Mosul. Over tea in Erbil, the capital of Iraqi Kurdistan, she showed me hundreds of photographs of children she has found in camps, on the streets, and dead in trash cans. Earlier this year, she saw someone throw a bundle out of a car, and found that it was a baby boy. She showed me a video of herself cradling him in the back of an ambulance, as blood bubbled out of his nostrils. He died on the way to the hospital."],["p","Outside the camps, thousands of other children have been abandoned or orphaned by the war. Many of them were born to Yazidi women who had been kidnapped by ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," and forced into sexual slavery. “After ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],", the Yazidis accepted the women back into the community, but not their half-",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," babies,” Younnis said. “They force the women to turn over their children to the orphanage. Every day, these women call me, wanting to know how their children are doing.”"],["p","Hundreds of small children are living in Iraqi prisons. Those whose parents were foreign fighters are often present in the courtroom when their mothers are sentenced to death. Iraqi children whom ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," trained to become fighters and potential suicide bombers are imprisoned, as if their lives were irredeemable. “They are useless in interrogations—they just cry,” the senior Iraqi intelligence official said. “We are holding children as young as twelve in cells with hard-core jihadi fighters.”"],["p","Thousands of children in Mosul live on the street, searching through the trash for scrap to sell. “After their parents were killed or imprisoned, their relatives refused to take them in,” Younnis said. “They are seen as tainted, even if they were too young to absorb the ideology.” Many of them hang out in traffic and at checkpoints, choking on dust and diesel, trying to wipe down windshields or sell water and tissues to passing motorists. “They will do anything for fifty dollars,” she said. “I go to many government officials, asking to find ways to help these kids, but they all say, ‘It’s not my area of responsibility.’ ”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inline-ad%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3Eadvertisement%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["p","advertisement"]],["p","“The camps are a time bomb,” Younnis continued. “The fathers are in prison or dead. The mothers are being raped. They will raise the kids accordingly, and their sons will seek revenge. This won’t just affect Mosul, or Nineveh, or Iraq. This will affect the whole world.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EOne%20morning%20in%20Mosul%2C%20I%20was%20told%20that%20an%20ardent%20supporter%20of%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20who%20goes%20by%20Umm%20Hamad%2C%20wanted%20to%20speak%20with%20me%2C%20in%20the%20market%20by%20the%20Saddam%20neighborhood.%20All%20three%20of%20her%20sons%20had%20been%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20commanders%2C%20and%20were%20now%20dead%2C%20but%20she%20had%20evaded%20deportation%20to%20the%20camps.%20My%20interpreter%20and%20I%20parked%20near%20a%20vegetable%20stand%2C%20fifty%20feet%20from%20an%20Iraqi%20Army%20checkpoint.%20There%20was%20another%20checkpoint%20a%20couple%20of%20hundred%20feet%20behind%20us%2C%20and%20no%20access%20to%20the%20side%20streets.%20For%20a%20moment%2C%20I%20wondered%20if%20it%20was%20a%20setup.%20Then%20two%20women%20approached%20the%20car%2C%20opened%20the%20back%20door%2C%20and%20climbed%20in.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20still%20proud%20of%20what%20they%20did%2C%E2%80%9D%20Umm%20Hamad%20said%2C%20of%20her%20sons.%20She%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20think%20of%20them%20as%20having%20lost%E2%80%94only%20of%20having%20proved%20that%20it%20was%20possible%20for%20a%20jihadi%20group%20to%20control%20territory%2C%20and%20to%20govern.%20Already%2C%20since%20its%20defeat%20in%20Mosul%2C%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20has%20set%20up%20checkpoints%20and%20carried%20out%20abductions%20and%20assassinations%20in%20several%20Iraqi%20provinces.%20Its%20leadership%20has%20reportedly%20buried%20large%20quantities%20of%20weapons%20and%20cash%20in%20tunnels%20and%20sand%20berms%2C%20to%20be%20unearthed%20in%20the%20years%20to%20come.%20According%20to%20the%20Pentagon%2C%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20is%20%E2%80%9Cmore%20capable%E2%80%9D%20now%20than%20Al%20Qaeda%20in%20Iraq%20was%20at%20its%20peak%2C%20in%202007%2C%20and%20there%20are%20still%20some%20thirty%20thousand%20fighters%20operating%20in%20Syria%20and%20Iraq.%20Citing%20the%20camps%2C%20Umm%20Hamad%20told%20me%20that%20she%20expects%20the%20Islamic%20State%20to%20return%20to%20Mosul.%20%E2%80%9CNot%20soon%2C%20but%20more%20powerful%20than%20before%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20other%20woman%20was%20Umm%20Hamad%E2%80%99s%20niece.%20She%20was%20in%20her%20twenties%2C%20and%20spoke%20softly%20and%20wistfully%20of%20the%20past.%20%E2%80%9CEveryone%20in%20my%20family%20welcomed%20the%20Islamic%20State%2C%20except%20my%20youngest%20brother%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20hated%20them.%E2%80%9D%20Throughout%20the%20occupation%2C%20she%20and%20her%20other%20brothers%20had%20tried%20to%20convince%20him%20of%20the%20merits%20of%20the%20caliphate%2C%20to%20no%20avail.%20Then%20he%20was%20arrested%20by%20the%20Iraqi%20security%20forces%2C%20under%20suspicion%20of%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EISIS%3C%2Fem%3E%20affiliation.%20He%20was%20twelve%20years%20old.%20She%20has%20no%20idea%20where%20he%20is%2C%20or%20when%20he%20will%20get%20out%20of%20prison%E2%80%94she%20knows%20only%20that%2C%20if%20the%20government%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20kill%20him%2C%20by%20the%20time%20it%20lets%20him%20go%20it%20will%20have%20taught%20him%20that%20she%20was%20right.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","One morning in Mosul, I was told that an ardent supporter of ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"],", who goes by Umm Hamad, wanted to speak with me, in the market by the Saddam neighborhood. All three of her sons had been ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," commanders, and were now dead, but she had evaded deportation to the camps. My interpreter and I parked near a vegetable stand, fifty feet from an Iraqi Army checkpoint. There was another checkpoint a couple of hundred feet behind us, and no access to the side streets. For a moment, I wondered if it was a setup. Then two women approached the car, opened the back door, and climbed in."],["p","“I’m still proud of what they did,” Umm Hamad said, of her sons. She doesn’t think of them as having lost—only of having proved that it was possible for a jihadi group to control territory, and to govern. Already, since its defeat in Mosul, ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," has set up checkpoints and carried out abductions and assassinations in several Iraqi provinces. Its leadership has reportedly buried large quantities of weapons and cash in tunnels and sand berms, to be unearthed in the years to come. According to the Pentagon, ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," is “more capable” now than Al Qaeda in Iraq was at its peak, in 2007, and there are still some thirty thousand fighters operating in Syria and Iraq. Citing the camps, Umm Hamad told me that she expects the Islamic State to return to Mosul. “Not soon, but more powerful than before,” she said."],["p","The other woman was Umm Hamad’s niece. She was in her twenties, and spoke softly and wistfully of the past. “Everyone in my family welcomed the Islamic State, except my youngest brother,” she said. “He hated them.” Throughout the occupation, she and her other brothers had tried to convince him of the merits of the caliphate, to no avail. Then he was arrested by the Iraqi security forces, under suspicion of ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," affiliation. He was twelve years old. She has no idea where he is, or when he will get out of prison—she knows only that, if the government doesn’t kill him, by the time it lets him go it will have taught him that she was right. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"5907ef12019dfc3494e9c8f2","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5907ef12019dfc3494e9c8f2","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"A Reporter at Large","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"a-reporter-at-large"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"A Taub","type":"author","title":"Ben Taub joined The New Yorker as a staff writer in 2017.","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Ben Taub joined ",["em","The New Yorker"]," as a staff writer in 2017. He has written for the magazine about a range of subjects related to jihadism, crime, conflict, and human rights, mostly in Africa, Europe, and the Middle East. In 2017, his work on Syria, which was supported by the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, was short-listed for a National Magazine Award and won the Livingston Award for International Reporting, the Robert F. Kennedy Award for International Print reporting, and the Overseas Press Club Award for Investigative Reporting. Taub also received the ASME Next Award for Journalists Under 30, and was named one of ",["em","Forbes’s"]," 30 Under 30 in Media. In 2018, his work on a convergence of crises in the Sahel won the George Polk Award for Magazine Reporting and the Prince Albert II of Monaco and U.N. Correspondents Association Global Prize for coverage of Climate Change."]],"social":[],"url":"/contributors/ben-taub","image":null}],"dek":"\u003cem class=\"small\">ISIS\u003c/em> has been destroyed, but will Iraq’s campaign of revenge help bring about its resurgence?","formatting":{},"hed":"Shallow Graves","id":"5c114192ef12204ae0c05e14","inlineEmbeds":{},"issueDate":"December 24 & 31, 2018","modifiedAt":"2018-12-18T18:07:05.622Z","photos":{"tout":[{"id":"5c104b521b07900f29567d0a","modelName":"photo","collection":"photos","aspectRatios":{"2:2":{"width":480,"height":480,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":1250,"y":521,"height":480,"width":480}},"duration":null},"16:9":{"width":2560,"height":1440,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":0,"y":438,"height":1440,"width":2560}},"duration":null},"4:3":{"width":2109,"height":1582,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":0,"y":337,"height":1582,"width":2109}},"duration":null},"3:4":{"width":1440,"height":1920,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":346,"y":0,"height":1920,"width":1440}},"duration":null},"2:3":{"width":1280,"height":1920,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"height":1920,"width":1280,"x":640,"y":0}},"duration":null},"3:2":{"width":2390,"height":1593,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":0,"y":326,"height":1593,"width":2390}},"duration":null},"1:1":{"width":1920,"height":1920,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"height":1920,"width":1920,"x":320,"y":0}},"duration":null},"master":{"format":"JPEG","url":"https://cn-copilot-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/tny-services/production/2018/12/11/5c104b521b07900f29567d09_181224_r33462.jpg","width":2560,"height":1920,"duration":null}},"caption":["div",["p","The widows of ",["em",{"class":"small"},"ISIS"]," fighters often have to flee their towns, for fear of retribution. \u003c/g>\u003c/svg>"}}},{"body":["div",["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20final%20masterpiece%20of%20twentieth-century%20music%20had%20its%20premi%C3%A8re%20last%20month%2C%20at%20La%20Scala%2C%20in%20Milan.%20%E2%80%9CSamuel%20Beckett%3A%20Fin%20de%20Partie%2C%E2%80%9D%20an%20operatic%20version%20of%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fsamuel-beckett%5C%22%3EBeckett%E2%80%99s%3C%2Fa%3E%20%E2%80%9CEndgame%E2%80%9D%20by%20the%20Hungarian%20composer%20Gy%C3%B6rgy%20Kurt%C3%A1g%2C%20is%20nominally%20a%20product%20of%20our%20time%3A%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20began%20writing%20it%20in%202010%20and%20finished%20it%20last%20year%2C%20at%20the%20age%20of%20ninety-one.%20Yet%20the%20score%20harks%20back%20to%20the%20heyday%20of%20modernism%20in%20the%20arts%2C%20when%20a%20figure%20like%20Beckett%20could%20hold%20a%20cultured%20public%20tensely%20in%20thrall%20as%20he%20tested%20the%20extremes.%20Such%20authority%20hardly%20exists%20any%20longer%3A%20the%20age%20of%20the%20dark%20male%20genius%20is%20past.%20Given%20how%20much%20brilliant%20music%20is%20being%20made%20by%20new%20and%20different%20voices%2C%20the%20retreat%20of%20that%20cult%20is%20not%20greatly%20to%20be%20mourned.%20Still%2C%20Kurt%C3%A1g%E2%80%99s%20achievement%20is%20stupendous%2C%20particularly%20since%20this%20is%20his%20first%20opera%20and%20by%20far%20the%20most%20ambitious%20undertaking%20of%20his%20career.%20There%20are%20many%20musical%20monuments%20of%20old%20age%3A%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2017%2F11%2F13%2Fthe-shakespeare-of-opera%5C%22%3EMonteverdi%E2%80%99s%3C%2Fa%3E%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Coronation%20of%20Poppea%2C%E2%80%9D%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2001%2F09%2F24%2Fverdis-grip%5C%22%3EVerdi%E2%80%99s%3C%2Fa%3E%20%E2%80%9COtello%E2%80%9D%20and%20%E2%80%9CFalstaff%2C%E2%80%9D%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F1991%2F03%2F04%2Fjanacek%5C%22%3EJan%C3%A1%C4%8Dek%E2%80%99s%3C%2Fa%3E%20%E2%80%9CFrom%20the%20House%20of%20the%20Dead.%E2%80%9D%20But%20no%20composer%20has%20ever%20taken%20so%20huge%20a%20leap%20so%20late.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EUntil%20now%2C%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20has%20been%20best%20known%20as%20a%20maker%20of%20supercharged%20miniatures.%20He%20developed%20fitfully%2C%20struggling%20through%20periods%20of%20creative%20block.%20In%20the%20nineteen-sixties%2C%20at%20a%20time%20when%20his%20compatriot%20and%20friend%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2001%2F05%2F28%2Fligeti-split%5C%22%3EGy%C3%B6rgy%20Ligeti%3C%2Fa%3E%20was%20seizing%20the%20world%E2%80%99s%20imagination%20with%20his%20%E2%80%9CAtmosph%C3%A8res%E2%80%9D%20and%20%E2%80%9CRequiem%2C%E2%80%9D%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20remained%20relatively%20obscure.%20Ligeti%20had%20fled%20to%20the%20West%20after%20the%20suppression%20of%20the%20Hungarian%20uprising%20of%201956%3B%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20had%20remained%20in%20Budapest.%20By%20the%20eighties%2C%20though%2C%20Kurt%C3%A1g%E2%80%99s%20time%20had%20come.%20Works%20such%20as%20%E2%80%9CKafka%20Fragments%2C%E2%80%9D%20for%20voice%20and%20violin%2C%20and%20%E2%80%9CStele%2C%E2%80%9D%20for%20orchestra%2C%20rose%20like%20craggy%20monoliths%20above%20the%20stylistic%20landscape%20of%20the%20day.%20Their%20musical%20language%20was%20compressed%2C%20gnomic%2C%20piercingly%20expressive.%20%E2%80%9CStele%2C%E2%80%9D%20whose%20title%20means%20%E2%80%9Cmemorial%20slab%2C%E2%80%9D%20begins%20with%20an%20emphatic%20held%20G%2C%20extracted%20from%20Beethoven%E2%80%99s%20Leonore%20Overture%20No.%203%2C%20and%20ends%20with%20catatonic%20repetitions%20of%20a%20ghostly%2C%20shiver-inducing%20seven-note%20chord.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThis%20aesthetic%20of%20shattered%20lyricism%20and%20occluded%20beauty%20is%20ideal%20for%20Beckett.%20At%20Ligeti%E2%80%99s%20urging%2C%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20went%20to%20see%20%E2%80%9CEndgame%E2%80%9D%20in%20Paris%20in%201957%2C%20shortly%20after%20its%20premi%C3%A8re.%20Fifty%20years%20later%2C%20he%20told%20the%20critic%20Jeremy%20Eichler%20that%20it%20was%20%E2%80%9Cone%20of%20the%20strongest%20experiences%20in%20my%20life.%E2%80%9D%20He%20set%20several%20shorter%20Beckett%20texts%20and%20dreamed%20of%20writing%20a%20full-length%20opera.%20Although%20Beckett%20was%20an%20astute%20music%20lover%2C%20cherishing%20the%20songs%20of%20Schubert%20above%20all%2C%20he%20resisted%20musical%20settings%20of%20his%20plays%2C%20deeming%20the%20words%20music%20enough.%20He%20might%20have%20changed%20his%20mind%20if%20he%20could%20have%20heard%20what%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20has%20done%20with%20%E2%80%9CEndgame.%E2%80%9D%20The%20opera%2C%20which%20lasts%20two%20hours%20without%20intermission%2C%20contains%20a%20bit%20more%20than%20half%20the%20play%2C%20following%20the%20original%20French%20line%20by%20line.%20(Although%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20gives%20us%20the%20heart%20of%20the%20text%2C%20including%20the%20beginning%20and%20the%20end%2C%20he%20has%20indicated%20that%20he%20plans%20to%20expand%20the%20score%20in%20coming%20years.)%20The%20music%20hovers%20around%20Beckett%E2%80%99s%20language%20without%20ever%20obscuring%20or%20upstaging%20it.%20Not%20since%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2018%2F10%2F29%2Fthe-velvet-revolution-of-claude-debussy%5C%22%3EDebussy%E2%80%99s%3C%2Fa%3E%20%E2%80%9CPell%C3%A9as%20et%20M%C3%A9lisande%E2%80%9D%20has%20there%20been%20vocal%20writing%20of%20such%20radical%20transparency%3A%20every%20wounded%20word%20strikes%20home.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CPell%C3%A9as%E2%80%9D%20is%20one%20of%20the%20models%20that%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20reportedly%20examined%20during%20a%20long%20period%20of%20preparation%20for%20%E2%80%9CFin%20de%20Partie.%E2%80%9D%20In%20his%20youth%2C%20he%20studied%20with%20Olivier%20Messiaen%2C%20who%20made%20a%20specialty%20of%20analyzing%20%E2%80%9CPell%C3%A9as%E2%80%9D%3B%20you%20hear%20echoes%20of%20Messiaen%20in%20%E2%80%9CFin%20de%20Partie%E2%80%9D%20as%20well.%20Two%20wheezing%20bayans%E2%80%94the%20Russian%20version%20of%20the%20accordion%E2%80%94lend%20the%20work%20a%20streetwise%20Parisian%20flavor%2C%20particularly%20when%20they%20are%20joined%20to%20a%20mangled%20little%20waltz%20melody%20that%20recurs%20throughout.%20The%20Frenchness%20of%20the%20opera%20may%20come%20as%20a%20surprise%2C%20given%20Kurt%C3%A1g%E2%80%99s%20Central%20European%20background%2C%20but%20he%20has%20long-standing%20Paris%20associations%20and%20lived%20in%20the%20South%20of%20France%20from%202001%20to%202015.%20(He%20now%20lives%20in%20Budapest%2C%20with%20Marta%20Kurt%C3%A1g%2C%20his%20wife%20and%20artistic%20partner%20for%20seven%20decades.)%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20other%20musical%20ghost%20who%20haunts%20%E2%80%9CFin%20de%20Partie%E2%80%9D%20is%20Anton%20Webern%2C%20the%20supreme%20aphorist%2C%20whose%20song-length%20orchestral%20pieces%20have%20the%20weight%20of%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2009%2F06%2F08%2Fendless-mahler%5C%22%3EMahler%3C%2Fa%3E%20symphonies.%20Webern%20was%20a%20Schoenbergian%20purist%2C%20expunging%20almost%20all%20traces%20of%20tonality%20from%20his%20music.%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20is%20more%20eclectic%20in%20his%20approach%2C%20making%20frequent%20use%20of%20tonal%20elements.%20But%20he%20gives%20them%20a%20hard%2C%20enigmatic%20sheen.%20That%20waltz%20tune%20keeps%20stopping%20short%20after%20just%20two%20bars%2C%20so%20that%20its%20simple%2C%20major-key%20contour%20becomes%20one%20more%20alienated%20object%20in%20Beckett%E2%80%99s%20garage%20sale%20of%20the%20human%20spirit.%20The%20power%20of%20Kurt%C3%A1g%E2%80%99s%20creation%20derives%20in%20part%20from%20its%20fusion%20of%20Debussy%E2%80%99s%20poetry%20and%20Webern%E2%80%99s%20pith.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CEndgame%2C%E2%80%9D%20like%20so%20much%20of%20Beckett%2C%20presents%20a%20condition%20rather%20than%20a%20plot.%20The%20characters%20are%20Hamm%2C%20a%20blind%20old%20man%20in%20a%20wheelchair%3B%20Clov%2C%20his%20long-suffering%20servant%3B%20and%20Nell%20and%20Nagg%2C%20Hamm%E2%80%99s%20ancient%20parents%2C%20who%20lost%20their%20legs%20in%20a%20bicycling%20accident%20and%20are%20confined%20to%20trash%20cans.%20Stories%20are%20told%3B%20resentments%20are%20aired%3B%20misery%20circulates%3B%20Nell%20and%20Nagg%20die%3B%20and%2C%20at%20the%20end%2C%20Clov%20prepares%20to%20take%20his%20leave%2C%20though%20he%20does%20not%20actually%20do%20so.%20Outside%20is%20a%20dead%2C%20ashen%20world.%20Clov%20declares%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20say%20to%20myself%20that%20the%20earth%20is%20extinguished%2C%20though%20I%20never%20saw%20it%20lit.%E2%80%9D%20Pierre%20Audi%2C%20who%20directed%20the%20La%20Scala%20production%2C%20stayed%20close%20to%20Beckett%E2%80%99s%20stage%20directions%2C%20though%20the%20characters%20are%20seen%20outside%20a%20decrepit%20old%20house%20rather%20than%20in%20its%20interior.%20The%20cast%E2%80%94Frode%20Olsen%20as%20Hamm%2C%20Leigh%20Melrose%20as%20Clov%2C%20Leonardo%20Cortellazzi%20as%20Nagg%2C%20and%20Hilary%20Summers%20as%20Nell%E2%80%94sang%20magnificently%2C%20under%20the%20exacting%20guidance%20of%20the%20conductor%20Markus%20Stenz.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBeckett%20humanizes%20his%20desolate%20scenario%20with%20skeletal%20wit.%20Kurt%C3%A1g%2C%20likewise%2C%20proves%20to%20be%20a%20deft%20musical%20comedian.%20Grunts%20of%20tuba%20and%20bassoon%2C%20scuttlings%20of%20strings%2C%20a%20splash%20of%20saxophone%2C%20and%20slapstick%20percussion%20hint%20at%20the%20vaudeville%20tradition%20that%20informs%20so%20much%20of%20Beckett%E2%80%99s%20work.%20More%20often%2C%20though%2C%20the%20music%20provokes%20not%20outright%20laughter%20but%20a%20wistful%20smile%E2%80%94humanization%20in%20a%20different%20mode.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHamm%2C%20in%20his%20opening%20monologue%2C%20says%2C%20%E2%80%9CNo%2C%20all%20is%20absolute%2C%20the%20bigger%20a%20man%20is%20the%20fuller%20he%20is.%20And%20the%20emptier.%20Clov!%20No%2C%20alone.%20What%20dreams!%20Those%20forests!%20Enough%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20time%20it%20ended%2C%20in%20the%20refuge%2C%20too.%20And%20yet%20I%20hesitate%2C%20I%20hesitate%20to%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20to%20end.%E2%80%9D%20Kurt%C3%A1g%E2%80%99s%20setting%20of%20these%20lines%20exemplifies%20his%20method.%20First%2C%20a%20prowling%20tuba%20and%20eerie%20whooshes%20of%20tam-tam%20and%20cymbals%20evoke%20Hamm%E2%80%99s%20solitude.%20The%20word%20%E2%80%9Cempty%E2%80%9D%20is%20unexpectedly%20joined%20to%20a%20low%20F-major%20triad%2C%20and%20a%20solo%20double%20bass%20traces%20out%20a%20plaintive%20micro-melody%20in%20that%20key%20area.%20A%20solo%20flute%20takes%20up%20the%20same%20motif%20in%20the%20area%20of%20D%2C%20bathing%20it%20in%20warm%20light.%20The%20mention%20of%20dreams%20and%20forests%E2%80%94beloved%20habitats%20of%20Baudelaire%20and%20the%20Symbolist%20poets%E2%80%94triggers%20hazy%2C%20Debussy-like%20chords%20in%20the%20strings.%20The%20harmony%20darkens%20again%20as%20Hamm%20speaks%20of%20ending%20it%20all.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EEach%20page%20of%20the%20score%20contains%20happenstance%20charms%20and%20fleeting%20epiphanies.%20I%20especially%20love%20the%20bouncy%20little%20march%20that%20kicks%20in%20when%20Nagg%20tells%20an%20old%20Jewish%20joke%20about%20a%20tailor%20who%20exasperates%20a%20client%20by%20taking%20too%20long%20to%20make%20a%20pair%20of%20pants.%20God%20made%20the%20world%20in%20six%20days%2C%20the%20client%20says%3B%20it%20takes%20you%20months%20to%20make%20a%20pair%20of%20pants.%20In%20the%20score%2C%20the%20episode%20carries%20the%20heading%20%E2%80%9CPoldy%20Bloom%20Singing%20a%20Jewish-Irish-Scottish%20Ballad.%E2%80%9D%20When%20the%20punch%20line%20arrives%E2%80%94%E2%80%9CMy%20dear%20sir%2C%20look%20at%20the%20world%2C%20and%20look%20at%20my%20trousers%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94Kurt%C3%A1g%20tells%20the%20performers%20to%20think%20of%20Mussorgsky%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9CPictures%20at%20an%20Exhibition%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20in%20particular%20of%20the%20movement%20depicting%20an%20argument%20between%20two%20Jews.%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20is%20of%20part-Jewish%20descent%2C%20and%20these%20intertwined%20allusions%20to%20Beckett%E2%80%99s%20fondness%20for%20Jewish%20jokes%2C%20Mussorgsky%E2%80%99s%20caricatures%20of%20Jews%2C%20and%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fjames-joyce%5C%22%3EJoyce%E2%80%99s%3C%2Fa%3E%20portrait%20of%20Leopold%20Bloom%20make%20one%20wonder%20if%20the%20composer%20thinks%20of%20%E2%80%9CEndgame%E2%80%9D%20as%20a%20post-Holocaust%20work%2C%20as%20Theodor%C2%A0W.%20Adorno%20did%20before%20him.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EJoyce%20once%20boasted%20that%20the%20puzzles%20of%20%E2%80%9CUlysses%E2%80%9D%20would%20keep%20the%20professors%20busy%20for%20centuries.%20The%20same%20might%20be%20said%20of%20Kurt%C3%A1g%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9CFin%20de%20Partie%2C%E2%80%9D%20although%20the%20self-critical%20composer%20is%20unlikely%20to%20say%20so.%20The%20opera%20is%20less%20a%20translation%20of%20literature%20into%20music%20than%20a%20kind%20of%20posthumous%20collaboration.%20And%2C%20like%20Verdi%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9COtello%2C%E2%80%9D%20it%20seems%20the%20equal%20of%20the%20celebrated%20text%20on%20which%20it%20is%20based.%20Beckett%20has%20been%20waiting%20for%20Kurt%C3%A1g%20all%20this%20time.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The final masterpiece of twentieth-century music had its première last month, at La Scala, in Milan. “Samuel Beckett: Fin de Partie,” an operatic version of ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/samuel-beckett"},"Beckett’s"]," “Endgame” by the Hungarian composer György Kurtág, is nominally a product of our time: Kurtág began writing it in 2010 and finished it last year, at the age of ninety-one. Yet the score harks back to the heyday of modernism in the arts, when a figure like Beckett could hold a cultured public tensely in thrall as he tested the extremes. Such authority hardly exists any longer: the age of the dark male genius is past. Given how much brilliant music is being made by new and different voices, the retreat of that cult is not greatly to be mourned. Still, Kurtág’s achievement is stupendous, particularly since this is his first opera and by far the most ambitious undertaking of his career. There are many musical monuments of old age: ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/11/13/the-shakespeare-of-opera"},"Monteverdi’s"]," “The Coronation of Poppea,” ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2001/09/24/verdis-grip"},"Verdi’s"]," “Otello” and “Falstaff,” ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/1991/03/04/janacek"},"Janáček’s"]," “From the House of the Dead.” But no composer has ever taken so huge a leap so late."],["p","Until now, Kurtág has been best known as a maker of supercharged miniatures. He developed fitfully, struggling through periods of creative block. In the nineteen-sixties, at a time when his compatriot and friend ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2001/05/28/ligeti-split"},"György Ligeti"]," was seizing the world’s imagination with his “Atmosphères” and “Requiem,” Kurtág remained relatively obscure. Ligeti had fled to the West after the suppression of the Hungarian uprising of 1956; Kurtág had remained in Budapest. By the eighties, though, Kurtág’s time had come. Works such as “Kafka Fragments,” for voice and violin, and “Stele,” for orchestra, rose like craggy monoliths above the stylistic landscape of the day. Their musical language was compressed, gnomic, piercingly expressive. “Stele,” whose title means “memorial slab,” begins with an emphatic held G, extracted from Beethoven’s Leonore Overture No. 3, and ends with catatonic repetitions of a ghostly, shiver-inducing seven-note chord."],["p","This aesthetic of shattered lyricism and occluded beauty is ideal for Beckett. At Ligeti’s urging, Kurtág went to see “Endgame” in Paris in 1957, shortly after its première. Fifty years later, he told the critic Jeremy Eichler that it was “one of the strongest experiences in my life.” He set several shorter Beckett texts and dreamed of writing a full-length opera. Although Beckett was an astute music lover, cherishing the songs of Schubert above all, he resisted musical settings of his plays, deeming the words music enough. He might have changed his mind if he could have heard what Kurtág has done with “Endgame.” The opera, which lasts two hours without intermission, contains a bit more than half the play, following the original French line by line. (Although Kurtág gives us the heart of the text, including the beginning and the end, he has indicated that he plans to expand the score in coming years.) The music hovers around Beckett’s language without ever obscuring or upstaging it. Not since ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/10/29/the-velvet-revolution-of-claude-debussy"},"Debussy’s"]," “Pelléas et Mélisande” has there been vocal writing of such radical transparency: every wounded word strikes home."],["p","“Pelléas” is one of the models that Kurtág reportedly examined during a long period of preparation for “Fin de Partie.” In his youth, he studied with Olivier Messiaen, who made a specialty of analyzing “Pelléas”; you hear echoes of Messiaen in “Fin de Partie” as well. Two wheezing bayans—the Russian version of the accordion—lend the work a streetwise Parisian flavor, particularly when they are joined to a mangled little waltz melody that recurs throughout. The Frenchness of the opera may come as a surprise, given Kurtág’s Central European background, but he has long-standing Paris associations and lived in the South of France from 2001 to 2015. (He now lives in Budapest, with Marta Kurtág, his wife and artistic partner for seven decades.)"],["p","The other musical ghost who haunts “Fin de Partie” is Anton Webern, the supreme aphorist, whose song-length orchestral pieces have the weight of ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2009/06/08/endless-mahler"},"Mahler"]," symphonies. Webern was a Schoenbergian purist, expunging almost all traces of tonality from his music. Kurtág is more eclectic in his approach, making frequent use of tonal elements. But he gives them a hard, enigmatic sheen. That waltz tune keeps stopping short after just two bars, so that its simple, major-key contour becomes one more alienated object in Beckett’s garage sale of the human spirit. The power of Kurtág’s creation derives in part from its fusion of Debussy’s poetry and Webern’s pith."],["p","“Endgame,” like so much of Beckett, presents a condition rather than a plot. The characters are Hamm, a blind old man in a wheelchair; Clov, his long-suffering servant; and Nell and Nagg, Hamm’s ancient parents, who lost their legs in a bicycling accident and are confined to trash cans. Stories are told; resentments are aired; misery circulates; Nell and Nagg die; and, at the end, Clov prepares to take his leave, though he does not actually do so. Outside is a dead, ashen world. Clov declares, “I say to myself that the earth is extinguished, though I never saw it lit.” Pierre Audi, who directed the La Scala production, stayed close to Beckett’s stage directions, though the characters are seen outside a decrepit old house rather than in its interior. The cast—Frode Olsen as Hamm, Leigh Melrose as Clov, Leonardo Cortellazzi as Nagg, and Hilary Summers as Nell—sang magnificently, under the exacting guidance of the conductor Markus Stenz."],["p","Beckett humanizes his desolate scenario with skeletal wit. Kurtág, likewise, proves to be a deft musical comedian. Grunts of tuba and bassoon, scuttlings of strings, a splash of saxophone, and slapstick percussion hint at the vaudeville tradition that informs so much of Beckett’s work. More often, though, the music provokes not outright laughter but a wistful smile—humanization in a different mode."],["p","Hamm, in his opening monologue, says, “No, all is absolute, the bigger a man is the fuller he is. And the emptier. Clov! No, alone. What dreams! Those forests! Enough, it’s time it ended, in the refuge, too. And yet I hesitate, I hesitate to . . . to end.” Kurtág’s setting of these lines exemplifies his method. First, a prowling tuba and eerie whooshes of tam-tam and cymbals evoke Hamm’s solitude. The word “empty” is unexpectedly joined to a low F-major triad, and a solo double bass traces out a plaintive micro-melody in that key area. A solo flute takes up the same motif in the area of D, bathing it in warm light. The mention of dreams and forests—beloved habitats of Baudelaire and the Symbolist poets—triggers hazy, Debussy-like chords in the strings. The harmony darkens again as Hamm speaks of ending it all."],["p","Each page of the score contains happenstance charms and fleeting epiphanies. I especially love the bouncy little march that kicks in when Nagg tells an old Jewish joke about a tailor who exasperates a client by taking too long to make a pair of pants. God made the world in six days, the client says; it takes you months to make a pair of pants. In the score, the episode carries the heading “Poldy Bloom Singing a Jewish-Irish-Scottish Ballad.” When the punch line arrives—“My dear sir, look at the world, and look at my trousers”—Kurtág tells the performers to think of Mussorgsky’s “Pictures at an Exhibition,” and in particular of the movement depicting an argument between two Jews. Kurtág is of part-Jewish descent, and these intertwined allusions to Beckett’s fondness for Jewish jokes, Mussorgsky’s caricatures of Jews, and ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/james-joyce"},"Joyce’s"]," portrait of Leopold Bloom make one wonder if the composer thinks of “Endgame” as a post-Holocaust work, as Theodor W. Adorno did before him."],["p","Joyce once boasted that the puzzles of “Ulysses” would keep the professors busy for centuries. The same might be said of Kurtág’s “Fin de Partie,” although the self-critical composer is unlikely to say so. The opera is less a translation of literature into music than a kind of posthumous collaboration. And, like Verdi’s “Otello,” it seems the equal of the celebrated text on which it is based. Beckett has been waiting for Kurtág all this time. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"5907f0a62179605b11ad1e99","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5907f0a62179605b11ad1e99","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Musical Events","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"musical-events"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"Musical Ross","type":"author","title":"Alex Ross, the magazine’s music critic since 1996, is the author of “\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Rest-Noise-Listening-Twentieth-Century/dp/0312427719\">The Rest Is Noise\u003c/a>” and “\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Listen-This-Alex-Ross/dp/0312610688\">Listen to This\u003c/a>.”","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Alex Ross has been contributing to ",["em","The New Yorker"]," since 1993, and he became the magazine’s music critic in 1996. He writes about classical music, covering the field from the Metropolitan Opera to the downtown avant-garde, and has also contributed essays on pop music, literature, twentieth-century history, and gay life. His first book, “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Rest-Noise-Listening-Twentieth-Century/dp/0312427719"},"The Rest Is Noise: Listening to the Twentieth Century"],",” a cultural history of music since 1900, won a National Book Critics Circle award and the ",["em","Guardian"]," First Book Award, and was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. In 2013, the Southbank Centre, in London, mounted a yearlong festival inspired by “The Rest Is Noise,” involving more than a hundred concerts. His second book is the essay collection “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Listen-This-Alex-Ross/dp/0312610688"},"Listen to This"],".” He is now at work on a third book, called “Wagnerism,” describing the composer’s vast cultural impact. In 2008, he was named a MacArthur Fellow; he has also received an Arts and Letters Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the Belmont Prize in Germany."]],"social":[{"network":"Twitter","handle":"alexrossmusic"}],"url":"/contributors/alex-ross","image":null}],"dek":"György Kurtág’s sublime first opera is a setting of Beckett’s “Endgame.”","formatting":{},"hed":"Trash and Vaudeville","id":"5c114c74e3e383419c88164d","inlineEmbeds":{},"issueDate":"December 24 & 31, \u003c/g>\u003c/svg>"}}},{"body":["div",["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EFor%20the%20past%20several%20weeks%2C%20New%20Yorkers%20have%20been%20abuzz%20over%20a%20mysterious%20visitor.%20A%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2018%2F10%2F31%2Fnyregion%2Fmandarin-duck-central-park-pond.html%5C%22%3Emandarin%20duck%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20an%20intricately%20colored%20waterfowl%20native%20to%20East%20Asia%2C%20has%20taken%20up%20residence%20alongside%20the%20mallards%20in%20the%20Central%20Park%20Pond%2C%20drawing%20crowds%20and%20inspiring%20memes%2C%20dog%20costumes%2C%20and%20a%20Twitter%20account%20(bio%3A%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20not%20from%20around%20here%E2%80%9D).%20Pundits%20have%20argued%20that%20the%20frenzy%20betrays%20a%20desire%20for%20good%20news.%20But%20perhaps%2C%20the%20Mexico%20City-born%20designer%20Rebeca%20M%C3%A9ndez%20suggested%20the%20other%20day%2C%20something%20deeper%20is%20at%20play.%20%E2%80%9CIn%20our%20own%20normal%20life%2C%20we%20have%20patterns%20that%20we%20are%20so%20used%20to.%20When%20something%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94an%20anatine%20interloper%2C%20say%E2%80%94%E2%80%9Ccomes%20in%20and%20breaks%20that%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20incredibly%20exciting%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20world%20suddenly%20collapses%E2%80%94it%E2%80%99s%20like%20a%20wormhole%20from%20far-east%20Asia%20to%20Manhattan.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EM%C3%A9ndez%20recently%20curated%20an%20exhibition%20of%20avian%20art%20at%20the%20Cooper%20Hewitt%2C%20Smithsonian%20Design%20Museum%2C%20across%20the%20street%20from%20the%20Park.%20It%E2%80%99s%20part%20of%20the%20%E2%80%9CSelects%E2%80%9D%20series%2C%20in%20which%20the%20museum%20invites%20a%20guest%20to%20put%20together%20a%20show%20from%20objects%20in%20its%20collection.%20(Previous%20guest%20curators%20include%20the%20architect%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2013%2F09%2F23%2Fa-sense-of-place%5C%22%3EDavid%20Adjaye%3C%2Fa%3E%20and%20Ellen%20DeGeneres.)%20M%C3%A9ndez%2C%20a%20National%20Design%20Award%20winner%20and%20the%20director%20of%20a%20U.C.L.A.%20design%20lab%2C%20focussed%20on%20birds%20partly%20in%20response%20to%20migration%20in%20the%20news.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20are%20setting%20our%20boundaries%20tighter%20and%20tighter%E2%80%94we%20are%20entrenching%20in%20our%20location%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20Birds%2C%20with%20their%20ability%20to%20fly%20away%2C%20%E2%80%9Crepresent%20incredible%20freedom.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EOn%20a%20recent%20Friday%2C%20M%C3%A9ndez%20and%20Christina%20De%20Le%C3%B3n%2C%20a%20Cooper%20Hewitt%20curator%20who%20worked%20on%20the%20show%2C%20took%20a%20spin%20through%20the%20galleries.%20In%20addition%20to%20items%20from%20the%20Cooper%20Hewitt%E2%80%99s%20holdings%20(a%20seventeenth-century%20falcon%20hood%2C%20a%20paper-clip-size%20flying%20robot)%2C%20M%C3%A9ndez%20had%20included%20some%20two%20dozen%20taxidermied%20birds%20from%20the%20National%20Museum%20of%20Natural%20History%2C%20in%20Washington%2C%20D.C.%2C%20home%20to%20six%20hundred%20and%20forty%20thousand-odd%20avian%20specimens%20collected%20by%20explorers%20and%20naturalists%20since%201818.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EInside%20a%20room%20filled%20with%20recordings%20of%20birdsong%2C%20M%C3%A9ndez%20and%20De%20Le%C3%B3n%20examined%20a%20display%20case%20holding%20a%20trio%20of%20preserved%20elegant%20trogons%2C%20small%20red-bellied%20birds%20from%20Mexico%20and%20Central%20America%3B%20each%20was%20lying%20on%20its%20back%2C%20its%20feet%20strung%20together.%20(Killing%20specimens%20for%20taxonomic%20research%20is%20still%20an%20accepted%20practice.)%20De%20Le%C3%B3n%20recalled%20the%20Museum%20of%20Natural%20History%E2%80%99s%20hesitation%20in%20lending%20the%20birds.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20were%20reticent%20because%20they%20didn%E2%80%99t%20want%20the%20specimens%20to%20be%20treated%20as%20curiosities%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20When%20the%20curators%20were%20granted%20access%2C%20the%20experience%20was%20shocking.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20just%20row%20after%20row%20of%20drawers%2C%E2%80%9D%20De%20Le%C3%B3n%20said%2C%20as%20the%20crystalline%20song%20of%20a%20resplendent%20quetzal%20rang%20out%20from%20a%20speaker.%20M%C3%A9ndez%2C%20who%20speaks%20with%20a%20soft%20Mexican%20accent%2C%20nodded%20gravely.%20%E2%80%9CYou%20cannot%20help%20but%2C%20first%20of%20all%2C%20smell%20the%20formaldehyde%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CAnd%20then%20you%20open%2C%20and%20you%20open%20to%20death.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAt%20the%20rear%20of%20the%20room%2C%20another%20vitrine%20housed%20a%20Japanese%20bamboo%20birdcage%2C%20four%20taxidermied%20green-breasted%20mangos%20(a%20type%20of%20long-billed%20hummingbird)%2C%20and%20a%20gold%20brooch%2C%20made%20around%201870%2C%20that%20featured%20the%20preserved%20head%20of%20a%20sunbird.%20M%C3%A9ndez%20gazed%20at%20the%20macabre%20accessory%2C%20which%20was%20fitted%20with%20a%20glinting%2C%20ruby-red%20eye.%20%E2%80%9CThat%20was%20repulsive%20when%20I%20found%20it%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CI%20hated%20it%2C%20and%20I%20had%20to%20have%20it%2C%20because%20it%20showed%20exactly%2C%20to%20me%2C%20where%20we%20were%20as%20a%20civilization.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EDe%20Le%C3%B3n%2C%20gesturing%20toward%20a%20necklace%20by%20the%20Norwegian%20artist%20Tone%20Vigeland%2C%20made%20by%20hammering%20nails%20into%20the%20shape%20of%20feathers%2C%20talked%20about%20the%20ubiquity%20of%20avian%20designs%20in%20fashion%3A%20%E2%80%9CYou%20start%20doing%20a%20project%2C%20and%20all%20of%20a%20sudden%20you%20start%20seeing%20it%20everywhere.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EM%C3%A9ndez%20brought%20up%20current%20events.%20%E2%80%9CBird%20migration%20is%20a%20constant%20flow%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20earth%20is%20screaming%20at%20us%2C%20in%20all%20possible%20ways%2C%20%E2%80%98Migration%20is%20how%20we%20need%20to%20exist!%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522cartoon%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522cartoon%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fcartoon%25252F5c1318f89ec14d553b1aea43%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c1318f89ec14d553b1aea43%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1318f89ec14d553b1aea43%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1318f89ec14d553b1aea43%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20pair%20decided%20to%20step%20outside.%20Leaving%20the%20gallery%2C%20they%20crossed%20Fifth%20Avenue%20and%20entered%20Central%20Park.%20The%20mandarin%20duck%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20around%2C%20so%20they%20searched%20for%20more%20ordinary%20birdlife.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CWe%20can%20go%20up%20here%2C%20toward%20the%20reservoir%2C%E2%80%9D%20De%20Le%C3%B3n%20said.%20As%20they%20turned%20up%20the%20path%2C%20a%20male%20house%20sparrow%20appeared%20beneath%20a%20bush.%20M%C3%A9ndez%20crouched%20down%20to%20look.%20%E2%80%9C%3Cem%3EHola%2C%20mi%20amor!%3C%2Fem%3E%20%E2%80%9D%20she%20called.%20She%20opened%20a%20bag%20of%20birdseed%20and%20tossed%20a%20handful%20to%20the%20bird%2C%20which%20hopped%20shyly%20away.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20won%E2%80%99t%20come%20back%20for%20a%20while%2C%E2%80%9D%20M%C3%A9ndez%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThey%20moved%20downhill.%20A%20white%20car%20drove%20down%20the%20lane%2C%20and%20M%C3%A9ndez%20stiffened%20slightly.%20%E2%80%9CThat%E2%80%99s%20not%20the%20police%2C%20right%3F%E2%80%9D%20she%20asked.%20It%20was%20not%E2%80%94just%20a%20Parks%20Department%20vehicle%2C%20which%20passed%20without%20slowing%20for%20the%20bird-feeders.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EDe%20Le%C3%B3n%20looked%20up%20into%20a%20tree%2C%20where%20she%20spotted%20a%20few%20sparrows%20flitting%20through%20its%20branches.%20%E2%80%9C%3Cem%3ESon%20cuatro!%3C%2Fem%3E%20%E2%80%9D%20she%20called%20to%20M%C3%A9ndez.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9C%3Cem%3ECuatro!%3C%2Fem%3E%20%E2%80%9D%20M%C3%A9ndez%20cried.%20%E2%80%9C%3Cem%3EAh%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20%3Cem%3Eque%20lindo%3C%2Fem%3E.%E2%80%9D%20She%20held%20up%20her%20hand%2C%20filled%20with%20seed.%20The%20birds%20ignored%20her.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EM%C3%A9ndez%20tossed%20the%20handful%20to%20the%20ground.%20%E2%80%9CThat%E2%80%99s%20the%20beauty%20of%20nature%E2%80%94we%20can%E2%80%99t%20control%20it%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CBut%20they%E2%80%99ll%20be%20eating%20a%20delicious%20feast%20in%20a%20little%20while.%E2%80%9D%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAn%20earlier%20version%20of%20this%20article%20incorrectly%20stated%20that%20Rebeca%20M%C3%A9ndez%20is%20based%20in%20Mexico%20City.%20She%20was%20born%20in%20Mexico%20City%20and%20is%20based%20in%20Los%20Angeles.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","For the past several weeks, New Yorkers have been abuzz over a mysterious visitor. A ",["a",{"href":"https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/31/nyregion/mandarin-duck-central-park-pond.html"},"mandarin duck"],", an intricately colored waterfowl native to East Asia, has taken up residence alongside the mallards in the Central Park Pond, drawing crowds and inspiring memes, dog costumes, and a Twitter account (bio: “I’m not from around here”). Pundits have argued that the frenzy betrays a desire for good news. But perhaps, the Mexico City-born designer Rebeca Méndez suggested the other day, something deeper is at play. “In our own normal life, we have patterns that we are so used to. When something”—an anatine interloper, say—“comes in and breaks that, it’s incredibly exciting,” she said. “The world suddenly collapses—it’s like a wormhole from far-east Asia to Manhattan.”"],["p","Méndez recently curated an exhibition of avian art at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum, across the street from the Park. It’s part of the “Selects” series, in which the museum invites a guest to put together a show from objects in its collection. (Previous guest curators include the architect ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/09/23/a-sense-of-place"},"David Adjaye"]," and Ellen DeGeneres.) Méndez, a National Design Award winner and the director of a U.C.L.A. design lab, focussed on birds partly in response to migration in the news. “We are setting our boundaries tighter and tighter—we are entrenching in our location,” she said. Birds, with their ability to fly away, “represent incredible freedom.”"],["p","On a recent Friday, Méndez and Christina De León, a Cooper Hewitt curator who worked on the show, took a spin through the galleries. In addition to items from the Cooper Hewitt’s holdings (a seventeenth-century falcon hood, a paper-clip-size flying robot), Méndez had included some two dozen taxidermied birds from the National Museum of Natural History, in Washington, D.C., home to six hundred and forty thousand-odd avian specimens collected by explorers and naturalists since 1818."],["p","Inside a room filled with recordings of birdsong, Méndez and De León examined a display case holding a trio of preserved elegant trogons, small red-bellied birds from Mexico and Central America; each was lying on its back, its feet strung together. (Killing specimens for taxonomic research is still an accepted practice.) De León recalled the Museum of Natural History’s hesitation in lending the birds. “They were reticent because they didn’t want the specimens to be treated as curiosities,” she said. When the curators were granted access, the experience was shocking. “It’s just row after row of drawers,” De León said, as the crystalline song of a resplendent quetzal rang out from a speaker. Méndez, who speaks with a soft Mexican accent, nodded gravely. “You cannot help but, first of all, smell the formaldehyde,” she said. “And then you open, and you open to death.”"],["p","At the rear of the room, another vitrine housed a Japanese bamboo birdcage, four taxidermied green-breasted mangos (a type of long-billed hummingbird), and a gold brooch, made around 1870, that featured the preserved head of a sunbird. Méndez gazed at the macabre accessory, which was fitted with a glinting, ruby-red eye. “That was repulsive when I found it,” she said. “I hated it, and I had to have it, because it showed exactly, to me, where we were as a civilization.”"],["p","De León, gesturing toward a necklace by the Norwegian artist Tone Vigeland, made by hammering nails into the shape of feathers, talked about the ubiquity of avian designs in fashion: “You start doing a project, and all of a sudden you start seeing it everywhere.”"],["p","Méndez brought up current events. “Bird migration is a constant flow,” she said. “The earth is screaming at us, in all possible ways, ‘Migration is how we need to exist!’ ”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1318f89ec14d553b1aea43%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1318f89ec14d553b1aea43%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c1318f89ec14d553b1aea43%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1318f89ec14d553b1aea43"}]],["p","The pair decided to step outside. Leaving the gallery, they crossed Fifth Avenue and entered Central Park. The mandarin duck wasn’t around, so they searched for more ordinary birdlife."],["p","“We can go up here, toward the reservoir,” De León said. As they turned up the path, a male house sparrow appeared beneath a bush. Méndez crouched down to look. “",["em","Hola, mi amor!"]," ” she called. She opened a bag of birdseed and tossed a handful to the bird, which hopped shyly away. “He won’t come back for a while,” Méndez said."],["p","They moved downhill. A white car drove down the lane, and Méndez stiffened slightly. “That’s not the police, right?” she asked. It was not—just a Parks Department vehicle, which passed without slowing for the bird-feeders."],["p","De León looked up into a tree, where she spotted a few sparrows flitting through its branches. “",["em","Son cuatro!"]," ” she called to Méndez."],["p","“",["em","Cuatro!"]," ” Méndez cried. “",["em","Ah"],", ",["em","que lindo"],".” She held up her hand, filled with seed. The birds ignored her."],["p","Méndez tossed the handful to the ground. “That’s the beauty of nature—we can’t control it,” she said. “But they’ll be eating a delicious feast in a little while.” ♦"],["p","An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated that Rebeca Méndez is based in Mexico City. She was born in Mexico City and is based in Los Angeles."]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c8781ab3335f580f184","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Birds","parent":[],"photos":{},"slug":"birds"},{"id":"5c2e1c87e56e652c90274678","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Ducks","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"ducks"},{"id":"5c2e1c87397f5b30646d0603","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Mandarin from his daughter) ushered in the Christmas spirit with a swinging recording of “Winter Wonderland.” Now Marsalis and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, along with the promising vocalists Vuyo Sotashe and Veronica Swift, offer “Big Band Holidays,” a program brimming with seasonal confections, both classic and reimagined. The series arrives on Dec. 19, with dollops of carefree nostalgia and abundant cheer, like all good traditions."]],"canonicalUrl":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/12/24/wynton-marsalis-seasonal-confections","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c792bfcc72cd92d0526","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Jazz","parent":[],"photos":{},"slug":"jazz"}],"sections":[{"id":"5907efdaebe912338a37175c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5907efdaebe912338a37175c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Goings zens%E2%80%94he%20does%20have%20a%20cell%20phone.%20He%20regularly%20posts%20his%20analyses%20of%20current%20events%20in%20online%20groups%2C%20and%20he%20has%20become%20an%20increasingly%20prominent%20pundit%20on%20the%20Chinese%20Internet.%20Since%202012%2C%20Jianguo%20has%20trained%20his%20criticism%20chiefly%20on%20one%20target%3A%20the%20%3Cem%3EGlobal%20Times%3C%2Fem%3E%20(%3Cem%3EHuanqiu%20Shibao%3C%2Fem%3E)%2C%20a%20pro-government%2C%20strongly%20nationalistic%2C%20and%20influential%20tabloid%20daily%2C%20which%20is%20distributed%20widely%20under%20the%20auspices%20of%20the%20%3Cem%3EPeople%E2%80%99s%20Daily.%3C%2Fem%3E%20In%20a%20series%20labelled%20%E2%80%9CDebating%20the%20%3Cem%3EGlobal%20Times%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20Jianguo%20took%20up%20editorials%20and%20scrutinized%20them%20point%20by%20point.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ELooking%20at%20his%20posts%2C%20I%20used%20to%20marvel%20at%20his%20bullheadedness%2C%20but%20the%20whole%20thing%20seemed%20to%20me%20like%20playing%20a%20game%20of%20solitaire%3B%20the%20posts%20appeared%20to%20go%20unnoticed.%20Gradually%2C%20however%2C%20I%20saw%20that%20Jianguo%20was%20honing%20a%20new%20voice%2C%20and%20gaining%20a%20following.%20From%202012%20to%202017%2C%20he%20produced%2C%20with%20accelerating%20frequency%2C%20a%20total%20of%20four%20hundred%20and%20fifty-six%20%E2%80%9CDebating%20the%20%3Cem%3EGlobal%20Times%3C%2Fem%3E%E2%80%9D%20posts.%20He%20was%20helped%20by%20the%20explosive%20growth%20of%20WeChat%2C%20the%20messaging%20and%20social-media%20app%3A%20by%202015%2C%20Jianguo%20was%20sending%20a%20new%20post%20every%20other%20day%20to%20between%20fifty%20and%20seventy%20WeChat%20groups%2C%20reaching%20tens%20of%20thousands%20of%20readers.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHe%E2%80%99s%20part%20of%20a%20broader%20trend.%20Since%20organized%20opposition%20is%20impossible%2C%20protest%20and%20resistance%20have%20increasingly%20shifted%20to%20the%20Internet.%20Spotlighting%20abuse%20and%20corruption%2C%20online%20critics%20and%20bloggers%20have%20often%20succeeded%20in%20rallying%20public%20opinion%20and%20pressuring%20authorities%20to%20act.%20Online%20platforms%20like%20WeChat%20and%20Weibo%2C%20in%20their%20fragmented%20immensity%2C%20can%20still%20provide%20badly%20needed%20public%20spaces%20for%20critical%20exchange%2C%20as%20well%20as%20bonding%20and%20camaraderie%2C%20all%20with%20the%20advantage%20of%20speed%20and%20influence.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBack%20in%20the%20late%20nineteen-nineties%2C%20the%20Democracy%20Party%20of%20China%20was%20a%20fringe%20group%20of%20radicals%20whom%20the%20government%20could%20easily%20quarantine.%20Reformist%20intellectuals%2C%20who%20supported%20a%20path%20of%20incremental%20change%2C%20viewed%20men%20like%20Jianguo%20as%20politically%20na%C3%AFve%20and%20their%20mission%20as%20suicidal.%20Few%20people%20even%20knew%20that%20his%20party%20existed.%20But%20now%2C%20using%20social%20media%2C%20Jianguo%20has%20accomplished%20something%20that%20his%20old%20comrades%20never%20could.%20He%20has%20reached%20the%20much%20larger%20camp%20of%20Chinese%20liberals%E2%80%94educated%20urbanites%20who%20generally%20embrace%20Western%20ideas%20of%20democracy%2C%20want%20the%20rule%20of%20law%2C%20and%20are%20critical%20of%20the%20party-state.%20Although%20they%20have%20flourished%20in%20China%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9Creform%20era%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94decades%20of%20fast%20growth%20that%20have%20brought%20them%20apartments%2C%20cars%2C%20holiday%20travels%2C%20study%20abroad%20for%20their%20children%E2%80%94they%20are%20mostly%20convinced%20of%20the%20superior%20vitality%20of%20the%20multiparty%20system.%20In%20a%20joke%20they%20liked%20about%20the%202016%20U.S.%20election%2C%20a%20bunch%20of%20eunuchs%20are%20so%20appalled%20by%20the%20bawdy%20quarrels%20among%20the%20married%20folk%20that%20they%20congratulate%20themselves%3A%20%E2%80%9CHow%20fortunate%20we%20are%20to%20be%20castrated!%E2%80%9D%20Yet%20many%20Chinese%20liberals%20doubt%20that%20the%20Western%20system%20is%20feasible%20in%20their%20country.%20They%20fret%20about%20the%20burden%20of%20history%2C%20about%20the%20prospect%20of%20chaos%20and%20mob%20rule.%20In%20their%20own%20lives%2C%20they%20avoid%20radicals%20and%20former%20political%20prisoners%2C%20for%20fear%20that%20such%20association%20might%20jeopardize%20their%20personal%20freedom.%20They%20shun%20the%20sort%20of%20political%20action%20that%20could%20put%20their%20comfortable%20life%20style%20at%20risk.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThese%20are%20the%20people%20I%E2%80%99m%20friends%20with%20in%20Beijing%3B%20they%20know%20me%20as%20a%20writer%20and%20as%20someone%20who%2C%20for%20years%2C%20was%20a%20regular%20presence%20on%20a%20moderate-liberal%20TV%20talk%20show%20that%20they%20all%20watched.%20(Which%20is%20to%20say%2C%20I%E2%80%99m%20mindful%20of%20what%20lines%20can%E2%80%99t%20be%20crossed%20when%20addressing%20the%20Chinese%20public%20on%20Chinese%20airwaves.)%20So%20why%20are%20so%20many%20of%20these%20liberals%20now%20reading%20the%20views%20of%20a%20radical%20like%20my%20brother%20Jianguo%3F%20One%20factor%20is%20the%20darkening%20of%20China%E2%80%99s%20political%20landscape.%20Xi%20Jinping%E2%80%99s%20initial%20speeches%20as%20President%20about%20%E2%80%9Cputting%20power%20into%20a%20cage%E2%80%9D%20had%20given%20hope%20to%20many%20liberal%20pragmatists%2C%20but%20what%20he%20really%20meant%20quickly%20became%20clear%3A%20he%20intended%20to%20cage%20any%20threats%20to%20his%20own%20authority.%20And%20he%20has%20managed%20to%20do%20so%20through%20a%20ruthlessly%20extralegal%20anticorruption%20campaign%2C%20all%20in%20the%20name%20of%20%E2%80%9Cstrengthening%20the%20rule%20of%20law%20under%20the%20Party%20leadership.%E2%80%9D%20Amid%20ever%20harsher%20crackdowns%20on%20civil%20society%2C%20many%20previously%20tolerated%20liberals%20are%20feeling%20a%20chill%3A%20every%20day%2C%20there%E2%80%99s%20more%20news%20about%20arrests%2C%20detention%2C%20censorship%2C%20and%20blackmail.%20Investigative%20journalists%2C%20public%20intellectuals%2C%20media%20critics%2C%20college%20professors%2C%20editors%20and%20publishers%2C%20human-rights%20lawyers%2C%20and%20environmental%20activists%E2%80%94nobody%20feels%20safe%20anymore.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Recently, the Beijing police took my brother sightseeing again. Nine days, two guards, chauffeured tours through a national park that’s a World Heritage site, visits to Taoist temples and to the Three Gorges, expenses fully covered, all courtesy of the Ministry of Public Security. The point was to get him out of town during the 2018 Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, held in early September. The capital had to be in a state of perfect order; no trace of trouble was permissible. And Zha Jianguo, a veteran democracy activist, is considered a professional troublemaker."],["p","While ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/xi-jinping"},"President Xi Jinping"]," played host to African dignitaries in the Great Hall of the People, the police played host to my big brother at various scenic spots in the province of Hubei, about a thousand kilometres away. A number of other Beijing activists and civil-rights lawyers, including several whom Jianguo knows well, were treated to similar trips. Pu Zhiqiang headed for Sichuan, Hu Jia to the port city of Tianjin, He Depu to the grasslands of Inner Mongolia, and Zhang Baocheng to Sanya, a beach resort on Hainan Island. Kept busy in the midst of natural beauty and attended to closely, they had no chance to speak to members of the foreign media or post provocative remarks online."],["p","This practice is known as ",["em","bei lüyou"],", “to be touristed.” The term is one of those sly inventions favored by Chinese netizens: whenever law enforcement frames people, or otherwise conscripts them into an activity, the prefix ",["em","bei"]," is used to indicate the passive tense. Hence: ",["em","bei loushui"]," (to be tax-evaded), ",["em","bei zisha"]," (to be suicided), ",["em","bei piaochang"]," (to be johned), and so on. In the past few years, the ",["em","bei"]," list has been growing longer, the acts more imaginative and colorful. “To be touristed” is no doubt the most appealing of these scenarios, and it is available only to a select number of troublemakers. In Beijing, perhaps dozens of people a year are whisked off on these exotic trips, typically diehard dissidents who have served time and are on the radar of Western human-rights organizations and media outlets. Outside the capital, the list includes not just activists but also petitioners (",["em","fangmin"],")—ordinary people from rural villages or small towns who travel to voice their grievances to high government officials about local malfeasances they have suffered from."],["p","Jianguo became a tourist only in recent years, but he has been a target of governmental attention for more than two decades. In 1999, he was given a nine-year prison sentence for helping to found a small opposition group, the Democracy Party of China, the year before. Since his release, in 2008, he has lived under constant police surveillance, which is ratcheted up during “sensitive” periods. For three months surrounding the Beijing Summer Olympics that year, the police parked in front of his apartment building night and day. Officers periodically knocked on his door to search his home, and followed him everywhere he went. Just as polluting factories were shut down and a barrage of rain-dispelling rockets were launched to insure clear skies during the Games, political irritants were vigorously contained."],["p","China has grown wealthier and more powerful in the ensuing years, and, as it hosts more global forums, there are more sensitive dates on the state’s calendar—Party congresses, trade summits, multinational meetings. Old imperial powers, with deep pockets and grand ambitions, tend to be fastidious about their image as host and benefactor, and China has always set great store by ceremony. Each occasion is vulnerable to disruption by protesters, so care is taken to sweep them out of sight. All major state functions have so far run without a hitch: perfect weather, perfect banquets, and perfect citizens waving glow sticks. Since 2011, China’s annual spending on domestic ",["em","weiwen"],", or “stability maintenance,” has, according to some reports, surpassed defense spending."],["p","But how serious is the threat of a disruption? After Jianguo and his comrades launched the Democracy Party, all its leaders were swiftly sent to prison, and, for the past ten years, Jianguo has been a solitary critic, with no party affiliation, no N.G.O. membership, no local or foreign patron. Now sixty-seven years old, he lives alone, having moved to a ground-floor apartment because he tires when climbing stairs. He eats and drinks modestly: mostly vegetables, a light beer or two. Having lost a lot of hair during his prison years, he shaves his head. He used to hold forth at meals; now he listens more than he talks. His smile is serene, as if to convey that all under Heaven is forgiven. Someone remarked to me once, “Your brother looks like a Buddha now.”"],["p","Yet, in recent years, the Chinese government has come to see him as more, not less, of a security threat. The authorities monitor his phone, block some of his messages, and bar him from certain gatherings. During sensitive periods, he is watched and followed around the clock. On ",["em","bei lüyou"]," trips, three officers usually accompany him, often including one who sleeps in his hotel room."],["p","Why do they think he is so dangerous? My brother may no longer operate a party cell, but—like more than a billion other Chinese citizens—he does have a cell phone. He regularly posts his analyses of current events in online groups, and he has become an increasingly prominent pundit on the Chinese Internet. Since 2012, Jianguo has trained his criticism chiefly on one target: the ",["em","Global Times"]," (",["em","Huanqiu Shibao"],"), a pro-government, strongly nationalistic, and influential tabloid daily, which is distributed widely under the auspices of the ",["em","People’s Daily."]," In a series labelled “Debating the ",["em","Global Times"],",” Jianguo took up editorials and scrutinized them point by point."],["p","Looking at his posts, I used to marvel at his bullheadedness, but the whole thing seemed to me like playing a game of solitaire; the posts appeared to go unnoticed. Gradually, however, I saw that Jianguo was honing a new voice, and gaining a following. From 2012 to 2017, he produced, with accelerating frequency, a total of four hundred and fifty-six “Debating the ",["em","Global Times"],"” posts. He was helped by the explosive growth of WeChat, the messaging and social-media app: by 2015, Jianguo was sending a new post every other day to between fifty and seventy WeChat groups, reaching tens of thousands of readers."],["p","He’s part of a broader trend. Since organized opposition is impossible, protest and resistance have increasingly shifted to the Internet. Spotlighting abuse and corruption, online critics and bloggers have often succeeded in rallying public opinion and pressuring authorities to act. Online platforms like WeChat and Weibo, in their fragmented immensity, can still provide badly needed public spaces for critical exchange, as well as bonding and camaraderie, all with the advantage of speed and influence."],["p","Back in the late nineteen-nineties, the Democracy Party of China was a fringe group of radicals whom the government could easily quarantine. Reformist intellectuals, who supported a path of incremental change, viewed men like Jianguo as politically naïve and their mission as suicidal. Few people even knew that his party existed. But now, using social media, Jianguo has accomplished something that his old comrades never could. He has reached the much larger camp of Chinese liberals—educated urbanites who generally embrace Western ideas of democracy, want the rule of law, and are critical of the party-state. Although they have flourished in China’s “reform era”—decades of fast growth that have brought them apartments, cars, holiday travels, study abroad for their children—they are mostly convinced of the superior vitality of the multiparty system. In a joke they liked about the 2016 U.S. election, a bunch of eunuchs are so appalled by the bawdy quarrels among the married folk that they congratulate themselves: “How fortunate we are to be castrated!” Yet many Chinese liberals doubt that the Western system is feasible in their country. They fret about the burden of history, about the prospect of chaos and mob rule. In their own lives, they avoid radicals and former political prisoners, for fear that such association might jeopardize their personal freedom. They shun the sort of political action that could put their comfortable life style at risk."],["p","These are the people I’m friends with in Beijing; they know me as a writer and as someone who, for years, was a regular presence on a moderate-liberal TV talk show that they all watched. (Which is to say, I’m mindful of what lines can’t be crossed when addressing the Chinese public on Chinese airwaves.) So why are so many of these liberals now reading the views of a radical like my brother Jianguo? One factor is the darkening of China’s political landscape. Xi Jinping’s initial speeches as President about “putting power into a cage” had given hope to many liberal pragmatists, but what he really meant quickly became clear: he intended to cage any threats to his own authority. And he has managed to do so through a ruthlessly extralegal anticorruption campaign, all in the name of “strengthening the rule of law under the Party leadership.” Amid ever harsher crackdowns on civil society, many previously tolerated liberals are feeling a chill: every day, there’s more news about arrests, detention, censorship, and blackmail. Investigative journalists, public intellectuals, media critics, college professors, editors and publishers, human-rights lawyers, and environmental activists—nobody feels safe anymore."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EOne%20evening%20in%20June%2C%202017%2C%20as%20I%20was%20leaving%20my%20Beijing%20apartment%20to%20meet%20some%20cousins%20of%20mine%20for%20dinner%2C%20I%20got%20a%20text%20message%20from%20a%20friend%2C%20a%20law%20professor%2C%20saying%20that%20the%20police%20had%20taken%20my%20brother%20away.%20Jianguo%20had%20planned%20to%20join%20us%20for%20dinner%20that%20evening%20but%20called%20the%20day%20before%20to%20cancel%2C%20because%20police%20were%20already%20stationed%20outside%20his%20building%2C%20in%20anticipation%20of%20the%20twenty-eighth%20anniversary%20of%20the%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2FTiananmen%2520Square%5C%22%3ETiananmen%20Square%3C%2Fa%3E%20massacre.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522cartoon%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522cartoon%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fcartoon%25252F5c12c19590c3112cd5d89aea%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c12c19590c3112cd5d89aea%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c12c19590c3112cd5d89aea%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12c19590c3112cd5d89aea%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EWhat%20I%20didn%E2%80%99t%20realize%20was%20that%2C%20the%20day%20before%20his%20arrest%2C%20Jianguo%20had%20posted%20a%20short%20piece%20in%20which%20he%20pointed%20out%20the%20political%20instability%20of%20the%20moment%20and%20the%20possibility%20of%20an%20accidental%20eruption.%20He%20then%20sketched%20out%20a%20potential%20cascade%20of%20protests%20and%20crackdowns%2C%20which%20could%20culminate%20in%20a%20military%20coup.%20The%20next%20day%2C%20while%20the%20piece%20circulated%20among%20his%20WeChat%20groups%2C%20Jianguo%20went%20to%20a%20neighborhood%20massage%20parlor.%20Herbal%20pads%20were%20being%20laid%20on%20his%20face%20when%20the%20manager%20rushed%20in.%20%E2%80%9CSome%20men%20at%20the%20door%20want%20to%20see%20you%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20told%20him%20breathlessly.%20Jianguo%20assumed%20it%20was%20his%20usual%20tails.%20%E2%80%9CTell%20them%20to%20wait%20outside%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20told%20the%20manager.%20But%20a%20moment%20later%20she%20returned%2C%20looking%20terrified.%20The%20men%20had%20shown%20her%20their%20police%20I.D.s%2C%20and%20insisted%20that%20her%20client%20come%20out%20right%20away.%20Jianguo%20knew%20then%20that%20it%20was%20serious.%20%E2%80%9COh%2C%20well%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said%2C%20apologizing.%20%E2%80%9CLooks%20like%20I%20can%E2%80%99t%20finish%20the%20facial%20today.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EWhen%20I%20got%20the%20news%20of%20Jianguo%E2%80%99s%20arrest%2C%20I%20called%20his%20cell%20phone%2C%20to%20no%20avail.%20After%20alerting%20his%20daughter%2C%20Huiyi%2C%20who%20lives%20in%20Orlando%2C%20I%20set%20off%20for%20the%20restaurant.%20My%20cousins%20were%20concerned%2C%20but%20not%20greatly%3B%20maybe%20we%20had%20all%20grown%20a%20little%20blas%C3%A9%20after%20witnessing%20Jianguo%E2%80%99s%20skillful%20dealings%20with%20the%20police%20for%20so%20many%20years.%20As%20we%20were%20leaving%20the%20restaurant%2C%20I%20got%20a%20message%20from%20a%20family%20friend%20who%20had%20stopped%20by%20Jianguo%E2%80%99s%20apartment.%20I%20clicked%20open%20an%20image%20of%20my%20brother%2C%20seated%20in%20his%20living%20room%2C%20in%20handcuffs%20and%20an%20olive-green%20prison%20uniform.%20The%20police%20had%20brought%20him%20home%20to%20conduct%20a%20search%20but%20were%20about%20to%20take%20him%20away%20again.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EI%20called%20various%20activists%20and%20lawyers%2C%20and%20made%20plans%20to%20meet%20at%20Jianguo%E2%80%99s%20apartment%20the%20following%20morning.%20My%20friends%20persuaded%20me%20that%20we%20should%20keep%20the%20news%20of%20his%20detention%20to%20ourselves%2C%20and%20make%20private%2C%20direct%20contact%20with%20the%20police.%20The%20next%20morning%2C%20to%20my%20surprise%2C%20I%20reached%20the%20district%20police%20officer%20in%20charge%20of%20the%20case%2C%20Officer%20Liu%2C%20on%20the%20first%20try.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20Jianguo%E2%80%99s%E2%80%94%E2%80%9D%20I%20began%2C%20and%20Liu%20replied%2C%20simply%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20know%20who%20you%20are.%E2%80%9D%20He%20assured%20me%20that%20he%20would%20meet%20me%20straightaway.%20I%20waited%20at%20Jianguo%E2%80%99s%20apartment%20for%20hours.%20Just%20as%20I%20was%20giving%20up%20hope%2C%20the%20door%20opened%2C%20revealing%20several%20uniformed%20police%20officers%20and%20Jianguo%E2%80%99s%20smiling%20face.%20Officer%20Liu%2C%20a%20genial-looking%20man%20who%20appeared%20to%20be%20in%20his%20late%20thirties%2C%20greeted%20me%20politely%20but%20clearly%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20eager%20to%20engage%20in%20a%20conversation.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20don%E2%80%99t%20want%20to%20interrupt%20the%20family%20reunion%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said%20quietly%2C%20before%20leaving.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","One evening in June, 2017, as I was leaving my Beijing apartment to meet some cousins of mine for dinner, I got a text message from a friend, a law professor, saying that the police had taken my brother away. Jianguo had planned to join us for dinner that evening but called the day before to cancel, because police were already stationed outside his building, in anticipation of the twenty-eighth anniversary of the ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/Tiananmen%20Square"},"Tiananmen Square"]," massacre."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c12c19590c3112cd5d89aea%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12c19590c3112cd5d89aea%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c12c19590c3112cd5d89aea%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c12c19590c3112cd5d89aea"}]],["p","What I didn’t realize was that, the day before his arrest, Jianguo had posted a short piece in which he pointed out the political instability of the moment and the possibility of an accidental eruption. He then sketched out a potential cascade of protests and crackdowns, which could culminate in a military coup. The next day, while the piece circulated among his WeChat groups, Jianguo went to a neighborhood massage parlor. Herbal pads were being laid on his face when the manager rushed in. “Some men at the door want to see you,” she told him breathlessly. Jianguo assumed it was his usual tails. “Tell them to wait outside,” he told the manager. But a moment later she returned, looking terrified. The men had shown her their police I.D.s, and insisted that her client come out right away. Jianguo knew then that it was serious. “Oh, well,” he said, apologizing. “Looks like I can’t finish the facial today.”"],["p","When I got the news of Jianguo’s arrest, I called his cell phone, to no avail. After alerting his daughter, Huiyi, who lives in Orlando, I set off for the restaurant. My cousins were concerned, but not greatly; maybe we had all grown a little blasé after witnessing Jianguo’s skillful dealings with the police for so many years. As we were leaving the restaurant, I got a message from a family friend who had stopped by Jianguo’s apartment. I clicked open an image of my brother, seated in his living room, in handcuffs and an olive-green prison uniform. The police had brought him home to conduct a search but were about to take him away again."],["p","I called various activists and lawyers, and made plans to meet at Jianguo’s apartment the following morning. My friends persuaded me that we should keep the news of his detention to ourselves, and make private, direct contact with the police.
