\u003c/g>\u003c/svg>"}}},{"body":["div",["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EShachar%20Pinsker%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FRich-Brew-Created-Modern-Culture%2Fdp%2F1479827894%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545058124%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3Da%2Brich%2Bbrew%2Bhow%2Bcaf%25C3%25A9s%2Bcreated%2Bmodern%2Bjewish%2Bculture%5C%22%3EA%20Rich%20Brew%3A%20How%20Caf%C3%A9s%20Created%20Modern%20Jewish%20Culture%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20(New%20York%20University)%20might%20seem%2C%20at%20a%20glance%2C%20like%20one%20of%20those%20%E2%80%9CBagels%20of%20Our%20Fathers%E2%80%9D%20books%20that%20a%20Leo%20Rosten%20could%20have%20written%20back%20when%20Jewishness%2C%20as%20a%20cultural%20subject%2C%20still%20struck%20Americans%20as%20fresh%20and%20mostly%20funny.%20The%20cover%20shows%20an%20appealing%20pastel%20of%20a%20sunny%2C%20amazingly%20high-ceilinged%20and%20arch-filled%20caf%C3%A9%20in%20Berlin%E2%80%94a%20lost%20Eden%20of%20conviviality%20and%20conversation.%20And%20the%20book%20itself%20is%20hugely%20entertaining%20and%20intimidatingly%20well%20researched%2C%20with%20scarcely%20a%20caf%C3%A9%20in%20which%20a%20Jewish%20writer%20raised%20a%20cup%20of%20coffee%20from%20Warsaw%20to%20New%20York%20left%20undocumented.%20Yet%20it%E2%80%99s%20really%20a%20close%20empirical%20study%20of%20an%20abstract%20political%20theory.%20The%20theory%2C%20associated%20with%20the%20eminent%20German%20sociologist%20and%20philosopher%20J%C3%BCrgen%20Habermas%2C%20is%20that%20the%20coffeehouses%20and%20salons%20of%20the%20seventeenth%20and%20eighteenth%20centuries%20helped%20lay%20the%20foundation%20for%20the%20liberal%20Enlightenment%E2%80%94a%20caffeinated%20pathway%20out%20of%20clan%20society%20into%20cosmopolitan%20society.%20Democracy%20was%20not%20made%20in%20the%20streets%20but%20among%20the%20saucers.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EWhen%20social%20spaces%20were%20created%20outside%20the%20direct%20control%20of%20the%20state%20(including%20commercial%20ones%2C%20run%20for%20profit)%2C%20civil%20society%20could%20start%20to%20flourish%20in%20unexpected%20ways.%20This%20was%20visible%20in%20the%20spread%20of%20caf%C3%A9%20life%20through%20European%20cities%2C%20Pinsker%20observes%2C%20in%20the%20nineteenth%20century%20and%20afterward.%20It%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20that%20the%20conversations%20in%20the%20caf%C3%A9%20were%20necessarily%20intellectually%20productive%3B%20it%20was%20that%20the%20practice%20of%20free%20exchange%20itself%E2%80%94the%20ability%20to%20interact%20on%20equal%20terms%20with%20someone%20not%20of%20your%20clan%20or%20club%E2%80%94generated%20social%20habits%20of%20self-expression%20that%20abetted%20the%20appetite%20for%20self-government.%20For%20Jews%2C%20with%20their%20constant%20habit%20of%20self-expression%20and%20their%20distant%20dream%20of%20self-government%2C%20the%20caf%C3%A9%20was%20an%20especially%20inviting%20space.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Shachar Pinsker’s “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Rich-Brew-Created-Modern-Culture/dp/1479827894/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545058124&sr=1-1&keywords=a+rich+brew+how+caf%C3%A9s+created+modern+jewish+culture"},"A Rich Brew: How Cafés Created Modern Jewish Culture"],"” (New York University) might seem, at a glance, like one of those “Bagels of Our Fathers” books that a Leo Rosten could have written back when Jewishness, as a cultural subject, still struck Americans as fresh and mostly funny. The cover shows an appealing pastel of a sunny, amazingly high-ceilinged and arch-filled café in Berlin—a lost Eden of conviviality and conversation. And the book itself is hugely entertaining and intimidatingly well researched, with scarcely a café in which a Jewish writer raised a cup of coffee from Warsaw to New York left undocumented. Yet it’s really a close empirical study of an abstract political theory. The theory, associated with the eminent German sociologist and philosopher Jürgen Habermas, is that the coffeehouses and salons of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries helped lay the foundation for the liberal Enlightenment—a caffeinated pathway out of clan society into cosmopolitan society. Democracy was not made in the streets but among the saucers."],["p","When social spaces were created outside the direct control of the state (including commercial ones, run for profit), civil society could start to flourish in unexpected ways. This was visible in the spread of café life through European cities, Pinsker observes, in the nineteenth century and afterward. It wasn’t that the conversations in the café were necessarily intellectually productive; it was that the practice of free exchange itself—the ability to interact on equal terms with someone not of your clan or club—generated social habits of self-expression that abetted the appetite for self-government. For Jews, with their constant habit of self-expression and their distant dream of self-government, the café was an especially inviting space."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThere%20was%20a%20time%E2%80%94astonishing%20to%20a%20contemporary%20New%20Yorker%2C%20shuffling%20ratlike%20to%20a%20precarious%20lunchtime%20perch%20at%20a%20Hale%20and%20Hearty%20Soups%E2%80%94when%20the%20places%20you%E2%80%99d%20go%20for%20a%20nosh%20and%20a%20cup%20were%20genuinely%20splendid%2C%20spacious%20and%20rich%20in%20an%20overcharge%20of%20luxury.%20The%20Israeli%20Nobel%20laureate%20Shmuel%20Agnon%20wrote%20of%20his%20first%20experience%20as%20a%20kid%20from%20a%20town%20in%20Galicia%20visiting%20a%20big-city%20caf%C3%A9%20in%20Lviv%3A%20%E2%80%9CGilded%20chandeliers%20suspended%20from%20the%20ceiling%20and%20lamps%20shining%20from%20every%20single%20wall%20and%20electric%20lights%20turned%20on%20in%20the%20daytime%20and%20marble%20tables%20gleaming%2C%20and%20people%20of%20stately%20mien%20wearing%20distinguished%20clothes%20sitting%20on%20plush%20chairs%2C%20reading%20big%20newspapers.%20And%20above%20them%2C%20waiters%20dressed%20like%20dignitaries.%E2%80%9D%20All%20that%20for%20the%20price%20of%20a%20coffee.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EOne%20of%20the%20pleasures%20of%20Pinsker%E2%80%99s%20book%2C%20for%20anyone%20with%20a%20longing%20for%20a%20lost%20era%20of%20public%20splendor%2C%20is%20to%20be%20introduced%20to%20the%20locales%20where%20people%20shared%20that%20splendor.%20In%20Vienna%2C%20the%20Caf%C3%A9%20Griensteidl%20proved%20a%20magnet%20for%20%E2%80%9Cmalcontents%20and%20raisonneurs%2C%E2%80%9D%20with%20bentwood%20chairs%20and%20plenty%20of%20reading%20light%20and%20newspapers%20on%20sticks.%20The%20still%20extant%20Caf%C3%A9%20Central%20had%20an%20interior%20like%20a%20miniaturized%20San%20Marco%2C%20with%20hallucinatory%20Byzantine%20columns%20and%20swooping%20enclosing%20spandrels%20and%20squinches.%20(The%20fin-de-si%C3%A8cle%20modernist%20writer%20Peter%20Altenberg%20listed%20his%20address%20as%20%E2%80%9CVienna%2C%20First%20District%2C%20Caf%C3%A9%20Central.%E2%80%9D)%20Yet%20in%20its%20prime%20it%20was%20a%20%E2%80%9Cplace%20of%20politics%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20crowded%20with%20%C3%A9migr%C3%A9%20revolutionaries.%20A%20famous%20story%20had%20Leopold%20Berchtold%2C%20the%20Foreign%20Minister%20of%20the%20Austro-Hungarian%20Empire%2C%20being%20warned%20that%20a%20great%20war%20might%20spark%20a%20revolution%20in%20Russia.%20%E2%80%9CAnd%20who%20will%20lead%20this%20revolution%3F%E2%80%9D%20he%20scoffed.%20%E2%80%9CPerhaps%20Mr.%20Bronshtein%20sitting%20over%20there%20at%20the%20Caf%C3%A9%20Central%3F%E2%80%9D%20Mr.%20Bronshtein%20took%20the%20name%20Leon%20Trotsky%2C%20and%20did.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EFor%20Jews%2C%20Pinsker%20argues%2C%20the%20investment%20in%20the%20caf%C3%A9%20as%20a%20social%20institution%20was%2C%20across%20Europe%20through%20the%20nineteenth%20and%20early%20twentieth%20centuries%2C%20particularly%20intense.%20The%20great%20caf%C3%A9s%20were%20%E2%80%9Cthirdspaces%2C%E2%80%9D%20neither%20entirely%20public%20nor%20entirely%20private%3B%20they%20were%20escape%20zones%20where%2C%20contrary%20to%20the%20theme%20from%20%E2%80%9CCheers%2C%E2%80%9D%20people%20often%20%3Cem%3Edidn%E2%80%99t%3C%2Fem%3E%20know%20your%20name%2C%20or%20what%20shtetl%20you%20hailed%20from.%20A%20patriotic%20Polish%20writer%20could%20meet%20other%20Polish%20patriots%20at%20a%20Warsaw%20caf%C3%A9%2C%20read%20the%20papers%2C%20make%20plans%2C%20share%20poems%2C%20or%20just%20decide%20to%20flee%20to%20Paris.%20A%20Jewish%20writer%20in%20the%20same%20caf%C3%A9%20had%20first%20to%20decide%20just%20how%20Polish%20to%20appear%2C%20and%20just%20how%20Jewish%20to%20remain.%20This%20affected%20how%20he%20dressed%20and%20whom%20he%20sat%20with%2C%20but%20also%20which%20language%20he%20wrote%20in%2C%20Yiddish%20or%20Polish%2C%20and%20what%20he%20chose%20to%20write%20about%20as%20he%20sat%20there.%20Pinsker%2C%20who%20teaches%20Judaic%20studies%20at%20the%20University%20of%20Michigan%2C%20tells%20the%20story%20of%20how%2C%20in%20Warsaw%20in%20the%20nineteen-thirties%2C%20a%20group%20of%20Jewish%20actors%20came%20into%20a%20caf%C3%A9%2C%20dressed%2C%20as%20a%20comic%20provocation%2C%20as%20%E2%80%9CJews%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94in%20caftans%20and%20fake%20beards%E2%80%94and%20were%20urged%20by%20the%20manager%20to%20go%20elsewhere.%20It%20was%20the%20Jewish%20regulars%20who%20were%20made%20most%20uncomfortable%20by%20the%20practical%20joke.%20Not%20because%20they%20were%20ashamed%E2%80%94as%20writers%2C%20they%20often%20wrote%20unabashedly%20as%20Jews%E2%80%94but%20because%20they%20were%20suddenly%20made%20aware%20of%20the%20ambiguities%20that%20they%20relied%20upon.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20caf%C3%A9s%20of%20the%20various%20European%20cities%20that%20Pinsker%20focusses%20on%E2%80%94Warsaw%2C%20Vienna%2C%20and%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fberlin%5C%22%3EBerlin%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%94reflected%2C%20with%20startling%20specificity%2C%20the%20Jewish%20reality%20around%20them.%20In%20Warsaw%2C%20which%20had%20Europe%E2%80%99s%20largest%20concentration%20of%20Jews%20(and%20a%20vast%20hinterland%20of%20orthodoxy)%2C%20the%20struggle%20for%20Jews%20to%20be%20both%20Poles%20and%20Jews%2C%20or%20neither%20Poles%20nor%20Jews%2C%20takes%20on%20particular%20pathos.%20The%20Warsaw%20caf%C3%A9%20beats%20out%20a%20theme%20of%20%E2%80%9COtherness%E2%80%9D%20and%20%E2%80%9CDifference.%E2%80%9D%20Many%20Jews%20were%20at%20once%20proud%20to%20be%20different%20and%20conscious%20of%20being%20readily%20%E2%80%9COthered%2C%E2%80%9D%20even%20when%20they%20felt%20most%20at%20home.%20In%20the%20nineteen-twenties%2C%20the%20poet%20Antoni%20Slonimski%20wrote%2C%20in%20Polish%2C%20a%20poem%20in%20which%20he%20asserted%20his%20dual%20love%20of%20a%20still%20gestating%20Israel%20and%20of%20Poland%2C%20merged%20into%20the%20image%20of%20a%20single%20idealized%20woman.%20(%E2%80%9CYou%20are%20my%20snowy%20Lebanon%2C%20dark-haired%20girl.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20For%20one%20kiss%20I%E2%80%99ll%20give%20two%20fatherlands.%E2%80%9D)%20Polish%20nationalists%20saw%20betrayal%20in%20his%20preference%20for%20pluralism.%20Later%2C%20Slonimski%20was%20assaulted%20in%20his%20caf%C3%A9%20by%20an%20indignant%20right-wing%20Pole.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20milieu%20of%20the%20Warsaw%20caf%C3%A9%20can%20even%20be%20seen%20as%20the%20basis%20of%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fcontributors%2Fisaac-bashevis-singer%5C%22%3EIsaac%20Bashevis%20Singer%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%99s%20entire%20%C5%93uvre.%20Singer%20wrote%20of%20his%20first%20night%20at%20a%20famous%20Warsaw%20caf%C3%A9%3A%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cblockquote%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBefore%20I%20opened%20the%20door%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20I%20tried%20for%20some%20time%20to%20summon%20courage.%20Why%20am%20I%20trembling%20like%20this%3F%E2%80%94I%20asked%20myself.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20I%20opened%20the%20door%2C%20and%20I%20saw%20a%20hall.%20Opposite%2C%20on%20the%20other%20side%20of%20the%20hall%2C%20there%20was%20a%20buffet%2C%20like%20in%20a%20restaurant.%20The%20writers%20sat%20by%20the%20tables.%20Some%20of%20them%20ate%2C%20others%20played%20chess%2C%20and%20some%20chatted.%20All%20of%20them%20seemed%20terribly%20important%20to%20me%2C%20full%20of%20wisdom%20and%20higher%20knowledge%20of%20the%20kind%20that%20elevates%20man%20above%20worldly%20troubles.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20I%20expected%20someone%20to%20ask%20me%20who%20I%20am%2C%20what%20do%20I%20want%2C%20but%20no%20one%20approached%20me.%20I%20stood%20there%20with%20wide-open%20mouth.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Fblockquote%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESinger%20eventually%20transposed%20the%20complexities%20of%20that%20space%E2%80%94the%20habit%20of%20argument%20and%20the%20uncertainty%20of%20origin%2C%20the%20pensive%20love%20stories%20shared%20and%20the%20brave%20assertions%20never%20quite%20backed%20up%E2%80%94into%20the%20humbler%20cafeterias%20of%20the%20Upper%20West%20Side.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20talk%20and%20arguments%20that%20went%20on%20in%20the%20caf%C3%A9s%20covered%20every%20imaginable%20subject%20under%20the%20Jewish%20sun%2C%20and%20the%20Gentile%20ones%2C%20too.%20Emigration%2C%20Zionism%2C%20assimilation%2C%20the%20flight%20to%20America%2C%20the%20urge%20to%20stay%20home.%20The%20caf%C3%A9s%20%E2%80%9Care%20the%20meeting%20place%20of%20the%20like-minded%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20journalist%20wrote%20in%20the%20early%20years%20of%20Berlin%E2%80%99s%20caf%C3%A9%20culture.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20merchant%20who%20wants%20to%20consider%20his%20affairs%20and%20the%20status%20of%20his%20stocks%20with%20someone%3B%20the%20journalist%20who%20must%20hear%20the%20latest%20and%20must%20catch%20up%20on%20the%20day%E2%80%99s%20events%20from%20the%20newspaper%3B%20the%20man%20of%20private%20means%20who%20does%20nothing%20and%20yet%20wishes%20to%20appear%20as%20something%3B%20officers%2C%20students%2C%20in%20short%2C%20everyone%20who%20has%20any%20kind%20of%20interest%20at%20all%20in%20public%20life.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20caf%C3%A9s%20became%20theatres%20of%20flirtation%20and%20romance%20as%20well%2C%20especially%20in%20interwar%20Vienna.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20presence%20of%20so%20many%20women%20in%20the%20caf%C3%A9s%2C%E2%80%9D%20Pinsker%20notes%2C%20%E2%80%9Cis%20described%20in%20literary%20texts%20by%20mostly%20male%20Jewish%20writers.%E2%80%9D%20One%20of%20them%2C%20Melech%20Chmelnitzki%2C%20wrote%20a%20Yiddish%20poem%20titled%20%E2%80%9CBeautiful%2C%20Strange%20Woman%20in%20a%20Noisy%20Caf%C3%A9.%E2%80%9D%20The%20caf%C3%A9s%20remained%2C%20though%2C%20largely%20a%20male%20preserve.%20Vicki%20Baum%2C%20who%20began%20her%20literary%20career%20in%20Vienna%20and%20went%20on%20to%20write%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FGrand-Hotel-Review-Books-Classics%2Fdp%2F1590179676%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545058287%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DGrand%2BHotel%2Bbaum%5C%22%3EGrand%20Hotel%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20adapted%20into%20the%20movie%20for%20M-G-M%2C%20said%2C%20acidly%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20don%E2%80%99t%20remember%20a%20ladies%E2%80%99%20room%20in%20the%20%3Cem%3EKaffeehaus%3C%2Fem%3E.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EEach%20caf%C3%A9%20town%20had%20its%20own%20character.%20In%20Vienna%2C%20the%20caf%C3%A9%20city%20par%20excellence%2C%20the%20Jewish%20caf%C3%A9goer%20wanted%20to%20seem%20not%20Austrian%20but%2C%20instead%2C%20a%20sophisticated%20cosmopolitan.%20City%20pride%20was%20the%20keynote.%20The%20patron%20writer-saint%20of%20the%20Viennese%20caf%C3%A9%20in%20the%20first%20third%20of%20the%20twentieth%20century%20was%20Karl%20Kraus%2C%20who%20was%20at%20once%20Jewish%20and%20anti-Semitic%2C%20a%20satirist%20of%20the%20caf%C3%A9s%20and%20a%20habitu%C3%A9%20of%20them.%20In%20Berlin%2C%20you%20had%20a%20smaller%20Jewish%20population%20and%20a%20simpler%20problem%3A%20the%20choice%20seemed%20more%20narrowly%20poised%20between%20being%20Jewish%20and%20being%20German.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnd%20finally%2C%20in%20New%20York%2C%20as%20caf%C3%A9%20culture%20was%20exported%2C%20the%20model%20of%20the%20central%20caf%C3%A9%20in%20which%20all%20kinds%20come%20together%20often%20gave%20way%20to%20the%20neighborhood%20caf%C3%A9%20that%20belonged%20to%20a%20subsect%2C%20usually%20on%20the%20political%20left.%20Emma%20Goldman%2C%20as%20a%20young%20Russian%20immigrant%2C%20found%20herself%20at%20home%20in%20New%20York%20when%20she%20arrived%20at%20a%20Lower%20East%20Side%20caf%C3%A9%20that%20was%20well%20known%20as%20an%20anarchist%20hangout.%20The%20melting%20pot%20of%20New%20York%2C%20curiously%2C%20produced%20the%20most%20distinct%20and%20separate%20crucibles%2C%20each%20annealing%20the%20complexities%20of%20identity%20into%20political%20causes.%20In%20every%20case%2C%20you%20could%20see%20your%20life%20in%20a%20single%20commercial%20space.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","There was a time—astonishing to a contemporary New Yorker, shuffling ratlike to a precarious lunchtime perch at a Hale and Hearty Soups—when the places you’d go for a nosh and a cup were genuinely splendid, spacious and rich in an overcharge of luxury. The Israeli Nobel laureate Shmuel Agnon wrote of his first experience as a kid from a town in Galicia visiting a big-city café in Lviv: “Gilded chandeliers suspended from the ceiling and lamps shining from every single wall and electric lights turned on in the daytime and marble tables gleaming, and people of stately mien wearing distinguished clothes sitting on plush chairs, reading big newspapers. And above them, waiters dressed like dignitaries.” All that for the price of a coffee."],["p","One of the pleasures of Pinsker’s book, for anyone with a longing for a lost era of public splendor, is to be introduced to the locales where people shared that splendor. In Vienna, the Café Griensteidl proved a magnet for “malcontents and raisonneurs,” with bentwood chairs and plenty of reading light and newspapers on sticks. The still extant Café Central had an interior like a miniaturized San Marco, with hallucinatory Byzantine columns and swooping enclosing spandrels and squinches. (The fin-de-siècle modernist writer Peter Altenberg listed his address as “Vienna, First District, Café Central.”) Yet in its prime it was a “place of politics,” and crowded with émigré revolutionaries. A famous story had Leopold Berchtold, the Foreign Minister of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, being warned that a great war might spark a revolution in Russia. “And who will lead this revolution?” he scoffed. “Perhaps Mr. Bronshtein sitting over there at the Café Central?” Mr. Bronshtein took the name Leon Trotsky, and did."],["p","For Jews, Pinsker argues, the investment in the café as a social institution was, across Europe through the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, particularly intense. The great cafés were “thirdspaces,” neither entirely public nor entirely private; they were escape zones where, contrary to the theme from “Cheers,” people often ",["em","didn’t"]," know your name, or what shtetl you hailed from. A patriotic Polish writer could meet other Polish patriots at a Warsaw café, read the papers, make plans, share poems, or just decide to flee to Paris. A Jewish writer in the same café had first to decide just how Polish to appear, and just how Jewish to remain. This affected how he dressed and whom he sat with, but also which language he wrote in, Yiddish or Polish, and what he chose to write about as he sat there. Pinsker, who teaches Judaic studies at the University of Michigan, tells the story of how, in Warsaw in the nineteen-thirties, a group of Jewish actors came into a café, dressed, as a comic provocation, as “Jews”—in caftans and fake beards—and were urged by the manager to go elsewhere. It was the Jewish regulars who were made most uncomfortable by the practical joke. Not because they were ashamed—as writers, they often wrote unabashedly as Jews—but because they were suddenly made aware of the ambiguities that they relied upon."],["p","The cafés of the various European cities that Pinsker focusses on—Warsaw, Vienna, and ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/berlin"},"Berlin"],"—reflected, with startling specificity, the Jewish reality around them. In Warsaw, which had Europe’s largest concentration of Jews (and a vast hinterland of orthodoxy), the struggle for Jews to be both Poles and Jews, or neither Poles nor Jews, takes on particular pathos. The Warsaw café beats out a theme of “Otherness” and “Difference.” Many Jews were at once proud to be different and conscious of being readily “Othered,” even when they felt most at home. In the nineteen-twenties, the poet Antoni Slonimski wrote, in Polish, a poem in which he asserted his dual love of a still gestating Israel and of Poland, merged into the image of a single idealized woman. (“You are my snowy Lebanon, dark-haired girl. . . . For one kiss I’ll give two fatherlands.”) Polish nationalists saw betrayal in his preference for pluralism. Later, Slonimski was assaulted in his café by an indignant right-wing Pole."],["p","The milieu of the Warsaw café can even be seen as the basis of ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/contributors/isaac-bashevis-singer"},"Isaac Bashevis Singer"],"’s entire œuvre. Singer wrote of his first night at a famous Warsaw café:"],["blockquote",["p","Before I opened the door . . . I tried for some time to summon courage. Why am I trembling like this?—I asked myself. . . . I opened the door, and I saw a hall. Opposite, on the other side of the hall, there was a buffet, like in a restaurant. The writers sat by the tables. Some of them ate, others played chess, and some chatted. All of them seemed terribly important to me, full of wisdom and higher knowledge of the kind that elevates man above worldly troubles. . . . I expected someone to ask me who I am, what do I want, but no one approached me. I stood there with wide-open mouth."]],["p","Singer eventually transposed the complexities of that space—the habit of argument and the uncertainty of origin, the pensive love stories shared and the brave assertions never quite backed up—into the humbler cafeterias of the Upper West Side."],["p","The talk and arguments that went on in the cafés covered every imaginable subject under the Jewish sun, and the Gentile ones, too. Emigration, Zionism, assimilation, the flight to America, the urge to stay home. The cafés “are the meeting place of the like-minded,” a journalist wrote in the early years of Berlin’s café culture. “The merchant who wants to consider his affairs and the status of his stocks with someone; the journalist who must hear the latest and must catch up on the day’s events from the newspaper; the man of private means who does nothing and yet wishes to appear as something; officers, students, in short, everyone who has any kind of interest at all in public life.”"],["p","The cafés became theatres of flirtation and romance as well, especially in interwar Vienna. “The presence of so many women in the cafés,” Pinsker notes, “is described in literary texts by mostly male Jewish writers.” One of them, Melech Chmelnitzki, wrote a Yiddish poem titled “Beautiful, Strange Woman in a Noisy Café.” The cafés remained, though, largely a male preserve. Vicki Baum, who began her literary career in Vienna and went on to write “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Grand-Hotel-Review-Books-Classics/dp/1590179676/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545058287&sr=1-1&keywords=Grand+Hotel+baum"},"Grand Hotel"],",” adapted into the movie for M-G-M, said, acidly, “I don’t remember a ladies’ room in the ",["em","Kaffeehaus"],".”"],["p","Each café town had its own character. In Vienna, the café city par excellence, the Jewish cafégoer wanted to seem not Austrian but, instead, a sophisticated cosmopolitan. City pride was the keynote. The patron writer-saint of the Viennese café in the first third of the twentieth century was Karl Kraus, who was at once Jewish and anti-Semitic, a satirist of the cafés and a habitué of them. In Berlin, you had a smaller Jewish population and a simpler problem: the choice seemed more narrowly poised between being Jewish and being German."],["p","And finally, in New York, as café culture was exported, the model of the central café in which all kinds come together often gave way to the neighborhood café that belonged to a subsect, usually on the political left. Emma Goldman, as a young Russian immigrant, found herself at home in New York when she arrived at a Lower East Side café that was well known as an anarchist hangout. The melting pot of New York, curiously, produced the most distinct and separate crucibles, each annealing the complexities of identity into political causes. In every case, you could see your life in a single commercial space."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EPinsker%2C%20lovingly%20attentive%20to%20the%20habitu%C3%A9s%20of%20his%20caf%C3%A9s%2C%20leaves%20the%20economics%20of%20the%20caf%C3%A9s%20quite%20shadowy.%20The%20rule%2C%20still%20in%20place%20in%20much%20of%20Europe%2C%20was%20that%20you%20need%20buy%20only%20a%20cup%20of%20coffee%20to%20occupy%20a%20seat%20indefinitely.%20Customer%20loyalty%20is%20the%20commercial%20principle%20here.%20Better%20to%20sell%20the%20same%20writer%20a%20hundred%20cups%20of%20coffee%20than%20to%20sell%20a%20hundred%20writers%20one%20cup%20of%20coffee%2C%20since%20the%20hundred-cup%20man%20is%20almost%20certain%20to%20return%20for%20the%20next%20hundred%2C%20and%20the%20hundred%20after%20that.%20Recent%20scholarship%20has%20made%20the%20case%20that%20repeat%20business%20is%20worth%20much%20more%20to%20a%20small%20enterprise%20than%20new%20business%2C%20given%20the%20stability%20of%20%E2%80%9Crecurring%20revenue.%E2%80%9D%20The%20one%20proviso%20would%20seem%20to%20be%20that%20there%20has%20to%20be%20enough%20room%20for%20new%20customers%20to%20find%20a%20place.%20The%20caf%C3%A9%20can%E2%80%99t%20become%20too%20exclusive%20a%20club%20and%20remain%20profitable.%20This%20may%20be%20why%20the%20adjective%20regularly%20applied%20to%20the%20caf%C3%A9%20is%20%E2%80%9Cgrand%2C%E2%80%9D%20or%20why%20so%20many%20caf%C3%A9s%20in%20Europe%20were%20exceptionally%20large%20spaces%2C%20even%20if%2C%20to%20judge%20by%20contemporary%20drawings%20and%20photographs%2C%20they%20were%20seldom%20close%20to%20being%20fully%20occupied.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20one%20of%20the%20greatest%20of%20caf%C3%A9%20comedies%2C%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fcharlie-chaplin%5C%22%3ECharlie%20Chaplin%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FImmigrant-Charles-Chaplin%2Fdp%2FB07JWJTZ1J%2Fref%3Dsr_1_2%3Fie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545058342%26amp%3Bsr%3D8-2%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DThe%2BImmigrant%2Bchaplin%5C%22%3EThe%20Immigrant%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20tramp%2C%20newly%20arrived%20in%20America%20from%20an%20unnamed%20but%20clearly%20Eastern%20European%20place%20of%20origin%2C%20tries%20to%20put%20off%20the%20arrival%20of%20a%20check%20he%20can%E2%80%99t%20foot%20simply%20by%20ordering%20more%20coffee.%20And%20it%20mattered%20that%20what%20caf%C3%A9%20habitu%C3%A9s%20were%20habituated%20to%20was%20drinking%20coffee.%20Pinsker%20is%20oddly%20reticent%20about%20how%20the%20coffee%20was%20made%20and%20dispensed.%20For%20coffee%20is%20in%20itself%20a%20kind%20of%20wonder%20drug%E2%80%94a%20stimulant%20that%20seems%20to%20ease%20attention-based%20tasks.%20The%20shape%20and%20meaning%20of%20a%20caf%C3%A9%20surely%20has%20much%20to%20do%20with%20the%20connection%20between%20coffee%20and%20social%20stimulation.%20Indeed%2C%20one%20of%20the%20historical%20functions%20of%20coffee%20was%20to%20not%20be%20alcohol.%20European%20cultures%20that%20had%20always%20drunk%20beer%20instead%20of%20unsafe%20water%20were%20liberated%20from%20their%20own%20stupor%20by%20the%20rise%20of%20caffeinated%20brews.%20The%20caf%C3%A9s%20were%20training%20playgrounds%20in%20attentiveness.%20They%20made%20the%20town%20alert.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Pinsker, lovingly attentive to the habitués of his cafés, leaves the economics of the cafés quite shadowy. The rule, still in place in much of Europe, was that you need buy only a cup of coffee to occupy a seat indefinitely. Customer loyalty is the commercial principle here. Better to sell the same writer a hundred cups of coffee than to sell a hundred writers one cup of coffee, since the hundred-cup man is almost certain to return for the next hundred, and the hundred after that. Recent scholarship has made the case that repeat business is worth much more to a small enterprise than new business, given the stability of “recurring revenue.” The one proviso would seem to be that there has to be enough room for new customers to find a place. The café can’t become too exclusive a club and remain profitable. This may be why the adjective regularly applied to the café is “grand,” or why so many cafés in Europe were exceptionally large spaces, even if, to judge by contemporary drawings and photographs, they were seldom close to being fully occupied."],["p","In one of the greatest of café comedies, ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/charlie-chaplin"},"Charlie Chaplin"],"’s “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Immigrant-Charles-Chaplin/dp/B07JWJTZ1J/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1545058342&sr=8-2&keywords=The+Immigrant+chaplin"},"The Immigrant"],",” the tramp, newly arrived in America from an unnamed but clearly Eastern European place of origin, tries to put off the arrival of a check he can’t foot simply by ordering more coffee. And it mattered that what café habitués were habituated to was drinking coffee. Pinsker is oddly reticent about how the coffee was made and dispensed. For coffee is in itself a kind of wonder drug—a stimulant that seems to ease attention-based tasks. The shape and meaning of a café surely has much to do with the connection between coffee and social stimulation. Indeed, one of the historical functions of coffee was to not be alcohol. European cultures that had always drunk beer instead of unsafe water were liberated from their own stupor by the rise of caffeinated brews. The cafés were training playgrounds in attentiveness. They made the town alert."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EWhat%2C%20then%2C%20of%20the%20Habermasian%20vision%20of%20the%20caf%C3%A9%20as%20an%20arena%20of%20civil%20society%2C%20and%20of%20civil%20society%20as%20the%20foundation%20of%20enlightened%20societies%3F%20Certainly%20the%20caf%C3%A9%20could%20be%20the%20foundation%20of%20emancipated%20life%E2%80%94that%20was%20why%20Agnon%E2%80%99s%20generation%20rushed%20there%20so%20ardently.%20But%20the%20study%20reveals%20a%20paradox%20of%20some%20poignancy%3A%20no%20matter%20how%20elaborately%20articulated%2C%20no%20matter%20how%20high%20its%20ceilings%20and%20how%20dignified%20its%20servers%2C%20civil%20society%20can%E2%80%99t%20protect%20cosmopolitan%20communities%20from%20assault%20when%20it%20happens.%20The%20caf%C3%A9%20may%20have%20been%20a%20foundation%2C%20but%20it%20could%20never%20be%20a%20fortress.%20The%20most%20heartbreaking%20scenes%20in%20Pinsker%E2%80%99s%20book%20are%20from%20Warsaw%2C%20where%20much%20loved%20ghetto%20institutions%20like%20Caf%C3%A9%20Sztuka%20stayed%20in%20business%20right%20up%20to%20the%20final%20expulsion%20of%20the%20Jews%20to%20Treblinka%2C%20in%201943.%20Singers%20sang%20and%20dancers%20danced%2C%20with%20the%20forbearance%20of%20easily%20bribed%20Germans%2C%20and%20while%20many%20condemned%20the%20frivolity%20(and%20the%20implicit%20collaboration%20with%20the%20Germans)%20of%20these%20last%20caf%C3%A9s%2C%20the%20writer%20Michel%20Mazor%20rightly%20praised%20their%20%E2%80%9Ccontinuous%20existence%20in%20a%20city%20which%20the%20Germans%20regarded%20as%20a%20cemetery%E2%80%94was%20it%20not%2C%20in%20a%20certain%20sense%2C%20the%20ghetto%E2%80%99s%20protest%2C%20its%20affirmation%20of%20the%20right%20to%20live%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EPinsker%20ends%20his%20book%20with%20a%20melancholy%20account%20of%20a%20couple%20on%20the%20Lower%20East%20Side%20of%20Manhattan%20who%20attempted%20to%20open%20a%20classic%20Central%20European-style%20caf%C3%A9%20a%20decade%20or%20so%20ago%20and%20failed.%20The%20rent%20was%20too%20high%2C%20the%20clientele%20too%20restless.%20Still%2C%20the%20streets%20of%20every%20American%20city%20these%20days%20are%20littered%20with%20coffee%20shops%20that%20attract%20hordes%20of%20laptop-equipped%20patrons%20aspiring%20to%20fill%20them%20for%20as%20much%20of%20the%20day%20as%20possible.%20The%20standard%20thing%20to%20say%2C%20in%20differentiating%20our%20post-Starbucks%20civilization%20from%20the%20vanished%20caf%C3%A9%20civilization%2C%20is%20that%2C%20where%20in%20the%20classic%20caf%C3%A9s%20the%20point%20was%20to%20interact%20with%20your%20fellows%2C%20the%20point%20of%20spending%20a%20day%20working%20in%20a%20Starbucks%2C%20or%20in%20its%20cuter%20and%20more%20local-seeming%20rivals%2C%20is%20%3Cem%3Enever%3C%2Fem%3E%20to%20interact%20with%20your%20fellows.%20Spending%20the%20day%20online%2C%20one%20may%20be%20in%20touch%20with%20friends%20and%20advocates%20and%20lovers%2C%20but%20they%20exist%20outside%20in%20the%20ether%2C%20not%20inside%20the%20coffee%20shop.%20We%20aren%E2%80%99t%20sharing%20space%20in%20a%20modern%20coffee%20shop%3B%20we%E2%80%99re%20simply%20renting%20it.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EYet%20all%20those%20lonely%20and%20alienated%20Jewish%20writers%20were%20elsewhere%2C%20too%E2%80%94lost%20in%20books%20and%20newspapers%2C%20which%20were%20the%20true%20pastime%20of%20the%20caf%C3%A9.%20What%20matters%20is%20not%20the%20words%20of%20the%20person%20at%20the%20next%20table%20but%20the%20feeling%20of%20nearness%E2%80%94the%20sense%20of%20being%20able%20to%20carve%20out%20an%20identity%20among%20other%20identities%2C%20of%20being%20potentially%20private%20in%20a%20public%20space%20and%20casually%20public%20even%20while%20lost%20in%20private%20reveries.%20Those%20subtle%20habits%20of%20coexistence%20are%20taught%20by%20the%20simultaneous%20clack%20of%20keyboards%20in%20a%20glass-front%20espresso%20chain%20as%20much%20as%20by%20the%20jostling%20of%20elbows%20in%20Warsaw%20as%20the%20pages%20of%20the%20%3Cem%3ELiterarishe%20Bleter%3C%2Fem%3E%20were%20turned.%20Mere%20silent%20proximity%20of%20social%20kinds%20seems%20an%20ignoble%20and%20inadequate%20social%20ideal.%20But%20it%20remains%20the%20first%20principle%20of%20the%20more%20potable%20forms%20of%20pluralism.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","What, then, of the Habermasian vision of the café as an arena of civil society, and of civil society as the foundation of enlightened societies? Certainly the café could be the foundation of emancipated life—that was why Agnon’s generation rushed there so ardently. But the study reveals a paradox of some poignancy: no matter how elaborately articulated, no matter how high its ceilings and how dignified its servers, civil society can’t protect cosmopolitan communities from assault when it happens. The café may have been a foundation, but it could never be a fortress. The most heartbreaking scenes in Pinsker’s book are from Warsaw, where much loved ghetto institutions like Café Sztuka stayed in business right up to the final expulsion of the Jews to Treblinka, in 1943. Singers sang and dancers danced, with the forbearance of easily bribed Germans, and while many condemned the frivolity (and the implicit collaboration with the Germans) of these last cafés, the writer Michel Mazor rightly praised their “continuous existence in a city which the Germans regarded as a cemetery—was it not, in a certain sense, the ghetto’s protest, its affirmation of the right to live?”"],["p","Pinsker ends his book with a melancholy account of a couple on the Lower East Side of Manhattan who attempted to open a classic Central European-style café a decade or so ago and failed. The rent was too high, the clientele too restless. Still, the streets of every American city these days are littered with coffee shops that attract hordes of laptop-equipped patrons aspiring to fill them for as much of the day as possible. The standard thing to say, in differentiating our post-Starbucks civilization from the vanished café civilization, is that, where in the classic cafés the point was to interact with your fellows, the point of spending a day working in a Starbucks, or in its cuter and more local-seeming rivals, is ",["em","never"]," to interact with your fellows. Spending the day online, one may be in touch with friends and advocates and lovers, but they exist outside in the ether, not inside the coffee shop. We aren’t sharing space in a modern coffee shop; we’re simply renting it."],["p","Yet all those lonely and alienated Jewish writers were elsewhere, too—lost in books and newspapers, which were the true pastime of the café. What matters is not the words of the person at the next table but the feeling of nearness—the sense of being able to carve out an identity among other identities, of being potentially private in a public space and casually public even while lost in private reveries. Those subtle habits of coexistence are taught by the simultaneous clack of keyboards in a glass-front espresso chain as much as by the jostling of elbows in Warsaw as the pages of the ",["em","Literarishe Bleter"]," were turned. Mere silent proximity of social kinds seems an ignoble and inadequate social ideal. But it remains the first principle of the more potable forms of pluralism. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59babd482af19b1403458545","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"59babd482af19b1403458545","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Books","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"books"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"Books","parent":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"books"},{"id":"5907ef77019dfc3494e9c911","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Books","parent":[],"photos":{},"slug":"books-tag"}]},"channel":"","contentSource":"magazine","contentTags":[],"contentType":"article","contributors":[{"name":"Adam Gopnik","type":"author","title":"Adam Gopnik, a staff writer, has been contributing to \u003cem>The New Yorker\u003c/em> since 1986. He is the author of “\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/dp/0307476960/?tag=thneyo0f-20\">The Table Comes First\u003c/a>.”","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Adam Gopnik, a staff writer, has been contributing to ",["em","The New\nYorker"]," since 1986. During his tenure at the magazine, he has written\nfiction, humor, book reviews, profiles, and reported pieces from abroad.\nHe was the magazine's art critic from 1987 to 1995, and the Paris\ncorrespondent from 1995 to 2000. From 2000 to 2005, he wrote a journal\nabout New York life. His books, ranging from essay collections about\nParis and food to children’s novels, include “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/0375758232/?tag=thneyo0f-20"},"Paris to the\nMoon"],",” “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/078681862X/?tag=thneyo0f-20"},"The\nKing in the\nWindow"],",” “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/1400075750/?tag=thneyo0f-20"},"Through\nthe Children’s Gate: A Home in New\nYork"],",” “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B001NLKYAQ/?tag=thneyo0f-20"},"Angels\nand Ages: A Short Book About Darwin, Lincoln, and Modern\nLife"],",” “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/0307476960/?tag=thneyo0f-20"},"The\nTable Comes First: Family, France, and the Meaning of\nFood"],",”\nand “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/088784975X/?tag=thneyo0f-20"},"Winter: Five Windows on the\nSeason"],".” Gopnik\nhas three National Magazine awards, for essays and for criticism, and\nalso the George Polk Award for Magazine Reporting. In March of 2013,\nGopnik was awarded the medal of Chevalier of the Order of Arts and\nLetters. He lectures widely, and, in 2011, delivered the Canadian\nBroadcasting Corporation’s Massey Lectures. His first musical, “The Most\nBeautiful Room In New York,” opened in 2017, at the Long Wharf Theatre, in\nNew \u003c/g>\u003c/svg>"}}},{"body":["div",["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EIn%202010%2C%20Daniel%20Stiepleman%20attended%20the%20funeral%20of%20his%20uncle%20Martin%20Ginsburg%2C%20a%20tax%20attorney.%20In%20one%20of%20the%20eulogies%2C%20a%20family%20friend%20told%20the%20story%20of%20Charles%20E.%20Moritz%20v.%20Commissioner%20of%20Internal%20Revenue%2C%20from%201972%2C%20the%20only%20case%20that%20Ginsburg%20argued%20alongside%20his%20wife.%20Their%20client%20was%20an%20unmarried%20salesman%20taking%20care%20of%20his%20elderly%20mother%2C%20but%20the%20tax%20code%20prohibited%20him%20from%20deducting%20caregiving%20expenses%2C%20because%20he%20was%20a%20man.%20The%20attorneys%2C%20working%20with%20the%20A.C.L.U.%2C%20thought%20that%20a%20male%20plaintiff%20would%20be%20the%20perfect%20vehicle%20for%20a%20gender-discrimination%20case.%20They%20were%20right%3A%20the%20Tenth%20Circuit%20ruled%20in%20their%20favor.%20%E2%80%9CI%20thought%2C%20Wow%2C%20that%20would%20be%20a%20great%20movie%2C%E2%80%9D%20Stiepleman%20said%20recently.%20After%20sitting%20on%20the%20idea%20for%20more%20than%20a%20year%2C%20he%20asked%20his%20aunt%20for%20her%20blessing%20to%20write%20a%20screenplay.%20%E2%80%9CWell%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said%2C%20skeptically%2C%20%E2%80%9Cif%20that%E2%80%99s%20how%20you%20think%20you%E2%80%99d%20like%20to%20spend%20your%20time.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIt%20was%20well%20worth%20his%20time%2C%20because%20Stiepleman%E2%80%99s%20aunt%20is%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fruth-bader-ginsburg%5C%22%3ERuth%20Bader%20Ginsburg%3C%2Fa%3E.%20In%20other%20words%2C%20he%20won%20the%20aunt%20lottery.%20The%20movie%2C%20%E2%80%9COn%20the%20Basis%20of%20Sex%2C%E2%80%9D%20which%20opens%20on%20Christmas%20Day%2C%20stars%20Armie%20Hammer%20as%20Martin%20and%20Felicity%20Jones%20as%20Ruth.%20%E2%80%9CI%20think%20we%20do%20her%20a%20disservice%20when%20we%20turn%20her%20into%20a%20superhero%2C%E2%80%9D%20Stiepleman%2C%20thirty-seven%2C%20said%20in%20his%20Upper%20West%20Side%20apartment.%20Growing%20up%2C%20on%20Long%20Island%2C%20he%20found%20his%20aunt%20%E2%80%9Cintimidating%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9Cbecause%20you%20talk%20to%20her%20and%20there%E2%80%99s%20always%20a%20long%20silence.%20It%20took%20me%20a%20while%20to%20figure%20out%20that%20that%20was%20how%20she%20communicated.%E2%80%9D%20Every%20Thanksgiving%20from%20when%20he%20was%20five%20to%20twelve%2C%20she%20would%20give%20him%20a%20copy%20of%20the%20U.S.%20Constitution%20for%20Hanukkah.%20%E2%80%9CIn%20my%20twenties%2C%20I%20thought%2C%20Aha!%20She%E2%80%99s%20teaching%20me%20something%20very%20important%20about%20patriotism%20and%20law.%20Now%20I%E2%80%99m%20in%20my%20thirties%20and%20have%20kids%20of%20my%20own%2C%20and%20I%20realize%2C%20No%2C%20she%20just%20gets%20a%20discount%20at%20the%20Supreme%20Court%20gift%20shop.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EMuch%20of%20the%20film%20centers%20on%20Ruth%20and%20Martin%E2%80%99s%20marriage%2C%20which%20Stiepleman%20came%20to%20see%20as%20a%20model%20for%20his%20own.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20were%20equal%20partners%20at%20home%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CMarty%20did%20all%20the%20cooking%2C%20because%20Ruth%20was%20terrible%20at%20it.%E2%80%9D%20(A%20cookbook%2C%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FChef-Supreme-Ginsburg-Justices-Memoriam%2Fdp%2FB00FIE0LL6%5C%22%3EChef%20Supreme%3A%20Martin%20Ginsburg%2C%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20was%20published%20posthumously%2C%20and%20the%20film%20features%20his%20acclaimed%20chicken-liver%20p%C3%A2t%C3%A9%2C%20and%20also%20Ruth%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9Cinedible%E2%80%9D%201956%20casserole.)%20Stiepleman%20recalled%20a%20holiday%20party%20during%20his%20childhood%20at%20which%20Martin%20served%20a%20delicious%20chocolate-mousse%20cake.%20A%20grownup%20asked%20Stiepleman%20what%20he%20wanted%20to%20be%20when%20he%20grew%20up.%20%E2%80%9CI%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98I%20want%20to%20be%20like%20Uncle%20Martin%2C%E2%80%99%20and%20the%20person%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98Oh%2C%20you%20want%20to%20be%20a%20lawyer%3F%E2%80%99%20And%20I%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98No%2C%20I%E2%80%99m%20going%20to%20be%20a%20cooking%20dad!%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ENow%20that%20Stiepleman%20is%20a%20cooking%20dad%E2%80%94his%20wife%20is%20an%20oncology%20fellow%20at%20Columbia%2C%20and%20they%20have%20two%20young%20children%E2%80%94he%20had%20decided%20to%20re-create%20the%20chocolate-mousse%20cake%20for%20a%20kindergarten%20potluck.%20Stiepleman%2C%20barefoot%20in%20his%20kitchen%2C%20preheated%20the%20oven%20and%20buttered%20the%20inside%20of%20a%20Bundt%20pan.%20His%20brother%20had%20texted%20him%20the%20recipe%2C%20which%20read%20like%20a%20gregarious%20tax%20lawyer%20had%20written%20it.%20(%E2%80%9CAmply%20feeds%208%20and%20can%20be%20stretched%20to%2012%20persons.%E2%80%9D)%20%E2%80%9CWhenever%20I%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20find%20Uncle%20Martin%20on%20the%20page%2C%20I%20would%20just%20go%20and%20read%20his%20cookbook%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAs%20he%20wrote%20the%20screenplay%2C%20Stiepleman%20made%20several%20trips%20to%20Washington%2C%20D.C.%2C%20where%20his%20aunt%20granted%20him%20access%20to%20her%20files%20at%20the%20Library%20of%20Congress.%20%E2%80%9CThen%2C%20by%20night%2C%20we%20would%20sit%20together%20and%20have%20dinner%20and%20usually%20polish%20off%20a%20bottle%20of%20wine%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20recalled.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2018%2F10%2F08%2Fruth-bader-ginsburgs-unlikely-path-to-the-supreme-court%5C%22%3EAunt%20Ruth%3C%2Fa%3E%20gave%20detailed%20notes%20on%20his%20drafts.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99d%20call%20her%20up%2C%20and%20she%E2%80%99d%20be%2C%20like%2C%20%E2%80%98Oh%2C%20Daniel%2C%20I%E2%80%99m%20in%20the%20middle%20of%20reading%20the%20Affordable%20Care%20Act.%20Can%20you%20call%20me%20back%20in%20twenty%20minutes%3F%E2%80%99%20And%20then%20she%E2%80%99d%20be%2C%20like%2C%20%E2%80%98O.K.%2C%20page%201%2C%E2%80%99%20and%20she%E2%80%99d%20go%20through%20it%20like%20a%20contract.%20%E2%80%98Here%20you%20have%20me%20wearing%20high%20heels%20at%20Harvard%2C%20but%20in%20those%20days%20I%20used%20to%20walk%20to%20school%2C%20so%20I%20wouldn%E2%80%99t%20wear%20high%20heels.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20After%20she%20saw%20the%20film%20for%20the%20first%20time%2C%20she%20told%20her%20nephew%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20just%20love%20that%20it%E2%80%99s%20joyous.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EStiepleman%20placed%20the%20chocolate%20batter%20in%20the%20oven.%20(Uncle%20Martin%20suggests%20serving%20the%20cake%20in%20thin%20slices.)%20He%20had%20spoken%20to%20his%20aunt%20two%20days%20earlier%2C%20not%20long%20after%20a%20fall%20had%20caused%20her%20to%20fracture%20three%20ribs%20and%20had%20given%20liberal%20America%20a%20panic%20attack.%20%E2%80%9CShe%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98I%E2%80%99m%20going%20back%20to%20work%20tomorrow.%E2%80%99%20I%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98Will%20you%20get%20some%20sleep%20first%3F%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20Stiepleman%20opened%20his%20wedding%20album%2C%20from%202007%2C%20which%20had%20photos%20of%20Aunt%20Ruth%20officiating%20in%20her%20robe%20and%20lace%20collar.%20Her%20speech%20included%20the%20line%20%E2%80%9Cby%20the%20authority%20vested%20in%20me%20by%20the%20Constitution.%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9CThat%20gets%20a%20laugh%20every%20time%2C%E2%80%9D%20Stiepleman%20said.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20like%20you%20need%20an%20act%20of%20Congress%20if%20you%20want%20to%20get%20divorced.%E2%80%9D%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","In 2010, Daniel Stiepleman attended the funeral of his uncle Martin Ginsburg, a tax attorney. In one of the eulogies, a family friend told the story of Charles E. Moritz v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, from 1972, the only case that Ginsburg argued alongside his wife. Their client was an unmarried salesman taking care of his elderly mother, but the tax code prohibited him from deducting caregiving expenses, because he was a man. The attorneys, working with the A.C.L.U., thought that a male plaintiff would be the perfect vehicle for a gender-discrimination case. They were right: the Tenth Circuit ruled in their favor. “I thought, Wow, that would be a great movie,” Stiepleman said recently. After sitting on the idea for more than a year, he asked his aunt for her blessing to write a screenplay. “Well,” she said, skeptically, “if that’s how you think you’d like to spend your time.”"],["p","It was well worth his time, because Stiepleman’s aunt is ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/ruth-bader-ginsburg"},"Ruth Bader Ginsburg"],". In other words, he won the aunt lottery. The movie, “On the Basis of Sex,” which opens on Christmas Day, stars Armie Hammer as Martin and Felicity Jones as Ruth. “I think we do her a disservice when we turn her into a superhero,” Stiepleman, thirty-seven, said in his Upper West Side apartment. Growing up, on Long Island, he found his aunt “intimidating,” he said, “because you talk to her and there’s always a long silence. It took me a while to figure out that that was how she communicated.” Every Thanksgiving from when he was five to twelve, she would give him a copy of the U.S. Constitution for Hanukkah. “In my twenties, I thought, Aha! She’s teaching me something very important about patriotism and law. Now I’m in my thirties and have kids of my own, and I realize, No, she just gets a discount at the Supreme Court gift shop.”"],["p","Much of the film centers on Ruth and Martin’s marriage, which Stiepleman came to see as a model for his own. “They were equal partners at home,” he said. “Marty did all the cooking, because Ruth was terrible at it.” (A cookbook, “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Chef-Supreme-Ginsburg-Justices-Memoriam/dp/B00FIE0LL6"},"Chef Supreme: Martin Ginsburg,"],"” was published posthumously, and the film features his acclaimed chicken-liver pâté, and also Ruth’s “inedible” 1956 casserole.) Stiepleman recalled a holiday party during his childhood at which Martin served a delicious chocolate-mousse cake. A grownup asked Stiepleman what he wanted to be when he grew up. “I said, ‘I want to be like Uncle Martin,’ and the person said, ‘Oh, you want to be a lawyer?’ And I said, ‘No, I’m going to be a cooking dad!’ ”"],["p","Now that Stiepleman is a cooking dad—his wife is an oncology fellow at Columbia, and they have two young children—he had decided to re-create the chocolate-mousse cake for a kindergarten potluck. Stiepleman, barefoot in his kitchen, preheated the oven and buttered the inside of a Bundt pan. His brother had texted him the recipe, which read like a gregarious tax lawyer had written it. (“Amply feeds 8 and can be stretched to 12 persons.”) “Whenever I couldn’t find Uncle Martin on the page, I would just go and read his cookbook,” he said."],["p","As he wrote the screenplay, Stiepleman made several trips to Washington, D.C., where his aunt granted him access to her files at the Library of Congress. “Then, by night, we would sit together and have dinner and usually polish off a bottle of wine,” he recalled. ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/10/08/ruth-bader-ginsburgs-unlikely-path-to-the-supreme-court"},"Aunt Ruth"]," gave detailed notes on his drafts. “I’d call her up, and she’d be, like, ‘Oh, Daniel, I’m in the middle of reading the Affordable Care Act. Can you call me back in twenty minutes?’ And then she’d be, like, ‘O.K., page 1,’ and she’d go through it like a contract. ‘Here you have me wearing high heels at Harvard, but in those days I used to walk to school, so I wouldn’t wear high heels.’ ” After she saw the film for the first time, she told her nephew, “I just love that it’s joyous.”"],["p","Stiepleman placed the chocolate batter in the oven. (Uncle Martin suggests serving the cake in thin slices.) He had spoken to his aunt two days earlier, not long after a fall had caused her to fracture three ribs and had given liberal America a panic attack. “She said, ‘I’m going back to work tomorrow.’ I said, ‘Will you get some sleep first?’ ” Stiepleman opened his wedding album, from 2007, which had photos of Aunt Ruth officiating in her robe and lace collar. Her speech included the line “by the authority vested in me by the Constitution.” “That gets a laugh every time,” Stiepleman said. “It’s like you need an act of Congress if you want to get divorced.” ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"59113a7276b9ca4b4bbd158c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"59113a7276b9ca4b4bbd158c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"The C%20Trump%20refuses%20to%20take%20action%20against%20Saudi%20Arabia%2C%20notwithstanding%20substantial%20evidence%20that%20Mohammed%20bin%20Salman%2C%20the%20Crown%20Prince%20and%20the%20putative%20head%20of%20state%2C%20directed%20the%20murder%20of%20Jamal%20Khashoggi%2C%20a%20journalist%20who%20lived%20in%20the%20United%20States.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESchiff%20also%20pointed%20out%20that%20Jared%20Kushner%2C%20the%20President%E2%80%99s%20son-in-law%2C%20met%20with%20the%20C.E.O.%20of%20a%20state-owned%20Russian%20bank%20in%20December%2C%202016%2C%20and%20that%2C%20the%20following%20month%2C%20Erik%20Prince%2C%20an%20informal%20adviser%20to%20the%20Trump%20campaign%2C%20met%20with%20the%20leader%20of%20a%20Russian%20sovereign-wealth%20fund%20in%20the%20Seychelles%2C%20an%20East%20African%20archipelago%20nation%20in%20the%20Indian%20Ocean.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20American%20people%20have%20a%20right%20to%20know%20that%20their%20President%20is%20working%20on%20their%20behalf%2C%20not%20his%20family%E2%80%99s%20financial%20interests%2C%E2%80%9D%20Schiff%20said.%20%E2%80%9CRight%20now%2C%20I%20don%E2%80%99t%20think%20any%20of%20us%20can%20have%20the%20confidence%20that%20that%E2%80%99s%20the%20case.%E2%80%9D%20All%20of%20these%20subjects%2C%20Schiff%20averred%2C%20were%20fair%20game%20for%20investigation%20by%20the%20committee%20that%20he%20will%20soon%20chair.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAs%20the%20ranking%20member%20of%20the%20Intelligence%20Committee%2C%20Schiff%20has%20directed%20a%20staff%20of%20eleven.%20As%20the%20chairman%2C%20he%20will%20direct%20twenty-five%2C%20some%20of%20whom%20will%20be%20devoted%20to%20the%20Russia%20investigation.%20%E2%80%9CWe%E2%80%99ve%20been%20deluged%20with%20r%C3%A9sum%C3%A9s%2C%E2%80%9D%20Schiff%20said.%20It%20is%20now%20clear%20that%20during%20the%20campaign%2C%20when%20Trump%20was%20advocating%20the%20removal%20of%20sanctions%20on%20Russia%2C%20he%20was%20privately%20trying%20to%20make%20money%20in%20Moscow%20in%20a%20deal%20that%20may%20have%20required%20Putin%E2%80%99s%20help.%20Schiff%20wants%20to%20know%3A%20%E2%80%9CIs%20that%20why%20Trump%20is%20so%20pro-Russian%3F%20Is%20his%20financial%20interest%20guiding%20his%20foreign%20policy%3F%E2%80%9D%20Schiff%20thinks%20the%20answer%20to%20those%20questions%20may%20be%20found%20in%20the%20records%20of%20Deutsche%20Bank%2C%20which%20has%20been%20fined%20hundreds%20of%20millions%20of%20dollars%20for%20laundering%20money%20for%20Russia%2C%20and%20was%20reportedly%20the%20only%20bank%20willing%20to%20do%20business%20with%20Trump%20in%20the%20nineteen-nineties%2C%20when%20major%20Wall%20Street%20firms%20declined%20to%20loan%20him%20money%20after%20a%20series%20of%20failed%20business%20ventures.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20are%20going%20to%20be%20looking%20at%20the%20issue%20of%20possible%20money%20laundering%20by%20the%20Trump%20Organization%2C%20and%20Deutsche%20Bank%20is%20one%20obvious%20place%20to%20start%2C%E2%80%9D%20Schiff%20added.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESince%20the%20beginning%20of%20the%20Trump%20Administration%2C%20Schiff%20has%20been%20a%20ubiquitous%20presence%20on%20television%2C%20speaking%20about%20matters%20related%20to%20the%20Russia%20investigation.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20voice%20that%20Adam%20gives%20to%20these%20issues%20is%20one%20that%20is%20calming%2C%20logical%2C%20linear%2C%20measured%20but%20forceful%2C%E2%80%9D%20Nancy%20Pelosi%2C%20the%20Democratic%20leader%20and%20likely%20the%20new%20Speaker%20of%20the%20House%2C%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CI%20have%20complete%20confidence%20in%20him%20to%20be%20very%20strategic%20in%20how%20he%20returns%20the%20Intelligence%20Committee%20to%20a%20bipartisan%20arena%2C%20without%20doing%20what%20Devin%20Nunes%20did%20as%20chairman%20of%20the%20committee%2C%20which%20I%20thought%20bordered%20on%20the%20criminal.%E2%80%9D%20The%20government%20watchdog%20Campaign%20for%20Accountability%20has%20filed%20complaints%20against%20Nunes%20for%20leaking%20confidential%20information%20from%20the%20ongoing%20Russia%20investigation.%20(Nunes%E2%80%99s%20office%20denies%20these%20accusations%20as%20%E2%80%9Cdiscredited%20fake%20news%20stories.%E2%80%9D)%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESchiff%20repeatedly%20chastised%20the%20Republicans%20on%20his%20committee%2C%20led%20by%20Nunes%2C%20for%20their%20refusal%20to%20conduct%20a%20thorough%20investigation%20into%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20possible%20misdeeds%2C%20and%20he%20defended%20Mueller%E2%80%99s%20efforts%20to%20impose%20some%20accountability%20for%20the%20issues%20that%20fall%20within%20the%20special%20counsel%E2%80%99s%20purview.%20With%20the%20Democrats%20now%20in%20control%20of%20the%20House%20of%20Representatives%2C%20Schiff%E2%80%99s%20responsibilities%20as%20chair%20of%20the%20committee%20will%20present%20both%20great%20opportunities%20and%20significant%20peril.%20Schiff%20will%20no%20longer%20be%20able%20to%20blame%20the%20Republicans%20for%20wasting%20time.%20It%E2%80%99s%20his%20investigation%20now%2C%20and%20he%E2%80%99s%20planning%20to%20heed%20the%20advice%2C%20familiar%20to%20viewers%20of%20the%20movie%20version%20of%20%E2%80%9CAll%20the%20President%E2%80%99s%20Men%2C%E2%80%9D%20to%20%E2%80%9Cfollow%20the%20money.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","President Trump said some time ago that he believes his personal finances should be off limits to investigators. In an interview with the ",["em","Times"]," in July, 2017, he asserted that if Robert Mueller, the special counsel, sought to investigate the Trump family’s business dealings he would be crossing a “red line.” When, later that year, several news reports suggested that Mueller had subpoenaed Deutsche Bank for records relating to Trump’s businesses, the President reportedly told members of his staff that he wanted to fire Mueller in response. It was never confirmed whether Mueller had actually subpoenaed Deutsche Bank, but the President’s aversion to the scrutiny of his business interests caught the attention of Representative Adam Schiff, who will become the chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence next year. On a recent weekend, at a busy restaurant in downtown Burbank, in the heart of his congressional district, Schiff talked about his plans for conducting an investigation that will be parallel to Mueller’s, probing Trump’s connections to Russia, Saudi Arabia, and other places around the world. As Schiff described his approach, it became clear that he wasn’t just planning to cross Trump’s red line—he intended to obliterate it."],["p","“Our role is not the same as Bob Mueller’s,” Schiff told me, over a vegan burger. (He changed his eating habits a few years ago, in order to lower his cholesterol.) The job of prosecutors like Mueller is to identify and prosecute crimes, not necessarily to inform and educate the public. Congressional committees, like the one Schiff will soon lead, are supposed to monitor the executive branch and expose wrongdoing. Mueller is supposed to file a report on his findings, but, in keeping with the regulations for the office of the special counsel, it will be up to his supervisor in the Justice Department, who is now Matthew Whitaker, the acting Attorney General, to determine whether Mueller’s report is made public. Schiff has his own agenda for areas to investigate. “The one that has always concerned me is the financial issues, which obviously have come much to the fore this week,” he said. Shortly before Schiff and I spoke, Michael Cohen, Trump’s former personal attorney, had pleaded guilty to lying to Congress about his role in the negotiations for building a Trump tower in Moscow. Cohen had said earlier that these discussions ended in January, 2016, but he admitted in court that he had been negotiating with Russian officials, and keeping Trump apprised, through the first half of 2016, during the Republican Presidential primaries. Trump has denied that he was doing business with the Russians during this period."],["p","Schiff went on, “At the end of the day, what should concern us most is anything that can have a continuing impact on the foreign policy and national-security policy of the United States, and, if the Russians were laundering money for the Trump Organization, that would be totally compromising.” Schiff hypothesizes that Trump went beyond using his campaign and the Presidency as a vehicle for advancing his business interests, speculating that he may have shaped policy with an eye to expanding his fortune. “There’s a whole constellation of issues where that is essentially the center of gravity,” Schiff said. “Obviously, that issue is implicated in efforts to build Trump Tower in Moscow. It’s implicated in the money that Trump is bragging he was getting from the Saudis. And why shouldn’t he love the Saudis? He said he was making so much money from them.” As the Washington ",["em","Post"]," has reported, Trump has sold a hotel to a Saudi prince, a $4.5-million apartment near the United Nations to the Saudi government, and many other apartments to Saudi nationals, and, since Trump became President, his hotels in New York and Chicago have seen significant increases in bookings from Saudi visitors. In a break with the Republican congressional leadership, Trump refuses to take action against Saudi Arabia, notwithstanding substantial evidence that Mohammed bin Salman, the Crown Prince and the putative head of state, directed the murder of Jamal Khashoggi, a journalist who lived in the United States."],["p","Schiff also pointed out that Jared Kushner, the President’s son-in-law, met with the C.E.O. of a state-owned Russian bank in December, 2016, and that, the following month, Erik Prince, an informal adviser to the Trump campaign, met with the leader of a Russian sovereign-wealth fund in the Seychelles, an East African archipelago nation in the Indian Ocean. “The American people have a right to know that their President is working on their behalf, not his family’s financial interests,” Schiff said. “Right now, I don’t think any of us can have the confidence that that’s the case.” All of these subjects, Schiff averred, were fair game for investigation by the committee that he will soon chair."],["p","As the ranking member of the Intelligence Committee, Schiff has directed a staff of eleven. As the chairman, he will direct twenty-five, some of whom will be devoted to the Russia investigation. “We’ve been deluged with résumés,” Schiff said. It is now clear that during the campaign, when Trump was advocating the removal of sanctions on Russia, he was privately trying to make money in Moscow in a deal that may have required Putin’s help. Schiff wants to know: “Is that why Trump is so pro-Russian? Is his financial interest guiding his foreign policy?” Schiff thinks the answer to those questions may be found in the records of Deutsche Bank, which has been fined hundreds of millions of dollars for laundering money for Russia, and was reportedly the only bank willing to do business with Trump in the nineteen-nineties, when major Wall Street firms declined to loan him money after a series of failed business ventures. “We are going to be looking at the issue of possible money laundering by the Trump Organization, and Deutsche Bank is one obvious place to start,” Schiff added."],["p","Since the beginning of the Trump Administration, Schiff has been a ubiquitous presence on television, speaking about matters related to the Russia investigation. “The voice that Adam gives to these issues is one that is calming, logical, linear, measured but forceful,” Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic leader and likely the new Speaker of the House, told me. “I have complete confidence in him to be very strategic in how he returns the Intelligence Committee to a bipartisan arena, without doing what Devin Nunes did as chairman of the committee, which I thought bordered on the criminal.” The government watchdog Campaign for Accountability has filed complaints against Nunes for leaking confidential information from the ongoing Russia investigation. (Nunes’s office denies these accusations as “discredited fake news stories.”)"],["p","Schiff repeatedly chastised the Republicans on his committee, led by Nunes, for their refusal to conduct a thorough investigation into Trump’s possible misdeeds, and he defended Mueller’s efforts to impose some accountability for the issues that fall within the special counsel’s purview. With the Democrats now in control of the House of Representatives, Schiff’s responsibilities as chair of the committee will present both great opportunities and significant peril. Schiff will no longer be able to blame the Republicans for wasting time. It’s his investigation now, and he’s planning to heed the advice, familiar to viewers of the movie version of “All the President’s Men,” to “follow the money.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EA%20few%20years%20after%20Schiff%20was%20first%20elected%20to%20the%20House%2C%20in%202000%2C%20he%20and%20his%20wife%2C%20Eve%2C%20who%20had%20been%20living%20in%20his%20district%20in%20California%2C%20enrolled%20their%20two%20children%20in%20school%20in%20the%20Washington%20suburbs%2C%20so%20that%20Schiff%20could%20spend%20more%20time%20with%20his%20family.%20Since%20then%2C%20he%20has%20spent%20every%20other%20weekend%20in%20his%20district%2C%20which%20includes%20Hollywood%20and%20parts%20of%20the%20San%20Fernando%20Valley.%20On%20a%20recent%20Sunday%2C%20he%20spoke%20at%20a%20church%20service%20commemorating%20World%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EAIDS%3C%2Fem%3E%20Day%2C%20lit%20a%20Christmas%20tree%20at%20a%20street%20festival%2C%20and%20viewed%20an%20exhibit%20at%20the%20Los%20Angeles%20Museum%20of%20the%20Holocaust%2C%20where%20the%20tour%20guide%20told%20him%20that%20a%20new%20documentary%20about%20the%20Sobib%C3%B3r%20concentration%20camp%20was%20%E2%80%9Cgetting%20Oscar%20buzz.%E2%80%9D%20Schiff%20then%20went%20to%20light%20the%20candles%20on%20an%20oversized%20menorah%20in%20front%20of%20a%20Mr.%20Luggage%20store%20at%20a%20mall%20in%20Burbank%2C%20where%20a%20man%20named%20David%20Nathan%20Schwartz%20introduced%20himself.%20They%20discovered%20that%20they%20had%20been%20in%20the%20same%20third-grade%20class%2C%20in%20Framingham%2C%20Massachusetts.%20Later%2C%20recalling%20third%20grade%2C%20Schiff%20told%20me%2C%20%E2%80%9CThat%20was%20the%20last%20time%20that%20someone%20called%20me%20Adam%20Shit.%20I%20think%20the%20kid%E2%80%99s%20mother%20actually%20washed%20his%20mouth%20out%20with%20soap.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHe%20was%20referring%20to%20an%20incident%20last%20month%2C%20when%20the%20President%20tweeted%2C%20%E2%80%9CSo%20funny%20to%20see%20little%20Adam%20Schitt%20(D-CA)%20talking%20about%20the%20fact%20that%20Acting%20Attorney%20General%20Matt%20Whitaker%20was%20not%20approved%20by%20the%20Senate%2C%20but%20not%20mentioning%20the%20fact%20that%20Bob%20Mueller%20(who%20is%20highly%20conflicted)%20was%20not%20approved%20by%20the%20Senate!%E2%80%9D%20(In%20fact%2C%20there%20is%20no%20requirement%20for%20Mueller%2C%20who%20was%20named%20to%20his%20post%20by%20Rod%20Rosenstein%2C%20the%20Deputy%20Attorney%20General%2C%20to%20be%20confirmed%20by%20the%20Senate.)%20Schiff%20has%20been%20a%20frequent%20target%20of%20Trump%2C%20who%20has%20called%20him%20%E2%80%9Csleazy%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20%E2%80%9Cleaker%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20%E2%80%9Clittle.%E2%80%9D%20Schiff%20is%20not%20especially%20short%20or%20slight%2C%20but%20he%20does%20appear%20diminutive.%20His%20expression%20is%20often%20neutral%2C%20and%20his%20countenance%20is%20unaffected%20by%20his%20periodic%20visits%20to%20the%20California%20sunshine%3B%20he%20could%20pass%20for%20someone%20in%20his%20late%20thirties%20or%20his%20early%20sixties.%20(He%E2%80%99s%20fifty-eight.)%20Schiff%E2%80%99s%20constituents%20at%20Disney%2C%20DreamWorks%2C%20and%20Paramount%20would%20probably%20cast%20him%20as%20an%20accountant.%20He%20seems%20to%20cultivate%20this%20blandness%20of%20affect%20to%20convey%20that%20he%20deals%20in%20facts%2C%20eschews%20drama%2C%20and%20tells%20the%20truth.%20As%20he%20often%20mentions%2C%20he%20spent%20half%20a%20dozen%20years%20as%20an%20Assistant%20U.S.%20Attorney%2C%20a%20job%20that%20trained%20him%20in%20the%20presentation%20of%20evidence.%20Schiff%20told%20me%2C%20%E2%80%9CTrump%20has%20created%20a%20constituency%20for%20people%20who%20are%20not%20running%20around%20with%20their%20hair%20on%20fire.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EUntil%20March%2020%2C%202017%2C%20Schiff%E2%80%99s%20skills%20were%20known%20to%20few.%20Most%20of%20the%20committee%E2%80%99s%20business%20is%20conducted%20in%20secret%2C%20in%20a%20secure%20suite%20of%20offices%20three%20floors%20below%20the%20Capitol%20Visitor%20Center.%20But%20on%20that%20day%20the%20Intelligence%20Committee%20held%20a%20rare%20public%20hearing%2C%20in%20which%20James%20Comey%2C%20who%2C%20at%20that%20point%2C%20was%20still%20the%20director%20of%20the%20F.B.I.%2C%20publicly%20confirmed%20for%20the%20first%20time%20that%20the%20Bureau%20was%20investigating%20Russian%20interference%20in%20the%202016%20election.%20Before%20Comey%20began%20to%20speak%2C%20Schiff%20gave%20an%20opening%20statement%20in%20which%20he%20clinically%E2%80%94and%20devastatingly%E2%80%94summarized%20the%20existing%20evidence%20in%20the%20case.%20%E2%80%9CLast%20summer%2C%20at%20the%20height%20of%20a%20bitterly%20contested%20and%20hugely%20consequential%20Presidential%20campaign%2C%20a%20foreign%2C%20adversarial%20power%20intervened%20in%20an%20effort%20to%20weaken%20our%20democracy%2C%20and%20to%20influence%20the%20outcome%20for%20one%20candidate%20and%20against%20the%20other%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThat%20foreign%20adversary%20was%2C%20of%20course%2C%20Russia%2C%20and%20it%20acted%20through%20its%20intelligence%20agencies%20and%20upon%20the%20direct%20instructions%20of%20its%20autocratic%20ruler%2C%20Vladimir%20Putin%2C%20in%20order%20to%20help%20Donald%C2%A0J.%20Trump%20become%20the%20forty-fifth%20President%20of%20the%20United%20States.%E2%80%9D%20Schiff%20laid%20out%20a%20story%20that%20became%20familiar%20in%20the%20next%20year%20and%20a%20half%3A%20how%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20campaign%20adviser%2C%20Carter%20Page%2C%20an%20eccentric%20oil-industry%20consultant%2C%20travelled%20to%20Russia%20during%20the%202016%20campaign%20and%20gave%20a%20speech%20in%20which%20he%20criticized%20U.S.%20policy%20toward%20Russia%20for%20being%20too%20harsh%3B%20how%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20friend%20Roger%20Stone%2C%20a%20longtime%20political%20consultant%2C%20had%20advance%20knowledge%20of%20the%20theft%2C%20by%20Russian%20interests%2C%20of%20the%20e-mails%20of%20prominent%20Democrats%3B%20how%20Paul%20Manafort%2C%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20campaign%20chairman%20and%20a%20noted%20lobbyist%20for%20pro-Russian%20interests%2C%20supervised%20the%20Republican%20Convention%2C%20where%20the%20Party%20platform%20became%20more%20sympathetic%20to%20Russia.%20Michael%20Bahar%2C%20who%20was%20then%20Schiff%E2%80%99s%20top%20staffer%20on%20the%20committee%2C%20recalled%2C%20%E2%80%9CSchiff%20kept%20saying%20at%20the%20time%20that%20it%E2%80%99s%20our%20job%20in%20Congress%20to%20educate%20people%20about%20what%20was%20really%20going%20on.%20That%E2%80%99s%20the%20way%20he%20approached%20his%20opening%20statement.%20He%20was%20saying%2C%20This%20is%20what%20we%20need%20to%20look%20at.%20It%20was%20so%20compelling%20and%20so%20detailed.%20It%20quickly%20became%20clear%20that%20it%20caused%20panic%20for%20those%20on%20the%20other%20side.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522cartoon%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522cartoon%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fcartoon%25252F5c12e45f2eb5b760bfa5e8be%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c12e45f2eb5b760bfa5e8be%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c12e45f2eb5b760bfa5e8be%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c12e45f2eb5b760bfa5e8be%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EWhat%20followed%2C%20a%20day%20later%2C%20has%20passed%20into%20Washington%20lore.%20Nunes%2C%20who%20represents%20a%20district%20in%20California%E2%80%99s%20agricultural%20San%20Joaquin%20Valley%2C%20and%20Schiff%20had%20a%20reasonably%20productive%20relationship.%20As%20the%20chair%20and%20the%20ranking%20member%20of%20the%20Intelligence%20Committee%2C%20respectively%2C%20before%20Trump%20became%20President%2C%20they%20collaborated%20on%20bills%20to%20improve%20cybersecurity%20and%20to%20codify%20the%20rules%20on%20the%20collection%20of%20metadata%20by%20the%20intelligence%20agencies.%20But%2C%20after%20Comey%20confirmed%20that%20there%20would%20be%20an%20F.B.I.%20investigation%20of%20the%202016%20election%2C%20Nunes%20slipped%20into%20a%20highly%20partisan%20mode%20from%20which%20he%20has%20not%20yet%20emerged.%20(Nunes%20has%20declined%20to%20comment.)%20On%20the%20night%20of%20March%2021st%2C%20Nunes%20leaped%20out%20of%20an%20Uber%2C%20in%20which%20he%20had%20been%20riding%20with%20a%20staffer%2C%20and%20made%20his%20way%20to%20the%20Eisenhower%20Executive%20Office%20Building%2C%20next%20to%20the%20White%20House%2C%20where%20he%20reportedly%20met%20with%20Michael%20Ellis%2C%20a%20national-security%20lawyer%20in%20the%20White%20House%20Counsel%E2%80%99s%20Office%2C%20and%20Ezra%20Cohen-Watnick%2C%20then%20the%20senior%20director%20for%20intelligence%20for%20the%20National%20Security%20Council.%20(A%20lawyer%20for%20Ezra%20Cohen-Watnick%20said%20that%20his%20client%20%E2%80%9Chad%20no%20knowledge%20of%20the%20meeting.%E2%80%9D)%20The%20next%20day%2C%20Nunes%20held%20a%20news%20conference%2C%20announcing%2C%20breathlessly%2C%20that%20he%20had%20received%20secret%20information%20corroborating%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20recent%20claim%20that%20President%20Obama%20had%20wiretapped%20his%20campaign.%20Nunes%E2%80%99s%20story%20quickly%20fell%20apart%2C%20however%2C%20and%20his%20late-night%20visit%20to%20the%20White%20House%20complex%2C%20known%20as%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20midnight%20run%2C%E2%80%9D%20became%20the%20source%20of%20much%20mockery.%20As%20a%20result%2C%20Nunes%20recused%20himself%20from%20his%20committee%E2%80%99s%20Russia%20investigation%2C%20although%20he%20continued%20to%20review%20related%20intelligence%20and%20later%20resumed%20leadership.%20The%20incident%20established%20the%20lengths%20to%20which%20Republicans%20on%20the%20committee%20would%20go%20to%20defend%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20behavior.%20Relations%20between%20Democrats%20and%20Republicans%20on%20the%20committee%20never%20recovered.%20(Nunes%20declined%20to%20comment%2C%20but%20his%20spokesperson%20said%2C%20in%20a%20statement%2C%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20amusing%20to%20see%20the%20Democrat-media%20complex%20continue%20to%20recall%20the%20false%20%E2%80%98midnight%20run%E2%80%99%20story%2C%20which%20was%20invented%20by%20Schiff%E2%80%99s%20own%20staffers%2C%20fed%20by%20them%20to%20Schiff%E2%80%99s%20worshipful%20media%20allies%2C%20and%20debunked%20publicly%20by%20Chairman%20Nunes%20himself.%E2%80%9D)%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EStill%2C%20during%20the%20following%20year%20the%20committee%20did%20bring%20in%20fifty-eight%20witnesses%20to%20testify%20about%20the%20Trump%20campaign%E2%80%99s%20connections%20to%20Russia%20in%202016%2C%20with%20Schiff%20usually%20leading%20the%20questioning%20for%20the%20Democrats.%20The%20Republicans%20on%20the%20committee%20largely%20devoted%20their%20efforts%20to%20damage%20control%20on%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20behalf.%20One%20critical%20issue%20was%20the%20meeting%20at%20Trump%20Tower%20on%20June%209%2C%202016%2C%20when%20the%20senior%20leadership%20of%20the%20Trump%20campaign%2C%20including%20Kushner%2C%20Manafort%2C%20and%20Donald%20Trump%2C%20Jr.%2C%20met%20with%20a%20lawyer%20whom%20they%20had%20been%20told%20was%20a%20representative%20of%20the%20Russian%20government%20who%20had%20%E2%80%9Cdirt%E2%80%9D%20on%20Hillary%20Clinton.%20According%20to%20telephone%20records%20available%20to%20the%20committee%2C%20three%20days%20before%20the%20meeting%20Trump%2C%20Jr.%2C%20made%20a%20series%20of%20calls.%20In%20the%20interval%20between%20one%20call%20from%20Russi
