\u003c/g> \u003c/g> \u003c/g> \u003c/g> \u003c/g> \u003c/g>\u003c/svg>"}}},{"body":["div",["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3ENobody%2C%20even%20at%20this%20relatively%20late%20date%20in%20the%20history%20of%20forced%20or%20free%20American%20race-mixing%2C%20knows%20exactly%20what%20to%20do%20with%20the%20idea%E2%80%94or%2C%20worse%2C%20the%20reality%E2%80%94of%20a%20black%20body%20and%20a%20white%20body%20coming%20together.%20The%20problem%20is%20a%20superfluity%20of%20meaning.%20Sex%20between%20the%20races%20means%20rape%20and%20reconciliation%2C%20repression%20and%20release%2C%20assimilation%20and%20radical%20rejection%2C%20inculcation%20into%20one%20faulty%20set%20of%20values%20and%20freedom%20from%20another.%20Its%20participants%20are%20revolutionaries%20or%20self-haters%2C%20or%20both%2C%20and%20they%20are%20evidence%20of%20an%20old%20stain%20but%20also%20hints%20of%20a%20world%20to%20come.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CSlave%20Play%2C%E2%80%9D%20written%20by%20Jeremy%C2%A0O.%20Harris%20and%20directed%20by%20Robert%20O%E2%80%99Hara%2C%20at%20New%20York%20Theatre%20Workshop%2C%20takes%20this%20multivalent%20theme%20by%20the%20neck%E2%80%94also%20the%20waist%3B%20often%20the%20crotch%E2%80%94and%20never%20stops%20squeezing.%20The%20show%E2%80%99s%20disorienting%20first%20moments%20show%20Kaneisha%2C%20played%20with%20a%20hoarse%20drawl%20by%20Teyonah%20Parris%2C%20dressed%20in%20a%20slave%E2%80%99s%20rags%20and%20sweeping%20the%20floor.%20Floodlights%20flare%2C%20accompanied%2C%20oddly%2C%20by%20snippets%20of%20the%20song%20%E2%80%9CWork%2C%E2%80%9D%20by%20Rihanna%2C%20making%20Kaneisha%20dance.%20She%20grinds%20down%20to%20the%20floor%2C%20then%20pops%20her%20hind%20parts%20toward%20the%20ceiling.%20The%20image%20is%20uncomfortably%20funny%20and%20gruesomely%20sexy%E2%80%94like%20one%20of%20the%20violent%2C%20coital%2C%20comic%20scenes%20from%20Kara%20Walker%E2%80%99s%20recent%20painting%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.moma.org%2Fcollection%2Fworks%2F274903%5C%22%3E%E2%80%9CChrist%E2%80%99s%20Entry%20Into%20Journalism%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%94and%20a%20harbinger%20of%20things%20to%20come.%20A%20white%20man%20with%20a%20whip%20enters%20the%20room%2C%20interrupting%20the%20twerk%2C%20and%20we%E2%80%99re%20off.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20play%20acts%20like%20a%20whittling%20knife%2C%20refining%20and%20clarifying%20as%20it%20cuts.%20The%20first%20act%20is%20broad%20and%20impressionistic%2C%20and%20each%20of%20the%20next%20two%20sections%20is%20more%20realistic%20and%20denser%20with%20psychic%20danger%20than%20the%20last.%20The%20back%20wall%20of%20the%20stage%20is%20a%20mirror%3B%20part%20of%20the%20point%20is%20your%20own%20reaction.%20Should%20you%20laugh%20or%20keep%20quiet%3F%20You%20can%E2%80%99t%20know%20until%20the%20ordeal%20is%20done%E2%80%94and%20even%20then%2C%20I%20can%20attest%2C%20the%20uncertainty%20may%20linger%20for%20days.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ENow%20is%20a%20good%20time%20to%20look%20away%20if%20you%20don%E2%80%99t%20want%20spoilers.%20After%20a%20series%20of%20sex%20sketches%E2%80%94a%20dildo-drunk%20mistress%20and%20a%20slave%20fiddler%3B%20a%20white%20indentured%20servant%20and%20the%20slave%20who%20has%20been%20assigned%20to%20oversee%20his%20work%E2%80%94something%20confusing%20happens.%20A%20white%20man%2C%20Jim%20(Paul%20Alexander%20Nolan)%2C%20has%20wound%20his%20way%2C%20clumsily%2C%20toward%20slave-overseer%20sex%20with%20Kaneisha%2C%20who%20keeps%20asking%20him%20to%20call%20her%20a%20%E2%80%9CNegress%E2%80%9D%20and%20insists%2C%20despite%20his%20aversion%2C%20on%20calling%20him%20%E2%80%9CMassa.%E2%80%9D%20Suddenly%2C%20Jim%20cries%20out%2C%20%E2%80%9CStarbucks!%20Starbucks!%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20people%20rush%20the%20stage%2C%20asking%20both%20if%20they%E2%80%99re%20O.K.%20I%E2%80%99ve%20never%20been%20so%20happily%20confused%20in%20the%20middle%20of%20a%20play.%20What%20gives%3F%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIt%20turns%20out%20that%20all%20three%20of%20the%20couples%20are%20participants%20in%20a%20study%2C%20engaging%20in%20%E2%80%9Cantebellum%20sexual%20performance%20therapy%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20now%20they%20sit%20in%20a%20semicircle%2C%20along%20with%20two%20therapists%2C%20Te%C3%A1%20(Chalia%20La%20Tour)%20and%20Patricia%20(Irene%20Sofia%20Lucio).%20Each%20of%20the%20black%20partners%20has%20been%20inexplicably%20losing%20sexual%20interest%2C%20experiencing%20what%20Te%C3%A1%20insists%20is%20a%20racial-romantic%20%E2%80%9Canhedonia%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20inability%20to%20feel%20pleasure.%20What%20ensues%20is%20not%20only%20a%20deft%20exploration%20of%20what%20happens%20when%20love%20and%20power%20(acknowledged%20or%20not)%20collide%20but%20also%20an%20excavation%20of%20a%20newly%20common%20kind%20of%20political-academic%20talk.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHarris%20shows%2C%20to%20very%20funny%20effect%2C%20how%20the%20language%20of%20critical%20theory%E2%80%94black%20studies%2C%20Marxist%20thought%2C%20queer%20and%20gender%20theories%E2%80%94and%20that%20of%20Freudian%20talk%20therapy%20have%20come%2C%20increasingly%2C%20to%20echo%20each%20other%2C%20sometimes%20fruitfully%20and%20sometimes%20not.%20Te%C3%A1%20and%20Patricia%20ostentatiously%20%E2%80%9Chear%E2%80%9D%20each%20other%20and%20their%20subjects%2C%20and%20take%20stricken%20care%20with%20what%20they%20introduce%20into%20the%20%E2%80%9Cspace.%E2%80%9D%20Of%20course%2C%20these%20words%20mask%20coarser%20realities%2C%20chief%20among%20them%20the%20fact%20that%20the%20white%20participants%20insist%20on%20taking%20up%20more%20%E2%80%9Cspace%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94verbal%20and%20sometimes%20physical%E2%80%94than%20their%20partners.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EPart%20of%20what%20is%20irritating%20about%20our%20racial%20regime%20is%20its%20tendency%20to%20reduce%20us%2C%20without%20our%20consent%20and%2C%20often%2C%20before%20we%20even%20know%20it%2C%20to%20archetypes.%20Thus%2C%20Dustin%20(James%20Cusati-Moyer)%2C%20who%20insists%20that%20he%20isn%E2%80%99t%20white%20but%20won%E2%80%99t%20say%20what%20he%20is%20instead%2C%20has%20been%20forced%20into%20the%20role%20of%20the%20oppressor%20in%20his%20doomed%20partnership%20with%20Gary%20(Ato%20Blankson-Wood)%2C%20who%2C%20in%20one%20of%20the%20show%E2%80%99s%20rare%20totally%20serious%20moments%2C%20reminds%20Dustin%20that%20some%20of%20us%20are%20%3Cem%3Eblack%3C%2Fem%3E%20black%2C%20undeniably%20so%2C%20beyond%20any%20hope%20of%20self-assertion%2C%20privatized%20choice%2C%20or%20disguise.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAs%20in%20any%20therapeutic%20environment%2C%20messes%20are%20made%20and%20%E2%80%9Cbreakthroughs%E2%80%9D%20are%20shared.%20%E2%80%9CThis%20is%20the%20work!%E2%80%9D%20Te%C3%A1%20shouts%20at%20one%20point%2C%20moved%20to%20ecstasy%20by%20one%20participant%E2%80%99s%20sudden%20insight%20into%20the%20sources%20of%20his%20bedroom%20troubles.%20Even%20at%20the%20moment%20of%20greatest%20release%E2%80%94to%20let%20some%20tell%20it%2C%20of%20greatest%20freedom%E2%80%94there%E2%80%99s%20far%20too%20much%20work%20to%20do.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Nobody, even at this relatively late date in the history of forced or free American race-mixing, knows exactly what to do with the idea—or, worse, the reality—of a black body and a white body coming together. The problem is a superfluity of meaning. Sex between the races means rape and reconciliation, repression and release, assimilation and radical rejection, inculcation into one faulty set of values and freedom from another. Its participants are revolutionaries or self-haters, or both, and they are evidence of an old stain but also hints of a world to come."],["p","“Slave Play,” written by Jeremy O. Harris and directed by Robert O’Hara, at New York Theatre Workshop, takes this multivalent theme by the neck—also the waist; often the crotch—and never stops squeezing. The show’s disorienting first moments show Kaneisha, played with a hoarse drawl by Teyonah Parris, dressed in a slave’s rags and sweeping the floor. Floodlights flare, accompanied, oddly, by snippets of the song “Work,” by Rihanna, making Kaneisha dance. She grinds down to the floor, then pops her hind parts toward the ceiling. The image is uncomfortably funny and gruesomely sexy—like one of the violent, coital, comic scenes from Kara Walker’s recent painting ",["a",{"href":"https://www.moma.org/collection/works/274903"},"“Christ’s Entry Into Journalism”"],"—and a harbinger of things to come. A white man with a whip enters the room, interrupting the twerk, and we’re off."],["p","The play acts like a whittling knife, refining and clarifying as it cuts. The first act is broad and impressionistic, and each of the next two sections is more realistic and denser with psychic danger than the last. The back wall of the stage is a mirror; part of the point is your own reaction. Should you laugh or keep quiet? You can’t know until the ordeal is done—and even then, I can attest, the uncertainty may linger for days."],["p","Now is a good time to look away if you don’t want spoilers. After a series of sex sketches—a dildo-drunk mistress and a slave fiddler; a white indentured servant and the slave who has been assigned to oversee his work—something confusing happens. A white man, Jim (Paul Alexander Nolan), has wound his way, clumsily, toward slave-overseer sex with Kaneisha, who keeps asking him to call her a “Negress” and insists, despite his aversion, on calling him “Massa.” Suddenly, Jim cries out, “Starbucks! Starbucks!,” and people rush the stage, asking both if they’re O.K. I’ve never been so happily confused in the middle of a play. What gives?"],["p","It turns out that all three of the couples are participants in a study, engaging in “antebellum sexual performance therapy,” and now they sit in a semicircle, along with two therapists, Teá (Chalia La Tour) and Patricia (Irene Sofia Lucio). Each of the black partners has been inexplicably losing sexual interest, experiencing what Teá insists is a racial-romantic “anhedonia,” the inability to feel pleasure. What ensues is not only a deft exploration of what happens when love and power (acknowledged or not) collide but also an excavation of a newly common kind of political-academic talk."],["p","Harris shows, to very funny effect, how the language of critical theory—black studies, Marxist thought, queer and gender theories—and that of Freudian talk therapy have come, increasingly, to echo each other, sometimes fruitfully and sometimes not. Teá and Patricia ostentatiously “hear” each other and their subjects, and take stricken care with what they introduce into the “space.” Of course, these words mask coarser realities, chief among them the fact that the white participants insist on taking up more “space”—verbal and sometimes physical—than their partners."],["p","Part of what is irritating about our racial regime is its tendency to reduce us, without our consent and, often, before we even know it, to archetypes. Thus, Dustin (James Cusati-Moyer), who insists that he isn’t white but won’t say what he is instead, has been forced into the role of the oppressor in his doomed partnership with Gary (Ato Blankson-Wood), who, in one of the show’s rare totally serious moments, reminds Dustin that some of us are ",["em","black"]," black, undeniably so, beyond any hope of self-assertion, privatized choice, or disguise."],["p","As in any therapeutic environment, messes are made and “breakthroughs” are shared. “This is the work!” Teá shouts at one point, moved to ecstasy by one participant’s sudden insight into the sources of his bedroom troubles. Even at the moment of greatest release—to let some tell it, of greatest freedom—there’s far too much work to do."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3ECongress%20between%20a%20black%20man%20and%20a%20white%20woman%20sits%2C%20of%20course%2C%20near%20the%20heart%20of%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FKill-Mockingbird-Harper-Lee%2Fdp%2F0446310786%5C%22%3E%E2%80%9CTo%20Kill%20a%20Mockingbird%2C%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fa%3E%20Aaron%20Sorkin%E2%80%99s%20new%20adaptation%20of%20Harper%20Lee%E2%80%99s%20classic%20novel%2C%20directed%20by%20Bartlett%20Sher%2C%20at%20the%20Shubert.%20Tom%20Robinson%20(Gbenga%20Akinnagbe)%20has%20been%20accused%E2%80%94obviously%20wrongly%E2%80%94of%20raping%20Mayella%20Ewell%20(Erin%20Wilhelmi)%2C%20the%20daughter%20of%20a%20poor%20arch-racist%20in%20Maycomb%2C%20Alabama%2C%20and%20our%20hero%2C%20the%20lawyer%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2018%2F12%2F17%2Fthe-contested-legacy-of-atticus-finch%5C%22%3EAtticus%20Finch%3C%2Fa%3E%20(Jeff%20Daniels)%2C%20has%20decided%20to%20take%20on%20the%20case.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EEverybody%20knows%20the%20story%2C%20and%20Sorkin%20stays%20mostly%20faithful%20to%20it%2C%20through%20the%20use%20of%20two%20reasonably%20successful%20theatrical%20devices.%20Atticus%E2%80%99s%20kids%2C%20Scout%20(Celia%20Keenan-Bolger)%20and%20Jem%20(Will%20Pullen)%2C%20along%20with%20their%20friend%20Dill%20(Gideon%20Glick)%2C%20serve%20as%20narrators%2C%20jumping%20in%20and%20out%20of%20their%20scenes%20to%20explain%20the%20stakes%20and%20keep%20the%20action%20moving.%20The%20drama%2C%20too%2C%20has%20been%20reworked%20so%20that%20the%20court%20case%20against%20Robinson%20is%20the%20frame%20for%20the%20whole%20play.%20The%20courtroom%20is%20set%20up%20like%20a%20frank%2C%20sad%2C%20Hopperish%20picture%2C%20with%20Atticus%E2%80%99s%20and%20Tom%E2%80%99s%20backs%20toward%20the%20audience.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20some%20ways%2C%20a%20Sorkin%20%E2%80%9CMockingbird%E2%80%9D%20was%20inevitable.%20His%20specialty%20is%20drawing%20a%20sort%20of%20moderate%20philosopher-hero%2C%20in%20the%20manner%20of%20Jed%20Bartlet%2C%20from%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FPilot%2Fdp%2FB000KZPG04%2Fref%3Dsr_1_3%3Fie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545078208%26amp%3Bsr%3D8-3%26amp%3Bkeywords%3Dthe%2Bwest%2Bwing%5C%22%3E%E2%80%9CThe%20West%20Wing%2C%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fa%3E%20or%20Daniels%E2%80%99s%20character%2C%20Will%20McAvoy%2C%20from%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fculture%2Fcultural-comment%2Fthe-newsroom-crazy-making-campus-rape-episode%5C%22%3E%E2%80%9CThe%20Newsroom.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fa%3E%20Sorkin%E2%80%99s%20Atticus%20is%20cut%20from%20this%20cloth%E2%80%94and%2C%20in%20this%20way%2C%20is%20largely%20faithful%20to%20Lee%E2%80%99s%20version%2C%20if%20endowed%20with%20a%20bit%20less%20gravitas.%20The%20wrinkle%20is%20that%20Sorkin%20is%20very%20obviously%20worried%20about%20Donald%20Trump%2C%20and%20about%20what%20the%20current%20political%20dispensation%20means%20for%20white%20folks%20of%20all%20political%20and%20ethical%20stripes.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAtticus%20keeps%20fending%20off%20the%20moral%20demands%20of%20his%20children%2C%20especially%20Jem%2C%20by%20saying%20that%20even%20the%20most%20racist%20of%20their%20neighbors%20have%20some%20good%20essence%20beneath%20the%20rubble%20of%20their%20wickedness.%20There%20are%20good%20people%20on%20both%20sides%2C%20he%20insists%2C%20echoing%20Trump.%20Although%20this%20is%20meant%20to%20foreground%20Atticus%E2%80%99s%20shortcomings%E2%80%94and%2C%20by%20extension%2C%20the%20kind%20of%20lukewarm%20white%20moderate%20excoriated%20by%20Martin%20Luther%20King%2C%20Jr.%2C%20in%20his%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fnews%2Fnews-desk%2Ffifty-years-after-the-birmingham-childrens-crusade%5C%22%3E%E2%80%9CLetter%20from%20Birmingham%20Jail%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%94it%20also%20pushes%20him%20even%20closer%20to%20the%20center%20of%20the%20play%E2%80%99s%20concern%2C%20making%20the%20defendant%20almost%20an%20afterthought.%20If%20anybody%20in%20this%20story%20could%20use%20a%20fresh%20excavation%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20Tom.%20Two%20black%20characters%2C%20Tom%20and%20Atticus%E2%80%99s%20much%20beloved%20maid%2C%20Calpurnia%20(LaTanya%20Richardson%20Jackson)%2C%20have%20more%20to%20say%20here%20than%20in%20the%20novel.%20Both%2C%20in%20their%20ways%2C%20try%20to%20rouse%20Atticus%20from%20his%20accommodationism%2C%20and%20to%20remind%20him%20that%20the%20truths%20he%20expounds%20abstractly%20have%20played%20out%2C%20concretely%2C%20in%20their%20lives.%20It%E2%80%99s%20unclear%20what%20lesson%20he%20actually%20gleans.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESeveral%20times%2C%20the%20kids%20play-act%20the%20old%20cartoonish%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FAdventures-Sawyer-Dover-Thrift-Editions%2Fdp%2F0486400778%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1_sspa%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545077964%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1-spons%26amp%3Bkeywords%3Dtom%2Bsawyer%26amp%3Bpsc%3D1%5C%22%3E%E2%80%9CTom%20Sawyer%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fa%3E%20game%E2%80%94in%20which%20the%20rascal%20tricks%20his%20buddies%20into%20doing%20his%20fence-painting%20chore%E2%80%94and%20the%20reference%20is%20apt.%20As%20opposed%20to%20%E2%80%9CSlave%20Play%2C%E2%80%9D%20in%20which%20the%20brutal%20and%20vaguely%20Hegelian%20master-slave%20racial%20dynamic%20acts%20as%20an%20engine%20of%20hilarious%20fire%2C%20%E2%80%9CTo%20Kill%20a%20Mockingbird%E2%80%9D%20is%20a%20showcase%20for%20the%20competing%20liberal%20views%20of%20the%20races%2C%20depicting%20them%20in%20a%20kind%20of%20tortured%20but%20ever-improving%20dance%2C%20with%20the%20worst%20days%20in%20the%20past%20and%20something%20more%20peaceful%2C%20possibly%2C%20waiting%20ahead.%20This%20view%20stretches%20from%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2Fs%2Fref%3Dsr_nr_p_lbr_one_browse-bin_0%3Ffst%3Das%253Aoff%26amp%3Brh%3Dn%253A283155%252Ck%253Abooks%2Bby%2Bmark%2Btwain%252Cp_lbr_one_browse-bin%253AMark%2BTwain%26amp%3Bkeywords%3Dbooks%2Bby%2Bmark%2Btwain%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545077827%26amp%3Brnid%3D2272759011%5C%22%3EMark%20Twain%3C%2Fa%3E%20through%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2Fs%2Fref%3Dnb_sb_ss_i_1_9%3Furl%3Dsearch-alias%253Dstripbooks%26amp%3Bfield-keywords%3Dralph%2Bellison%26amp%3Bsprefix%3Dralph%2Bell%252Cstripbooks%252C116%26amp%3Bcrid%3D6O289HHLMX39%26amp%3Brh%3Dn%253A283155%252Ck%253Aralph%2Bellison%5C%22%3ERalph%20Ellison%3C%2Fa%3E%20and%20now%20has%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2Fs%2Fref%3Dnb_sb_ss_i_1_6%3Furl%3Dsearch-alias%253Dstripbooks%26amp%3Bfield-keywords%3Dbarak%2Bobama%2Bbook%26amp%3Bsprefix%3Dbarak%2B%252Cstripbooks%252C116%26amp%3Bcrid%3D3FANB77SZML9N%26amp%3Brh%3Dn%253A283155%252Ck%253Abarak%2Bobama%2Bbook%5C%22%3EBarack%20Obama%3C%2Fa%3E%20as%20its%20greatest%20avatar%3B%20it%20has%20its%20moments%20of%20sentimental%20beauty%20but%20so%20often%20seems%20crippled%20by%20its%20focus%20on%20reason%2C%20on%20talk%2C%20even%20as%20power%20gathers%20in%20nefarious%20places.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAtticus%20loves%20to%20talk%E2%80%94Sorkin%20gives%20him%20a%20flurry%20of%20humorous%20quips%20and%20slick%20moral%20epigrams%E2%80%94but%20%E2%80%9CSlave%20Play%2C%E2%80%9D%20whose%20fierceness%20and%20fun%20have%20me%20pining%2C%20already%2C%20to%20see%20it%20again%2C%20makes%20me%20wonder%20what%20would%20happen%20if%20he%20ever%20tried%20shutting%20up.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAn%20earlier%20version%20of%20this%20article%20misstated%20the%20location%20of%20the%20fictional%20town%20of%20Maycomb.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Congress between a black man and a white woman sits, of course, near the heart of ",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Kill-Mockingbird-Harper-Lee/dp/0446310786"},"“To Kill a Mockingbird,”"]," Aaron Sorkin’s new adaptation of Harper Lee’s classic novel, directed by Bartlett Sher, at the Shubert. Tom Robinson (Gbenga Akinnagbe) has been accused—obviously wrongly—of raping Mayella Ewell (Erin Wilhelmi), the daughter of a poor arch-racist in Maycomb, Alabama, and our hero, the lawyer ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/12/17/the-contested-legacy-of-atticus-finch"},"Atticus Finch"]," (Jeff Daniels), has decided to take on the case."],["p","Everybody knows the story, and Sorkin stays mostly faithful to it, through the use of two reasonably successful theatrical devices. Atticus’s kids, Scout (Celia Keenan-Bolger) and Jem (Will Pullen), along with their friend Dill (Gideon Glick), serve as narrators, jumping in and out of their scenes to explain the stakes and keep the action moving. The drama, too, has been reworked so that the court case against Robinson is the frame for the whole play. The courtroom is set up like a frank, sad, Hopperish picture, with Atticus’s and Tom’s backs toward the audience."],["p","In some ways, a Sorkin “Mockingbird” was inevitable. His specialty is drawing a sort of moderate philosopher-hero, in the manner of Jed Bartlet, from ",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Pilot/dp/B000KZPG04/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1545078208&sr=8-3&keywords=the+west+wing"},"“The West Wing,”"]," or Daniels’s character, Will McAvoy, from ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/culture/cultural-comment/the-newsroom-crazy-making-campus-rape-episode"},"“The Newsroom.”"]," Sorkin’s Atticus is cut from this cloth—and, in this way, is largely faithful to Lee’s version, if endowed with a bit less gravitas. The wrinkle is that Sorkin is very obviously worried about Donald Trump, and about what the current political dispensation means for white folks of all political and ethical stripes."],["p","Atticus keeps fending off the moral demands of his children, especially Jem, by saying that even the most racist of their neighbors have some good essence beneath the rubble of their wickedness. There are good people on both sides, he insists, echoing Trump. Although this is meant to foreground Atticus’s shortcomings—and, by extension, the kind of lukewarm white moderate excoriated by Martin Luther King, Jr., in his ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/fifty-years-after-the-birmingham-childrens-crusade"},"“Letter from Birmingham Jail”"],"—it also pushes him even closer to the center of the play’s concern, making the defendant almost an afterthought. If anybody in this story could use a fresh excavation, it’s Tom. Two black characters, Tom and Atticus’s much beloved maid, Calpurnia (LaTanya Richardson Jackson), have more to say here than in the novel. Both, in their ways, try to rouse Atticus from his accommodationism, and to remind him that the truths he expounds abstractly have played out, concretely, in their lives. It’s unclear what lesson he actually gleans."],["p","Several times, the kids play-act the old cartoonish ",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Adventures-Sawyer-Dover-Thrift-Editions/dp/0486400778/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545077964&sr=1-1-spons&keywords=tom+sawyer&psc=1"},"“Tom Sawyer”"]," game—in which the rascal tricks his buddies into doing his fence-painting chore—and the reference is apt. As opposed to “Slave Play,” in which the brutal and vaguely Hegelian master-slave racial dynamic acts as an engine of hilarious fire, “To Kill a Mockingbird” is a showcase for the competing liberal views of the races, depicting them in a kind of tortured but ever-improving dance, with the worst days in the past and something more peaceful, possibly, waiting ahead. This view stretches from ",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=sr_nr_p_lbr_one_browse-bin_0?fst=as%3Aoff&rh=n%3A283155%2Ck%3Abooks+by+mark+twain%2Cp_lbr_one_browse-bin%3AMark+Twain&keywords=books+by+mark+twain&ie=UTF8&qid=1545077827&rnid=2272759011"},"Mark Twain"]," through ",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_i_1_9?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=ralph+ellison&sprefix=ralph+ell%2Cstripbooks%2C116&crid=6O289HHLMX39&rh=n%3A283155%2Ck%3Aralph+ellison"},"Ralph Ellison"]," and now has ",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_i_1_6?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=barak+obama+book&sprefix=barak+%2Cstripbooks%2C116&crid=3FANB77SZML9N&rh=n%3A283155%2Ck%3Abarak+obama+book"},"Barack Obama"]," as its greatest avatar; it has its moments of sentimental beauty but so often seems crippled by its focus on reason, on talk, even as power gathers in nefarious places."],["p","Atticus loves to talk—Sorkin gives him a flurry of humorous quips and slick moral epigrams—but “Slave Play,” whose fierceness and fun have me pining, already, to see it again, makes me wonder what would happen if he ever tried shutting up. ♦"],["p","An earlier version of this article misstated the location of the fictional town of Maycomb."]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"5910aa3ddd6207318b5db99c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5910aa3ddd6207318b5db99c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"The Cunningham","type":"author","title":"Vinson Cunningham joined The New Yorker as a staff writer in 2016.","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Vinson Cunningham joined ",["em","The New Yorker"]," as a staff writer in 2016. His writing on books, art, and culture has appeared in the ",["em","Times Magazine"],", the ",["em","Times Book Review"],", Vulture, The Awl, ",["em","The Fader"],", and ",["em","McSweeney’s"],", where he wrote a column called “Field Notes from Gentrified Places.” He previously served as a staff assistant at the Obama White House, and is based in New York City."]],"social":[],"url":"/contributors/vinson-cunningham","image":null}],"dek":"Jeremy O. 3EBritton%20paused%20in%20front%20of%20a%20comma-shaped%20lounge%20chair%20(price%3A%20%241%2C675)%20hanging%20from%20a%20thick%20tree%20branch.%20She%20jiggled%20its%20metal%20chain.%20%E2%80%9CWhat%20if%20the%20tree%20breaks%3F%E2%80%9D%20she%20asked.%20She%20hoisted%20herself%20in%20and%20lay%20back.%20Emboldened%2C%20she%20rushed%20over%20to%20a%20larger%20comma%20chair%20swaying%20from%20another%20tree.%20It%20bobbed%20from%20side%20to%20side%20as%20she%20attempted%20to%20get%20in.%20%E2%80%9CNope%2C%20no%2C%20not%20interested%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said%2C%20letting%20it%20go.%20%E2%80%9CNo%2C%20thank%20you%2C%20no.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ELike%20Debra%2C%20Britton%20is%20a%20divorced%20single%20mother%3B%20she%20adopted%20her%20seven-year-old%20son%2C%20Yoby%2C%20in%202011.%20%E2%80%9CI%20can%20certainly%20relate%20to%20a%20kind%20of%20ideal%3A%20%E2%80%98Oh%2C%20if%20only%20I%20had%20a%20partner%2C%20this%20wouldn%E2%80%99t%20be%20quite%20so%20difficult%2C%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20Can%20she%20relate%20to%20the%20bad%20online%20dates%20that%20Debra%20endures%20before%20meeting%20her%20charming%20con%20man%3F%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20not%20ever%20going%20to%20go%20on%20a%20Web%20site%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99d%20rather%20meet%20people%20through%20friends%2C%20and%20that%20can%20go%20just%20as%20badly.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAmong%20Britton%E2%80%99s%20friends%20is%20the%20New%20York%20senator%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2013%2F12%2F16%2Fstrong-vanilla%5C%22%3EKirsten%20Gillibrand%3C%2Fa%3E.%20They%20attended%20Dartmouth%20together%2C%20and%20Gillibrand%20helped%20propel%20Britton%20into%20get-out-the-vote%20efforts.%20(On%20Election%20Day%2C%20she%20wore%20a%20sweater%20that%20said%2C%20in%20pink%20cursive%20script%2C%20%E2%80%9CNevertheless%2C%20she%20voted.%E2%80%9D)%20The%20two%20women%20text%20frequently.%20%E2%80%9COn%20the%20days%20when%20I%20feel%20really%20frustrated%20with%20what%E2%80%99s%20happening%20in%20the%20news%2C%20I%E2%80%99ll%20reach%20out%20to%20her%20and%20say%2C%20%E2%80%98Tell%20me%20the%20real%20deal%2C%20what%20do%20we%20need%20to%20do%20here%2C%20what%20can%20the%20average%20citizen%20do%3F%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20Britton%20said.%20%E2%80%9CSpeaking%20to%20her%20is%20very%20soothing.%E2%80%9D%20Gillibrand%20recently%20visited%20Yoby%E2%80%99s%20school%20to%20talk%20about%20her%20picture%20book%20about%20suffragists%2C%20%E2%80%9CBold%20%26amp%3B%20Brave.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAn%20assortment%20of%20beanbag%20chairs%20had%20the%20give%20of%20packed%20soil%3B%20a%20velvet%20settee%20felt%20like%20%E2%80%9Cit%E2%80%99s%20got%20sand%20in%20it%20or%20something%2C%E2%80%9D%20Britton%20said.%20She%20wryly%20regarded%20an%20assortment%20of%20fifty-nine-dollar%20woven%20baskets%3A%20%E2%80%9CLike%2C%20if%20I%20only%20had%20those%20things%2C%20I%20could%20organize%20my%20entire%20house.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBefore%20leaving%2C%20she%20trekked%20to%20the%20market%E2%80%99s%20rest%20room%2C%20a%20faux-rustic%20windowed%20outhouse.%20Another%20shopper%20had%20accidentally%20locked%20the%20door%20on%20the%20way%20out.%20Britton%20flagged%20down%20a%20salesman.%20%E2%80%9CDo%20you%20need%20to%20get%20in%20there%3F%E2%80%9D%20he%20asked%2C%20not%20especially%20solicitous.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBritton%20frowned.%20%E2%80%9CWell%2C%20yeah%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAfterward%2C%20she%20headed%20to%20her%20black%20S.U.V.%20The%20perfect%20chair%20was%20proving%20elusive.%20She%E2%80%99d%20find%20one%20another%20day.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The other day, Connie Britton, the actress, found herself at an indoor-outdoor furniture market in Malibu, shopping for items to fill a Spanish Colonial home that she had recently purchased. “I’m going to try to do a lot of vintage stuff from that period, but I love Art Deco and mid-century modern, too,” she said. She wore jeans and an olive-green sweater, and held a can of lime-flavored LaCroix. “I do think of interior design as an art form,” she said. Therefore, she had hired a professional. But comfortable seating defies outsourcing: Britton said she would test the chairs herself."],["p","Britton stars in the Bravo television drama “",["a",{"href":"https://www.vulture.com/2018/11/dirty-john-bravo-showrunner-interview.html"},"Dirty John"],",” based on a true-crime podcast about Debra Newell, an interior designer who gets duped by a handsome, sociopathic grifter. Britton plays Debra, a Maserati-driving self-made business owner and single mother, who founded her company in part to employ other single moms. “She’s actually an incredibly strong woman,” Britton said. She’s also a hopeless romantic, who speaks in breathy uptalk and fails to notice a parade of red flags flapping around her latest love interest. “It’s why Debra as a character is so fascinating,” Britton said. “Who she is to a man is what gives her value. Her ability to take care of him, to be loved by him, to give him what he needs, is as important—if not more important—than all the things that she’s capable of creating on her own.” She added, “To me, it’s a woman’s study.”"],["p","Britton, fifty-one, is famous for taking on a different type: voluminously haired Middle American moms who don’t take a lot of crap (Tami Taylor, in “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Friday-Night-Lights-Kyle-Chandler/dp/B005CA4SOM"},"Friday Night Lights"],",” Rayna Jaymes, in “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Nashville-Season-1/dp/B009M73DN8"},"Nashville"],"”). Her career took off around the time she turned forty—rare in Hollywood—and benefitted, she said, from “life experience.” She grew up in Maryland and Virginia, one of two daughters of a physicist and a homemaker. “My mom had a lot of Southern-lady friends, and they were, you know, ",["em","ladies"],",” she said, sinking into a cushy gray daybed. “But I was also brought up in a household where I was urged to pursue whatever I dreamed of doing.” So playing Debra required some digging: “For me to speak in her register, it shifts something internally.”"],["p","Britton paused in front of a comma-shaped lounge chair (price: $1,675) hanging from a thick tree branch. She jiggled its metal chain. “What if the tree breaks?” she asked. She hoisted herself in and lay back. Emboldened, she rushed over to a larger comma chair swaying from another tree. It bobbed from side to side as she attempted to get in. “Nope, no, not interested,” she said, letting it go. “No, thank you, no.”"],["p","Like Debra, Britton is a divorced single mother; she adopted her seven-year-old son, Yoby, in 2011. “I can certainly relate to a kind of ideal: ‘Oh, if only I had a partner, this wouldn’t be quite so difficult,’ ” she said. Can she relate to the bad online dates that Debra endures before meeting her charming con man? “I’m not ever going to go on a Web site,” she said. “I’d rather meet people through friends, and that can go just as badly.”"],["p","Among Britton’s friends is the New York senator ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/12/16/strong-vanilla"},"Kirsten Gillibrand"],". They attended Dartmouth together, and Gillibrand helped propel Britton into get-out-the-vote efforts. (On Election Day, she wore a sweater that said, in pink cursive script, “Nevertheless, she voted.”) The two women text frequently. “On the days when I feel really frustrated with what’s happening in the news, I’ll reach out to her and say, ‘Tell me the real deal, what do we need to do here, what can the average citizen do?’ ” Britton said. “Speaking to her is very soothing.” Gillibrand recently visited Yoby’s school to talk about her picture book about suffragists, “Bold & Brave.”"],["p","An assortment of beanbag chairs had the give of packed soil; a velvet settee felt like “it’s got sand in it or something,” Britton said. She wryly regarded an assortment of fifty-nine-dollar woven baskets: “Like, if I only had those things, I could organize my entire house.”"],["p","Before leaving, she trekked to the market’s rest room, a faux-rustic windowed outhouse. Another shopper had accidentally locked the door on the way out. Britton flagged down a salesman. “Do you need to get in there?” he asked, not especially solicitous."],["p","Britton frowned. “Well, yeah,” she said."],["p","Afterward, she headed to her black S.U.V. The perfect chair was proving elusive. She’d find one another day. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c7e7e716b454591adb2","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Connie ly%20minted%20songs.%20The%20manner%20of%20Mary%E2%80%99s%20return%2C%20summoned%20by%20a%20kite%2C%20is%20lifted%20from%20another%20sequel%E2%80%94%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FMary-Poppins-Comes-Back-Travers%2Fdp%2F0544439570%2Fref%3Dtmm_pap_swatch_0%3F_encoding%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D%26amp%3Bsr%3D%5C%22%3EMary%20Poppins%20Comes%20Back%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20P.%C2%A0L.%20Travers%E2%80%99s%20novel%20of%201935%2C%20which%20she%20wrote%20on%20the%20elegant%20heels%20of%20the%20first%20book.%20The%20eighth%20and%20final%20one%2C%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FPoppins-House-Puffin-Books-Paperback%2Fdp%2FB010EWBOCG%2Fref%3Dsr_1_7%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545073278%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-7%26amp%3Bkeywords%3Dmary%2Bpoppins%2Band%2Bthe%2Bhouse%2Bnext%2Bdoor%5C%22%3EMary%20Poppins%20and%20the%20House%20Next%20Door%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20did%20not%20appear%20until%201988%2C%20when%20Travers%20was%20approaching%20ninety.%20At%20the%20end%20of%20it%2C%20Mary%20is%20asked%20where%20she%E2%80%99s%20from.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20at%20home%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20replies%2C%20%E2%80%9Cwherever%20I%20am!%E2%80%9D%20Few%20fictional%20figures%20have%20been%20quite%20so%20self-possessed.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20children%20from%20the%20first%20film%2C%20Jane%20and%20Michael%20Banks%2C%20are%20now%20grown%20up.%20Jane%20(%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2018%2F12%2F17%2Fshades-of-the-suffragette-in-a-grownup-jane-banks%5C%22%3EEmily%20Mortimer%3C%2Fa%3E)%20is%20cheerful%2C%20single%2C%20and%20intent%20on%20improving%20the%20lives%20of%20working%20folk.%20(Well%2C%20up%20to%20a%20point.%20Although%20she%20carries%20flyers%20for%20a%20rally%2C%20we%20never%20see%20her%20attending%20it.%20In%20the%201964%20movie%2C%20the%20kids%E2%80%99%20mother%20sang%20lustily%20in%20favor%20of%20the%20suffragettes%2C%20whereas%20this%20version%20nods%20nervously%20at%20politics%20and%20hurries%20on%20by.)%20Michael%20(%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fben-whishaw%5C%22%3EBen%20Whishaw%3C%2Fa%3E)%20has%20fared%20less%20well.%20He%20is%20widowed%20and%20woebegone%2C%20with%20three%20young%20offspring%20to%20care%20for%3A%20Annabel%20(Pixie%20Davies)%2C%20John%20(Nathanael%20Saleh)%2C%20and%20Georgie.%20There%20is%20a%20flustered%20housekeeper%2C%20Ellen%20(Julie%20Walters)%2C%20who%20can%20barely%20keep%20control.%20Jane%20is%20doing%20her%20best%20to%20lend%20support%2C%20but%20money%20is%20tight%2C%20and%20their%20family%20house%2C%2017%20Cherry%20Tree%20Lane%2C%20is%20about%20to%20be%20repossessed.%20Only%20a%20miracle%20can%20save%20them.%20Hail%20Mary.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHow%20long%20does%20it%20take%20to%20be%20sure%2C%20beyond%20a%20reasonable%20doubt%2C%20that%20Blunt%20is%20right%20for%20the%20part%3F%20About%20two%20seconds%2C%20by%20my%20watch.%20Consider%20her%20first%20appearance%2C%20in%20the%20park.%20Fresh%20from%20on%20high%2C%20she%20lands%20not%20in%20a%20stutter%20or%20a%20rush%20but%20with%20one%20foot%20at%20a%20decorous%20angle%20and%20the%20other%20taking%20a%20gently%20purposeful%20stride.%20Nureyev%20could%20not%20have%20set%20her%20down%20with%20greater%20grace%2C%20and%20something%20about%20that%20initial%20step%20tells%20you%20all%20you%20need%20to%20know.%20(We%20sense%20at%20once%20a%20healthy%20impatience%20with%20fusspots%20and%20fools%2C%20for%20the%20grass%2C%20as%20the%20signs%20indicate%2C%20is%20not%20to%20be%20trodden%20on.)%20Whatever%20the%20job%20is%2C%20this%20Mary%20will%20get%20it%20done.%20%E2%80%9CSnap!%20The%20job%E2%80%99s%20a%20game%2C%E2%80%9D%20Julie%20Andrews%20informed%20us%2C%20more%20than%20half%20a%20century%20ago%2C%20when%20the%20role%20was%20hers.%20So%20what%E2%80%99s%20different%2C%20with%20Emily%20Blunt%20in%20charge%3F%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EA%20spoonful%20less%20sugar%2C%20I%20reckon%2C%20and%20a%20pinch%20more%20spice.%20A%20fraction%20of%20the%20lung%20power%2C%20as%20expected%2C%20though%20the%20accent%20is%20a%20touch%20posher%2C%20which%20makes%20you%20wonder%20what%20noble%20company%20Mary%E2%80%99s%20been%20keeping%20in%20the%20intervening%20years.%20An%20extra%20shade%20of%20slyness%2C%20too%2C%20is%20detectable%20in%20her%20sidelong%20glance%2C%20and%20in%20the%20curve%20of%20her%20smile%2C%20as%20though%20there%20were%20secrets%20neatly%20folded%20and%20tucked%20away%20in%20her%20carpetbag%20(which%2C%20like%20its%20owner%2C%20is%20infinite%20but%20bounded)%2C%20rarely%20to%20be%20revealed.%20If%20Blunt%20is%20my%20favorite%20living%20actress%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20partly%20because%20she%20brings%20to%20mind%20those%20other%20performers%E2%80%94no%20longer%20alive%2C%20but%20immortal%E2%80%94who%20traded%20with%20equal%20ease%20in%20the%20mystery%20of%20blithe%20spirits.%20Like%20Veronica%20Lake%20in%20%E2%80%9CI%20Married%20a%20Witch%E2%80%9D%20(1942)%2C%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fcarole-lombard%5C%22%3ECarole%20Lombard%3C%2Fa%3E%20in%20her%20screwball%20heyday%2C%20and%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Flauren-bacall%5C%22%3ELauren%20Bacall%3C%2Fa%3E%20in%20pretty%20much%20anything%2C%20Blunt%20requires%20an%20exceptionally%20good%20reason%20not%20to%20be%20amused.%20That%E2%80%99s%20why%20she%20sailed%20through%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2006%2F07%2F10%2Fdressed-to-kill%5C%22%3EThe%20Devil%20Wears%20Prada%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20(2006)%2C%20why%20she%20was%20becalmed%20in%20the%20murk%20of%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2016%2F10%2F17%2Fthe-girl-on-the-train-and-under-the-shadow%5C%22%3EThe%20Girl%20on%20the%20Train%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20(2016)%2C%20and%20why%20there%E2%80%99s%20such%20a%20frothing%20sense%20of%20release%2C%20in%20%E2%80%9CMary%20Poppins%20Returns%2C%E2%80%9D%20as%20she%20perches%20on%20the%20rim%20of%20a%20full%20bathtub%2C%20exclaims%2C%20%E2%80%9COff%20we%20go!%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20falls%20in.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20children%20are%20already%20under%20the%20suds.%20There%20they%20discover%20an%20aquatic%20haven%2C%20where%20they%20bob%20along%20within%20giant%20bubbles%3B%20it%E2%80%99s%20just%20one%20of%20the%20playgrounds%20in%20which%20they%20are%20immersed%20at%20Mary%E2%80%99s%20command%E2%80%94or%2C%20rather%2C%20at%20the%20bidding%20of%20her%20imagination%2C%20which%20feels%20as%20strict%20as%20other%20people%E2%80%99s%20scoldings.%20Further%20exploits%20include%20a%20visit%20to%20her%20cousin%20Topsy%20(%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fmeryl-streep%5C%22%3EMeryl%20Streep%3C%2Fa%3E)%2C%20whose%20bric-a-brac%20emporium%20turns%20upside%20down%20every%20second%20Wednesday%20of%20the%20month%2C%20and%20a%20frenzied%20nocturnal%20dance%20with%20Jack%20and%20his%20fellow-lamplighters.%20%E2%80%9CChina!%E2%80%9D%20Mary%20says%2C%20when%20the%20children%20inquire%20where%20they%20will%20be%20heading%20next%2C%20though%20what%20she%20means%20is%20not%20the%20country%20but%20a%20porcelain%20bowl%2C%20prized%20and%20crazed%2C%20into%20which%20they%20somehow%20jump%2C%20and%20where%20the%20ground%20underfoot%20gives%20off%20a%20fragile%20ceramic%20%3Cem%3Eding%3C%2Fem%3E.%20The%20creatures%20who%20romp%20around%20them%20are%20animated%20cartoons%2C%20and%20the%20colors%20are%20a%20riot%20of%20candy%20stripes.%20Remind%20you%20of%20anything%3F%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAlmost%20every%20musical%20number%20in%20the%20new%20film%20is%20designed%20to%20match%20a%20sequence%20in%20the%20old%20one.%20Topsy%20is%20the%20answer%20to%20Mary%E2%80%99s%20buoyant%20uncle%2C%20who%20took%20tea%20on%20the%20ceiling%3B%20Jack%20is%20the%20nephew%20of%20Bert%20the%20chimney%20sweep%2C%20played%20by%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2010%2F12%2F13%2Fsupercalifragilistic%5C%22%3EDick%20Van%20Dyke%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20and%20%E2%80%9CTrip%20a%20Little%20Light%20Fantastic%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20lamplighters%E2%80%99%20chorus%2C%20picks%20up%20from%20%E2%80%9CStep%20in%20Time%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20rooftop%20cry%20of%20the%20sweeps%3B%20and%20the%20trip%20inside%20the%20bowl%20mirrors%20%E2%80%9CJolly%20Holiday%2C%E2%80%9D%20which%20began%20with%20a%20leap%20into%20a%20chalk%20drawing%2C%20roughly%20sketched%20on%20the%20sidewalk.%20Blunt%20even%20hushes%20the%20children%20with%20a%20lullaby%2C%20as%20Andrews%20did%20before.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIt%E2%80%99s%20far%20too%20soon%20to%20know%20whether%20the%20songs%20of%20today%20will%20stick%2C%20lodging%20in%20our%20collective%20ear%20as%20those%20of%201964%20have%20done.%20What%E2%80%99s%20amazing%20is%20the%20tenacity%20with%20which%20the%20gods%20of%20Disney%2C%20for%20all%20the%20novelties%20of%20their%20digital%20art%2C%20have%20clung%20to%20the%20formulas%20of%20yore.%20You%20can%20find%20the%20sequel%20unadventurous%20in%20that%20regard%2C%20while%20still%20being%20seduced%20and%20soothed%20by%20its%20vow%20of%20innocence.%20Mary%20may%20be%20radical%20in%20her%20fancies%3B%20follow%20her%20lead%2C%20though%2C%20and%20you%E2%80%99ll%20find%20that%20her%20voyaging%20always%20brings%20you%20back%20to%20where%20you%20started%2C%20just%20as%20Dorothy%2C%20post-Oz%2C%20wakes%20up%20in%20her%20own%20warm%20bed.%20There%20is%20joy%2C%20not%20merely%20fear%2C%20in%20the%20wish%20to%20play%20things%20safe.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","It’s about time. Some of us have been waiting all our lives, but, at last, she’s back. In “Mary Poppins Returns,” a small boy named Georgie Banks (Joel Dawson) goes to a park, in London, chasing an old kite that gets carried away by the wind. He grabs the string, and the string pulls him. Before he can be swept off, he is brought down to earth by Jack (",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/02/09/hamiltons"},"Lin-Manuel Miranda"],"), a friendly sort whose job is to light the city’s lamps, and who happens to be passing by. Together, he and Georgie tug at the string, but instead of a kite they reel in Mary Poppins (",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/emily-blunt"},"Emily Blunt"],"), the help from heaven. Lo! She comes with clouds descending, and Georgie runs home to spread the news. “I was flying a kite and it got caught on a nanny!” he declares."],["p","Thus begins Rob Marshall’s film, written by David Magee. Set during the “Great Slump,” presumably of the nineteen-thirties, it’s not a remake of the 1964 original, or a vain attempt to haul Mary into the modern age (although, God knows, we need her here), but a sequel, flush with newly minted songs. The manner of Mary’s return, summoned by a kite, is lifted from another sequel—“",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Mary-Poppins-Comes-Back-Travers/dp/0544439570/ref=tmm_pap_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr="},"Mary Poppins Comes Back"],",” P. L. Travers’s novel of 1935, which she wrote on the elegant heels of the first book. The eighth and final one, “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Poppins-House-Puffin-Books-Paperback/dp/B010EWBOCG/ref=sr_1_7?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545073278&sr=1-7&keywords=mary+poppins+and+the+house+next+door"},"Mary Poppins and the House Next Door"],",” did not appear until 1988, when Travers was approaching ninety. At the end of it, Mary is asked where she’s from. “I’m at home,” she replies, “wherever I am!” Few fictional figures have been quite so self-possessed."],["p","The children from the first film, Jane and Michael Banks, are now grown up. Jane (",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/12/17/shades-of-the-suffragette-in-a-grownup-jane-banks"},"Emily Mortimer"],") is cheerful, single, and intent on improving the lives of working folk. (Well, up to a point. Although she carries flyers for a rally, we never see her attending it. In the 1964 movie, the kids’ mother sang lustily in favor of the suffragettes, whereas this version nods nervously at politics and hurries on by.) Michael (",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/ben-whishaw"},"Ben Whishaw"],") has fared less well. He is widowed and woebegone, with three young offspring to care for: Annabel (Pixie Davies), John (Nathanael Saleh), and Georgie. There is a flustered housekeeper, Ellen (Julie Walters), who can barely keep control. Jane is doing her best to lend support, but money is tight, and their family house, 17 Cherry Tree Lane, is about to be repossessed. Only a miracle can save them. Hail Mary."],["p","How long does it take to be sure, beyond a reasonable doubt, that Blunt is right for the part? About two seconds, by my watch. Consider her first appearance, in the park. Fresh from on high, she lands not in a stutter or a rush but with one foot at a decorous angle and the other taking a gently purposeful stride. Nureyev could not have set her down with greater grace, and something about that initial step tells you all you need to know. (We sense at once a healthy impatience with fusspots and fools, for the grass, as the signs indicate, is not to be trodden on.) Whatever the job is, this Mary will get it done. “Snap! The job’s a game,” Julie Andrews informed us, more than half a century ago, when the role was hers. So what’s different, with Emily Blunt in charge?"],["p","A spoonful less sugar, I reckon, and a pinch more spice. A fraction of the lung power, as expected, though the accent is a touch posher, which makes you wonder what noble company Mary’s been keeping in the intervening years. An extra shade of slyness, too, is detectable in her sidelong glance, and in the curve of her smile, as though there were secrets neatly folded and tucked away in her carpetbag (which, like its owner, is infinite but bounded), rarely to be revealed. If Blunt is my favorite living actress, it’s partly because she brings to mind those other performers—no longer alive, but immortal—who traded with equal ease in the mystery of blithe spirits. Like Veronica Lake in “I Married a Witch” (1942), ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/carole-lombard"},"Carole Lombard"]," in her screwball heyday, and ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/lauren-bacall"},"Lauren Bacall"]," in pretty much anything, Blunt requires an exceptionally good reason not to be amused. That’s why she sailed through “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2006/07/10/dressed-to-kill"},"The Devil Wears Prada"],"” (2006), why she was becalmed in the murk of “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/10/17/the-girl-on-the-train-and-under-the-shadow"},"The Girl on the Train"],"” (2016), and why there’s such a frothing sense of release, in “Mary Poppins Returns,” as she perches on the rim of a full bathtub, exclaims, “Off we go!,” and falls in."],["p","The children are already under the suds. There they discover an aquatic haven, where they bob along within giant bubbles; it’s just one of the playgrounds in which they are immersed at Mary’s command—or, rather, at the bidding of her imagination, which feels as strict as other people’s scoldings. Further exploits include a visit to her cousin Topsy (",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/meryl-streep"},"Meryl Streep"],"), whose bric-a-brac emporium turns upside down every second Wednesday of the month, and a frenzied nocturnal dance with Jack and his fellow-lamplighters. “China!” Mary says, when the children inquire where they will be heading next, though what she means is not the country but a porcelain bowl, prized and crazed, into which they somehow jump, and where the ground underfoot gives off a fragile ceramic ",["em","ding"],". The creatures who romp around them are animated cartoons, and the colors are a riot of candy stripes. Remind you of anything?"],["p","Almost every musical number in the new film is designed to match a sequence in the old one. Topsy is the answer to Mary’s buoyant uncle, who took tea on the ceiling; Jack is the nephew of Bert the chimney sweep, played by ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2010/12/13/supercalifragilistic"},"Dick Van Dyke"],", and “Trip a Little Light Fantastic,” the lamplighters’ chorus, picks up from “Step in Time,” the rooftop cry of the sweeps; and the trip inside the bowl mirrors “Jolly Holiday,” which began with a leap into a chalk drawing, roughly sketched on the sidewalk. Blunt even hushes the children with a lullaby, as Andrews did before."],["p","It’s far too soon to know whether the songs of today will stick, lodging in our collective ear as those of 1964 have done. What’s amazing is the tenacity with which the gods of Disney, for all the novelties of their digital art, have clung to the formulas of yore. You can find the sequel unadventurous in that regard, while still being seduced and soothed by its vow of innocence. Mary may be radical in her fancies; follow her lead, though, and you’ll find that her voyaging always brings you back to where you started, just as Dorothy, post-Oz, wakes up in her own warm bed. There is joy, not merely fear, in the wish to play things safe."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EMarshall%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20get%20everything%20right.%20Over%20the%20years%2C%20David%20Tomlinson%E2%80%99s%20performance%20as%20Mr.%20Banks%2C%20in%20%E2%80%9CMary%20Poppins%2C%E2%80%9D%20has%20grown%20peculiarly%20moving%20in%20its%20bluster%20and%20its%20bowler-hatted%20despair%20(%E2%80%9CA%20man%20has%20dreams%20of%20walking%20with%20giants%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20confessed)%2C%20whereas%20Ben%20Whishaw%2C%20as%20the%20latest%20man%20of%20the%20house%2C%20is%20craven%20and%20crushed.%20Julie%20Walters%2C%20offered%20pretty%20much%20the%20same%20part%20that%20she%20plays%20in%20the%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fculture%2Frichard-brody%2Fthe-chilling-sweetness-of-paddington-2%5C%22%3EPaddington%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20films%2C%20obliges%20with%20an%20identical%20turn.%20At%20one%20point%2C%20we%20are%20confronted%20by%20BMX%20bikers%E2%80%94a%20spectacularly%20ill-judged%20addition%2C%20though%20it%20does%20drive%20home%20the%20firmness%20of%20period%20details%20elsewhere.%20The%20villains%2C%20naturally%2C%20are%20bankers%3B%20the%20more%20a%20movie%20costs%20to%20make%2C%20the%20more%20gleefully%20it%20must%20demonize%20the%20practice%20of%20basic%20capitalism.%20Having%20said%20that%2C%20the%20casting%20of%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fcolin-firth%5C%22%3EColin%20Firth%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20as%20the%20leading%20malefactor%2C%20is%20fiendishly%20smart%2C%20for%20which%20of%20us%20would%20not%20entrust%20our%20pennies%20to%20him%3F%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EOn%20the%20credit%20side%20of%20the%20ledger%2C%20there%20are%20rich%20rewards.%20Lin-Manuel%20Miranda%20kicks%20off%20the%20action%20not%20with%20a%20bang%20but%20with%20a%20wistful%2C%20Whistler-hued%20hymn%20to%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20lovely%20London%20sky%E2%80%9D%20(which%20is%20mostly%20gray)%2C%20and%20that%20restraint%20endures%2C%20though%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fhamilton%5C%22%3EHamilton%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20fans%20should%20not%20fret%3B%20one%20of%20his%20songs%2C%20packed%20with%20a%20patter%20of%20crispy%20consonants%20and%20delivered%20in%20double-quick%20time%2C%20is%20enough%20to%20convince%20us%20that%20hip-hop%20was%20born%20in%20the%20music%20hall.%20Drops%20of%20the%20old%20score%2C%20if%20you%20listen%20carefully%2C%20are%20melted%20into%20the%20soundtrack.%20There%20are%20cameos%20for%20Dick%20Van%20Dyke%2C%20who%20prances%20like%20it%E2%80%99s%201964%3B%20for%20Karen%20Dotrice%2C%20who%20was%20Jane%20all%20those%20years%20ago%2C%20and%20who%20now%20bumps%20into%20her%20adult%20self%3B%20and%20for%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fvideo.newyorker.com%2Fwatch%2Fangela-lansbury%5C%22%3EAngela%20Lansbury%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20whose%20very%20existence%20is%20a%20force%20of%20anti-gravity%2C%20as%20a%20seller%20of%20balloons.%20The%20tailoring%20is%20uniformly%20spiffy%20(Jane%20wears%20pants%20as%20wide%20as%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fkatharine-hepburn%5C%22%3EKatharine%20Hepburn%E2%80%99s%3C%2Fa%3E)%2C%20and%20Mary%E2%80%99s%20shoes%20alone%20are%20worth%20the%20price%20of%20admission%2C%20especially%20the%20blue%20pair%20with%20the%20scarlet%20laces.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20short%2C%20those%20of%20us%20who%20pursue%20Mariolatry%E2%80%94the%20worship%20of%20all%20things%20Poppins%E2%80%94are%20free%20to%20delight%20in%20this%20film.%20Indeed%2C%20it%20shifts%20a%20little%20nearer%20than%20its%20predecessor%20did%20to%20the%20spiky%2C%20peppery%20briskness%20of%20Travers%E2%80%99s%20tales%2C%20and%20the%20whole%20enterprise%20exhales%2C%20as%20it%20should%2C%20an%20air%20of%20the%20politely%20mad.%20%E2%80%9CMary%20Poppins%2C%20how%20much%20do%20you%20weigh%3F%E2%80%9D%20one%20of%20the%20children%20asks%2C%20as%20they%20are%20all%20about%20to%20perch%20on%20Jack%E2%80%99s%20bicycle.%20Mary%E2%80%99s%20face%2C%20in%20response%2C%20is%20a%20picture%20of%20indignant%20horror.%20Manners%2C%20to%20her%2C%20are%20not%20a%20curb%20on%20emotion%2C%20or%20a%20falsifying%20mask%2C%20but%20vital%20accessories%20for%20getting%20on%20in%20the%20world%20or%20taking%20a%20principled%20stand.%20She%20is%20not%20old-fashioned%20in%20that%20belief.%20It%20simply%20means%2C%20as%20Julie%20Andrews%20suggested%2C%20and%20as%20Emily%20Blunt%20triumphantly%20confirms%2C%20that%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2005%2F12%2F19%2Fbecoming-mary-poppins%5C%22%3EMary%20Poppins%3C%2Fa%3E%20never%20goes%20out%20of%20style.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Marshall doesn’t get everything right. Over the years, David Tomlinson’s performance as Mr. Banks, in “Mary Poppins,” has grown peculiarly moving in its bluster and its bowler-hatted despair (“A man has dreams of walking with giants,” he confessed), whereas Ben Whishaw, as the latest man of the house, is craven and crushed. Julie Walters, offered pretty much the same part that she plays in the “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/culture/richard-brody/the-chilling-sweetness-of-paddington-2"},"Paddington"],"” films, obliges with an identical turn. At one point, we are confronted by BMX bikers—a spectacularly ill-judged addition, though it does drive home the firmness of period details elsewhere. The villains, naturally, are bankers; the more a movie costs to make, the more gleefully it must demonize the practice of basic capitalism. Having said that, the casting of ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/colin-firth"},"Colin Firth"],", as the leading malefactor, is fiendishly smart, for which of us would not entrust our pennies to him?"],["p","On the credit side of the ledger, there are rich rewards. Lin-Manuel Miranda kicks off the action not with a bang but with a wistful, Whistler-hued hymn to “the lovely London sky” (which is mostly gray), and that restraint endures, though “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/hamilton"},"Hamilton"],"” fans should not fret; one of his songs, packed with a patter of crispy consonants and delivered in double-quick time, is enough to convince us that hip-hop was born in the music hall. Drops of the old score, if you listen carefully, are melted into the soundtrack. There are cameos for Dick Van Dyke, who prances like it’s 1964; for Karen Dotrice, who was Jane all those years ago, and who now bumps into her adult self; and for ",["a",{"href":"https://video.newyorker.com/watch/angela-lansbury"},"Angela Lansbury"],", whose very existence is a force of anti-gravity, as a seller of balloons. The tailoring is uniformly spiffy (Jane wears pants as wide as ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/katharine-hepburn"},"Katharine Hepburn’s"],"), and Mary’s shoes alone are worth the price of admission, especially the blue pair with the scarlet laces."],["p","In short, those of us who pursue Mariolatry—the worship of all things Poppins—are free to delight in this film. Indeed, it shifts a little nearer than its predecessor did to the spiky, peppery briskness of Travers’s tales, and the whole enterprise exhales, as it should, an air of the politely mad. “Mary Poppins, how much do you weigh?” one of the children asks, as they are all about to perch on Jack’s bicycle. Mary’s face, in response, is a picture of indignant horror. Manners, to her, are not a curb on emotion, or a falsifying mask, but vital accessories for getting on in the world or taking a principled stand. She is not old-fashioned in that belief. It simply means, as Julie Andrews suggested, and as Emily Blunt triumphantly confirms, that ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/12/19/becoming-mary-poppins"},"Mary Poppins"]," never goes out of style. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"59b9bf9c66a5ca32dcef1772","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"59b9bf9c66a5ca32dcef1772","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"The Lane","type":"author","title":"Anthony Lane has been a film critic for \u003cem>The New Yorker\u003c/em> since 1993. He is the author of “\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/dp/0375714340/?tag=thneyo0f-20\">Nobody’s Perfect\u003c/a>.”","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Anthony Lane has been a film critic for ",["em","The New Yorker"]," since 1993. Before coming to the magazine, he worked at the ",["em","Independent"],", in London, where he was appointed deputy literary editor in 1989 and, a year later, a film critic for the ",["em","Independent on Sunday"],". In 2001, his reviews received the National Magazine Award for Reviews and Criticism. His writings for ",["em","The New Yorker"]," are collected in the book “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Nobodys-Perfect-Writings-New-Yorker/dp/0375714340/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1489425175&sr=1-1&keywords=nobody%27s+perfect+anthony+lane"},"Nobody’s
