\u003c/g>\u003c/svg>"}}},{"body":["div",["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3ELike%20many%20people%2C%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fjames-comey%5C%22%3EJames%20Comey%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20the%20former%20F.B.I.%20director%2C%20has%20been%20thinking%20about%20the%20best%20way%20for%20the%20Presidency%20of%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fdonald-trump%5C%22%3EDonald%20Trump%3C%2Fa%3E%20to%20end.%20Interviewed%20in%20New%20York%20last%20week%2C%20Comey%20said%20that%20his%20own%2C%20possibly%20%E2%80%9Cweird%E2%80%9D%20thought%20is%20that%20impeachment%20is%20not%20the%20ideal%20course%3B%20for%20one%20thing%2C%20it%20would%20let%20voters%20%E2%80%9Coff%20the%20hook%E2%80%9D%20in%202020.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20need%20a%20clear%20jump%20upward%2C%20and%20it%20will%20come%20from%20tens%20of%20millions%20of%20Americans%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20told%20his%20interviewer%2C%20Nicolle%20Wallace.%20But%20Comey%20put%20the%20burden%20on%20the%20Democrats%2C%20saying%2C%20%E2%80%9CThey%20have%20to%20win.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20response%2C%20Trump%20tweeted%20that%20Comey%20had%20%E2%80%9Cjust%20totally%20exposed%20his%20partisan%20stance%20by%20urging%20his%20fellow%20Democrats%20to%20take%20back%20the%20White%20House%20in%202020.%E2%80%9D%20(Comey%20says%20that%20he%E2%80%99s%20an%20independent.)%20He%20added%2C%20%E2%80%9CComey%20had%20no%20right%20heading%20the%20FBI%20at%20any%20time%2C%20but%20especially%20after%20his%20mind%20exploded!%E2%80%9D%20The%20date%20and%20the%20circumstances%20of%20the%20alleged%20detonation%20were%20not%20clear%2C%20but%20the%20message%20was%3A%20to%20speak%20about%20confronting%20Trump%20at%20the%20polls%20is%20to%20speak%20as%20a%20Democrat.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThere%E2%80%99s%20some%20practical%20truth%20to%20that.%20Given%20that%20the%20Republicans%2C%20particularly%20in%20Congress%2C%20have%20largely%20ceded%20their%20party%20to%20Trump%2C%20the%202020%20campaign%20seems%20headed%20toward%20a%20contest%20between%20him%20and%20the%20Democratic%20nominee.%20The%20Democrats%20now%20have%20to%20decide%20what%20kind%20of%20candidate%20they%20want.%20But%20why%20should%20the%20Republicans%20be%20let%20off%20the%20hook%3F%20Those%20who%20don%E2%80%99t%20share%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20more%20corrosive%20views%20often%20wallow%20in%20the%20perception%20of%20their%20own%20powerlessness.%20Yet%20they%20have%20options%2C%20if%20they%20choose%20to%20use%20them%2C%20including%20one%20that%20the%20Democrats%20don%E2%80%99t.%20They%20can%20challenge%20Trump%20in%20the%20primaries.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ETrump%20knows%20that%2C%20which%20is%20why%20his%20campaign%20is%20already%20working%20to%20engineer%20a%20pre%C3%ABmptive%20endorsement%20in%20the%20New%20Hampshire%20primary%2C%20the%20first%20in%20the%20nation%2C%20from%20the%20state%20Party%2C%20which%20traditionally%20remains%20neutral.%20He%20could%20be%20much%20more%20vulnerable%20by%20August%20of%202020%2C%20when%20the%20Republican%20National%20Convention%20meets%20in%20Charlotte%2C%20North%20Carolina%2C%20depending%20on%2C%20among%20other%20things%2C%20how%20the%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Frussia-investigation%5C%22%3EMueller%20investigation%3C%2Fa%3E%20develops.%20(Last%20week%2C%20forty-four%20former%20senators%2C%20ten%20of%20them%20Republicans%2C%20signed%20an%20open%20letter%2C%20urging%20the%20Senate%20to%20uphold%20the%20rule%20of%20law%3B%20it%20reads%20like%20a%20foreshadowing%20of%20a%20crisis.)%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EOne%20Republican%20who%20has%20been%20openly%20considering%20a%20run%20against%20Trump%20is%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fjohn-kasich%5C%22%3EJohn%20Kasich%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20the%20outgoing%20governor%20of%20Ohio%2C%20who%20was%20the%20last%20candidate%20to%20drop%20out%20of%20the%202016%20Presidential%20primaries.%20He%20has%20been%20to%20New%20Hampshire%20twice%20recently%2C%20and%20his%20advisers%20have%20spoken%20out%20against%20the%20attempt%20to%20change%20the%20state%20Party%20rules.%20Still%2C%20Kasich%20told%20the%20Columbus%20%3Cem%3E%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dispatch.com%2Fnews%2F20181210%2Fkasich-thinking-about-job-in-media-still-opposes-gun-bill%5C%22%3EDispatch%3C%2Fa%3E%3C%2Fem%3E%20last%20week%2C%20%E2%80%9CMaybe%20the%20Lord%20will%20say%2C%20%E2%80%98John%2C%20enough%20of%20you%20for%2030%20years%2C%20enough%20of%20you.%20Go%20sit%20somewhere%20in%20the%20corner%2C%20shut%20up%20for%20awhile.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20He%20is%20not%20alone%20in%20this%20wavering.%20%E2%80%9CI%20do%20hope%20that%20somebody%20else%20runs%20in%20the%20Republican%20primary%2C%E2%80%9D%20Senator%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fjeff-flake%5C%22%3EJeff%20Flake%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20of%20Arizona%2C%20who%20will%20retire%20next%20month%2C%20said%20in%20October.%20But%2C%20he%20added%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20don%E2%80%99t%20see%20that%20happening%20in%20my%20case.%E2%80%9D%20Ten%20days%20later%2C%20he%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20not%20ruling%20it%20out%E2%80%94but%20I%20need%20a%20break.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EPerhaps%20a%20way%20to%20speed%20matters%20up%20is%20to%20put%20some%20more%20names%20on%20the%20table.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fmitt-romney%5C%22%3EMitt%20Romney%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20once%20a%20vocal%20opponent%20of%20Trump%2C%20was%20just%20elected%20to%20the%20U.S.%20Senate%20from%20Utah%2C%20and%20so%20he%20has%20an%20active%20political%20operation.%20Romney%E2%80%99s%20old%20running%20mate%2C%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fpaul-ryan%5C%22%3EPaul%20Ryan%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20who%20is%20retiring%20as%20Speaker%20of%20the%20House%2C%20and%20liked%20to%20hint%2C%20when%20convenient%2C%20that%20he%20was%20not%20happy%20with%20the%20President%2C%20might%20want%20to%20prove%20that%20he%20meant%20it.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fnikki-haley%5C%22%3ENikki%20Haley%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20the%20former%20governor%20of%20South%20Carolina%2C%20left%20her%20job%20as%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20U.N.%20Ambassador%20with%20her%20dignity%20intact%E2%80%94a%20harder%20trick%20than%20winning%20some%20primaries%E2%80%94and%20may%20be%20positioning%20herself%20for%20a%20post-Trump%20moment.%20Why%20wait%20until%202024%3F%20Aside%20from%20Romney%2C%20several%20other%20senators%20could%20be%20potential%20challengers.%20Rob%20Portman%2C%20Kasich%E2%80%99s%20fellow-Ohioan%2C%20had%20considered%20running%20in%202016%2C%20and%20withdrew%20his%20endorsement%20of%20Trump%20after%20the%20%E2%80%9CAccess%20Hollywood%E2%80%9D%20tape%20emerged.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Flisa-murkowski%5C%22%3ELisa%20Murkowski%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20of%20Alaska%2C%20most%20recently%20showed%20her%20independence%20with%20her%20%E2%80%9CNo%E2%80%9D%20vote%20on%20Brett%20Kavanaugh%E2%80%99s%20confirmation.%20Susan%20Collins%2C%20of%20Maine%2C%20a%20frequent%20Trump%20critic%2C%20voted%20the%20other%20way%2C%20but%20that%20might%20prove%20useful%20with%20G.O.P.%20primary%20voters.%20Last%20month%2C%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fbob-corker%5C%22%3EBob%20Corker%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20of%20Tennessee%2C%20who%20is%20also%20retiring%2C%20said%2C%20when%20asked%20if%20he%20might%20run%20in%202020%2C%20that%20he%20hadn%E2%80%99t%20%E2%80%9Cruled%20it%20out.%E2%80%9D%20In%20September%2C%20when%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fnews%2Four-columnists%2Fben-sasses-unconvincing-diagnosis-of-american-partisanship%5C%22%3EBen%20Sasse%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20of%20Nebraska%2C%20who%20talks%20a%20lot%20about%20his%20problems%20with%20Trump%2C%20was%20asked%20the%20same%20thing%2C%20he%20said%20that%20the%20%E2%80%9Codds%20are%20a%20lot%20higher%20that%20I%20run%20for%20the%20noxious-weed-control%20board%20of%20Dodge%20County.%E2%80%9D%20But%20he%20allowed%20that%20such%20odds%20were%20better%20than%20zero.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnti-Trump%20conservatives%2C%20some%20of%20whom%20have%20been%20raising%20money%20for%20a%20potential%2C%20still%20unnamed%20challenger%2C%20attended%20a%20conference%20last%20week%20in%20Washington%20called%20%E2%80%9CStarting%20Over%3A%20The%20Center-Right%20After%20Trump.%E2%80%9D%20Larry%20Hogan%2C%20a%20Republican%20who%20was%20just%20overwhelmingly%20re%C3%ABlected%20governor%20of%20Maryland%2C%20a%20blue%20state%2C%20was%20the%20opening%20speaker.%20Charlie%20Baker%2C%20of%20Massachusetts%2C%20and%20Phil%20Scott%2C%20of%20Vermont%2C%20are%20other%20moderate%20Republican%20governors%20who%20have%20been%20mentioned%20as%20Never%20Trump%20standard-bearers.%20For%20that%20matter%2C%20why%20shouldn%E2%80%99t%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Ftag%2Fmichael-bloomberg%5C%22%3EMichael%20Bloomberg%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20who%20was%20once%20a%20Republican%2C%20run%20as%20one%20again%2C%20if%20only%20for%20the%20chance%20to%20take%20part%20in%20primary%20debates%20and%20speak%20directly%20to%20Republican%20voters%3F%20(He%20was%20an%20adept%20supporter%20of%20red-state%20Democrats%20in%20the%20midterms%2C%20outmaneuvering%20the%20N.R.A.%20in%20some%20races.)%20He%20could%20remind%20them%20that%20there%20are%20other%20visions%20of%20what%20being%20a%20Republican%20has%20meant%20and%20can%20mean.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EMany%20people%20may%20not%20see%20the%20point%2C%20wondering%20if%2C%20at%20this%20stage%2C%20the%20G.O.P.%20is%20worth%20reviving.%20But%20a%20national%20journey%20away%20from%20Trumpism%20requires%20some%20middle%20ground.%20So%20does%20a%20healthy%20electoral%20system.%20The%20obvious%20cost%20to%20potential%20challengers%20is%20that%20Trump%20would%20attack%E2%80%94with%20tweets%20and%20smears.%20But%20that%20tactic%20works%20partly%20because%20other%20Republican%20politicians%20vouch%20for%20him%3B%20a%20real%2C%20sustained%20challenge%20might%20reveal%20what%20is%20strength%20and%20what%20is%20show.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ETherein%20lies%20what%20may%20be%20the%20most%20compelling%20reason%20for%20not%20just%20one%20Republican%20but%20several%20to%20get%20into%20the%20race%3A%20a%20chance%20to%20tell%20the%20truth.%20Without%20opponents%2C%20Trump%20will%20saunter%20through%20the%20primaries%2C%20plying%20voters%20with%20whatever%20made-up%20stories%20about%20gangs%20and%20the%20wall%20and%20conspiracies%20he%20likes.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ELast%20week%2C%20Comey%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CAll%20of%20us%20should%20use%20every%20breath%20we%20have%20to%20make%20sure%20that%20the%20lying%20stops%20on%20January%2020%2C%202021.%E2%80%9D%20Wallace%2C%20a%20journalist%20who%20has%20worked%20on%20Republican%20campaigns%2C%20asked%2C%20%E2%80%9CWould%20you%20ever%20run%3F%E2%80%9D%20Comey%20replied%2C%20%E2%80%9CNo%2C%E2%80%9D%20adding%2C%20%E2%80%9CYou%20don%E2%80%99t%20have%20to%20run%20for%20office%20to%20be%20useful%20to%20your%20country%20and%20your%20community.%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9CBut%20it%20helps%2C%E2%80%9D%20Wallace%20said.%20It%20certainly%20does.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Like many people, ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/james-comey"},"James Comey"],", the former F.B.I. director, has been thinking about the best way for the Presidency of ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/donald-trump"},"Donald Trump"]," to end. Interviewed in New York last week, Comey said that his own, possibly “weird” thought is that impeachment is not the ideal course; for one thing, it would let voters “off the hook” in 2020. “We need a clear jump upward, and it will come from tens of millions of Americans,” he told his interviewer, Nicolle Wallace. But Comey put the burden on the Democrats, saying, “They have to win.”"],["p","In response, Trump tweeted that Comey had “just totally exposed his partisan stance by urging his fellow Democrats to take back the White House in 2020.” (Comey says that he’s an independent.) He added, “Comey had no right heading the FBI at any time, but especially after his mind exploded!” The date and the circumstances of the alleged detonation were not clear, but the message was: to speak about confronting Trump at the polls is to speak as a Democrat."],["p","There’s some practical truth to that. Given that the Republicans, particularly in Congress, have largely ceded their party to Trump, the 2020 campaign seems headed toward a contest between him and the Democratic nominee. The Democrats now have to decide what kind of candidate they want. But why should the Republicans be let off the hook? Those who don’t share Trump’s more corrosive views often wallow in the perception of their own powerlessness. Yet they have options, if they choose to use them, including one that the Democrats don’t. They can challenge Trump in the primaries."],["p","Trump knows that, which is why his campaign is already working to engineer a preëmptive endorsement in the New Hampshire primary, the first in the nation, from the state Party, which traditionally remains neutral. He could be much more vulnerable by August of 2020, when the Republican National Convention meets in Charlotte, North Carolina, depending on, among other things, how the ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/russia-investigation"},"Mueller investigation"]," develops. (Last week, forty-four former senators, ten of them Republicans, signed an open letter, urging the Senate to uphold the rule of law; it reads like a foreshadowing of a crisis.)"],["p","One Republican who has been openly considering a run against Trump is ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/john-kasich"},"John Kasich"],", the outgoing governor of Ohio, who was the last candidate to drop out of the 2016 Presidential primaries. He has been to New Hampshire twice recently, and his advisers have spoken out against the attempt to change the state Party rules. Still, Kasich told the Columbus ",["em",["a",{"href":"https://www.dispatch.com/news/20181210/kasich-thinking-about-job-in-media-still-opposes-gun-bill"},"Dispatch"]]," last week, “Maybe the Lord will say, ‘John, enough of you for 30 years, enough of you. Go sit somewhere in the corner, shut up for awhile.’ ” He is not alone in this wavering. “I do hope that somebody else runs in the Republican primary,” Senator ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/jeff-flake"},"Jeff Flake"],", of Arizona, who will retire next month, said in October. But, he added, “I don’t see that happening in my case.” Ten days later, he said, “I’m not ruling it out—but I need a break.”"],["p","Perhaps a way to speed matters up is to put some more names on the table. ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/mitt-romney"},"Mitt Romney"],", once a vocal opponent of Trump, was just elected to the U.S. Senate from Utah, and so he has an active political operation. Romney’s old running mate, ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/paul-ryan"},"Paul Ryan"],", who is retiring as Speaker of the House, and liked to hint, when convenient, that he was not happy with the President, might want to prove that he meant it. ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/nikki-haley"},"Nikki Haley"],", the former governor of South Carolina, left her job as Trump’s U.N. Ambassador with her dignity intact—a harder trick than winning some primaries—and may be positioning herself for a post-Trump moment. Why wait until 2024? Aside from Romney, several other senators could be potential challengers. Rob Portman, Kasich’s fellow-Ohioan, had considered running in 2016, and withdrew his endorsement of Trump after the “Access Hollywood” tape emerged. ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/lisa-murkowski"},"Lisa Murkowski"],", of Alaska, most recently showed her independence with her “No” vote on Brett Kavanaugh’s confirmation. Susan Collins, of Maine, a frequent Trump critic, voted the other way, but that might prove useful with G.O.P. primary voters. Last month, ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/bob-corker"},"Bob Corker"],", of Tennessee, who is also retiring, said, when asked if he might run in 2020, that he hadn’t “ruled it out.” In September, when ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/news/our-columnists/ben-sasses-unconvincing-diagnosis-of-american-partisanship"},"Ben Sasse"],", of Nebraska, who talks a lot about his problems with Trump, was asked the same thing, he said that the “odds are a lot higher that I run for the noxious-weed-control board of Dodge County.” But he allowed that such odds were better than zero."],["p","Anti-Trump conservatives, some of whom have been raising money for a potential, still unnamed challenger, attended a conference last week in Washington called “Starting Over: The Center-Right After Trump.” Larry Hogan, a Republican who was just overwhelmingly reëlected governor of Maryland, a blue state, was the opening speaker. Charlie Baker, of Massachusetts, and Phil Scott, of Vermont, are other moderate Republican governors who have been mentioned as Never Trump standard-bearers. For that matter, why shouldn’t ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/tag/michael-bloomberg"},"Michael Bloomberg"],", who was once a Republican, run as one again, if only for the chance to take part in primary debates and speak directly to Republican voters? (He was an adept supporter of red-state Democrats in the midterms, outmaneuvering the N.R.A. in some races.) He could remind them that there are other visions of what being a Republican has meant and can mean."],["p","Many people may not see the point, wondering if, at this stage, the G.O.P. is worth reviving. But a national journey away from Trumpism requires some middle ground. So does a healthy electoral system. The obvious cost to potential challengers is that Trump would attack—with tweets and smears. But that tactic works partly because other Republican politicians vouch for him; a real, sustained challenge might reveal what is strength and what is show."],["p","Therein lies what may be the most compelling reason for not just one Republican but several to get into the race: a chance to tell the truth. Without opponents, Trump will saunter through the primaries, plying voters with whatever made-up stories about gangs and the wall and conspiracies he likes."],["p","Last week, Comey said, “All of us should use every breath we have to make sure that the lying stops on January 20, 2021.” Wallace, a journalist who has worked on Republican campaigns, asked, “Would you ever run?” Comey replied, “No,” adding, “You don’t have to run for office to be useful to your country and your community.” “But it helps,” Wallace said. It certainly does. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c762bfcc72cd92d051d","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Donald Trump","parent":[],"photos":{},"slug":"donald-trump"},{"id":"5c2e1c762bc86f2c9a24498f","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Republican Party","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"republican-party"},{"id":"5c2e1c86ee7fe02cbd163348","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"2020 Presidential She has been at ",["em","The New Yorker"]," since 1995, and as a senior editor for many years focussed on national security, international reporting, and features. Sorkin helped to reconceive newyorker.com, where she served as the site’s executive editor and the editor of Daily Comment. it%20gives%20Midge%20kids%2C%20a%20baby%20and%20a%20toddler.%20It%20also%20makes%20her%20a%20winner.%20Whereas%20Rivers%20was%20an%20alienated%20oddball%2C%20a%20loner%20fuelled%20by%20rejection%2C%20gagging%20onstage%20at%20her%20own%20%E2%80%9Cugliness%2C%E2%80%9D%20Midge%20is%20popular%20and%20pretty.%20She%E2%80%99s%20skilled%20(and%20brags%20of%20her%20skill)%20at%20everything%20from%20sex%20to%20brisket.%20When%20Joel%2C%20a%20wannabe%20comic%2C%20cheats%20with%20his%20secretary%2C%20Midge%20gets%20drunk%20and%20jumps%20onstage%2C%20and%2C%20right%20away%2C%20she%20kills.%20She%20keeps%20on%20killing%E2%80%94at%20cocktail%20parties%20and%20dive%20bars%2C%20even%20at%20a%20Washington%20Square%20rally%2C%20where%20she%20awes%20Jane%20Jacobs%20with%20a%20speech%20about%20how%20women%20%E2%80%9Caccessorize%E2%80%9D%20the%20world%2C%20as%20a%20multiethnic%20crowd%20cheers.%20%E2%80%9COh%2C%20that%E2%80%99s%20good%2C%20write%20that%20down%2C%E2%80%9D%20Jacobs%20tells%20her%20assistant.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EMidge%20builds%20her%20%E2%80%9Ctight%20ten%E2%80%9D%20routine%20faster%20than%20any%20comic%20ever%2C%20according%20to%20Susie%20(Alex%20Borstein)%2C%20who%20gets%20teary%20at%20her%20client%E2%80%99s%20raw%20talent.%20(The%20butch%20Susie%20is%20so%20focussed%20on%20Midge%E2%80%99s%20prospects%20that%20she%20never%20gets%20a%20crush%20on%20her%2C%20or%20on%20anyone.%20Neither%20does%20Lenny%20Bruce.%20For%20a%20show%20about%20a%20woman%20who%20works%20blue%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20oddly%20prudish.)%20By%20the%20finale%20of%20the%20first%20season%2C%20Midge%20has%20a%20dangerous%20enemy%E2%80%94Sophie%20Lennon%20(Jane%20Lynch)%2C%20an%20older%20star%20who%20tells%20fat%20jokes%2C%20in%20a%20fat%20suit%E2%80%94but%2C%20as%20ever%2C%20she%20keeps%20killing%2C%20swatting%20down%20sexists.%20As%20the%20crowd%20roars%2C%20her%20louse%20of%20an%20ex%20wanders%20the%20street%2C%20moaning%20at%20her%20talent%3A%20%E2%80%9CShe%E2%80%99s%20%3Cem%3Egood%3C%2Fem%3E.%20She%E2%80%99s%20%3Cem%3Egood%3C%2Fem%3E.%E2%80%9D%20The%20show%20is%20downright%20Sorkinian%20in%20its%20emphasis%20on%20Midge%E2%80%99s%20superiority%E2%80%94and%20more%20than%20a%20bit%20Streisandian%2C%20too%2C%20except%20that%20Midge%20starts%20%3Cem%3Eand%3C%2Fem%3E%20ends%20as%20a%20swan.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EMany%20people%20found%20this%20fantasy%20invigorating.%20For%20me%2C%20it%20felt%20grating%2C%20and%20not%20just%20in%20terms%20of%20verisimilitude%E2%80%94the%20verbal%20anachronisms%20(%E2%80%9Ctotally%E2%80%9D)%2C%20the%20sitcom%20clams%20(%E2%80%9CGood%20talk!%E2%80%9D)%2C%20the%20cloying%20Disneyfication%20of%20Midge%E2%80%99s%20Jewish%20family%E2%80%94but%20in%20its%20central%20psychology.%20In%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Marvelous%20Mrs.%20Maisel%2C%E2%80%9D%20sexism%20exists.%20But%20it%20never%20gets%20%3Cem%3Einside%3C%2Fem%3E%20Midge.%20Her%20marvellousness%20comes%20from%20the%20fact%20that%20she%E2%80%99s%20immune%2C%20a%20self-adoring%20alpha%20whose%20routines%20feel%20like%20feminist%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ETED%3C%2Fem%3E%20talks%2C%20with%20some%20%E2%80%9Cfucks%E2%80%9D%20thrown%20in.%20Brosnahan%20delivers%20them%20with%20moxie%2C%20but%20they%E2%80%99re%20rarely%20funny.%20They%E2%80%99re%20also%20the%20opposite%20of%20Rivers%E2%80%99s%20act%2C%20which%20relied%20on%20the%20tension%20between%20looking%20pretty%20and%20%3Cem%3Ecalling%3C%2Fem%3E%20herself%20a%20dog%E2%80%94provoking%20taboo%20laughs%20from%20the%20revelation%20that%20even%20this%20nice%20girl%20felt%20like%20a%20loser%2C%20desperate%2C%20unfuckable.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20%E2%80%9CMrs.%20Maisel%2C%E2%80%9D%20Rivers%E2%80%99s%20more%20unsettling%20qualities%E2%80%94her%20vengefulness%2C%20her%20perception%20of%20women%20as%20competitors%2C%20her%20eating%20disorder%E2%80%94all%20get%20displaced%20onto%20Midge%E2%80%99s%20foe%2C%20fat-joke%20Sophie%2C%20who%20lives%20in%20an%20opulent%20French-themed%20apartment%2C%20like%20the%20one%20Rivers%20lived%20in%2C%20collects%20furs%2C%20and%2C%20like%20the%20real%20Joan%2C%20wanted%20to%20be%20a%20serious%20actress.%20It%E2%80%99s%20as%20if%20Rivers%20has%20been%20split%20into%20good%20Joan%20and%20bad%20Joan%2C%20because%20it%E2%80%99s%20too%20hard%20to%20make%20such%20a%20caustic%20trailblazer%20seem%20cute%2C%20to%20acknowledge%20how%20much%20her%20success%20derived%20from%20being%20shaped%20by%20misogyny%2C%20not%20from%20transcending%20it.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","It took two minutes of Season 2 before someone said the words: “Gosh, you’re amazing.” The speaker was one of Miriam (Midge) Maisel’s colleagues at the B. Altman switchboard, but, really, it might have been anyone: a genius painter at the Cedar Inn, who says, “It’s like Vermeer painted you! Or you swallowed a light bulb”; a Johnny Mathis-esque crooner at a telethon; Lenny Bruce; Jane Jacobs; Midge’s estranged husband, Joel, who is still stuck on her; her boyfriend, a choosy doctor who prefers Midge to the vapid gold-diggers in the Catskills; her devoted agent, Susie; or even some Parisian drag queens, who dub her Miss America. Is there anyone who ",["em","doesn’t"]," love Midge?"],["p","Me, as it happens. Last year, “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel” was a boffo hit for Amazon and for its top-hatted creator, Amy Sherman-Palladino. The series swept the Emmys. It sent shivers of delight up the spines of vintage-shoppers everywhere. Lusciously art-directed, from Midge’s classic six to her kitten heels, the production landed at an ideal moment, tapping into a desperation—particularly among women—for something sweet and inspiring. No more “Handmaid’s Tale,” no more pussy-grabbing. “Mrs. Maisel” offered a bright-pink escape hatch from 2017."],["p","I craved such an escape myself—but I was also mystified by the show’s reception, because the first season struck me as both treacly and exhausting. This was true despite its having a premise that was so far up my alley it was practically chopping onions in my kitchen: a Jewish girl does standup comedy in the late nineteen-fifties in New York, when ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/02/23/last-girl-larchmont"},"Joan Rivers"]," first rose to fame. And, in fact, the show’s heroine, played by Rachel Brosnahan, is—exactly like Rivers was—a college-educated rich girl in her twenties, who is forced to move back home after her marriage blows up. When Midge enters show biz, her shtick, just like Rivers’s was, is to dress for a date, in a black dress and pearls, then free-associate truths about women’s lives. As with Rivers, the radical “sick” comic ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2011/01/24/lenny-again"},"Lenny Bruce"]," is Midge’s inspiration—and, in the show, Bruce (Luke Kirby) becomes her mentor. (In real life, after Rivers once bombed, Bruce left her a note: “You’re right, they’re wrong.” She kept it in her bra, for luck.)"],["p","But “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel” makes two major adjustments. First, it gives Midge kids, a baby and a toddler. It also makes her a winner. Whereas Rivers was an alienated oddball, a loner fuelled by rejection, gagging onstage at her own “ugliness,” Midge is popular and pretty. She’s skilled (and brags of her skill) at everything from sex to brisket. When Joel, a wannabe comic, cheats with his secretary, Midge gets drunk and jumps onstage, and, right away, she kills. She keeps on killing—at cocktail parties and dive bars, even at a Washington Square rally, where she awes Jane Jacobs with a speech about how women “accessorize” the world, as a multiethnic crowd cheers. “Oh, that’s good, write that down,” Jacobs tells her assistant."],["p","Midge builds her “tight ten” routine faster than any comic ever, according to Susie (Alex Borstein), who gets teary at her client’s raw talent. (The butch Susie is so focussed on Midge’s prospects that she never gets a crush on her, or on anyone. Neither does Lenny Bruce. For a show about a woman who works blue, it’s oddly prudish.) By the finale of the first season, Midge has a dangerous enemy—Sophie Lennon (Jane Lynch), an older star who tells fat jokes, in a fat suit—but, as ever, she keeps killing, swatting down sexists. As the crowd roars, her louse of an ex wanders the street, moaning at her talent: “She’s ",["em","good"],". She’s ",["em","good"],".” The show is downright Sorkinian in its emphasis on Midge’s superiority—and more than a bit Streisandian, too, except that Midge starts ",["em","and"]," ends as a swan."],["p","Many people found this fantasy invigorating. For me, it felt grating, and not just in terms of verisimilitude—the verbal anachronisms (“totally”), the sitcom clams (“Good talk!”), the cloying Disneyfication of Midge’s Jewish family—but in its central psychology. In “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,” sexism exists. But it never gets ",["em","inside"]," Midge. Her marvellousness comes from the fact that she’s immune, a self-adoring alpha whose routines feel like feminist ",["em",{"class":"small"},"TED"]," talks, with some “fucks” thrown in. Brosnahan delivers them with moxie, but they’re rarely funny. They’re also the opposite of Rivers’s act, which relied on the tension between looking pretty and ",["em","calling"]," herself a dog—provoking taboo laughs from the revelation that even this nice girl felt like a loser, desperate, unfuckable."],["p","In “Mrs. Maisel,” Rivers’s more unsettling qualities—her vengefulness, her perception of women as competitors, her eating disorder—all get displaced onto Midge’s foe, fat-joke Sophie, who lives in an opulent French-themed apartment, like the one Rivers lived in, collects furs, and, like the real Joan, wanted to be a serious actress. It’s as if Rivers has been split into good Joan and bad Joan, because it’s too hard to make such a caustic trailblazer seem cute, to acknowledge how much her success derived from being shaped by misogyny, not from transcending it."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EBelieve%20me%2C%20when%20a%20TV%20hit%20unites%20women%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20no%20fun%20to%20be%20Morales%20in%20%E2%80%9CA%20Chorus%20Line%2C%E2%80%9D%20feeling%20nothing.%20As%20with%20Sherman-Palladino%E2%80%99s%20earlier%20shows%2C%20the%20sometimes%20charming%2C%20often%20irritating%20%E2%80%9CGilmore%20Girls%E2%80%9D%20and%20the%20more%20effectively%20bittersweet%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2012%2F08%2F27%2Fdance-dance-revolution%5C%22%3EBunheads%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20this%20is%20a%20show%20that%20is%20fantastical%20by%20design.%20Why%20nitpick%3F%20Why%20growl%20at%20Midge%E2%80%99s%20icebox%20parenting%2C%20which%20the%20show%20sees%20as%20adorable%3F%20Why%20kvetch%20about%20Midge%E2%80%99s%20greedy%20father-in-law%2C%20a%20portrait%20so%20coarse%20that%20it%20verges%20on%20anti-Semitism%3F%20Why%20mutter%20that%2C%20if%20the%20series%20hadn%E2%80%99t%20magically%20pushed%20Rivers%E2%80%99s%20night-club%20origins%20back%20into%20the%20fifties%2C%20it%20might%20have%20had%20to%20show%20her%201961%20peers%20at%20the%20Gaslight%20Caf%C3%A9%2C%20including%20Woody%20Allen%20and%20Bill%20Cosby%2C%20figures%20who%20are%20far%20tougher%20to%20sanitize%3F%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESo%20I%20tried%20to%20open%20my%20heart%20to%20Season%202.%20People%20grow%2C%20people%20change%E2%80%94even%20critics%2C%20even%20shows.%20But%20the%20season%20begins%20with%20a%20tooth-rottingly%20twee%20trip%20to%20Paris%2C%20followed%20by%20a%20cloying%20trip%20to%20the%20Catskills%2C%20a%20setting%20far%20better%20served%20by%20%E2%80%9CDirty%20Dancing.%E2%80%9D%20It%20veers%20from%20one%20inconsistent%20family%20plot%20to%20another%2C%20with%20a%20baffling%20focus%20on%20Joel%2C%20who%20screws%20around%20but%20finds%20no%20one%20who%20lives%20up%20to%20his%20ex.%20(Despite%20its%20feminist%20theme%2C%20%E2%80%9CMrs.%20Maisel%E2%80%9D%20has%20more%20one-line%20bimbos%20than%20%E2%80%9CEntourage.%E2%80%9D)%20There%E2%80%99s%20loads%20of%20ethnic%20shtick%2C%20from%20chain-smoking%20Frenchies%20to%20an%20Italian%20family%20singing%20%E2%80%9CFunicul%C3%AC%2C%20Funicul%C3%A0.%E2%80%9D%20Things%20perk%20up%20whenever%20the%20focus%20shifts%20to%20the%20salty%2C%20bruised%20Susie%2C%20a%20scrapper%20from%20the%20Rockaways%E2%80%94but%20even%20her%20plots%20are%20marred%20by%20dese-and-dose%20mobsters.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20show%E2%80%99s%20writers%20do%2C%20to%20be%20fair%2C%20give%20their%20heroine%20more%20pushback%20this%20season.%20When%20she%20slams%20male%20comics%20(rightly%2C%20because%20they%E2%80%99re%20pigs)%2C%20she%20loses%20gigs.%20When%20she%20gives%20a%20filthy%20toast%20at%20a%20Catholic%20wedding%2C%20the%20bride%20won%E2%80%99t%20forgive%20her.%20(I%20cheered.)%20When%20her%20dad%20catches%20her%20using%20him%20as%20material%2C%20he%20gives%20her%20the%20silent%20treatment.%20Her%20act%20rarely%20matches%20her%20charmed%20life%E2%80%94why%20would%20Midge%2C%20so%20wooed%20and%20worshipped%2C%20rave%20about%20how%20women%20are%20experts%20on%20rejection%3F%E2%80%94but%20Brosnahan%20jolts%20each%20bit%20with%20charisma.%20Yet%2C%20by%20the%20finale%2C%20nothing%20adds%20up.%20When%20the%20season%20lands%20on%20a%20note%20of%20darkness%2C%20tied%20to%20Lenny%20Bruce%E2%80%99s%20routine%20%E2%80%9CAll%20Alone%2C%E2%80%9D%20it%20feels%20unearned.%20Why%20should%20Midge%20choose%20art%20over%20love%3F%20Her%20patient%2C%20supportive%20boyfriend%20%3Cem%3Eand%3C%2Fem%3E%20her%20ex%20think%20that%20she%E2%80%99s%20a%20comic%20genius.%20Her%20childcare%20is%20free%20(and%20often%20invisible).%20No%20force%20keeps%20her%20from%20having%20both%2C%20other%20than%20her%20own%20unacknowledged%20solipsism.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThere%20are%20better%20escape%20hatches.%20There%E2%80%99s%20also%20high-feminine%20mythmaking%20(as%20well%20as%20fashion%20inspo%20and%20more%20authentic%20Jewishness)%20available%20on%20less%20pretentious%20TV%20shows%2C%20among%20them%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2014%2F06%2F23%2Fid-girls%5C%22%3EBroad%20City%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2016%2F01%2F25%2Fglee-club%5C%22%3ECrazy%20Ex-Girlfriend%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2017%2F07%2F03%2Fthe-glitzy-verve-of-glow-and-claws%5C%22%3EClaws%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fculture%2Fcultural-comment%2Fhow-younger-became-gossip-girl-for-the-publishing-industry%5C%22%3EYounger%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9C%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EGLOW%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2016%2F06%2F20%2Fcall-the-midwife-a-primal-procedural%5C%22%3ECall%20the%20Midwife%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2018%2F03%2F12%2Fjane-the-virgin-is-not-a-guilty-pleasure%5C%22%3EJane%20the%20Virgin%3C%2Fa%3E.%E2%80%9D%20But%20what%20I%E2%80%99d%20really%20recommend%20is%20digging%20up%20an%20old%20copy%20of%20%E2%80%9CThis%20Is%20My%20Life%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20first%20movie%20that%20Nora%20Ephron%20directed%2C%20based%20on%20a%20novel%20by%20Meg%20Wolitzer.%20Julie%20Kavner%20stars%20as%20Dottie%20Ingels%2C%20a%20divorced%20Jewish%20comedian%20from%20New%20York%2C%20whose%20quest%20for%20fame%20leads%20her%20to%20ditch%20her%20kids.%20The%20movie%20manages%20to%20celebrate%20that%20choice%20without%20stacking%20the%20deck.%20It%E2%80%99s%20realistic%20about%20a%20sexist%20industry.%20It%20treats%20Dottie%E2%80%99s%20children%20as%20real%20people%2C%20who%20are%20as%20interesting%20as%20she%20is.%20It%20even%20manages%20to%20be%20funny.%20There%E2%80%99s%20more%20than%20one%20way%20to%20have%20it%20all.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Believe me, when a TV hit unites women, it’s no fun to be Morales in “A Chorus Line,” feeling nothing. As with Sherman-Palladino’s earlier shows, the sometimes charming, often irritating “Gilmore Girls” and the more effectively bittersweet “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/08/27/dance-dance-revolution"},"Bunheads"],",” this is a show that is fantastical by design. Why nitpick? Why growl at Midge’s icebox parenting, which the show sees as adorable? Why kvetch about Midge’s greedy father-in-law, a portrait so coarse that it verges on anti-Semitism? Why mutter that, if the series hadn’t magically pushed Rivers’s night-club origins back into the fifties, it might have had to show her 1961 peers at the Gaslight Café, including Woody Allen and Bill Cosby, figures who are far tougher to sanitize?"],["p","So I tried to open my heart to Season 2. People grow, people change—even critics, even shows. But the season begins with a tooth-rottingly twee trip to Paris, followed by a cloying trip to the Catskills, a setting far better served by “Dirty Dancing.” It veers from one inconsistent family plot to another, with a baffling focus on Joel, who screws around but finds no one who lives up to his ex. (Despite its feminist theme, “Mrs. Maisel” has more one-line bimbos than “Entourage.”) There’s loads of ethnic shtick, from chain-smoking Frenchies to an Italian family singing “Funiculì, Funiculà.” Things perk up whenever the focus shifts to the salty, bruised Susie, a scrapper from the Rockaways—but even her plots are marred by dese-and-dose mobsters."],["p","The show’s writers do, to be fair, give their heroine more pushback this season. When she slams male comics (rightly, because they’re pigs), she loses gigs. When she gives a filthy toast at a Catholic wedding, the bride won’t forgive her. (I cheered.) When her dad catches her using him as material, he gives her the silent treatment. Her act rarely matches her charmed life—why would Midge, so wooed and worshipped, rave about how women are experts on rejection?—but Brosnahan jolts each bit with charisma. Yet, by the finale, nothing adds up. When the season lands on a note of darkness, tied to Lenny Bruce’s routine “All Alone,” it feels unearned. Why should Midge choose art over love? Her patient, supportive boyfriend ",["em","and"]," her ex think that she’s a comic genius. Her childcare is free (and often invisible). No force keeps her from having both, other than her own unacknowledged solipsism."],["p","There are better escape hatches. There’s also high-feminine mythmaking (as well as fashion inspo and more authentic Jewishness) available on less pretentious TV shows, among them “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/06/23/id-girls"},"Broad City"],",” “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/01/25/glee-club"},"Crazy Ex-Girlfriend"],",” “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/07/03/the-glitzy-verve-of-glow-and-claws"},"Claws"],",” “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/culture/cultural-comment/how-younger-became-gossip-girl-for-the-publishing-industry"},"Younger"],",” “",["em",{"class":"small"},"GLOW"],",” “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/06/20/call-the-midwife-a-primal-procedural"},"Call the Midwife"],",” and “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/03/12/jane-the-virgin-is-not-a-guilty-pleasure"},"Jane the Virgin"],".” But what I’d really recommend is digging up an old copy of “This Is My Life,” the first movie that Nora Ephron directed, based on a novel by Meg Wolitzer. Julie Kavner stars as Dottie Ingels, a divorced Jewish comedian from New York, whose quest for fame leads her to ditch her kids. The movie manages to celebrate that choice without stacking the deck. It’s realistic about a sexist industry. It treats Dottie’s children as real people, who are as interesting as she is. It even manages to be funny. There’s more than one way to have it all. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"5910eeb86c4c222f03a85a53","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5910eeb86c4c222f03a85a53","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"On Television","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"on-television"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"On Nussbaum","type":"author","title":"Emily Nussbaum, \u003cem>The New Yorker\u003c/em>’s television critic, won the 2016 Pulitzer Prize for criticism.","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Emily Nussbaum is the television critic for ",["em","The New Yorker"]," and, in 2016, won the Pulitzer Prize for criticism. She has written about “The Good Wife,” “Girls,” “Mad Men,” and “Scandal,” among other shows. Previously, she worked at ",["em","New York"]," for seven years, editing the Culture Pages (and creating the Approval Matrix) and writing both features and criticism."]],"social":[{"network":"Twitter","handle":"emilynussbaum"}],"url":"/contributors/emily-nussbaum","image":null}],"dek":"The cloying fantasia of “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel.”","formatting":{},"hed":"Hello, Gorgeous","id":"5c0ffcbc6fe65d7e16f1bbd8","inlineEmbeds":{},"issueDate":"December 24 & 31, 2018","modifiedAt":"2018-12-18T18:05:05.962Z","photos":{"tout":[{"id":"5c100a2fcd021f1a6611b063","modelName":"photo","collection":"photos","aspectRatios":{"2:2":{"width":732,"height":732,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":177,"y":86,"height":732,"width":732}},"duration":null},"16:9":{"width":1118,"height":629,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":0,"y":286,"height":629,"width":1118}},"duration":null},"4:3":{"width":1122,"height":842,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":0,"y":82,"height":842,"width":1122}},"duration":null},"1:1":{"width":1125,"height":1125,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":0,"y":47,"height":1125,"width":1125}},"duration":null},"master":{"format":"JPEG","url":"https://cn-copilot-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/tny-services/production/2018/12/11/5c100a2fcd021f1a6611b062_181224_r33478.jpg","width":1125,"height":1410,"duration":null}},"caption":["div",["p","Rachel Brosnahan delivers the comedy routines with moxie, but they’re rarely funny."]],"altText":"Illustration of The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel","credit":"Illustration by Petra Eriksson","filename":"181224_r33478.jpg","revision":9,"tags":[],"title":"181224_r33478","variants":{}}]},"promoDek":"The production landed at an ideal moment, tapping into a desperation among women for something sweet. {"desktop":false,"tablet":false,"mobile":["375x50"]},"render":{"slot":{"after":{"every":1,"el":"p","when":"function condition(el, meta) {\n function updateWordCount() {\n window.__instreamPreviousWordCount = meta.accumulatedWordCount;\n }\n\n function calculateWordCount() {\n var appendAd = false;\n var wordCountInterval = 1500;\n window.__instreamMetaTracker = window.__instreamMetaTracker || 0;\n\n /*\n * if the total number of words (so far)\n * minus the last checked total word count is greater than X words\n * append an ad\n */\n if (window.__instreamPreviousWordCount && meta.accumulatedWordCount - window.__instreamPreviousWordCount > wordCountInterval) {\n /* update word count and check if this is the first ad inline on the page */\n updateWordCount();\n window.__instreamMetaTracker++;\n\n /* if this is the first ad, load it */\n if (window.__instreamMetaTracker === 1) {\n appendAd = true;\n }\n } else if (!window.__instreamPreviousWordCount) {\n updateWordCount();\n }\n\n return appendAd;\n }\n\n return calculateWordCount();\n document.body.appendChild(s);
